HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Surprise Intervention Halts Decline in Dollar
The Clinton Administration and a dozen foreign countries bought billions of dollars in a surprise currency intervention that appeared to halt yet another slump in the dollar. The dollar surged, though not to the levels that traders said would signal a new stability.
 
The dollar settled in New York at 84.54 yen, up 1.68 yen from Tuesday, after trading as high as 85.28. It jumped to 1.4157 marks, up from 1.3905 marks. [Page A1.]
 
Dole Accuses Hollywood Of a 'Nightmare of Depravity'
Senator Bob Dole aimed a withering attack at the entertainment industry, accusing it of producing movies and records which were slashing the nation's social fabric. The speech propelled Mr. Dole into the forefront of Republican presidential candidates denouncing Hollywood for producing what he called "nightmares of depravity" involving sex and violence. [A1.]
 
The conservative political advocate William Bennett sent letters to Time Warner board members demanding that the company stop distributing "gangsta rap" music. [B10.]
 
G.D.P. Grows Only 2.7%
The gross domestic product grew at a revised 2.7 percent for the first quarter, down from the 2.8 percent estimate a month ago and the slowest pace in 1 1/2 years. [D2.]
 
Merck Buys Pollution Rights
Merck agreed to buy pollution rights from Public Service Electric and Gas. The deal, for which regulatory approval is likely, would let Merck's boilers in Rahway, N.J., emit tons more smog-causing chemicals. [B6.]
 
Mobil Cuts Back in Europe
Mobil said it would close a large refinery in Germany and scale back operations at two refineries in France and Britain in a continuing effort to cut costs. [D6.]
 
Bronfman Upbeat on MCA
Seagram's president, Edgar Bronfman Jr., was upbeat to shareholders about MCA's future, but had no word on whether Michael Ovitz would be running MCA. [D4.]
 
Morrison Knudsen Near Deal
Morrison Knudsen said that although it would be in default on $122 million in bank loans, it was close to an agreement with its banks for an extension. [D3.]
 
Dreamworks Forms Venture
Silicon Graphics and Dreamworks said they would jointly develop a system for computer animation and expected to provide about $50 million in financing. [D3.]
 
Alcatel Names Chairman
Alcatel Alsthom named Serge Tchuruk, chairman of Total S.A., as chairman and chief executive, succeeding Pierre Suard, who was indicted in March. [D6.]
 
Leo Burnett Gets Fruitopia
Coca-Cola assigned Leo Burnett the worldwide responsibilities for its Fruitopia line of fruit and tea drinks, which has been handled by Chiat/Day in New York. Burnett will then resign as the agency for 7Up, which will be reassigned after a closed review. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D5.]
 
Fund Dips 11.4% in One Day
It is a rare mutual fund that suffers a double-digit loss in a single day, but the American Heritage Fund managed it on Tuesday. The mutual fund fell 11.4 percent when it wrote down its investment in Kouri Capital Group by about 85 percent. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Stunning Surge On Wall Street: Dow Up 86.46

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market, after falling in recent sessions, vaulted yesterday to all-time highs, dumbfounding analysts as the Dow Jones industrial average soared to its biggest one-day percentage gain in a year and its biggest point gain in more than three.
No single explanation seemed to suffice. The Government reported more data that reinforced Wall Street's view that the economy is slowing enough to contain inflation but without choking corporate profits. The dollar rose in value after the world's leading central banks took concerted action to buy it. And the market seemed to chase the usual rumors, including a breakthrough in trade talks with Japan that proved unfounded. 
 Whatever the case, the Dow rose 86.46 points, to a record 4,465.14. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.82 points, to 533.40, also a new high.
Even the Nasdaq composite index, rich in the technology stocks that have taken a beating in the last four sessions, came clawing back, though short of its record 879.64 last Tuesday. It rose 5.88 points yesterday, to 864.58.
It is normal for markets, after rising quickly, to drop or plateau and then recover. But yesterday's powerful rally defied convention. At 3:09 P.M., the surge set off the New York Stock Exchange's "circuit breaker" rules that are intended to calm volatile markets. The Dow then roared ahead another 36 points.
The stock market has not seen such a one-day rise since Dec. 23, 1991, when the Dow surged 88.10 points, to 3,022.58, for an advance of 3 percent. Yesterday's climb was equal to a rise of 1.97 percent and brings the Dow to a day or two's trading away from the 4,500-point level.
To be sure, for much of the session stocks simply made up lost ground from Thursday's and Friday's declines. And until the last half-hour of trading, when the market's climb picked up even more speed, stock traders were simply buying back the very stocks whose prices they had battered the week before.
Suddenly cheaper shares of the Microsoft Corporation, for example, rose 111/16 , to 8411/16 , though still short of their 52-week high of 89 1/4 on Thursday. And the Intel Corporation's stock, the most active stock, , rose 1 3/4 a share, to 112 1/4, still shy of its top price of 117 1/2.
The Dow recovered from a tepid opening and picked up 30 points in the morning, as the dollar surged in response to a buying spree by American, Japanese and European central banks. But stocks leveled off by midday, leaving analysts groping for explanations for the sharp afternoon rally.
"I can only think the stock market has been lagging the bond market and it's just catching up," said Gail M. Dudack, chief investment strategist for S. G. Warburg & Company. Bond prices, which often influence stock performance, have risen faster than stock prices recently.
The Commerce Department also reported its first revision of first-quarter growth in gross domestic product yesterday. Wall Street economists had expected a rise to 3 percent or more from 2.8 percent, but were surprised by a downward revision to 2.7 percent.
The weaker-than-expected first quarter reinforced the "soft landing" outlook for the economy, but also prompted speculation of a stronger-than-expected second quarter, primarily because unsold goods, or inventory, had piled up in warehouses at a slower rate. The expectations of a weak second quarter depended on factories producing less because of bulging inventories.
The department also reported that new-home sales slipped 2.7 percent, to an annual rate of 580,000 sales, far less than expected.
But the housing sales and G.D.P. figures, which barely moved the bond market, seemed an unsatisfactory explanation for the rise in stocks, according to Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities. For one thing, he said, the figures do not seem to justify the cut in interest rates by the Fed expected to take place later this year.
"If anything, the economy is not strong enough for the Fed to tighten and not weak enough for the Fed to ease," Mr. Fine said.
Meanwhile, the dollar's surge yesterday was not by itself large enough to encourage numerous foreign investors to buy American stocks. The Dow, for example, has risen 16.45 percent so far this year in dollars, but only 6.46 percent in German marks, and has fallen nearly 1 percent in Japanese yen.
Some analysts cited rumors that a leading brokerage house was about to recommend a change in its "asset allocation," raising its recommended share of stocks. But no brokerage house appeared to make such a declaration by the end of the session.
Other analysts pointed to rumors of a significant breakthrough in the stalemated trade talks with Japan concerning the sale of American auto parts. But as of yesterday, the Clinton Administration had agreed only to reschedule the resumption of talks to mid-June from late June.
Jan Terbrueggen, a bond portfolio manager for Flagship Financial, which manages $4.5 billion in bonds, said there would be more than enough mine fields in the days ahead to send financial markets heading downward. Gold, for example, is hovering at about $385 an ounce rather than declining, a sure sign that traders expect to see inflation sometime this year, Mr. Terbrueggen said.
Also, the Government's April leading economic indicators are due tomorrow. Three declining index numbers in a row are "90 percent correlated with a recession," Mr. Terbrueggen said. "I, for one, am going to watch that number."
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 4.57 points, to 286.44, with advancing stocks outnumbering decliners, 1,585 to 708. Big Board volume totaled 366.2 million shares. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.77 point, to 492.10.
Among advancing stocks was that of the Ride Snowboard Company, a snowboard maker in Redmond, Wash. Its shares rose 4 1/4, to 24 7/8, after an analyst appearing on Dan Dorfman's program on CNBC made a bullish forecast. The Altera Corporation, a maker of integrated circuits, rose 3 1/2 a share, to 77 7/8.
Among declining stocks was that of the Roberts Pharmaceutical Corporation, a drug manufacturer. Its shares fell 4 1/8, to 19 3/8, after its management said the company expected its 1995 earnings to fall short of analysts' expectations. The American depository receipts of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Japanese electronics conglomerate, fell 4, to 157.

HEADLINE: First Members Are Named to Washington Financial Control Board

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
President Clinton today named a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board to head a new financial control board that will have final authority over every aspect of the District of Columbia's finances until the city's fiscal crisis ends.
In Andrew F. Brimmer, Mr. Clinton appointed a specialist in monetary policy, with a deep interest in urban finance, to reverse trends that have led the city to a budget deficit of more than $700 million. Mr. Brimmer, 68, an economist, served on the Federal Reserve Board from 1966 to 1974. 
 Mr. Clinton also appointed two other people to three-year terms on the five-member panel whose members are not paid -- Joyce A. Ladner, interim president of Howard University, and Constance B. Newman, undersecretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The President is expected to name the other members after background checks are completed.
Under the law establishing the board, it is required to balance the city's budget in four years and to continue to monitor that the budget is balanced for four more years, after which it would be disbanded.
" "We were fortunate to have such a wealth of talented, committed individuals who sought to do this vital job," Mr. Clinton said in a statement issued by the White House. Mr. Clinton predicted that the board would help "insure a stable economic future for the District." City officials have said that without a loan from the Federal Treasury, the District, which has a low bond rating on Wall Street, will be bankrupt in a month.
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said he looked forward to working with Mr. Brimmer and hoped that the board would help the city obtain more money from the Federal Government or new taxes.
It is widely believed by Federal lawmakers involved in creating the board, as well as by local officials, that part of Mr. Barry's enthusiasm for the board is that it will provide him with political cover for tough decisions, perhaps including dramatically reducing the number of city employees.
Mr. Brimmer, who returned to Washington today from a business trip, issued a statement through his office saying he was "pleased with the President's expression of confidence in me." He was not available for further comment.
As the most powerful board ever created to rescue a city in trouble, the District of Columbia Financial Responsibility and Management Assistance Authority becomes, in effect, more powerful than all the city's elected officials. It also ends expectations, for now, of expanding the limited home rule that Congress granted the city in 1974 and, beyond that, of statehood.
But the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a strong advocate of statehood, said the board might actually be a "silver lining in the the cloud of Congressional occupation" and enhance prospects for statehood by helping the city overcome longstanding financial problems.
Created by act of Congress, the board has final authority over city budgets, contracts and loans, with its ultimate power the right to veto any measure that has a fiscal effect. It also has the power to enact its own alternatives to specific spending plans and make recommendations on contracts.
Federal lawmakers said that no previous control board, including the one that rescued New York in the 1970's, the Municipal Assistance Corporation, had had such power. That is, in part, because the Washington board also has the responsibility to seek long-term solutions to such problems as the financing of Medicaid and the operation of jails, for which other cities in financial trouble have had state financing and other aid.
The city's financial plight has coincided with what many residents have regarded as a decline in the quality of life in Washington in recent years, attributed to lax and inefficient municipal government, a huge demand for social services and limited sources of revenue.
In the last few weeks alone, the city's foster care system was placed under court supervision, crime rates have risen as the police budget has been pared, trash recycling has ended because of cutbacks in the public works budget and Federal authorities have subpoenaed Mr. Barry's personal financial records as part of an investigation into his relationship with a contractor who did renovations at his house. The same authorities are investigating accusations that Mr. Barry's wife diverted $2,000 in campaign funds last year to her brother.
Beyond those problems, the capital has suffered a steady exodus of businesses and middle-class residents to suburbs in Maryland and Virginia, shrinking the city's tax base. That, in turn, has reduced the annual Federal payment to the city, a subsidy intended to compensate for the exemptions of foreign embassies, nonprofit organizations and the Federal Government from property taxes.
Mr. Brimmer, a native of Newellton, La., who has lived in Washington for nearly 20 years, emerged as the Administration's choice as chairman of the control board after a career as an economist, an economics teacher and, since 1976, the president of Brimmer and Company, a Washington-based economic and financial consulting firm.
Eleanor Holmes Norton, Washington's representative in Congress, referring to the first chairman of New York's control board, said "I think Andrew Brimmer will become Washington's Felix Rohatyn.".
But just how effectively Mr. Brimmer and his colleagues solve city problems will depend largely on the cooperation of Mr. Barry and the City Council, which also supports the board's creation.
Mr. Barry said today that because spending reductions would not be sufficient, the control board must study "the revenue side" of the city's problems. "We can't cut our way out of this," the Mayor said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
US. LEADS NATIONS IN SURPRISE BUYING TO PROP UP DOLLAR

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration and a dozen foreign countries took the currency markets by surprise today, buying billions of dollars in an intervention that appeared to have stopped yet another slump in the dollar.
After several days of sliding slowly down toward its record lows of mid-April, the dollar bounced back sharply today against the Japanese yen and the German mark. But when trading ended, the dollar had not quite reached the levels that traders said would signal a new stability. 
 Still, the dollar's recovery contributed to a sharp rally on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average posted its biggest percentage gain in a year, surging 86.46 points, or nearly 2 percent, to a record high of 4,465.14. [Page D1.]
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin issued a statement this morning that described the currency market intervention as consistent with a commitment in April by the United States and six other leading industrial nations to bring about an orderly reversal of the dollar's fall this year.
"We acted in the exchange markets this morning consistent with the exchange rate objectives expressed in the April 25 G-7 Communique," he said, referring to the Group of Seven nations. "We are prepared to continue to cooperate in exchange markets as appropriate."
American officials said privately that the Administration also wanted to make clear that it would not use a weak dollar as a weapon in the negotiations with Japan in the contentious trade dispute over American automobiles and auto parts. They also indicated that the White House was leaning toward moving up the date of the next round of talks.
Previous trans-Pacific trade disputes have produced sharp drops in the dollar that have made Japanese goods more expensive and less salable in the United States.
But the fall in the dollar has result
ed this year in a steady rise in the prices of imported goods. The resulting threat of possible inflation has made it somewhat harder for the Federal Reserve to consider a reduction in interest rates, even though the American economy appears to be slowing.
Administration officials have also been watching with concern the growing number of indications that the economy may be weak during the 1996 election campaign. Propping up the dollar in currency markets, if successful, allows the Administration to continue confronting Japan while also leaving the Federal Reserve with the option of lowering interest rates at some point.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, predicted in an interview this afternoon that the economy was continuing to slow from the torrid growth of late 1994, but would not slip into a recession. "We're going to see continued moderation in the pace of growth, but we're going to have growth," he said.
Mr. Lindsey also acknowledged some concerns about the effect of rising import prices on inflation, but emphasized that imports accounted for only a fraction of the goods and services sold in the United States. "I think it is a matter of concern but I think the numerical effects are relatively small," he said.
Currency traders said that if the Administration had not acted to support the dollar, it would have continued its recent decline. "You can characterize today as a pre-emptive strike before the dollar could test its lows again -- that was the direction that market sentiment had been building," said Stephen Flanagan, a currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York.
The dollar settled in New York late this afternoon at 84.54 yen, up 1.68 yen from Tuesday, after trading as high as 85.28 yen around 9 A.M. after the Federal Reserve and Japanese and European central banks entered the currency markets. It also jumped to 1.4157 marks today from 1.3905 marks. [The dollar showed little change in Asian trading by mid-afternoon on Thursday.]
Because the dollar did not end trading in New York above 85 yen and 1.42 marks, two key psychological levels, traders said the dollar might still be vulnerable to further attacks by speculators.
Still, traders cited several reasons why the Administration succeeded in pushing up the dollar today after previous interventions in currency markets this year had failed.
David F. DeRosa, the director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said traders were reluctant to bet against the success of Government purchases of dollars because many traders' profits and losses were calculated today, the last day of the month. That makes traders eager to protect the profits they have already made or minimize the losses they have already suffered.
Kevin J. Lawrie, a foreign exchange manager at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said traders were also content to let the dollar rise because they feared that today's currency market intervention might be part of a coordinated international strategy that could include a cut in German interest rates when the top council of the German Bundesbank meets on Thursday. Lower German interest rates would make it less attractive for international investors to put money there and more attractive for them to buy dollars and invest here.
For every dollar won in foreign exchange trading, somebody else loses a dollar, and traders said that losses today were probably heavy. The heaviest damage probably was in Asia, where markets were closed when the intervention took place and some traders might not have been able to undo their bets against the dollar, said Neal M. Soss, a hedge fund manager in Manhattan.
European money managers may also have had trouble selling other currencies and buying dollars within seconds so as to avoid losses. "It happened today at a time when many Europeans were probably thinking more about lunch than about their positions," Mr. Soss said.
The decision to intervene in currency markets is made by the Treasury Secretary, Mr. Rubin. But the Federal Reserve actually buys the dollars in exchange for yen and marks from its own reserves and from the Treasury's Exchange Stabilization Fund.
Mr. Rubin used to direct currency trading at Goldman, Sachs and has a reputation as a savvy market strategist. But until now, his record in directing currency interventions had been mixed.
Traders had more respect for Mr. Rubin today. "A lot of people have criticized Rubin and his predecessors for not carrying out skillful interventions -- this time they did a pretty good job," Mr. DeRosa of the Swiss Bank Corporation said.

HEADLINE: Man in the News: Andrew Felton Brimmer;
New Washington Leader

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
Andrew F. Brimmer was brought in today to help shore up the sagging fortunes of the District of Columbia more than a decade after predicting the city was in for "steady erosion" of its financial base.
As the head of a five-member financial control board, Mr. Brimmer, a 68-year-old former Federal Reserve Board governor, is expected to hand out tough medicine to a city that has been mired in financial crisis for more than a year. It is a prescription that will appeal to the city's critics on Capitol Hill. 
 Earlier this year Congress -- dismayed by the weak reaction of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to the financial crisis -- gave control of the city's financial concerns to a board.
The board, similar to those established in New York and Philadelphia when they were struggling financially, has broad power to recommend and even put into effect its own budget plans for the city if local officials fail to move toward a balanced budget in the next several years. The board will also review major city labor contracts and all legislation emerging from the District of Columbia City Council.
"I think he's an excellent choice," Terry Lynch, director of the Downtown Coalition of Churches said of Mr. Brimmer's three-year appointment to the unpaid post. "Right now we've basically got a city government that has collapsed. We need someone with his kind of management and fiscal expertise and at the same time proven civic and civil rights concerns."
Mr. Brimmer, the first black to serve as a governor at the Federal Reserve Board, emerged as the top choice from a short list of candidates under consideration by the White House, Administration officials said, because he combined strong fiscal and management skills with a commitment to civil rights. He has headed his own financial consulting firm, Brimmer and Company, in Washington for almost 20 years
Mr. Brimmer was appointed to a full 14-year term at the Federal Reserve by President Lyndon B. Johnson in March 1966 but he resigned in August 1974 to pursue other ventures.
"I am pleased with the President's expression of confidence in me," Mr. Brimmer said in a statement from his office today. "I will meet promptly with the other appointees to the authority to organize the work of the board."
For starters, Mr. Brimmer is likely to propose such solutions as a commuter tax and the restructuring of Federal assistance to help the city with its long-range financial planning -- moves that are likely to meet some resistance in Congress if they call for it to take more responsibility.
"This will be the toughest fiscal control board job in the country," said Bernard Anderson, an assistant secretary at the Labor Department who was chairman of the fiscal oversight board in Philadelphia in the early 1990's. "Tougher than Philadelphia, much tougher than New York. But Andrew Brimmer does not suffer fools gladly," said Mr. Bernard, who was Mr. Brimmer's graduate assistant when he taught at the University of Michigan. "He will decide what needs to be done and he has the kind of strength and courage to get it done."
During his time at the Federal Reserve "he was always very outspoken, thoughtful, and well-prepared," said J. Dewey Daane, a former Federal Reserve governor who served eight years with Mr. Brimmer and is now a professor emeritus at Vanderbilt University. "I expect him to be all those things in this job."
A tough but gentlemanly taskmaster, Mr. Brimmer is known as a workaholic, who rarely takes vacations, but savors long weekends of deep sea fishing off the coast of Vancouver.
Andrew Felton Brimmer was born Sept., 13, 1926, in Newellton, La., where his father, Andrew Sr., was a sharecropper and warehouse worker. After graduating from high school in 1944, he left the South for Washington State. He served in the Army in the Pacific during World War II until his discharge in 1946 in Hawaii.
Like many veterans, he took advantage of Federal grants to attend the University of Washington. He switched majors from journalism to economics, convinced that it offered him the best way to understand America. He received his undergraduate degree in 1950, a master's degree in 1951 and doctorate in economics from Harvard University in 1957.
Mr. Brimmer is married to the former Doris Millicent Scott. The couple have one daughter, Esther Diane. Besides fishing, Mr. Brimmer enjoys reading world history and business travel.
At Mr. Brimmer's offices today, his appointment was met with delight. Garth Trinkl, an economist who has been Mr. Brimmer's executive assistant for 12 years, said his boss expected "a lot of work and some contention but looked forward to the challenge."

HEADLINE: H. Don Reynolds, 83, Specialist in Aviation Law

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
H. Don Reynolds, whose career in commercial aviation spanned the days of propeller planes to those of supersonic airliners, died on Monday at his home in Phoenix. He was 83.
The cause was cancer, a spokesman for the family said. 
 A specialist in aviation and transportation law, Mr. Reynolds was house counsel for Pan American World Airways in the early 1950's and assistant director of the International Air Transport Association from 1961 until 1972. At the association, based in Montreal, he often found himself mediating differences over contentious issues like fares and deregulation.
He was the first director of the United States Tour Operators Association from 1976 to 1979, when he became the association's counsel on legal and government affairs. He was with the tour operators group, whose members package domestic and international tours for bus companies, travel agencies and airlines, until 1991.
Howard Donald Reynolds was born in Greeley, Colo. He graduated from Simpson College in Indianola, Iowa, in 1932 and from the Law School of Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., in 1936. In 1942, he joined the Civil Aeronautics Board as chief of economic regulation, and after service in the Navy he returned to the C.A.B., where he headed its first office of enforcement and litigation.
After his brief tenure as house counsel for PanAm, he continued to provide legal representation for the carrier, as well as for Butler Aviation and American Express. At other points in his career he worked for Northwest Orient Airlines and American Airlines.
Mr. Reynolds is survived by his wife, Imogene, who lives in Phoenix and in Scarsdale, N.Y., where he also lived part of the year; a daughter, Donogene Mealie of Kansas City, Mo.; a sister, Jane Ellen Morgan of Placerville, Calif., and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE DIPLOMACY;
U.S. Says It Plans to Propose New Concessions to Serbia

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has decided to offer new concessions to President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, and plans to propose indefinitely suspending most of the trade and financial sanctions against Yugoslavia, Administration officials said today.
According to the officials, Mr. Milosevic will be asked to grant diplomatic recognition to Bosnia and Herzegovina and denounce the taking of United Nations hostages by Bosnian Serb forces. The hope is that Mr. Milosevic will exert his considerable power as President of Serbia to press for a settlement of the Balkan conflict, which has continued for nearly four years. 
 Robert Frasure, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, met in Belgrade with Mr. Milosevic today, and Administration officials said he was instructed to sweeten a previous offer for relaxing the sanctions.
In exchange for Mr. Milosevic's steps towards bringing peace to the Balkans, Mr. Frasure was prepared to make it harder for Western nations to reinstitute the sanctions once they were suspended, a key concern of Mr. Milosevic's.
The economic sanctions, imposed by the United Nations three years ago, have been widely breached by smugglers and neighboring nations. But they have substantially harmed the Yugoslav economy, and are the main remaining leverage the West has in the region.
Last year, as part of a diplomatic bargain with Mr. Milosevic, the United Nations -- but not the United States -- suspended some of the restrictions, allowing resumption of international flights to Belgrade. Yugoslavia was also allowed to participate again in international sporting and cultural events.
In exchange, Serbia agreed to cut off supplies to the Bosnian Serbs, a step which if fully effective would have hobbled their war effort. The hope was that as Mr. Milosevic distanced himself from the Serbs in Bosnia, the remaining sanctions, including an oil embargo, could be suspended one by one.
American officials say the cordon between Serbia and the Bosnian Serbs has been leaky at best. Nonetheless, earlier this month, Mr. Frasure traveled to Belgrade with a proposal for the next round of suspending sanctions. The Serbs rebuffed the offer, insisting that the sanctions be immediately and completely lifted.
After a NATO bombing raid prompted the Bosnian Serbs to take hostages, American officials reconsidered their stance towards Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Frasure was dispatched with new orders.
Under the previous American negotiating stance, sanctions were suspended, but held in abeyance, and could have been reimposed if any member of the United Nations Security Council, including the United States, raised questions about Serbia's compliance with the terms of the deal. This gave Washington a means of unilaterally triggering the resumption of sanctions if Mr. Milosevic reneged.
The proposal to be delivered in Belgrade by Mr. Frasure, officials said, gives the United Nations Secretary General sole responsibility for judging whether Yugoslavia has carried out its side of the bargain. American and Western officials said this approach was worked out between the Administration and the other four countries that make up the so-called contact group: Britain, France, Germany and Russia.
In previous negotiating sessions, the officials said, Serbia has been pressing American negotiators for relief from the embargo on importing oil, an important aspect of the sanctions. The Serbs wanted permission to import hundreds of thousands of tons of oil a month, the officials said, an amount that would quickly have allowed Belgrade to amass a huge stockpile as insurance against any future embargo.
While the Clinton Administration was cool to that proposal, officials said the approach that Mr. Frasure was to convey would allow Serbia to satisfy most of its domestic needs.
The officials said Serbia would be allowed to resume trade with its neighbors, but would not be allowed to import goods that could be used for military purposes.
American officials said Yugoslavia would still be banned, for the moment, from applying for help from international financial institutions like the World Bank. In addition, the Yugoslav assets that were frozen in Western banks around the world would not be released until the nations that emerged from the wreckage of Yugoslavia could agree on how the money should be parceled out.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Optimism in Belgrade
 By The New York Times
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 31 -- The Foreign Minister of Yugoslavia expressed optimism today as talks with Mr. Frasure began.
"The talks are serious and productive, and I expect that everything will go well," the Foreign Minister, Vladislav Jovanovic, said in a televised interview. "By everything, I mean that our expectations, our requests will be met by the other side."
Mr. Jovanovic's comments were the first official indication that the talks were making progress.

HEADLINE: Lab's Fate Is in Air Force Numbers;
New York Officials Say Pentagon Tailors Its Data to Politics

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Last October, anticipating a new round of military base closings, Air Force analysts used a computer to estimate how much the Defense Department would save if it closed its high-tech military laboratory in Rome, N.Y., and merged it with a lab elsewhere.
Their October cost-benefit analysis found that moving the lab would be so expensive -- $133.8 million -- that it would far outweigh the $1.5 million in annual savings from closing it. Indeed, the computer determined it would take more than 100 years to recoup the price of the move. So the Air Force ranked the Rome laboratory among the last installations it would consider closing. 
 But four months later, as politicians across the country lobbied feverishly to save their local bases, the Air Force issued a whole new cost-benefit analysis. It said the relocation would cost less than half as much -- $52.8 million -- with big annual savings of $11.5 million.
Suddenly the cost of closing Rome Lab could be recouped in just four years. Suddenly the Air Force had the numbers to justify shutting Rome. On Feb. 28, a week after the second computer run, the Pentagon made public the list of 119 installations it hoped to close or consolidate this year, including, for the first time, Rome Lab, which develops sophisticated electronic equipment for commanders to use to communicate with their forces.
The search for the true numbers provides a window on the jockeying that goes on as the military labors to substantiate its decisions. It is a process even Government Accounting Office auditors have characterized as elusive.
To some, the Rome Lab case suggests that the base closing system is hardly the open and apolitical process it was intended to be.
Supporters of the lab -- including Raymond Meier, the County Executive of Oneida County, where it lies, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- say they are sure the Air Force altered the numbers between October and February to support a behind-the-scenes political decision to shut Rome.
"They're cooking the books," Mr. D'Amato said. "The decision to move the lab was made. And then they had to invent the numbers to justify the decision."
Indeed, the discrepancy between the October and February numbers was so striking that the special Presidential commission on base closings asked the Air Force in April to do a third calculation. On May 23, the computer produced an estimate radically different from the first two.
 
Small Changes Make A Big Difference
 The Rome case illustrates how subtle changes in estimating basic costs like maintenance, moving or construction can strikingly alter an installation's fate. For example, in October the Air Force estimated the one-time costs to move and reinstall Rome's equipment at $16.8 million. But in February, the Air Force cut this estimate to $7.6 million, making it cheaper to close Rome.
Air Force officials, defending their analyses, say the estimates changed with circumstances. The October numbers were based on the premise that Rome would be merged into one other Air Force base, Hanscom, near Boston. The February estimate is based on splitting Rome between two sites, Hanscom and the Army base in Fort Monmouth, N.J., resulting in far less new construction, Air Force officials say.
"The data used in the Air Force analysis is publicly available, and has been certified and reviewed within the Air Force," said Maj. Gen. Jay D. Blume Jr., special assistant to the chief of staff for base realignment and closure. General Blume said he expected the commission on base closings "to closely scrutinize our data and we are confident the commission will find the recommendation is well supported."
But the May 23 computer run, which followed recent visits by Air Force analysts to Rome, Hanscom and Fort Monmouth, seems to raise more questions than it answers.
For example, the estimated relocation cost went from $133.8 million in October down to $52.8 million in April, and then back up to $79.2 million in the third analysis.
An analyst in the Air Force, who insisted on anonymity, defended the third computer run, calling it "the best possible estimate of what it will really take to do this action." He said it indicated that closing Rome was feasible and that the costs could be recouped in six years.
Senator D'Amato is no more convinced by these numbers, however, than by the previous set from the Air Force. "They are not big enough to admit they were wrong," he said.
Even as savvy a political operator as Mr. D'Amato has only theories on what political strings may have been pulled. He says it may have been California interests, trying to save a large Air Force depot at McClellan Air Force Base, near Sacramento, or Massachusetts interests protecting Hanscom Air Force Base.
After Senator D'Amato and Gov. George E. Pataki railed against the Air Force's numbers at a May 5 hearing, the commission's chairman, former Senator Alan J. Dixon of Illinois, said: "I think we're interested in looking at Rome more carefully." The independent commission is to begin voting in late June on the Pentagon's recommendations.
 
Explanations Draw Criticism
 Senior Air Force officials say that the wide variation between the October and February analyses of Rome, which employs about 1,000 civilians, has a simple explanation. Moving the whole lab to Hanscom, they said, would have required $95 million in new construction. But splitting Rome between two bases would take advantage of existing empty space.
In explaining the specific changes -- like the change in equipment-moving costs from $16.8 million in October to $7.6 million in February to $10.4 million in May -- Air Force officials have hardly been definitive. When first asked by a reporter why the moving costs fell between October and February, a senior Air Force official said that some equipment would be left behind at Rome.
As to why the moving estimates then jumped from $7.6 million in February to $10.4 million in May, the Air Force analyst said the May estimate included buying new equipment to replace what had been left behind.
Such explanations have not satisfied two retired military budget officers, Paul Freund and Bill Harvey, both veterans of previous rounds of closings, who were hired by community officials in Rome to check the Air Force numbers.
For weeks, Mr. Freund has been arguing that the February moving figure, $7.6 million, was too low. He produced an internal Air Force memorandum, dated Dec. 29, 1994, which says that moving just four pieces of heavy equipment from Rome would cost nearly $7 million alone. What about the thousands of other items that must be moved, Mr. Freund asked.
On seeing the Air Force's third moving estimate, $10.4 million, in the May 23 analysis, he said: "At least they're going up. That's a step in the right direction."
The case of Rome Lab is not unique. Since 1988, when the Pentagon first proposed post-cold war base closings, communities have complained loudly that the costs of shutting their bases were underestimated and the savings inflated. In past rounds, the odds that a locality would persuade the commission to reverse the Defense Department were slim, about 1 in 10.
That has not deterred economic development officials in the Rome region. Already stung by the closing of Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome in 1993, a team led by the Oneida County Executive, Mr. Meier, has spent $500,000 to plead its cause. They say the lab has more than $100 million in annual contracts with upstate companies and universities.
The local officials hired a public relations firm. They also hired Mr. Freund, a retired lieutenant colonel who oversaw the Air Force's base-closing budget process in 1993, and Mr. Harvey, a retired colonel who had a similar role in the Army. The two consultants, who have named their Virginia firm the Survivors Group, have been retained by a half-dozen communities facing closings.
Among their questions about Rome is "real property maintenance," an annual budget line that includes replacing broken toilets, repainting offices and other odd repairs. In October, the Air Force estimated it would save $3.2 million in maintenance by moving Rome to Hanscom. But in February and again in May, the Air Force increased the maintenance savings, to $8.1 million.
 
Shifting Estimates Of Needed Space
 Air Force analysts said more would be saved by moving the lab into existing space at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth, where maintenance is already provided. But the consultants say that if the space is empty now at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth, the maintenance costs will increase when it is occupied.
Equally troubling, they said, was the Air Force's assumption about the space needed to relocate the 500,000-square-foot laboratory. In October, the Air Force said it would need 328,000 square feet to move the entire Rome Lab to Hanscom; in February, the combined space it requested at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth fell to 223,000 square feet.
The less space needed at a new site, of course, the stronger the argument for closing Rome.
After the February numbers became public, the consultants said they were skeptical about whether the lab could be squeezed so small. In the May 23 analysis, the Air Force seemed to agree, saying the laboratory would now require 365,000 square feet at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth.
It is difficult to determine if politics played a role in all this. In a report in April, the General Accounting Office chastised the Air Force for providing insufficient documentation "to substantiate the extent of deliberations and analyses leading to decisions to close" bases.
There is no shortage of theories about Rome. Representative Sherwood Boehlert, an Oneida County Republican, says he believes that Rome did not have an "angel" in the Pentagon's inner circle. Senator D'Amato suspects early Presidential politics and theorizes that Rome was selected for closing to save the depot at McClellan, which employs 10,000 civilians, because of California's electoral votes.
The Senator and Representative both said they suspected that Hanscom, in Bedford, Mass., was designated to inherit about 60 percent of the Rome laboratory because the base has a strong relationship with Massachusetts Institute of Technology. For the three decades before she became the Air Force Secretary in 1993, Sheila E. Widnall was a professor of aeronautics at M.I.T., which would benefit if the lab moved nearby.
Rudy de Leon, the Air Force undersecretary, said suggestions of favoritism were ludicrous. "The Secretary is a person of absolute integrity," he said.
Air Force officials say they supported Rome until November, when a Defense Department committee first suggested moving part of the lab to the Fort Monmouth Army base so the Army and Air Force could combine similar functions.
Still, Representative Boehlert said he believed the commission would vote Rome's way next month. "The numbers are with us," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rome Laboratory has been the subject of shifting figures in computations used by the Air Force to justify closing the high-tech laboratory. (Michael Okoniewski for The New York Times) (pg. B6)
 
Chart: "ADDING IT UP: Closing an Air Force Lab"
 Before it can recommend closing an installation, the Air Force, like the other services, must estimate the potential costs and savings. It does so using a computer model nicknamed Cobra, or Cost of Base Realignment Actions. Chart shows selected results from three Cobra analyses on Rome Laboratory, a high-tech Air Force research installation in Rome, N.Y. The Air Force believes the final analysis to be most accurate. HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS;
Clinton Speaks: Battling Forces of Disintegration

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., May 31

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech today at the United States Air Force Academy, as provided by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:
Our security objectives over the last 50 years have been dictated by straightforward events, often beyond our control, but at least they were straightforward and clear. In World War II, the objective was simple: win the war. In the cold war, the objective was clear: contain communism and prevent nuclear war. In the post-cold-war world, the objectives are often more complex, and it is clear that American security in the 21st century will be determined by forces that are operating both beyond and within our own borders. . . . 
 Clearly there are powerful historical forces pulling us together: a worldwide thirst for freedom and democracy, a growing commitment to market economics, a technological revolution that moves information, ideas, money and people around the globe at record speed.
All these things are bringing us together and helping to make our future more secure. But these same forces have a dark underside which can also lead to more insecurity. We understand now that the openness and freedom of society make us even more vulnerable to the organized forces of destruction, the forces of terror and organized crime and drug trafficking.
The technological revolution that is bringing our world closer together can also bring more and more problems to our shores. The end of Communism has opened the door to the spread of weapons of mass destruction and lifted the lid on age-old conflicts rooted in ethnic, racial and religious hatreds. These forces can be all the more destructive today because they have access to modern technology.
Nowhere are the forces of disintegration more obvious today than in Bosnia. For the past two and a half years, the United States has sought to contain and end the conflict, to help to preserve the Bosnian nation as a multistate entity, multiethnic entity, to keep faith with our NATO allies and to relieve human suffering. To these ends, we have led the NATO military responses to calls by the United Nations for assistance in the protection of its forces and safe areas for the people of Bosnia; led efforts to achieve a negotiated settlement; deployed peacekeeping troops to the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia to contain the conflict within the present borders of Bosnia; and conducted the longest humanitarian airlift to the people there in history.
Two weeks ago the Bosnian Serbs unleashed 1,400 shells on the civilians of Sarajevo. The United Nations called this attack a return to medieval barbarism. They asked for a NATO air response, which we supported. Now we have joined our allies to develop a coordinated response to the Serbs' continued refusal to make peace and their illegal capturing of United Nations personnel as hostages. We believe still that a strengthened United Nations operation is the best insurance against an even worse humanitarian disaster, should they leave.
We have a longstanding commitment to help our NATO allies, some of whom have troops in the U.N. operation in Bosnia, to take part in a NATO operation to assist them in a withdrawal if that should ever become necessary. And so, if necessary, and after consultation with Congress, I believe we should be prepared to assist NATO if it decides to meet a request from the United Nations troops for help in a withdrawal or a reconfiguration and a strengthening of its forces. We have received no such request for any such assistance, and we have made no such decision.
But in any event, we must know that we must continue to work for peace there. And I still believe that we have made the right decision in not committing our own troops to become embroiled in this conflict in Europe, nor to join the United Nations operations. So I want to say to you we have obligations to our NATO allies, and I do not believe we can leave them in the lurch. So I must carefully review any request for an operation involving a temporary use of our ground forces. But we have made the right decision in what we have done and what we have not done in Bosnia.
I believe we must look at all of these problems and all these opportunities in new and different ways. For example, we see today that the clear boundaries between threats to our nation's security from beyond our borders and the challenges to our security from within our borders are being blurred. One once was clearly the province of the armed services, the other clearly the province of local law enforcement. Today we see people from overseas coming to our country for terrorist purposes, blurring what is our national security. We must see the threats for what they are and fashion our response based on their true nature, not just where they occur.

HEADLINE: Citing Rising Costs, Port Authority Kills Airport Rail Plan

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has decided not to build a 22-mile railway from Manhattan to Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports in Queens because of rising costs, dealing a major setback to a decades-old search for an affordable and convenient way to transport travelers between the airports and the city's center.
The rail line would have been the largest new public-works venture in the region in years, an undertaking that recalled the mammoth projects of earlier eras: the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the subways, the Hudson River tunnels. But its demise reflects the pressures of today, when public spending is a political concern and a new generation of Republicans wants to shrink government and rein in its aspirations. 
 "The full 22-mile plan is dead," George J. Marlin, the authority's new executive director, said in an interview yesterday. "It cannot be. We don't have the resources for it."
Seeking to salvage something from their years of work, planners are now examining whether it might be feasible to construct only one small part of the railway. Such a segment, for example, might move people between a terminal at East 59th Street in Manhattan and La Guardia, but nowhere else.
But without the full railway, most travelers will be left with the much-bemoaned options they have had for years, most of them expensive, time-consuming or both -- taxis, buses or driving and parking at the airport for fees that can run $18 a day.
Mr. Marlin said the estimates for the plan had soared in recent months. When it was originally conceived in 1991, as a pet project ofGov. Mario M. Cuomo, a smaller version of the proposal was expected to cost $1.6 billion. The latest figure for completing the entire 22-mile railway is $4 billion to $5 billion, officials said, with some in the agency maintaining that it is even higher.
Port Authority officials first disclosed misgivings about building the entire 22-mile railway in January, but they did not appear ready at that time to drop it altogether.
The move to abandon the proposal throws the Port Authority's plans for improving the routes to Kennedy and La Guardia into uncertainty, raising the prospect that the two might continue to lose business to other airports. It has also angered officials in Queens, who accuse the authority of giving up too soon.
Before the proposal was scuttled, the agency was to have built a railway from the station at East 59th Street and Lexington Avenue over the Queensboro Bridge to La Guardia and then south to Kennedy before returning to Manhattan, making other stops along the way at places like Shea Stadium. The fare would probably have ranged from $9 to $13.
But the plan drew strong criticism from some transportation experts, largely because it was financed by a $3 surcharge on airline tickets that sharply limits its scope. Under Federal law, that money cannot be used for general transportation purposes, meaning that the railway could not be connected directly to subways or commuter rail lines.
The transportation experts said it made no sense to allocate so much for a railway that was isolated from other transportation systems. The project also stirred a backlash on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, with some residents complaining that the terminal at 59th Street would increase traffic congestion.
By the end of this year the fund generated by the ticket surcharge is expected to reach about $280 million. Any money not used for the railway would probably be spent on renovations of the two airports. Either way, the Port Authority hopes to receive approval from the Federal Aviation Administration to continue collecting the surcharge.
Mr. Marlin, who was brought in by Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, with a mandate to turn over some of the authority's operations to private industry, said he feared that the project could ensnare the Port Authority in a financial fiasco, like those he had watched unfold in his last job as a municipal bond expert, including the long-delayed construction of Denver's new airport.
He said the authority would be able to raise $1 billion from the ticket surcharge, leaving it several billion dollars short unless it borrowed to make up the difference. In recent months, some officials in the agency have also suggested that it try to find a private company as a partner, but that apparently is not considered possible.
The Port Authority has never broken ground on the railway project, but it has spent millions of dollars on engineering, environmental and other studies. The authority's board has not yet formally canceled the full plan, but its commissioners have been talking in recent weeks about alternatives and are expected to take them up this summer.
The project had been pushed by Mr. Cuomo, who is from Queens, but Mr. Pataki, has expressed doubts about it since the campaign.
"The Governor's views are like mine," said Charles A. Gargano, a Port Authority commissioner and Mr. Pataki's economic adviser. "During this time of budget problems, before we go forward with a project of this magnitude, we have to see whether it can sustain itself later, or else the public is going to have to subsidize it forever."
Another commissioner and Pataki adviser, Peter S. Kalikow, said he hoped that the authority would still be able to handle the one segment of the railway from Manhattan to La Guardia. But first, he said, it was important that costs be laid out more clearly.
"I can't vote for something if they say $2 billion, $3 billion, $7 billion," he said. "These are the numbers that they are throwing around."
One of the project's biggest boosters, the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, a Democrat, said that Port Authority officials were inflating the figures to gain support for abandoning it.

HEADLINE: Richer for Failing

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
When the head of National Medical Care announced a takeover attempt for that company last month, analysts were quick to praise the offer. This was not, they insisted, another Kirk Kerkorian bid.
That day should have convinced everyone that the naysayers were right: Mr. Kerkorian's $22.8 billion takeover bid for the Chrysler Corporation was dead in the water. Since he announced his offer on April 12, Mr. Kerkorian had been transformed in the eyes of Wall Street from a credible suitor to the personification of an empty bidder. 
 Are there lessons to be learned from this apparent stumble? Or did Mr. Kerkorian outsmart them all, having found some victory in his apparent defeat?
The answer depends on Mr. Kerkorian's intent when his Tracinda Corporation announced its offer of $55 a share. If he really planned to gain control of Chrysler, his moves could well become a case study in how to doom a takeover attempt.
Mr. Kerkorian's first misstep may have been to rely to much on the cult of personality, having teamed up with Lee A. Iaccoca, the former Chrysler chairman.
What was missing was cash: Mr. Kerkorian had no financing, and had not hired an investment bank to assist him. As the days passed without Mr. Kerkorian's announcing his bankers or advisers, his credibility suffered.
Making it all worse was the structure of his proposed deal. Mr. Kerkorian was attempting a highly leveraged transaction in a cyclical industry -- one that has significant ups and downs as the economy changes. As a measure of risk, remember that even in the 1980's, the heyday of the fast-money mergers, no one attempted a deal as large as Mr. Kerkorian's proposal for a cyclical company. It was considered too risky.
"One thing that is clear from this is that it is very hard to get financing for a leveraged deal in a cyclical industry, and that is a good thing," said Steven Kaplan, a professor of finance at the University of Chicago business school.
Finally, Mr. Kerkorian and his advisers projected an image that was almost too naive. They railed about Chrysler's attempts to persuade the banks not to lend money for the deal -- something that is Step No. 1 in every corporate defense playbook. They criticized Chrysler for calling the bid hostile, when, they contended, the company had been made aware of Mr. Kerkorian's intentions and never raised objections. Their continuous talk about past events served only to undermine their credibility, since Wall Street cared only about the future of the bid.
But perhaps Mr. Kerkorian did not lose so badly as it appears. Indeed, some on Wall Street argue that he never intended to acquire Chrysler, or his attempt would not have been so badly mishandled. Instead, this theory goes, Mr. Kerkorian's loud saber-rattling was an attempt to gain a measure of control over Chrysler's management.
"Whatever happens down the road," said one lawyer specializing in mergers, who spoke on he condition that he not be identified, "you can be sure that Chrysler is going to listen closely to what Kerkorian has to say."
Mr. Kerkorian's announcement yesterday underscores that. While withdrawing his bid, he pointedly disclosed that Wasserstein Perella & Company, a firm that made its name in mergers, had been retained to help him map out his next step. The implicit threat: that Mr. Kerkorian could well come back with a refined bid that would prove more palatable for Wall Street.
And Mr. Kerkorian has already won a victory of sorts. Chrysler shares are up 11 percent from where they stood before Mr. Kerkorian announced his bid. That is almost double the 6 percent rise of the Standard & Poor's 500 in the same period, and Chrysler shares outperformed those of Ford and General Motors.
"Clearly, Kerkorian scored some points," Mr. Kaplan said. "You can attribute some of that rise to him."
What that means for Mr. Kerkorian personally is that his 36 million shares of Chrysler are now worth about $160 million more than they were the day before he announced his bid -- not bad for a deal he never did.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Mixed; 30-Year Bond Yields 6.64

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices closed mixed yesterday as the bond market reacted to several economic reports that reduced the odds that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates soon.
The 30-year bond rose 6/32 , to a price of 112 20/32 for a yield of 6.64 percent, down from 6.66 percent on Tuesday. Intermediate notes were mixed. A 10-year maturity moved lower in price to yield 6.28 percent, up from 6.27 percent on Tuesday. 
 Economists and dealers said the market was disappointed by nearly all of the economic data released yesterday, especially the final sales and inventory components of the revised first-quarter gross domestic product.
While the Chicago purchasing managers index fell to 53.5 in May from April's 57.6, it was still slightly up from average estimates of 53.1 and above the key 50-point level, hurting Treasury securities.
Theodore Ake, government trading manager at Kemper Securities in Chicago, said, "It brings down the odds that the Fed is going to ease anytime soon."
April new-home sales were down 2.7 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 580,000 units, lower than consensus estimates of 582,000, and thus provided little support to the market.
First-quarter gross domestic product was revised slightly downward to show a growth rate of 2.7 percent, down from 2.8 percent, and well below an expected 3.1 percent.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said some of the components of the revised first quarter G.D.P. numbers implied that second-quarter growth was likely to be revised upward. "Growth during the second quarter, nevertheless, continues to appear weak, with final sales growing an estimated 2.0 percent," she said.
Chris Leary, senior vice president and portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management, said the numbers "were bullish on the surface, but not quite as good when you looked at the underlying components."
The market is now looking at tomorrow's employment number as a jump ball, he said, forecasting "a large revision to April's number."
Looking ahead toward reports on April consumption, the May purchasing managers report, April factory orders, May chain store sales, May auto sales and initial weekly jobless claims, Mr. Leary said, "You have to be at least cautiously neutral right now because the numbers should be favorable to the bond market."
In the municipal bond market, yields were little changed but still near 13-month lows. Investors were attracted in droves to yesterday's $1.25 billion bond offering by the Foothill/Eastern Transportation Corridor Agency of Orange County, Calif., through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities, which offered higher yields. It was by far the largest auction in the muni market this year.
Despite the strong demand, investors were seeking yields of more than 7 percent on many of the securities because of concern about the start-up nature of the project and because this toll road will run through the heart of the nation's largest bankrupt municipality.
The financing includes $813.5 million in senior lien current interest bonds priced to yield from 6.50 percent for an issue due in 2016 to 6.78 percent in 2032, 6.75 percent in 2034 and 6.73 percent in 2035.
For $207 million of zero-coupon bonds, which pay no interest, dealers priced the securities to yield 6.70 percent in 2004 to 7.30 percent in 2026 through 2030. And for $151.5 million of zeros that are convertible to current interest rate bonds, yields ranged from 6.95 percent in 2007 to 7.15 percent in 2013 and 2014.
All the bonds are rated triple-B- by Standard & Poor's
Walter Kreutzen, executive vice president of finance and administration for the Transportation Corridor Agencies, said he did not think the offering had been penalized by the Orange County bankruptcy.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of 13-day cash management bills, which are used to meet short-term borrowing needs beyond the money raised through the Government's regularly scheduled auctions:

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why hasn't a weaker dollar cut America's trade deficit?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE dollar, everyone knows, has taken a pounding in the last year while the yen is flying high. Yet trade accounts have not responded: indeed the United States deficit has swelled while Japan's surplus has continued to climb. Doesn't that prove adjustments in exchange rates have little or no influence over trade flows?
The search for an alternative theory of what drives foreign trade accounts has taken on a new urgency after the latest round of exchange-rate gyrations. For if exchange rates don't matter, the assumption that free markets in currencies can more or less keep the world trading system on an even keel no longer holds. 
 Not to worry. William Cline of the Institute of International Economics has marshaled impressive evidence that exchange rates really do drive the trade accounts of the economic superpowers. Or perhaps you should worry: Mr. Cline's estimates suggest that the dollar would still have to fall a long way before America shed its status as a borrower. For the foreseeable future, it seems, the world's richest economy is destined to remain dependent on loans from its friends.
The simplest explanation for the failure of the depreciating dollar to slash the trade deficit is that it has not depreciated nearly as much as most people assume. For while the dollar has tanked against the yen and the European currencies linked to the German mark, it has held its own against the currencies of the smaller Asian trading countries and done very, very nicely against the Canadian dollar and Mexican peso.
But that simple explanation is hardly complete. After all, the trade-weighted dollar has still depreciated by about 10 percent in the last year, with a seemingly perverse impact on America's trade balance.
Mr. Cline fills in the missing pieces of the puzzle by showing that the trade accounts of both America and Japan are, in fact, quite responsive to changes in exchange rates. The catch is that other factors, notably the business cycle, also affect trade. Make that two catches: Exchange rates work, but only with a considerable time lag.
Specifically, Mr. Cline used statistical techniques to isolate the impact of exchange rates on the "current account" -- the broadest measure of trade flows. Economic growth at home sucks in imports, while growth abroad increases the demand for exports. Once adjustments are made for changes in growth rates, he found that the current account responded to the exchange rate with a two-year lag.
So the real story of trade and exchange rates over the last few years goes something like this. The rise (yes, rise) in the dollar in 1993 is only now being fully felt on the American trade account, with each percentage point increase adding roughly $7 billion to the deficit. And the impact has been exacerbated by the fact that the American economy has been growing since 1992 while Japan remained mired in recession.
By Mr. Cline's analysis, the decline of the dollar in the last year has been fully justified; otherwise the American current account deficit, now pushing a record $200 billion, would balloon past $250 billion by 1997.
By the same token, the appreciation of the yen makes good sense in light of the Japanese recession and Tokyo's failure to stimulate the economy. Assuming the Japanese economy grows at a tepid 2.5 percent rate this year and a less-than-spectacular 4.5 percent rate in following years, Mr. Cline predicts that today's yen exchange rate would only just barely push Japan's current account surplus below $100 billion in 1997.
Evidence that exchange rates work according to Hoyle should be only modest comfort, though. By Mr. Cline's numbers, it would take an additional 15 percent drop in the dollar merely to halve America's current account deficit. Moreover, since the Canadian dollar and Mexican peso along with most Latin American and Asian currencies would probably follow the dollar, real progress on reducing America's deficit would require sharp dollar depreciation with respect to the yen and the strong European currencies.
There is a very different way of looking at the same problem. The dollar-yen crisis, if you want to call it that, is really the indirect consequence of Japan's economic stagnation. If Japan could return to a growth path, say, two percentage points above that of the United States, the pressure for further adjustment in exchange rates would presumably dissipate.
But don't count on it. The best and perhaps the only way Japan can beat the economic blues anytime soon is to stimulate the economy with tax cuts that increase the Government's already substantial budget deficit. And judging from the past year's sorry performance, the deeply conservative bureaucracy controlling economic policy would rather watch Japan's great industrial complex wither than spend its way out of recession.

HEADLINE: A Poor Plan for Nynex

 BODY:
The future of telephone service in New York State will be shaped today when the state Public Service Commission votes on a poorly fashioned plan to loosen regulations on Nynex, which provides residential phone service to over seven million customers. The plan, which the commission's staff negotiated with Nynex, would slightly lower and then freeze residential rates for up to seven years. In return, Nynex would be allowed to keep whatever extra money it earns from cutting costs and selling new communications services. The goal is to entice Nynex into lower costs and greater innovation. But the plan will not work unless drastically altered.
For starters, the duration of the plan is too long. To lock in rates today based on seven-year projections of inflation and productivity invites serious problems. Either the rates wind up too low, forcing Nynex to cut back services, or too high, thereby generating windfall profit with which to subsidize -- to its competitors' detriment -- entry into new fields. Consumer groups complain, with justification, that the plan will not force Nynex to improve its poor service record. They also claim that the proposed rate reductions are skimpy, falling below those achieved in other states. 
 One provision threatens to misshape the telephone market for years. AT&T, MCI and other alternative carriers want to compete against Nynex for medium-distance toll service. But toll calls start and finish on Nynex's wires to the home, a service for which Nynex charges an access fee. The alternative carriers say the proposed plan sets access fees above Nynex's costs and much too high to allow them to provide a low-cost service.
The commission could fashion a better plan by shortening its term and further reducing residential rates and access fees. It is also important to clarify that the plan would be pre-empted by a forthcoming restructuring of telecommunications markets so that every service is opened to competition. That way Nynex's privileged position will not endure longer than necessary.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Essay;
War on the World

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
By taking hundreds of peacekeepers hostage, using them as human shields and calling them "prisoners of war," the Bosnian Serbs have declared war on the world.
Will the world fight back? Not likely; it prefers to disengage in high dudgeon. 
 The British response -- dispatching combat engineers with artillery -- has as its purpose the extrication of its forces from a doomed mission. The French will follow; the international decision is being made to withdraw, and President Clinton has agreed to some American cover.
The Serbs know that the U.N. is a sponge designed to absorb humiliation. Now they are testing the Western powers to see who has the will to fight and win in Bosnia.
No outsiders have that will. When Americans dare to suggest that Europeans collectively enforce Europe's peace, the response is: Without you? You lead, America -- send U.S. troops to fight -- and we may follow, criticizing all the way.
They know that America won't become Europe's internal policeman. And so Serbs -- with the arms and the will to win -- are winning.
No one doubts that an exercise of force three years ago -- European troops, U.S. air power, world economic pressure -- would have saved the day for collective defense. But that was then; appeasement failed; continued peacekeeping requires war-making; what now?
The Surrender Solution is the one preferred here now, provided enough fig leaves can be found. This would include angry warnings to terrorist hostage-takers; fighting forces added, under national commands, to cover a withdrawal in strength; pressure on the Bosnians to be good sports and surrender. This would avoid a televised bloodbath and an unwanted guilty conscience all around. The problem is with the victims, who prefer to fight.
The Secular Muslim Solution is quietly being bruited about. If the U.N. is paralyzed by terrorists, some suggest turning to Turkey and Pakistan to do for Bosnia's Muslims what the West has no will to do: send the 100,000 troops needed to persuade the Serbs that they could lose everything by fighting.
A grateful European Union could make such intercession worth Turkey and Pakistan's while. This romantic notion -- stimulated by the picture of Tansu Ciller and Benazir Bhutto visiting Sarajevo -- is admittedly far-fetched.
The Fundamentalist Muslim Solution is one that no European wants, but that Serbs invite. Iran is already smuggling arms into Bosnia, and -- with gun-for-hire Afghanis -- radicalizing secular Bosnian Muslims. Teheran's idea is to turn the victims into villains: secure a guerrilla foothold in Europe, and -- as Iran becomes nuclear with Russia's help -- intimidate northward from a base of persecuted and angry Bosnians.
The Balance of Power Solution is "belated lift-and-strike," never seriously pressed by Clintonites, now made costlier by delay. It calls for actively taking Bosnia's side.
Stage one: Lift the U.N. arms embargo, and supply and train Bosnian troops, while removing U.N. peacekeepers with U.S. air support. Offer up no more hostages.
Recognize that in the pullout's aftermath, eastern enclaves will be overrun; Serbian terrorists will kill tens of thousands of innocents. If most Bosnians are prepared to pay this price for a nation of their own, it is not for the West to fail to arm them.
Stage two: See what heavy bombing does to the Bosnian Serb forces, cut off from Serbia. Such suppressing fire from the air might allow the Muslim advantage in military manpower -- three to two over Serbs in Bosnia -- to manifest itself.
This last is not a happy or heroic solution. It will cost lives sooner rather than later. But it levels the killing field. That bloody balancing of power is the only language terrorists understand.
The U.S. should help in a withdrawal guaranteed to lead to lift-and-strike, but not in any "reconfiguration" intended to prolong the embargo and the dithering.
Outsiders do not have the will to win. Serbs do. So do embattled Bosnian Muslims. Humanitarians must become air-support allies; in that way, the world can win the war.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: How New York City Privatized Street Cleaning and Rued It

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The statement by Prof. E. S. Savas, the "prophet" of privatization (news article, May 25), that "introducing competition into the delivery of public services" is "new" displays astonishing ignorance. 
 Between 1842 and 1881 the streets of New York City were cleaned by private contractors, whose contracts were awarded by competitive bidding. (Competitive bidding was probably used even earlier, but information about the period before 1826 is incomplete. Between 1826 and 1841 the streets were cleaned by public employees, who performed remarkably well.)
There were strict means to enforce performance, including the right of the mayor, with just 24 hours' notice, to order the streets cleaned at the derelict contractor's expense. What's interesting is that despite competitive bidding and the availability of strict enforcement measures, the streets of New York City were continuously filthy.
In 1860 the city inspector declared that the contracting-out system "has in every instance proved a failure." It is precisely because of the failure of competition that the city government stepped in, in the first place.
 
MOSHE ADLER
Assoc. Prof., Economics, Rutgers U.
Newark, May 25, 1995

HEADLINE: Wolfensohn to Step Down As Kennedy Center Head

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
James D. Wolfensohn, who had hoped to remain as chairman of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts even after assuming the presidency of the World Bank on Thursday, has decided instead to relinquish the arts position, a spokeswoman for the center said tonight.
Confirming a report of Mr. Wolfensohn's decision in The Washington Post, the spokeswoman, Tiki Davies, said that Mr. Wolfensohn would leave the Kennedy Center at the end of the year, and that the center's board would start a search for his successor. 
 Mr. Wolfensohn, a New York financier and philanthropist, previously headed Carnegie Hall and was credited with bringing a measure of financial stability to the Kennedy Center. He will become chairman emeritus at the Kennedy Center, Ms. Davies said, a position he holds at Carnegie Hall.
Attempts to reach Mr. Wolfensohn by telephone tonight were unsuccessful. The Post quoted him as having said that "the more I got into the work at the bank, the more it became clear to me that I could not take on the total responsibility" of heading both the World Bank and the Kennedy Center.
In March, President Clinton chose Mr. Wolfensohn to succeed Lewis T. Preston as president of the World Bank. Mr. Preston was ill with cancer, and died early this month. By tradition, the United States selects the head of the World Bank, which issues $17 billion in loans each year for development projects in poor countries.
Mr. Wolfensohn was born in Australia and became an American citizen in 1980. The chairman of his firm, James D. Wolfensohn Inc., which advises major corporate clients, is Paul A. Volker, a former chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Mr. Wolfensohn is a cellist and has moved freely in the disparate worlds of high finance and performing arts. When his selection as head of the World Bank was disclosed, Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International and a former official in the Carter and Reagan Administrations, said of Mr. Wolfensohn, "He's a Renaissance man, with extremely good judgment and great integrity."
