HEADLINE: An Italian Master Works His Glass Alchemy

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
THERE are magicians who saw people in half or make them disappear in miracles of illusion. And there is Lino Tagliapietra, a magician whose miracles are real.
Dipping his blowpipe into a 2,000-degree mass of molten glass, Mr. Tagliapietra breathes gentle puffs of air through the tube and then in a flash, with a snip of steel tweezers, a pull and a tug, creates a planet Saturn, wreathed in rings. Or a delicate gleaming goblet with a base like an inverted parasol that pings musically at the tap of a finger. 
 Eccolo: It is a miracle.
Mr. Tagliapietra, a master glassblower from Murano, a town in the Lagoon of Venice, can blow glass into a perfect circle with the ease of a child blowing a soap bubble.
William Gudenrath, a glass blower who lives in Jersey City and whose goblets are sold at places like Bergdorf Goodman, said, "A master has two qualities -- a sense of design, and he invents something new to do in glass."
William Traver, Mr. Tagliapietra's dealer in Seattle, said, "Lino has blended the traditional European mastery of glass with the innovative American way of making larger, more abstract forms."
How does he do it? Many Murano glassblowers would never say, their techniques having been treated like state secrets for centuries. But Mr. Tagliapietra, who is 61 now and who became a glass-factory apprentice at 11 and a master by 22, is more relaxed.
His generosity in sharing the art and craft of glass making, which the Venetians have been practicing for 1,000 years, has not made him popular with his colleagues at home.
Indeed, since 1979, he has not only collaborated with artists like Mr. Chihuly, but also taught regularly at Pilchuck Glass School, near Seattle, and occasionally at Haystack Mountain School of Crafts in Deer Isle, Me.
For such disclosure, which has helped stimulate interest in glass blowing, he has been ostracized by some other Murano glassblowers. He is not the first glassblower to leave Murano to teach, but he is the first to teach so often.
"When I teach, I teach everything," Mr. Tagliapietra said. He also blows his own designs, which sell from $1,200 for a goblet to $28,000 for a sculpture that is 30 inches in diameter.
In addition to the William Traver Gallery in Seattle, his dealers include the Sanske Gallery in Zurich.
One artist who has worked with Mr. Tagliapietra is Izhar Patkin, who hired him to execute a design for a 14-foot glass sculpture, a full-breasted figure with six arms that looks like a composite of Carmen Miranda, Josephine Baker and the Hindu god Shiva.
"If you go to Venice and to Murano and hire a glassblower, there's a maestro who does extremely beautiful roses and a maestro who does very beautiful vases -- but Lino can do everything," Mr. Patkin said. The sculpture, called "Where Each Is Both," was acquired last year by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
When Mr. Tagliapietra collaborates, he charges $1,500 to $2,000 a day, plus expenses, and salary and expenses for a team of other glassblowers and assistants to help him.
Mr. Patkin went to Murano to arrange for a factory to let Mr. Tagliapietra blow. "The owner said yes, and the workers said no," Mr. Patkin recalled. "It was a horrible moment for me, to go back to Lino with the factory owner, and say, 'We don't know how to tell you this, but the workers will walk out.' "
And so Mr. Tagliapietra blew the 14-foot-high sculpture at the New York Experimental Glass Workshop, now called Urban Glass, in Brooklyn. The ostracism was gradual.
"The first time, in 1979, nobody say nothing," he said. Then, he added, "My social life practically disappeared."
"There were no more invitations to the party, no dinners with some friends," he added. "If the economy has a little problem, it's because Lino took out the secrets."
Mr. Patkin said later: "You have to be very centered when you're sitting there to blow a perfect bubble. This extends to his personality."
Last month, Mr. Tagliapietra returned to Urban Glass to blow glass from designs by Dorothy Hafner, an artist and ceramicist, for her show at the Heller Gallery at 71 Greene Street (at Spring Street) that opens tomorrow. Even maestros do not blow alone: Ms. Hafner assembled a team to work with Mr. Tagliapietra, including two glassblowers from Seattle, Bryan Rubino and Janusz Pozniak, over the course of the four days it took to blow the 27 objects of mosaic glass. Glassblowing is theater: when Mr. Tagliapietra finished a vessel, many applauded.
Mr. Tagliapietra's tools, ancient and simple, were laid out by his bench. There were the hollow blowpipe, shears, and pincers for pulling the glass. To shape it, there were long wooden blades called jacks, wooden blocks, cork paddles and large wads of wet newspaper. The pontil, a solid rod, attaches to the bottom of the glass.
During the process, a clear glass bubble is rolled across a tray of colored glass pieces that adhere to it. It is then blown into its final shape, emerging as a painting in the round.
First, Mr. Pozniak dipped the blowpipe into the furnace, gathering the bubbling liquid onto the tip. He began to blow the 15-pound bubble, repeating the process until it was nearly the right size to pick up the mosaic pieces. Then he passed it to Mr. Tagliapietra, who, as Ms. Hafner said, "blows in the magic."
Amy Schwartz, who, with Andrew Stenerson, was one of the assistants, used the wood paddles to shield his hands from the heat. Then, as Mr. Rubino blew, Mr. Tagliapietra began to shape the vessel with wet newspapers.
It was reheated, then rolled in brilliant bits of cobalt, scarlet and ochre glass, which had been heated. As Mr. Tagliapietra blew, circles became ovals and squares metamorphosed into diamonds.
In 12 hours, the finished vessel will cool to room temperature. What will sell for $6,000 to $12,000 took Mr. Tagliapietra an hour to make. "Or 40 years," he said, smiling.

HEADLINE: Evidence Shows Link of 2 Centuries of Drought to Maya Decline

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
New evidence from a Mexican lake bed has revealed that an unusually severe drought about 1,200 years ago may well have contributed to the abrupt decline of classic Maya civilization.
Scientists from the University of Florida said an analysis of sediments beneath Lake Chichancanab on the Yucatan Peninsula provided "the first unambiguous evidence" for a period of extreme aridity between A.D. 800 and 1000. The drought was the harshest in the region in 8,000 years and coincided with the widespread collapse of Maya culture, a time of spreading warfare and finally the abandonment of many great cities of monumental architecture. 
 Although in recent years archeologists have made many new discoveries in Maya ruins and managed to decipher telling hieroglyphic texts, the mystery of the civilization's sudden decline a thousand years ago persists. Various theories have implicated overpopulation, environmental degradation and bitter intercity rivalries leading to destructive warfare throughout much of the Maya lowlands of what is now Mexico, Guatemala, Belize and Honduras.
And now, in a report being published today in the journal Nature, scientists added regional drought as a possibly critical factor in the civilization's fate. The findings from a chemical analysis of shell carbonate and gypsum, burned grasses and root fragments in cores from the lake bed might not alone support the drought theory, they said, but other geological evidence of low lake levels elsewhere in Mexico and Costa Rica suggested that the climate shift was just in Central America.
The study was conducted by Dr. David A. Hodell and Dr. Jason H. Curtis, both geologists at the University of Florida and Dr. Mark Brenner of the university's department of fisheries and aquatic sciences.
In an accompanying commentary, Dr. Jeremy A. Sabloff, director of the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archeology and Anthropology and a Maya specialist, said the new findings added "another important component to the model that archeologists are currently building to help explain the upheavals of the late eighth century and early ninth century A.D. in the Maya lowlands."
But the drought lasting at least two centuries was probably not solely responsible. The region, Dr. Sabloff noted, was "already under heavy stress" from political, economic and environmental problems.
"To a civilization facing a number of stresses both internal and external, the scarcity of water could have greatly increased the vulnerability of numerous classic Maya cities," Dr. Sabloff wrote. "The arrival of a drier regime would have exacerbated the perilous situation, ultimately causing the demise of elite power, the abandonment of many urban centers and important demographic and economic shifts from the southern to northern lowlands."
Such research into the causes of the Maya collapse could have implications for other cultures, ancient and contemporary.
By identifying the circumstances contributing to Maya successes and failures, Dr. Sabloff said, anthropologists might learn "how severe do internal stresses in a civilization have to become before relatively minor climate shifts can trigger widespread cultural collapse."

HEADLINE: U.S. Called Ready to Compromise on Date for Japan Trade Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
In a small step intended to accommodate complaints by Asian and European trade officials, the Clinton Administration is leaning toward moving up the date of the next round of talks with Japan on trade in automobiles and auto parts, several American officials said today.
Last week, the Administration rebuffed a Japanese call for urgent negotiations, proposing that the talks be held in Washington on June 20 or 21. Instead, officials said today, the Administration is now leaning toward offering dates of June 15 or 16 for the discussions, possibly to be held in Geneva. American punitive tariffs on Japanese luxury cars are scheduled to take effect on June 28. 
 The new willingness for earlier talks is significant because it would bring the United States into partial compliance with an international trade agreement. It would also separate the trade talks from a meeting of heads of government of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations on June 15-17 in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
Anne R. Luzzatto, a spokeswoman in the Office of the United States Trade Representative, said no final decision on further negotiations would be made until at least Thursday. But other American officials said momentum was building in favor of earlier talks. Ryutaro Hashimoto, the Japanese Minister of International Trade and Industry and Tokyo's top official involved in the auto dispute, was the first to suggest the new schedule.
Tonight, Michael McCurry, the White House press secretary, said on Air Force One that President Clinton planned to meet privately with Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, on June 15 in Halifax. However, an Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity said there was no intention of resolving the auto-trade issue in Halifax.
The rules of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization, which the United States and Japan helped establish at the beginning of this year, require that members begin to hold negotiations within 30 days of a complaint. Japan filed such a complaint on May 17 against the American plan to impose 100 percent tariffs on 13 models of Japanese luxury cars if an auto-trade deal was not reached by the June 28 cutoff.
A 30-day deadline for talks in the auto dispute expires on June 16, the date now tentatively envisioned for resumption of the negotiations.
The main sticking point in the talks has been the United States' insistence that Japanese companies agree to a plan to increase their purchases of American-made auto parts. The Japanese refuse to discuss such plans, regretting that they agreed to a similar arrangement during the Bush Administration. The targets in that arrangement, on computer semiconductors, have since been met. But while American officials were signaling new flexibility today on procedural matters like the timing of negotiations, they showed no sign of backing down on the substance.
In Geneva, at a meeting of delegates to the World Trade Organization, the Americans today expressed a new willingness to meet soon with Japanese officials, people who attended those discussions said. "There was general appreciation that both sides had agreed to seek a solution to the dispute under the dispute settlement mechanism" of the World Trade Organization, said Krishnasamy Kesavapany, Singapore's representative to the trade group, in a telephone interview.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, has said he does not want the dispute with Japan to become the centerpiece of next month's Group of Seven meeting. By holding separate trade talks on another continent at the same time, the Clinton Administration would at least make it possible for other issues, like the weakness of the American dollar, to hold center stage in Halifax.
In a move that seems likely to complicate the auto-trade talks even further, the 15-nation European Union made a formal request today to the United States for inclusion in these negotiations. Such requests are made under a specific procedure in World Trade Organization rules and may be hard to turn down. American officials had no immediate reaction to the request this afternoon.
The Europeans have been increasingly nervous in recent weeks that the United States and Japan might cut a deal at their expense. The Americans this year have been emphasizing their desire for Japan to buy more American auto parts, rather than that Japan open its market to auto parts from any country.
In the 1980's, the United States tried to negotiate a guaranteed share of the Japanese semiconductor market for its producers. European officials warned at the time that increases in the American share might come at the expense of other exporters to Japan. They eventually persuaded the American negotiators to pursue overall increases in the market shares of all companies shipping semiconductors to Japan.

HEADLINE: Films and Recordings Threaten Nation's Character, Dole Says

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 31

 BODY:
In his quest to gather support from conservative Republicans for his Presidential bid, Senator Bob Dole made a withering attack tonight on the entertainment industry for what he said was a barrage of movies and recordings that are slashing the social fabric of the nation.
"We have reached the point where our popular culture threatens to undermine our character as a nation," said Mr. Dole, whose speech propelled him into the forefront of Republican candidates denouncing Hollywood for producing what he called "nightmares of depravity" involving sex and violence. 
 Early reaction to Mr. Dole's speech ranged from muted to angry. Some critics of the speech said Hollywood was an easy target for conservatives like Mr. Dole, who, they said, were failing to deal with social issues like gun control and unemployment.
Specifically singling out Time Warner for promoting gangsta rap recordings with depictions of violence against the police, the Senate majority leader said, "I would like to ask the executives of Time Warner a question: is this what you intended to accomplish with your careers? You have sold your souls, but must you debase our nation and threaten our children as well?"
Another challenge to Time Warner today today came from William J. Bennett, the former Education Secretary, who wrote to board members of the company, demanding that it stop distributing gangsta rap because of its violent or sexually degrading content. Several executives at the Warner Music Group said that if they were forced to drop the genre it could have a corrosive effect on the company. [Page B10.]
Mr. Dole made his remarks at a fund-raising dinner before a group of about 600 business leaders and Republican stalwarts, only a few from the entertainment industry. Bo Derek, the actress, sat in the front row and was the only performer on hand.
The speech was Mr. Dole's most muscular attack on the entertainment industry since announcing his Presidential drive in April. As the front-runner for the Republican nomination, Mr. Dole has sought to gather support among hard-line conservatives within the party who dominate the primary process. Abortion rights, gun control and, lately, Hollywood have been targets for the 71-year-old lawmaker who has in recent weeks lashed out at entertainment executives for promoting "casual violence and even more casual sex."
But aides to Mr. Dole felt that his earlier forays into social politics had been too general for a candidate who has never been known to strongly espouse the party's moral agenda and concluded that he had to add some punch and some detail to his oratory on the subject.
Other politicians have sought to criticize Hollywood's standards ever since former Vice President Quayle began the 1992 campaign's "family values" debate by denouncing the morality of the comedy series "Murphy Brown."
Mr. Quayle's attacks were initially successful for the Republicans, but backfired at the 1992 Republican National Convention in Houston, where speaker after speaker focused on social and moral issues and, in the view of many Republican and Democratic strategists, alienated large groups of voters. Since then, the Republicans have been seeking ways to bring a family values agenda back to life, but none have seized the issue in quite the same way as Mr. Dole.
Tonight he cited such films as "Natural Born Killers" and "True Romance," as well as groups like Cannibal Corpose, Geto Boys and 2 Live Crew for their depictions of "mindless violence and loveless sex." (An aide to Mr. Dole acknowledged that the candidate has not actually seen the movies or heard the songs, but read the film reviews and lyrics).
Some of the more vocal liberals in Hollywood were unresponsive to the Dole speech. Marilyn Bergman, chairman of American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, which represents 68,000 people in the music business, said she would have no comment. Others declined to speak for the record.
But Norman Lear, creator of "All in the Family" and other television hits, said: "Hollywood in its presentation of violence and sex has no more to answer for than the Congress of the United States. The name of the game in the entertainment business is short-term profit. This is exactly what Congess is all about: how can we get re-elected in the short term and every other value be damned."
Lara Bergthold, executive director of the Hollywood Women's Political Committee, representing mostly wealthy female executives in the entertainment business, termed the Dole speech "unbelievable hypocrisy."
"It's always easier for a Senator to blame fictional characters than to blame themselves for their inability to take guns off the streets and provide jobs to people."
Some of the bluntest comments came from Michael Fuchs, newly appointed chairman of the Warner Music Group, who also runs Home Box Office. In the face of ongoing criticism about rap lyrics, Mr. Fuchs had been asked last week by Gerald M. Levin, chairman of Time Warner, to develop guidelines to place more specific warning labels on some rap albums.
In his attack, Mr. Dole was not singling out all rap, but mainly the songs often referred to as gangsta rap that deal with violence against police and contain sexually charged lyrics.
Speaking over the telephone from his office in New York, Mr. Fuchs said that Mr. Dole "had made no effort to have a dialogue or to try to look at this thing in anything less than an expedient political manner.
Citing Mr. Dole's strong opposition to gun control, Mr. Fuchs added, "I'd like some objective opinion as to whether guns or lyrics are causing the kind of turmoil among America's youth that's tearing at the fabric of this country."
He said that some of the most profitable films in recent years were actually family films like "The Lion King," "The Santa Clause" and "The Flintstones." He also included "Forrest Gump" in his list and oddly "True Lies," an action thriller in which Arnold Schwarzenegger's character kills with high-tech Hollywood abandon.
But Mr. Dole said Hollywood was utterly failing to deal with various films and songs extolling violence. He deplored "music extolling the pleasures of raping, torturing and mutilating women" as well as "songs about killing policemen and rejecting law."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
AIR FRANCE AND BOEING REVISE DEAL ON ORDERS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Air France reached an agreement yesterday with the Boeing Company to revise its airplane orders, increasing the number of planes but postponing delivery until 1999 to 2001, without incurring penalties. The new order could be worth as much as $988 million to Boeing, compared with $578 million for the old orders. Air France said it expected to reach a similar agreement soon with the European airplane consortium Airbus Industrie. The airline said its previous orders for 7 Boeing jets had been replaced by an order for 15 planes -- 7 wide-body 767-300 extended-range aircraft and 8 narrow-body 737-500's -- to be delivered between 1999 and March 2001. Shares of Boeing, which is based in Seattle, gained 62.5 cents, to $58.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;
Germany to Reorganize New York Tourist Office

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BONN, May 31

 BODY:
The German Government promised today to reorganize its official tourism office in New York after a series of scandals that culminated last week with the disclosure of a policy document saying no American "blacks, Jews, Hispanics and Asiatics" should be encouraged to visit Germany.
Gunter Rexrodt, the Economics Minister, whose office pays 85 percent of the New York office's $30 million-plus annual expenses, said the German Government official who oversaw the New York office, Ulrich Geisendorfer, would be dismissed. He said the office would be thoroughly reorganized by July and that Government money might be withdrawn. 
 The German National Tourism Office in New York is already facing lawsuits totaling some $15 million from employees charging sexual and racial discrimination.
And an employee has been dismissed for disseminating documents seeking to discount the Holocaust.
But the event that most shocked Germans was the disclosure last week by the office's acting director, Fred Gross, that a directive had been in effect since 1984 to discourage "blacks, Jews, Hispanics and Asiatics" from visiting Germany.

HEADLINE: Lab's Fate Is in Air Force Numbers;
New York Officials Say Pentagon Tailors Its Data to Politics

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Last October, anticipating a new round of military base closings, Air Force analysts used a computer to estimate how much the Defense Department would save if it closed its high-tech military laboratory in Rome, N.Y., and merged it with a lab elsewhere.
Their October cost-benefit analysis found that moving the lab would be so expensive -- $133.8 million -- that it would far outweigh the $1.5 million in annual savings from closing it. Indeed, the computer determined it would take more than 100 years to recoup the price of the move. So the Air Force ranked the Rome laboratory among the last installations it would consider closing. 
 But four months later, as politicians across the country lobbied feverishly to save their local bases, the Air Force issued a whole new cost-benefit analysis. It said the relocation would cost less than half as much -- $52.8 million -- with big annual savings of $11.5 million.
Suddenly the cost of closing Rome Lab could be recouped in just four years. Suddenly the Air Force had the numbers to justify shutting Rome. On Feb. 28, a week after the second computer run, the Pentagon made public the list of 119 installations it hoped to close or consolidate this year, including, for the first time, Rome Lab, which develops sophisticated electronic equipment for commanders to use to communicate with their forces.
The search for the true numbers provides a window on the jockeying that goes on as the military labors to substantiate its decisions. It is a process even Government Accounting Office auditors have characterized as elusive.
To some, the Rome Lab case suggests that the base closing system is hardly the open and apolitical process it was intended to be.
Supporters of the lab -- including Raymond Meier, the County Executive of Oneida County, where it lies, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- say they are sure the Air Force altered the numbers between October and February to support a behind-the-scenes political decision to shut Rome.
"They're cooking the books," Mr. D'Amato said. "The decision to move the lab was made. And then they had to invent the numbers to justify the decision."
Indeed, the discrepancy between the October and February numbers was so striking that the special Presidential commission on base closings asked the Air Force in April to do a third calculation. On May 23, the computer produced an estimate radically different from the first two.
 
Small Changes Make A Big Difference
 The Rome case illustrates how subtle changes in estimating basic costs like maintenance, moving or construction can strikingly alter an installation's fate. For example, in October the Air Force estimated the one-time costs to move and reinstall Rome's equipment at $16.8 million. But in February, the Air Force cut this estimate to $7.6 million, making it cheaper to close Rome.
Air Force officials, defending their analyses, say the estimates changed with circumstances. The October numbers were based on the premise that Rome would be merged into one other Air Force base, Hanscom, near Boston. The February estimate is based on splitting Rome between two sites, Hanscom and the Army base in Fort Monmouth, N.J., resulting in far less new construction, Air Force officials say.
"The data used in the Air Force analysis is publicly available, and has been certified and reviewed within the Air Force," said Maj. Gen. Jay D. Blume Jr., special assistant to the chief of staff for base realignment and closure. General Blume said he expected the commission on base closings "to closely scrutinize our data and we are confident the commission will find the recommendation is well supported."
But the May 23 computer run, which followed recent visits by Air Force analysts to Rome, Hanscom and Fort Monmouth, seems to raise more questions than it answers.
For example, the estimated relocation cost went from $133.8 million in October down to $52.8 million in April, and then back up to $79.2 million in the third analysis.
An analyst in the Air Force, who insisted on anonymity, defended the third computer run, calling it "the best possible estimate of what it will really take to do this action." He said it indicated that closing Rome was feasible and that the costs could be recouped in six years.
Senator D'Amato is no more convinced by these numbers, however, than by the previous set from the Air Force. "They are not big enough to admit they were wrong," he said.
Even as savvy a political operator as Mr. D'Amato has only theories on what political strings may have been pulled. He says it may have been California interests, trying to save a large Air Force depot at McClellan Air Force Base, near Sacramento, or Massachusetts interests protecting Hanscom Air Force Base.
After Senator D'Amato and Gov. George E. Pataki railed against the Air Force's numbers at a May 5 hearing, the commission's chairman, former Senator Alan J. Dixon of Illinois, said: "I think we're interested in looking at Rome more carefully." The independent commission is to begin voting in late June on the Pentagon's recommendations.
 
Explanations Draw Criticism
 Senior Air Force officials say that the wide variation between the October and February analyses of Rome, which employs about 1,000 civilians, has a simple explanation. Moving the whole lab to Hanscom, they said, would have required $95 million in new construction. But splitting Rome between two bases would take advantage of existing empty space.
In explaining the specific changes -- like the change in equipment-moving costs from $16.8 million in October to $7.6 million in February to $10.4 million in May -- Air Force officials have hardly been definitive. When first asked by a reporter why the moving costs fell between October and February, a senior Air Force official said that some equipment would be left behind at Rome.
As to why the moving estimates then jumped from $7.6 million in February to $10.4 million in May, the Air Force analyst said the May estimate included buying new equipment to replace what had been left behind.
Such explanations have not satisfied two retired military budget officers, Paul Freund and Bill Harvey, both veterans of previous rounds of closings, who were hired by community officials in Rome to check the Air Force numbers.
For weeks, Mr. Freund has been arguing that the February moving figure, $7.6 million, was too low. He produced an internal Air Force memorandum, dated Dec. 29, 1994, which says that moving just four pieces of heavy equipment from Rome would cost nearly $7 million alone. What about the thousands of other items that must be moved, Mr. Freund asked.
On seeing the Air Force's third moving estimate, $10.4 million, in the May 23 analysis, he said: "At least they're going up. That's a step in the right direction."
The case of Rome Lab is not unique. Since 1988, when the Pentagon first proposed post-cold war base closings, communities have complained loudly that the costs of shutting their bases were underestimated and the savings inflated. In past rounds, the odds that a locality would persuade the commission to reverse the Defense Department were slim, about 1 in 10.
That has not deterred economic development officials in the Rome region. Already stung by the closing of Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome in 1993, a team led by the Oneida County Executive, Mr. Meier, has spent $500,000 to plead its cause. They say the lab has more than $100 million in annual contracts with upstate companies and universities.
The local officials hired a public relations firm. They also hired Mr. Freund, a retired lieutenant colonel who oversaw the Air Force's base-closing budget process in 1993, and Mr. Harvey, a retired colonel who had a similar role in the Army. The two consultants, who have named their Virginia firm the Survivors Group, have been retained by a half-dozen communities facing closings.
Among their questions about Rome is "real property maintenance," an annual budget line that includes replacing broken toilets, repainting offices and other odd repairs. In October, the Air Force estimated it would save $3.2 million in maintenance by moving Rome to Hanscom. But in February and again in May, the Air Force increased the maintenance savings, to $8.1 million.
 
Shifting Estimates Of Needed Space
 Air Force analysts said more would be saved by moving the lab into existing space at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth, where maintenance is already provided. But the consultants say that if the space is empty now at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth, the maintenance costs will increase when it is occupied.
Equally troubling, they said, was the Air Force's assumption about the space needed to relocate the 500,000-square-foot laboratory. In October, the Air Force said it would need 328,000 square feet to move the entire Rome Lab to Hanscom; in February, the combined space it requested at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth fell to 223,000 square feet.
The less space needed at a new site, of course, the stronger the argument for closing Rome.
After the February numbers became public, the consultants said they were skeptical about whether the lab could be squeezed so small. In the May 23 analysis, the Air Force seemed to agree, saying the laboratory would now require 365,000 square feet at Hanscom and Fort Monmouth.
It is difficult to determine if politics played a role in all this. In a report in April, the General Accounting Office chastised the Air Force for providing insufficient documentation "to substantiate the extent of deliberations and analyses leading to decisions to close" bases.
There is no shortage of theories about Rome. Representative Sherwood Boehlert, an Oneida County Republican, says he believes that Rome did not have an "angel" in the Pentagon's inner circle. Senator D'Amato suspects early Presidential politics and theorizes that Rome was selected for closing to save the depot at McClellan, which employs 10,000 civilians, because of California's electoral votes.
The Senator and Representative both said they suspected that Hanscom, in Bedford, Mass., was designated to inherit about 60 percent of the Rome laboratory because the base has a strong relationship with Massachusetts Institute of Technology. For the three decades before she became the Air Force Secretary in 1993, Sheila E. Widnall was a professor of aeronautics at M.I.T., which would benefit if the lab moved nearby.
Rudy de Leon, the Air Force undersecretary, said suggestions of favoritism were ludicrous. "The Secretary is a person of absolute integrity," he said.
Air Force officials say they supported Rome until November, when a Defense Department committee first suggested moving part of the lab to the Fort Monmouth Army base so the Army and Air Force could combine similar functions.
Still, Representative Boehlert said he believed the commission would vote Rome's way next month. "The numbers are with us," he said.

HEADLINE: Orange County: Reluctant Fiscal Test Case

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

 BODY:
Faced with the nuts and bolts of dismantling much of their bankrupt government, the residents of Orange County are finding themselves divided, angry about the options they face, but unable to turn back from a course that many conservatives had encouraged even before the county's financial debacle.
As deadlines approach and tough decisions are made, Orange County's bitter struggle to reverse years of government growth is providing an accidental laboratory of sorts in the new less-is-more civics of the 1990's. 
 Nearly six months after becoming the largest municipal government ever to file for bankruptcy -- after a ruinous $1.7 billion loss on investments in the bond market -- Orange County has reached a critical juncture in its battles for financial survival and direction. The issues are no longer ideology but specifics: which social programs will be eliminated, whether the county will make good on its debts, which library branches will be closed and how much elementary school students will do without.
"We didn't approach this as a multiple-choice exam," said William J. Popejoy, 56, the corporate executive who became the county's unpaid interim chief executive in February. "At this point, what we have here isn't a dogma or a political problem. We have a financial problem. And what we need is to fix it. The longer we wait to fix it, the more expensive it is going to get. Nobody likes that. They like it less and less all the time."
Mr. Popejoy has restructured the budget, eliminating 41 percent of the county's operating costs. He has initiated the sale of nearly $100 million in assets, from office buildings to landfills. About 10 percent of the county's 15,000 employees have lost their jobs.
He has also pushed for a half-cent increase in the sales tax, to 8.25 percent, a measure that has sharply increased the anger in this rigidly anti-tax area.
The county's lawyers said they were close to reaching an agreement with investors in $975 million of the county's bonds to wait an extra year for repayment and to accept a lower interest rate.
Mr. Popejoy has insisted that the measures, while painful, are merely a financial tourniquet to rescue a county bankrupted by reckless investments.
Robert L. Citron, the former Treasurer, pleaded guilty last month to six felony charges of misappropriating funds and misleading investors, but most of those crimes appear to have been committed in a desperate effort to prop up his collapsing house of cards. Mr. Citron's former deputy, Matthew Raabe, was recently indicted on six counts of similar charges and is free on a $200,000 bond.
Residents will vote on the proposed tax on June 27. It will help determine whether the county will be able to construct a long-term plan for repaying its bondholders. Thus, it will have a large impact on when the county can emerge from bankruptcy and on what terms.
But no matter how the vote goes, Mr. Popejoy said in an interview, he has begun laying plans for a more profound transformation of the county government, which could affect it far longer than a default on its bonds. Perhaps the most important change will be satisfying the demands of residents who distrust government, yet expect a minimum of services to be delivered efficiently.
"People here regard government as a vending machine," said Frank Benest, the city manager of Brea, an upper-middle-class area at the northern edge of the county. "They put in a quarter and they still want a dollar's worth of services."
Mr. Popejoy said one of the first lessons he learned was that, in effect, there is not one county budget but three: separate portions financed by the Federal Government, by the state, and by the county.
Of the county's total $1.6 billion annual budget, he found, only $463 million was paid for with the county's own revenue -- and all the cuts had to come from that sliver. He has already sliced off $180 million. And that is not enough.
There are two reasons for the sharp reductions. By suffering the huge losses on its investment fund, the county also lost $160 million in interest that it expected to take in as revenues. And the county is being forced to cut operating costs in the hopes of putting away enough money to repay its bondholders.
What is more, Mr. Popejoy said, he also found that some of the county-financed portion of the budget had to be spent to entitle the county to substantially greater matching sums from the state and Federal governments. For instance, a drug rehabilitation and education program requires the county to put up $600,000 to get $20 million in Federal money. Mr. Popejoy said he was not cutting the program now.
Mr. Popejoy also faced a disappointment when it came to selling county assets, a course strongly encouraged by conservatives and libertarians. For instance, when he looked into selling the county's John Wayne Airport he said he had discovered that the unprecedented sale -- no public airport has ever been sold to the private investors in the United States -- would require changes in Federal law.
Little by little, the cutbacks are starting to be felt. The county had to abandon most of its water testing along its 42 miles of coastline for fecal coliform bacteria. Some defendants in county courts who cannot pay fines are now being ordered to perform maintenance duties at the courthouse.
Schoolpower, a parent-run foundation that supplements classrooms with educational materials, has started a drive to help fill a $820,000 cut in the school budget. Without private money, programs like physical education at elementary schools, marching bands and continuing education for teachers could be slashed or dropped.
"I feel defeated," said Lisa Montague Hamer, the mother of a kindergarten-aged child, as she read in a school flier that in addition to being asked for $200 by Schoolpower she would now have to pay $220 a year for previously free bus service.
Mr. Popejoy said: "There will be muscle and bone cut from the county's services. We're probably going to be sued."
That fact underscores one of the most telling responses of residents in this conservative, Republican county.
Mr. Benest, the city manager of Brea, said he worried that hastily slashed budgets were destroying the county's enviable standard of living and could drive away business.
But Robert Poole, president of the conservative Reason Foundation, argued that, if anything, county officials had not gone far enough in handing over basic services to the private sector.
While these two fiscal warriors are world's apart in their fiscal views, they agree on how residents have responded to precisely the sort of experiment in restructuring government that many Republicans in Congress are advocating for the country at large.
"People aren't willing to take any responsibility," Mr. Benest said. "This a tremendous era of selfishness. People are libertarian in philosophy here, but when it comes down to their service they want to keep it."
Mr. Poole was blunter. "There's a certain amount of hypocrisy out there," he said. "It's true: People don't want to take responsibility for doing the things they depend on government for now."
The state has played a large role in the recovery. On one hand, some state officials have threatened a takeover of the county if it defaults on its bonds; such a default, it is feared, could hurt all municipal borrowers in California.
But the state has also provided crucial aid by accelerating a variety of payments to the county and easing some regulations. A legislative package recently passed in Sacramento includes $360 million for waste-management programs, $660 million from motor vehicle fees and $160 million in advance payments on various tax programs.
That assistance is one essential element of Mr. Popejoy's financial rescue; the second part is the sales tax increase, which would raise about $160 million a year and provide collateral for immediate borrowings. Bruce Bennett, the county's bankruptcy lawyer, said that if the tax was passed -- polls show that voters are closely divided -- and everything else proceeded well, the county could emerge from bankruptcy in about a year at the earliest.
One of the most popular, if misunderstood, aspects of Mr. Popejoy's recovery strategy is his effort to hand off to cities many services previously offered by the county.
This is a popular measure in Congress as well. The premise is that grass-roots social programs should be shaped and administered by government agencies that are closer to those receiving the services. But that still leaves a problem that few officials have so far had the stomach to address here.
"The question is, Will there be revenues to pay for those services?" Mr. Benest said. "We are in no position to accept those services without a discussion about money. And so far nobody has talked about money."
Mr. Popejoy said he nevertheless planned to merge several county government departments to save money, push services like the issuing of building permits to the cities and make fundamental changes in how the county's supervisors work.
Currently, there are five elected supervisors with overlapping responsibilities. Mr. Popejoy said he wanted to model the system on a corporation. The board would be expanded to seven or nine supervisors, but they would be paid less and would work part-time. And they would operate like corporate directors; they would set policy and hire a chief executive to enforce it.
The supervisors, he said, should get just a telephone and a secretary, rather than suites of offices, and they would be paid $30,000 to $40,000 a year, down from $82,056 now.
"The people don't know what it is going to feel like yet," said John H. Sawyer, general manager of the Orange County Employees Association. "They haven't felt the bankruptcy. They read about it in the paper. But pretty soon this is going to start trickling down. People aren't going to like it."
But Mr. Poole of the Reason Foundation is adamant that the people will prefer a government that is less intrusive and makes people are more self-reliant.
Mr. Benest is less sure.
"If they privatize things like environmental protection to some engineering conglomerate, who is going to look after the public interest?" Mr. Benest asked. "You can't privatize that.
"That's why I say, ultimately, some of this is misleading. Government cannot really function without a sense of community, and we've lost that. What does that say?"

Stocks Continue Rally; Some Indexes Set Records
 The stock market continued to climb in the wake of its huge rally on Wednesday, providing relief to traders who feared the market might plateau or drop. 
 The Dow industrials rose 7.61 points, to a record 4,472.75, rebounding from a morning fall of more than 27 points. The broader S.& P. 500 index rose 0.09 point, to 533.49, also a record. The dollar rose to 84.65 yen, but fell to 1.4055 marks. [Page D6.]
 
Auto Sales Fall 2.8%
 Car and truck sales for May fell 2.8 percent. The results were better than expected, but virtually insured that 1995 sales would lag behind those of 1994. [D3.]
 
Retail Sales Encouraging
 The nation's big retailers reported encouraging sales gains in May, helped by milder weather and some bigger tax refunds. But most retail executives and analysts agreed that the figures did not point to a genuine recovery in consumer spending. [D2.]
 A major reason for the weakness in consumer spending this spring was the sharp rise in payments by homeowners and affluent taxpayers to cover high 1994 tax obligations, two Wall Street economists have found. [D2.]
 
Further Signs of a Slowdown
 The National Association of Purchasing Management index showed greater weakness in manufacturing than had been expected. Also, the Government reported that personal income and spending each rose just 0.3 percent in April, further indications of a slowdown, since consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. [D6.]
 
America Online to Buy Web Site
 America Online plans to create a separate business, offering Internet access to computer users. To get it off to a quick start, the company agreed to pay $11 million for Global Network Navigator. [D6.]
 
Ex-Honda Executives Convicted
 Two former executives of American Honda were found guilty of accepting more than $15 million in kickbacks from dealers. [D3.]
 
Sony in Deal With Film Executive
 Stanley Jaffe, the former president of Paramount Communications, has struck a deal with Sony Pictures in which the studio would invest $75 million in his independent production company. [D4.]
 
Study Sees Obstacle for Unions
 Helping to explain the nationwide decline in union membership, a survey showed that many workers were often too cowed by management opposition to vote in favor of a union at their workplace. [D16.]
 
Recall Does Not Worry Smokers
 Reports of the contamination of eight billion Philip Morris cigarettes heaped more bad publicity on the tobacco industry, but smokers seem to have taken the news without panicking. [A18.]
 
Ads Spoof Martha Stewart
 How do you promote a magazine meant to embody the life style of a woman who has been called everything from "the diva of domesticity" to "a control-freakish middlebrow taste maker." A new campaign for Martha Stewart Living does it by spoofing everyone's perceptions of Ms. Stewart. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]
 
Strike Aids Brazilian President
 A monthlong strike by Brazilian oil workers is crumbling, providing political gains for President Fernando Henrique Cardoso. [D5.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Regulators Back Plan to Freeze Nynex Rates

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
New York State's top utility regulators approved a sweeping plan yesterday that would freeze the telephone rates of 7.4 million New Yorkers for up to seven years and substantially deregulate the Nynex Corporation.
Nynex has until July 19 to accept or reject the Public Service Commission's plan, which would allow the company to earn unregulated profits in return for a slight reduction and subsequent freeze in local phone rates. Nynex would also have to improve its poor reputation for customer service to avoid onerous financial penalties. 
 The company has operated under rate-of-return regulation -- in which the commission strictly governed its profits -- for most of the period since it was created in the 1984 breakup of the Bell System.
"This is a major breakthrough for this company and the state," Ivan G. Seidenberg, the chairman and chief executive of Nynex, said. "But it's not a big thing if it's not right."
Although Nynex initiated the plan two years ago, Mr. Seidenberg said the company would withhold judgment on yesterday's proposal until it had a chance to study the details, which the commission does not plan to disclose until June 15. Several industry executives, however, said yesterday that they expected the company to accept it.
"This is a very good deal for Nynex," said Michael Morrissey, the vice president for government affairs at the AT&T Corporation.
If Nynex accepts the plan, New York would vault to the forefront of the 20 states that have deregulated their monopoly local telephone markets in an effort to spur competition and keep rates down. The plan would have an enormous impact on Nynex, which is laboring to turn itself from a regional utility serving New York and New England into a global communications conglomerate.
Massachusetts also recently abandoned its rate-of-return regulation of Nynex in favor of a "price cap" plan similar to the one approved yesterday by New York's public service commission. As a result, close to 95 percent of Nynex's telephone revenue would now be governed by price-cap regulation.
Under such regulation, Nynex would be able to keep the extra profits it generates by running its operations more efficiently. But it would no longer have the cushion of steadily increasing phone rates. The company's stock rose 25 cents yesterday, to $41.875, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"This is a truly revolutionary step," said Harold A. Jerry Jr., the chairman of the Public Service Commission, who brokered the plan in a month of intense negotiations with the other four commissioners. Mr. Jerry said the proposal would be the most significant change in New York's telecommunications regulation in his 22 years on the commission.
The new plan will not add up to much in savings for residential customers -- at least initially. The only local rate Nynex would immediately cut is the 50 cents it now charges customers for touch-tone, or push button, service. Eliminating that charge would reduce Nynex's average monthly residential bill by 1.7 percent, to $33.
Over time, however, consumers would benefit as inflation enhanced the value of the rates, which would stay at current levels. Nynex estimates that its residential and business customers would have cumulative savings of $1 billion in the first five years of the seven-year plan.
Customers would also pay lower rates for short-haul long-distance calls -- from Manhattan to New Rochelle, N.Y., for example. Nynex said yesterday that it could not quantify what an average customer might save, but that the company would forgo $191.3 million in toll revenue over five years.
Yesterday's plan is substantially similar to the "incentive regulation" proposal that the commission staff and Nynex jointly submitted last fall. But the commission has stiffened the financial penalties that Nynex would face if it fails to improve its customer service.
"Nynex's service, particularly in Brooklyn and Queens, has been terrible for the last few years, and everybody knows it," Mr. Jerry said. "Nynex's service has just got to improve."
He said that if Nynex did not bolster its service from last year -- when it fell short of the commission's standards in the frequency of its breakdowns and missed-repair appointments -- the company would have to pay $77 million in penalties.
Mr. Seidenberg said Nynex's service record had already improved somewhat. The number of the company's service interruptions and missed-repair calls each declined 14 percent in the first three months of this year, compared with the corresponding period last year.
The commission also said that Nynex must reduce the access fees it charges long-distance carriers for switching calls from their networks to its local customers. AT&T, MCI, and Sprint contend that these charges hamper them from competing for Nynex's local and toll customers.
But Mr. Morrissey said the reduction in access fees was not sufficient to enable AT&T or other long-distance carriers to compete with Nynex. "If we can't make money in this market, it's an open question whether we'll want to participate in it," he said.
Long-distance carriers were not the only groups that criticized the plan. Several consumer advocates chastised the commission for not reducing local residential phone rates enough.
"The P.S.C. was duped into believing that it had to give Nynex unlimited profits and high rates in exchange for the possibility of reasonable service," said Robert Ceisler, the executive director of the Citizens Utility Board. "The result will be high telephone rates for the vast majority of New York residents for years to come."
If the commission is dissatisfied with Nynex's performance under the new regulations, it can pull the plug. The commission's staff and Nynex had proposed reviewing the company's progress after the fifth year of the plan's seven-year cycle. But in yesterday's ruling, the commission added a second checkpoint in the third year.

HEADLINE: Bond Lawyer Admits Filing No Tax Forms

 BODY:
A bond lawyer who used to be a major fund-raiser for former Mayor David N. Dinkins pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to failing to file tax returns for three years, despite earning more than $600,000 in those years, Federal prosecutors said.
The lawyer, Joseph N. Barnes, 44, admitted in court that he never filed Federal tax returns for 1987, 1988 and 1991. He faces a year in prison and $300,000 in fines. 
 Mr. Barnes, a longtime supporter of Mr. Dinkins, worked on Mr. Dinkins's campaign finance committees in the 1985 race for Borough President of Manhattan and in the 1989 campaign for Mayor. He was a member of the screening panel that selected heads of economic development agencies when Mr. Dinkins took office in 1990.

HEADLINE: Purchasing Survey Indicates Sharper Economic Slowdown

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
A closely watched industry survey showed greater weakness in manufacturing than had been expected today, suggesting that the economic slowdown has been sharper than previously suspected.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index of manufacturing activity fell to 46.1 last month from 52.0 in April -- the first time in 21 months it dropped under the critical level of 50 that marks the dividing point between growth and contraction. 
 The report buttressed signs of weakness that appeared in April, as the Commerce Department today reported the sharpest fall in factory orders in nine months and a sharp slowdown in consumer incomes and spending.
As consumers have cut back on spending, inventories have risen. As a result, factories have slowed production and scaled back operations.
"Clearly the economy is losing momentum more rapidly than was anticipated," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. "Consumers have cut back on their purchases of big-ticket items like new cars, and that is one reason manufacturers are cutting back; they will in turn cut jobs."
The Commerce Department report on personal incomes and spending during April noted that manufacturing payrolls fell in April at a rate of $7.4 billion a year, more than twice the $3.6 billion rate of decline in March.
That was partly because workers in the auto industry received large bonus payments in February and March but none in April, reflecting the industry's problem with weaker sales.
Overall incomes rose just three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $6.01 trillion in April, the smallest rise since November, when they were flat, following a revised increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in March.
Spending also gained three-tenths of 1 percent, to $4.82 trillion, in April -- less than half the big revised rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in March. Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of national economic activity, which means that as spending slows so does the economy.
"The trend is pretty well set now: slower economic growth along with weaker income growth and cutbacks by producers," Mr. Sohn said.
Tepid business activity was evident at factory gates in April, as new orders fell 1.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $293.96 billion, after declines of four-tenths of 1 percent in March and three-tenths of 1 percent in February.
Not since the March-May period of 1993 had orders dropped for three consecutive months. In addition, shipments of finished products and order backlogs also weakened from March.
Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said companies "fundamentally overpredicted" the strength of consumer demand this year and were paying the price.
"The result is that business is facing a glut of unsold goods while consumers have been forced to scale back purchases," Mr. Richards said. "Production will have to be curtailed until surplus stocks are sold off."
The purchasing managers said their index of manufacturing activity plunged to its lowest in four years, since it was at 44.5 in May 1991 shortly after the last recession ended.
At every stage -- from new orders to production to backlogs, inventories and employment -- activity continued to weaken last month from earlier in the year, the purchasing managers reported.
Mr. Sohn of Norwest speculated that Federal Reserve policy makers might be forced to reverse course after seven interest-rate rises and possibly cut rates by August to try to stimulate economic activity and avert a recession.

HEADLINE: Weak Consumer Spending Is Linked to Bigger Tax Bite

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
One of the major reasons for the weakness in consumer spending this spring was the sharp rise in payments among many homeowners and affluent taxpayers to cover their unexpectedly high 1994 income tax obligations, two separate reports by Wall Street economists have found.
"Consumers got hit with a whopping tax bill in April," Joseph Liro, an economist at S. G. Warburg & Company, wrote in a research report that was released yesterday. 
 Another economist, David J. Greenlaw at Morgan Stanley, came to similar conclusions. After analyzing Treasury Department reports, Mr. Greenlaw, said: "Individuals wrote $20 billion more in checks this year than last to settle their obligations with the I.R.S. That's a 30 percent increase."
Indeed, spending growth slowed sharply in April, when most of those who owe taxes file their returns, a report from the Commerce Department showed yesterday. The agency reported that spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to $4.82 trillion, compared with a revised March gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Many economists have cited the slow pace at which the Internal Revenue Service issued tax refunds this year as a chief culprit for weak consumer spending.
Mr. Greenlaw disputed this view, saying that at the worst point the value of refund checks issued was $6 billion behind and in mid-April began to surge ahead. And refunds, which are running slightly higher than last year, now appear to be contributing to a modest improvement in the outlook for consumer spending.
"In the last few weeks there has been an acceleration in refunds," Mr. Greenlaw said. "Right now refunds are $9 billion above last year's pace."
The average refund check this year is $1,128, up from $1,037 in 1994, the I.R.S. said. I.R.S. officials said they had not computed the average amount of checks submitted with tax returns.
The reason so much more money was owed the I.R.S. this year appears to be a result of two factors that date to 1993. The first was the 1993 tax rate increase for the highest-income Americans and the other was the sharp drop in mortgage interest rates, which prompted many people to refinance their homes in late 1993.
Mr. Greenlaw said Government data showed that "mortgage payments fell to 5.7 percent of disposal personal income in 1994, down from a peak of 7 percent" in the early 1990's.
Reduced mortgage interest payments mean smaller deductions for taxpayers who itemize. Many homeowners who did not adjust their income tax withholding ended 1994 owing money to the I.R.S., Mr. Greenlaw said.
The 1993 tax rate increase was retroactive to the first of that year. In response to criticism that a retroactive rate increase was unfair, those affected were allowed to delay part of the payment on the retroactive increase until this spring.
Evidence that wealthy taxpayers also wrote bigger-than-usual checks to the I.R.S. is found in data on savings rates, according to Mr. Liro of S. G. Warburg. He noted that wealthy individuals tended to withdraw savings to cover large tax payments.
"The savings rate plunged from 5.2 percent in March to 4.3 percent in April," Mr. Liro wrote in his research report. He attributed the decline primarily to withdrawals to cover April tax payments.

HEADLINE: Rowland Signs Budget With Tax Cut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 1

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland today signed a two-year budget that cuts taxes by $200 million and features what he called the smallest increase in state spending in 30 years.
The budget represents a victory for Mr. Rowland, the state's first Republican Governor in two decades, who campaigned last year on a pledge to phase out the state income tax and shrink state government. While the tax and spending cuts fall short of his campaign oratory, Mr. Rowland can point to them as the best that could be expected when faced with the political reality of a Democrat-controlled State House of Representatives. 
 Still, some Democrats charged that the $20 billion budget, which runs from July 1 through June 30, 1997, relied on gimmicks, like the sale of the state lottery and postponing debt payments, that do little to control state spending.
And it remains to be seen whether the income tax cut, which will amount to about $235 for a typical joint return in 1997, will help turn around the sagging Connecticut economy, as Mr. Rowland has promised.
Yet, the budget won impressive bipartisan support, and five prominent Democratic House members joined Mr. Rowland this afternoon at the signing ceremony.
"We came together and decided we should govern and not have partisan battles," Mr. Rowland said. "And we're in the process of turning this aircraft carrier around.
"The tax cuts will go a long way toward bringing back the confidence in the state that we want not only among our taxpayers, but our businesses also," he said.
According to the Office of Fiscal Analysis, a nonpartisan legislative agency, the appropriation for next year's budget is $9.9 billion and then $10.1 billion for the following year, up from estimated expenditures of $9.6 billion in this year's budget.
Using these figures, the agency estimated that spending would increase 2.57 percent next year and 2.64 percent the following year, the smallest increases in state spending in at least 30 years. But critics said that these figures and the balanced budget in general were a product of smoke and mirrors. In a scathing editorial this morning, The Hartford Courant called the budget "as fragile as a house of cards and as fraudulent as a three-dollar bill."
And at a news conference this afternoon, State Senator George Jepsen, a Democrat, said that the budget was rife with "gimmickry" and that it had the same growth in spending as the previous four years under Lowell P. Weicker Jr., if one did not include the restructuring of debt payments.
Mr. Jepsen said that expenditures were held down partly by stringing out over the next four years a debt payment of $328 million due next year, costing the state an additional $28 million in interest.
He also said that the $200 million needed for the tax cut was only made available through a last-minute proposal to make Connecticut the first state in the nation to sell an interest in its lottery to a private company. The idea is still being developed and must be acted on by the State Legislature in January before bids can be solicited.
"It seems absolutely incredible to me to project a $200 million tax cut based on something we haven't even studied," Mr. Jepsen said. "Why not make it $400 million?"
There is little question, however, that the budget represents a shift in how the state spends its money.
The budget estimates, for example, that the amount devoted to the welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, will be reduced from $369 million this year to $314 million next year and $316 million in the second year. The decrease comes largely from a reduction in monthly benefits from $581 to as low as $500 for a family of three.
And the state also expects savings of $17 million over two years from closing two institutions for the mentally ill.
Republicans have admitted that the cuts were not as deep as they would have liked and that compromises had to be made to win support in the House. Many of Mr. Rowland's most dramatic proposals in his original budget -- bundling of funding for social service programs into block grants and the consolidation of 29 state agencies to 12 -- largely fell by the wayside.
The $200 million tax cut is about one-fourth of what Mr. Rowland had proposed in the campaign, and about $300 million less than what he had called for in his budget address in February.
But Republicans called the tax cut a substantial achievement, one that many Democrats in February would have said was impossible.
Only last week, it had seemed that debate over the tax cut could jeopardize the entire budget.
Renewing the dispute over the income tax, which was adopted in 1991, Mr. Rowland had proposed cuts in the tax through the year 2000. Democrats balked at the idea of income tax cuts beyond the proposed budget and prepared for a fight that could have undermined the entire budget package.
But Mr. Rowland surprised many by withdrawing the income tax cuts for 1998, 1999 and 2000, although he said he would seek such reductions in the future.
With that obstacle out of the way, the Senate passed the budget late Wednesday night by a 21-to-15 vote, with the support of two Democrats.
The House had approved the budget early Saturday morning, in a 143-to-6 vote for the spending plan and a 126-to-21 vote for the revenue package.

HEADLINE: Russia to Activate Role in NATO Partnership

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 1

 BODY:
After nearly six months of hesitation and mixed signals, Russia has agreed to activate its membership in the program NATO calls Partnership for Peace, but Russian officials warned that NATO expansion would put an end to Moscow's participation.
Russian Defense Ministry officials said President Boris N. Yeltsin remained strictly opposed to NATO expansion eastward to Russia's borders. If and when such expansion occurs, the officials say -- a process that will take at least four or five years -- Russia will "immediately suspend" its participation in Partnership for Peace, a sort of associated status in NATO that can lead to full membership down the road. 
 Washington has been explicit in saying that NATO will expand and that Russia will have no veto over that expansion. But American and NATO officials also emphasize to Moscow that the process will be complicated and careful -- that new members must qualify on a long list of requirements from a civilian defense minister to ammunition compatibility, and that a new member must be ratified unanimously by all 16 current members and their parliaments.
So even Russia's warning that its membership will be suspended with expansion is regarded as a way to make membership digestible to Russian nationalist feeling. Four or five years is a long time in Russian politics, and NATO countries, including the United States, are in no hurry to create a domestic political crisis for Mr. Yeltsin, already weakened by the Chechnya situation and the unevenness of Russian economic reform, by pushing expansion now.
No one wants NATO to be an issue in Russian parliamentary elections in December, or in presidential elections scheduled for June 1996.
Military officials also think, according to Pavel Y. Felgengauer, the military expert of Sevodnya newspaper, that a firm Russian "no" to expansion will help delay it, and may even persuade nations like Greece, Portugal and Spain -- and perhaps others, like France -- to vote against expansion, which will be expensive. There is no point in Moscow's not talking tough right up until the end, these officials argue.
Mr. Yeltsin's foreign-policy adviser, Dmitri Ryurikov, said, "Russia strongly desires a general, all-European security system in which Russia and other countries have equal rights." That means an altered Organization for Cooperation and Security in Europe.
Widening NATO "will simply divide Europe again," he said, and isolate Russia.
When Mr. Yeltsin sent relations into the freezer in December and refused to allow Russia to activate its NATO partnership, Moscow thought expansion was imminent, officials say. Asked what Russia gained from the delay, since no document was renegotiated, Mr. Ryurikov said that "we now have a much better and deeper understanding" of NATO enlargement.
But Moscow also forced the West to listen a little more closely, a Western diplomat said, and "to stop taking Russia too much for granted."

HEADLINE: Dallas Townsend, 76, CBS Radio News Anchor

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dallas S. Townsend Jr., who wrote and anchored the morning CBS radio news roundup for 25 years, died yesterday at Montclair Community Hospital in New Jersey. A former resident of Montclair, he was 76 and lived in Sarasota, Fla., after retiring in 1985.
The cause was complications from injuries from a fall last week, a spokeswoman for the CBS Radio Division said. Mr. Townsend had gone to New Jersey on a family visit. 
 He presided at "CBS World News Roundup," which was broadcast on radio nationally, from 1956 to 1961 and again from 1963 to 1982, with two years out to anchor its evening counterpart, "The World Tonight."
In his 44 years with the network, he covered all the Democratic and Republican conventions from 1948 until 1984. He reported on the Japanese peace conference of 1951 and the start of the Vietnam peace talks in Paris in 1968.
His rich, distinctive voice informed millions of Americans about two Mercury space flights, four Gemini missions and two Apollo launchings. In addition, he covered atomic tests in Nevada in the early 1950's, and the inaugurations of Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower and John F. Kennedy.
Born in Manhattan, he grew up in New Jersey. His father was an assistant Attorney General in the Eisenhower Administration.
He graduated from Princeton University in 1940 and from the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University the following year. He briefly worked as a news editor at WQXR in New York before joining CBS in 1941.
He spent World War II in the Army, assigned to signal and communications centers in New Guinea, the Philippines and Japan, and became a captain. He helped to set up advance signal centers in Yokohama and Tokyo immediately after the Japanese surrender.
Returning to CBS, he worked successively as a news editor, director of special events and manager of television news broadcasts. In 1954, he was named a news correspondent. From 1982 until his retirement, he anchored several hourly news broadcasts.
He received an Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Award in Broadcast Journalism, a Peabody Award and an Armstrong Radio Pioneer Award for his work on the morning roundup, the longest running radio newscast in the country.
"For 25 years, the voice of Dallas Townsend has meant intelligent, incisive reporting and editing on CBS's enduring and distinguished 'World News Roundup,' " the duPont-Columbia jury said in 1983. "No other newsman in our day has had a broader acquaintance with news nor communicated it with more economy and precision."
Mr. Townsend is survived by his wife of 52 years, Lois Bradley Townsend; three daughters, Katherine Hamlin of Greenbelt, Md., Patricia West of Miami and Nancy Wilson of Upper Montclair; a son, Douglas, of Baltimore; a sister, Elizabeth T. McFadden of Bethesda, Md.; two brothers, Louis, of Washington, and Robert, of Toms River, N.J., and 10 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Steven R. Fenster, 52, an Expert In Corporate Restructuring, Dies

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Steven R. Fenster, a longtime investment banker and a visiting professor at the Harvard Business School, died yesterday at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. He was 52 and had lived in Cambridge, Mass., since 1991.
The cause was pancreatic cancer, his wife, Kerin, said. 
 Mr. Fenster, one of Wall Street's top experts in corporate restructuring, counted as clients a variety of the United States' leading corporations, including Pan Am, Digital Equipment, International Harvester and the Chase Manhattan Bank.
As a limited partner in the Blackstone Group in recent years, he worked on Federated Department Stores' takeover of R. H. Macy & Company. And in recent weeks, he had served as a consultant to the real estate investment trust that holds the mortgage on Rockefeller Center.
He was a native of Belle Harbor, Queens, and was a summa cum laude graduate of Harvard College and a Baker Scholar at the Harvard Business School. He also had a Fulbright Fellowship in the Netherlands, where he studied the relation between econometrics and economic policy for a year. After business school, he worked for three years as one of the "whiz kids" of Secretary Robert S. McNamara in the Defense Department before heading for Wall Street and Lehman Brothers in 1969.
At Lehman Brothers, he served as head of the financial restructuring and merger and acquisition groups. He was frequently consulted both by other investment bankers and by clients.
After Lehman Brothers was acquired by the American Express Company in 1984, he taught briefly at the Harvard Business School, worked as a consultant to the chairman and vice chairman at the Chase Manhattan Corporation, and then served for four years as a managing director at Dillon, Read & Company.
In 1991, when Mr. Fenster learned of his cancer, colleagues and friends established an endowed chair in his name at the Harvard Business School. Mr. Fenster then decided to teach there, and set up a course in corporate restructuring. He wrote many of the case studies, including cases he had worked on as an investment banker.
He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and a fund-raiser for Harvard, and served for many years as a director of American Management Systems Inc., Bloomberg L.P. and Sealy Inc.
Charles Rossotti, chairman of American Management Systems, who first met Mr. Fenster when they worked together at the Defense Department, said that when he and others started his company in 1970, they so valued Mr. Fenster's advice that they made him a special adviser to the board and brought him to meetings even though he was still very junior at Lehman.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Fenster is survived by a daughter, Emily, and a son, Edward, all of Cambridge, as well as his mother, Esther Hausman Fenster of Belle Harbor, and his sister, Ruth Block of Baldwin Harbor, L.I.

HEADLINE: Service Adds Another Portal To the Internet

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
America Online Inc., the country's fastest-growing consumer on-line information service, said yesterday that it would create a separate business to offer Internet access to computer users.
To get the new Internet business off to a quick start, the company agreed to pay $11 million for Global Network Navigator, one of the most popular information sites on the Internet's World Wide Web. 
 America Online already offers Internet access as one part of the on-line services it offers to an estimated 2.5 million subscribers. But to reach a broader audience of computer users who may not be interested in hobby forums, chat groups and other of its own information services, America Online and its rivals are creating separate Internet access businesses.
"It's a little bit like why General Motors makes pickup trucks as well as Chevys, or why American Express offers gold cards as well as Optima cards," said Gary Arlen, president of Arlen Research of Bethesda, Md. "It gets them into different wallets."
America Online said yesterday that it would acquire Global Network Navigator from O'Reilly & Associates Inc. of Sebastopol, Calif., a publisher of technical books, for $9 million in stock and $2 million in cash. G.N.N. is in effect an electronic publishing company, read by thousands of subscribers each month.
America Online also said it had purchased rights to Webcrawler, a popular search tool that makes it easier to find information on the World Wide Web, the most popular service on the Internet.
The announcements are the latest confirmation of a blurring line between consumer networks and Internet service providers, who are racing to create friendlier systems to attract the consumer market.
"All roads are leading to the same place," said Steve Harmon, a media analyst with Paul Kagen Associates of Carmel, Calif. Mr. Harmon said that by making five major acquisitions in the last six months, America Online appeared to believe that it was easier to buy access into the Internet than to risk developing services and technologies on its own.
America Online's main rivals, Compuserve Inc. and the Prodigy Services Company, disclosed their separate Internet service plans last year. But America Online, which has grown rapidly through aggressive marketing and by offering customers easy access to the on-line world, appears to have found a kindred spirit in the Internet world in the form of Global Network Navigator.
G.N.N. was the first major electronic publishing site on the Internet's World Wide Web, offering more than a dozen "magazines," or subject areas, ranging from personal finance information to offbeat travel news. It organizes and catalogues the information for its readers in an easily navigated system.
"G.N.N. is one of the strongest searching and directory companies in the world of the Web," said Adam Schoenfeld, vice president of Jupiter Communications Inc. of New York. He noted that G.N.N. recorded more than 2 million "hits," or requests for information, from Web users in December. G.N.N. says it has more than 400,000 regular viewers, of whom 180,000 are registered electronic subscribers.
There is currently no extra charge to read information published on the G.N.N. site, and the electronic publications are supported by on-line advertising. Lisa Gansky, who will become vice president and general manager of G.N.N. programming for America Online if the deal goes through, said the site would at least initially remain free and open to all Internet users.
