HEADLINE: Dow Up 7.61 A Day After Huge Rally

 BODY:
A day after one of the biggest rallies in its history, the stock market closed up only slightly yesterday, a relief to traders who feared the market might reach a plateau or drop.
Markets often decline the day after a big surge, as potential buyers become more hesitant with higher stock prices. "But today wasn't bad by any stretch of the imagination," said Todd Clark, managing director for equity trading at Rodman & Renshaw. 
 After falling more than 27 points, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.61 points, to a record 4,472.75, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.09 point, to 533.49, also a record.
The Nasdaq composite index, rich in the technology stocks that dropped sharply last week, continued to recover yesterday. The Nasdaq rose 4.24 points, to 868.82, but was still short of the 879.64 record posted on May 23.
The Dow rose 86.46 points on Wednesday, the biggest one-day point gain in more than three years and, at 1.97 percent, the biggest percentage gain in a year.
As with Wednesday's trading, there seemed to be no particular catalyst for the market's moves. But a report of weaker-than-expected manufacturing activity by the National Association of Purchasing Management, a trade group, continued to reinforce Wall Street's belief in a "soft landing" for the economy. In such a situation, corporate profits rise but inflation remains tame.
And yesterday's Commerce Department report on a drop in factory orders in April seemed to give support to the soft-landing theory.
Traders are certain to watch the May employment data due out this morning, as well as the April index of leading economic indicators, a combination of several indicators said to predict the future course of the economy.
Some traders and analysts contend that three months of declining indicators correlate as much as 90 percent of the time with the onset of a recession. The previous two months have been declines.
Meanwhile, the dollar rose to 84.65 Japanese yen, from 84.54 yen on Wednesday, and fell to 1.4055 German marks from 1.4157.
The value of the dollar is important because as the stock market rally continues, traders wonder whether American investors will continue to pour record amounts of money into mutual funds, which has helped lift stock prices. If the dollar rises, an influx of foreign investors would help insure that the rally continues.
But the declining value of the dollar has so far penalized foreigners when they seek to convert dollar gains back to their native currencies. The Dow has risen 16.65 percent in dollar terms so far this year, but only 5.79 percent in marks and has fallen 0.90 percent in yen.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.29 point, to 286.73, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks, 1,275 to 943. Big Board volume totaled 345.9 million shares, down from Wednesday's 366.2 million shares. The American Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.20 points, to 490.90.
Among advancing stocks was Texas Instruments, an electronics and semiconductor company, which rose 5 3/8, to 121, after an analyst at Soundview Financial raised his 1995 earnings estimate to $11.15 a share from $11. Advanced Semiconductor rose 3 1/4, to 21 7/8, after falling from a 52-week high of 26 1/8 last Tuesday.
Among declining stocks was Cordis, a biotechnology company, which fell 6 1/4, to 62 3/4, after an analyst with Cowen & Company cut his assessment of the company from a "strong buy" to a "buy."
Celestial Seasonings, a tea company, dropped 1 3/8, to 16 1/4, after the company's management said on Wednesday that it expected third-quarter earnings to be below expectations.
The most active stock, at 8.5 million shares, was Ford Motor, which rose 3/4, to 30, after General Motors and Chrysler reported a decline in May auto sales. Ford reports its sales on Monday.

HEADLINE: Big U.S. Retailers Say May Was a 'Pretty Good Month'

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The nation's big retailers reported yesterday that they had encouraging sales gains in May, helped by milder weather and shoppers with bigger tax refunds in their pockets than they had a year ago.
But most retail executives and analysts agreed that despite some signs of strength, the monthly figures did not point to a genuine recovery in consumer spending. 
 "It was a pretty good month for the industry as a whole," said Karen M. Hoguet, a senior vice president and treasurer of Federated Department Stores Inc., whose 450 stores include the Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains. "But we don't see any major pickup in consumer spending."
Store sales were propped up by better weather in May than for the corresponding month a year ago, when unseasonable cold kept shoppers at home. Weather changes, analysts say, can account for more than half the month-to-month variations in store traffic.
The monthly retail sales may also have benefited from the Government's having paid an unusually high volume of tax refunds in May, later than in most years. The Internal Revenue Service was slow in making repayments to taxpayers this year, and the logjam broke in May, according to David Kelly, an economist for Lehman Brothers in Boston. I.R.S. refunds paid in May were $25.4 billion, up from $17.1 billion in May 1994.
That extra spending money stood in sharp contrast to the period up to April 15. The I.R.S. was slow to send refunds to many Americans and a great many relatively affluent taxpayers faced unexpectedly high tax bills that contributed to a sharp rise in their payments.
It is uncertain how much of the extra money returned to American households last month was quickly spent. "But I'm sure it helped retail sales in May," Mr. Kelly said.
Most retail analysts focused on what the May figures suggested about trends of strength and weakness in the retail industry rather than pointing to broader trends in consumer spending. The Goldman Sachs Retail Composite Index, a weighted average of same-store sales of some 60 retailers, increased 3.4 percent.
A strong sector of the business was discount stores, like Wal-Mart and Kmart, whose same-store sales were up 5.4 percent, according to the Goldman Sachs Index. The other healthy performer was the department-store group, like Federated and May Department Stores, whose sales were up 3.1 percent.
The biggest weakness was in specialty apparel stores, like the Gap and the Limited, whose same-store sales dropped 2.6 percent in May. The weakness in the specialty apparel stores, which cater mostly to young women, has been evident for more than a year. Analysts and marketing experts have attributed the problem to a range of causes, from the declining number of women under 35 to a steady trend away from dressing up.
"You talk to 10 different people in the industry and you can get 10 different explanations for the problem in specialty apparel," Daniel Barry, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, said. "But the May figures show that the problem is still there."
There were stores, however, that reported solid gains in the specialty apparel group. Talbots reported that its sales increased 9.6 percent in May over May of last year, while sales at Ann Taylor Stores were up 4.7 percent. "But those two chains get their core group of customers from older women, 35 years old and up," said Richard N. Baum, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs.
Some retailers saw regional trends in the May figures. Federated, for example, has stores in 35 states. Ms. Hoguet, the senior vice president, said that her company was seeing some solid signs of retail strength in the Northeast, especially in New York. She attributed part of the improvement to the apparent success of the company's consolidation, begun in May, as its Abraham & Straus stores were converted to Macy's and Stern's stores.
But, she said, the rest of the pickup was the result of stronger store traffic caused by increased spending in general and foreign tourists taking advantage of the lower value of the dollar to shop for bargains in New York.
Kmart reported that same-store sales at its discount stores increased 5.6 percent in May, compared with a year ago, suggesting that the new management was making progress in improving its performance. Still, Wal-Mart remains well ahead and continues to lengthen its lead, posting a same-store gain of 6.7 percent for the month.
Straining to catch up, Kmart announced yesterday that it would close 72 poorly performing stores this year, eliminating about 5,800 jobs. Last year, the company, based in Troy, Mich., closed or relocated 120 stores, shedding 7,100 jobs.
About 2,200 Kmart and larger Super Kmart Centers remain. To compete with efficient rivals like Wal-Mart, some analysts said further streamlining was needed. "This isn't enough yet," Walter F. Loeb, an independent retail analyst, said. "Kmart has to close another 500 or 600 stores."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fresh Data Help Treasuries; Short-Term Issues Strongest

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, though the 30-year bond underperformed most other Government issues.
Fresh data raised expectations that the economy was slowing and that inflation remained subdued. Some participants are trading on the belief that a cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve could come as soon as July. 
 Analysts said that was the reason shorter-maturity securities were the market's strongest sector. The Fed controls short-term rates to carry out monetary policy and these issues would benefit by a Fed cut.
Analysts said that over all the weak data released in the morning touched off the rally. But, they added, the market's direction will depend on the May employment report that is scheduled today.
The 30-year benchmark Treasury bond rose 14/32 , to a price of 1132/32 for a yield of 6.61 percent, down from 6.64 percent on Wednesday. The yield on the two-year note dropped 12 basis points, to 5.72 percent, while that of the five-year note dropped 9 basis points, to 5.95 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Among the economic indicators that moved the market were personal income and consumption data, which confirmed that a rebound in the economy could not be ruled out. The concerns were raised on Wednesday by revised figures for the first-quarter gross domestic product. Yesterday's data, along with the G.D.P. revision, caused prices to sag in early trading as investors grew nervous.
Anthony Chan, chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said traders' concerns about signs of continued consumer strength were offset by signals in the labor market suggesting slower growth ahead. Since the labor figures scheduled for release today are "considered to be the mother of all economic releases," he said, "market participants eventually realized that they couldn't ignore this information."
Market consensus for the May employment number to be released today calls for a gain of 183,000 jobs, Mr. Chan's own estimate is for a gain of 160,000.
Mr. Chan said the broad-based weakness in yesterday's report by the National Association of Purchasing Management for May caused investors to ignore an inflationary signal in the index's price component, which showed prices at the manufacturing level continuing to rise.
A report by the Government showed factory orders fell 1.9 percent in April, but that had been foreshadowed by an earlier report on orders for durable goods. The weakness in the purchasing managers' report was the surprise.
Traders said the market largely ignored the Federal Reserve's mid-quarter survey of loan officers, which found softer consumer demand but rising business demand. "But market participants did receive some encouragement from the report in that they realized that slower consumer-loan growth may help in extinguishing some of the present inflationary pressures in the economy," Mr. Chan said.
Mr. Chan said the credit markets "ended up concentrating on the data which suggested slower growth ahead and thereby ignored all the data such as consumer spending, which suggested firmer economic activity ahead."
Traders even slighted a rise of 1.88 points in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of commodity prices. Such a gain would normally raise red flags as a possible precursor of inflationary pressures.
"The market," Mr. Chan said, "is gaining solace from the realization that the number of economists predicting a tightening move by the Fed this year are slowly becoming an endangered species."
In the municipal bond market, yields were little changed amid low returns and lingering concern about tax revision that slowed demand for tax-exempt securities.
Traders said investors were concerned that the tax advantage of such securities over other investments could be diminished should significant tax-change measures win passage.

HEADLINE: Survey Points to a Cause of Union Decline

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Once workers organized unions in defiance of management, but now many are often too cowed by management opposition to vote in favor of a union at their workplace, even though they want one, according to a new survey released yesterday.
That finding helps to explain the nationwide decline in union membership, said Richard Freeman, a Harvard University labor economist involved in the survey. "People don't want to anger their managers -- management power is simply too great today -- although they feel a need for a greater say over their working conditions," he said. 
 The survey, carried out by Princeton Survey Research Associates, also found that more than 80 percent of American workers favor using independent arbitrators, rather than the courts, to settle disputes with management. Roughly 60 percent of those surveyed said that such an arbitration system would encourage workers to bring more complaints, which then would be settled "more fairly" than in the courts.
But workers want the arbitration system jointly administered by them and managers. Corporate America is increasingly using arbitrators to settle disputes, to sidestep the costs of a lawsuit. In many cases, however, management appoints the arbitrators.
The survey's most noteworthy finding was the growing reluctance of many workers to oppose managers, a finding that other, less thorough surveys have also uncovered. This one, supervised by Mr. Freeman and Joel Rogers, a professor at the University of Wisconsin Law School, was carried out over a five-month period and involved 2,400 people, representative of about 70 million workers in the private sector, most of them below the rank of manager.
The survey's first results, released in December after three months of telephone interviews and focus group discussions in various regions, found that the old willingness of American workers to struggle with management had greatly diminished. Management power in the workplace has become "so great in the United States today that employees see" cooperation with management as necessary.
The second set of findings, released yesterday, examined this new attitude, through follow-up interviews with 800 workers previously interviewed. Some 33 percent of all nonunion workers said they favored union representation, or roughly three times the number of workers who actually belong to unions today in the private sector. But 12 percent of those who support unions would nevertheless vote against one at their workplaces rather than confront an angry management on the issue, the survey found.
Under American labor law, a union is formed at a workplace only if a majority of the workers vote in favor of one in an election supervised by the National Labor Relations Board. That 12 percent is "enough to swing most N.L.R.B. elections" against union representation, Mr. Freeman and Mr. Rogers concluded.
"Management opposition is clearly a major reason for the decline of unions in the United States, although not the only reason," Mr. Freeman said, and he listed such other factors as fear among workers of losing their jobs if the company brought in replacements for them or moved a factory to another state or abroad to avoid unionization.

HEADLINE: Max Ratner, 87, Philanthropist and Developer

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Max Ratner, a businessman, philanthropist and the founder of the America-Israel Chamber of Commerce, died on Wednesday at his home in Cleveland. He was 87.
Mr. Ratner, who was born in Bialystok, Poland, emigrated to the United States in 1920 and received a law degree from Cleveland Marshall Law School. He began his career at the Buckeye Material Company, a Cleveland lumber concern, which later became Forest City Enterprises. 
 As the company grew, Mr. Ratner worked as a salesman, buyer and manager and, ultimately, served as president and chairman. Forest City is now primarily a national real estate development company with annual revenues of about $500 million. It has redeveloped urban areas in the United States and constructed the Tower City Center in Cleveland.
In 1986, Forest City and Mr. Ratner's nephew Bruce Ratner formed a joint venture, the Forest City Ratner Companies, that helped transform the Brooklyn skyline. Its projects there included One Pierrepont Plaza in Brooklyn Heights and Metrotech, a large office, commercial and academic complex in downtown Brooklyn.
A long-time supporter of Israel, which he first visited in the year of its independence in 1948, Mr. Ratner was founder and chairman of the America-Israel Chamber of Commerce. He also was active in the State of Israel Bonds organization and participated in many investments in Israel.
Mr. Ratner was a trustee of the Cleveland Museum of Art and a board member of the Greater Cleveland Growth Association. He also had been president of the Park Synagogue in Cleveland. Mr. Ratner and his wife, Betty, donated works to the Jewish Museum in New York.
Mr. Ratner is survived by his wife; his sons, Charles, Mark, James and Ronald; his sister, Fannye Shafran, and 10 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A Day After Intervention, Dollar Resumes Its Slide Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the mark yesterday, hurt by a decision to leave German interest rates unchanged and by a flurry of data that showed the United States economy was slowing faster than currency traders had anticipated.
The retreat followed Wednesday's broad intervention in foreign-exchange markets by the central banks of the United States and a dozen other nations, which bought billions of dollars in an effort to halt the currency's renewed slide. The coordinated effort stopped the slump for a day, and the dollar bounced back against the mark and the Japanese yen. 
 Still, many traders saw an opportunity yesterday to sell the dollar, reasoning it was warranted by evidence of weakness in the American economy. "The economic numbers showed the economy may be heading toward a hard landing," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal in New York. "The central-bank intervention yesterday could not help too much today."
The dollar was also weighed down by the Bundesbank's decision to leave German interest rates unchanged. Many currency dealers had reckoned that the Germans would cut rates as a gesture of support for a stronger dollar. Lower rates in Germany would tend to diminish demand for marks, weakening the mark against the dollar.
"There was a bit of disappointment in the market that there was not any follow-through to the intervention," said Peggy Reed, vice president at Credit Agricole in New York. "The lack of movement by the Bundesbank made the market nervous and sent the dollar down."
In European trading yesterday, the dollar rose as high as 1.4371 marks, its highest level since May 25. But it fell steadily in New York, settling at 1.4055 marks, down from 1.4157 on Wednesday. It edged up to 84.65 yen from 84.54.
The dollar came under pressure early in the day after a series of weak Government reports on personal income and spending, and on factory orders. In addition, a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed a sharper decline than expected in manufacturing.
Recent weak economic figures have prompted concern that the economy is slowing to a point where the Federal Reserve may feel compelled to cut interest rates to pre-empt a recession. Lower rates make dollar-denominated holdings less attractive.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Price at Six-Week High After a Decline in Stockpiles

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper rose to its highest price in six weeks yesterday on the Commodity Exchange after a drop in stockpiles indicated that demand from industry had not faded as the economy slowed.
On other commodity markets, gasoline prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities gained 1.88 points, to 234.60. 
 On Wednesday, the Commodity Exchange said that its warehouse inventories of copper fell by 1,217 tons, to 7,034 tons, the lowest since April 14, when stockpiles slid to a five-year low. Stockpiles have dropped by 3,588 tons, or 33 percent, during the last eight trading days.
"The stockpile levels keep coming down and it makes people nervous," said Tommy Laman, manager of copper marketing for the Commercial Metals Company in Dallas. "We don't see a lot of scrap metal out there and there's apparently not a lot of refined metal either."
The copper inventory decline comes even though economic reports show industrial consumption is weakening. Factory orders, a key barometer of copper demand, posted their third monthly decline in April, the Commerce Department said yesterday.
Copper for July delivery rose 2.5 cents, to $1.335 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange, its highest price since April 19. Copper prices have risen 9.2 percent since reaching a six-month low on May 4.
Traders will be looking for today's inventory report from the London Metal Exchange to see whether global inventories are falling as well.
Gasoline prices fell below 60 cents a gallon for the first time in seven weeks as rising production and inventories eased concerns that refiners could not keep pace with demand this summer.
After the market closed on Wednesday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that American gasoline inventories rose 1.25 million barrels last week to 209.5 million barrels. The rise came as refiners in the United States increased gasoline output 1.6 percent, to 7.86 million barrels a day, the highest rate since mid-December.
"I don't think there is any concern about making enough gasoline to meet demand," said Leonard Camporeale, manager of refined-product risk and trading at Total Petroleum Inc. in Denver.
Unleaded gasoline for July delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange fell 0.26 cent, to 59.78 cents a gallon, the lowest price for the contract closest to delivery since April 4. July crude oil rose 1 cent, to $18.90 a barrel.

HEADLINE: 1995 N.H.L. PLAYOFFS;
Brodeur Shuts Out Tension to Shut Out the Opponent

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 1

 BODY:
Five pucks were lined up a few feet in front of Martin Brodeur's goal crease after many of the New Jersey Devils had left the ice. Just before the end of practice, Jacques Caron, the team's goaltending coach, was happily supervising a nightmare.
A teammate of Brodeur's would shoot a puck from in close, again and again. Brodeur faced backhands, wrist shots and jabs at rebounds, separated only by the time required for the shooter to pivot, reach back for another puck, and start again. The goaltender would drop to his knees or lean on his side, and when a puck would enter the net, a high-pitched shout would come from within his red, white and black mask. 
 As the Devils and the Philadelphia Flyers develop the strategies for the Eastern Conference finals that begin Saturday night at the Spectrum, the purpose of the drill was simple: To remind one of the most influential players in the playoffs of the days, all those years ago, when he was a child.
"Sometimes it's just good for him to feel the joy of the game," Caron said. "He tells me he plays his best when he feels like he's playing road hockey."
In a season shortened by a labor conflict, with his own contractual situation no clearer now than it was months ago, Brodeur has managed to operate as efficiently as he did when the game was played on Montreal asphalt and the stakes were not nearly so high.
His goals-against average of 1.25 and save percentage of .952 led the league after the second round of playoffs. Brodeur's three shutouts in the opening-round series against Boston marked the fifth time that a goaltender has had that many shutouts in a four-of-seven-game series and the first time the feat was completed in as few as five games. His current goals-against average is the best by any regular goaltender in the history of the Stanley Cup playoffs.
Brodeur's economy of movement and a rare sense of poise for a 23-year-old in his second full National Hockey League season have provided an ideal match for New Jersey's careful defensive approach.
The expectations were heightened a year after Brodeur won the Calder Trophy as rookie of the year and allowed an average of 1.95 goals in the playoffs. This year, in an inconsistent Devil season, it was Brodeur's decision to return to basics that helped return him to a central role in the semifinals for a second consecutive year.
"When I go out there, it's a different world," Brodeur said. "I don't feel you've got to be nervous to be able to perform. That's one thing I try to do. Don't put extra pressure out there. Sometimes I'm nervous. It probably doesn't show. I've got my mask on. I can do whatever I want.
"Every time I go out there, and you hear the music going and the fans going crazy, I say to myself, 'It doesn't get better than that.' Nobody can buy that. If you're not a hockey player or a sport person, it's hard to live that experience."
Brodeur is old enough to be the subject of an extended and so far unresolved negotiation that could eventually multiply his current salary of $140,000 by an additional zero. An arbitrator is expected to award the maximum of $850,000 for this season. He could become a free agent after the season, but the Devils would be able to match any offer.
But he is young enough that nine years ago, when Patrick Roy led Montreal to a Stanley Cup as a rookie, Brodeur was a teen-aged fan at the victory parade. Even now, in his old room at the home of his parents, the pictures on the wall include one of Ron Hextall, who will be in the Flyer goal.
When Brodeur was 15, Hextall was the Conn Smythe Winner, the most valuable player of the playoffs in a losing cause, at the end of a memorable rookie season. "When he came in the league, it was such a big change from other goalies," Brodeur said. "It was so different. I think that's what I liked about him. He was so different."
So Brodeur became the opposite. Hextall's passionate energy is clear from the last row. Brodeur, a professional conformist, can be so subtly efficient that his success has been attributed more to New Jersey's neutral zone trap than his own ability.
"I think one goes with the other," said Jacques Lemaire, the New Jersey coach. "You have to rely on the goalie if your team loses control in a certain part of the game. They attack. They attack. What's going on? Before you get your team back on the track, you need the goalie to help the team stay there. And when the team is going well and there's nothing much to do, it helps the goalie."
Caron, in his second season with the Devils, has seen improvement in Brodeur's awareness, especially his ability to anticipate plays around the net. "He is positioning himself well," Caron said. "He doesn't run around. He places himself early. This is the secret of a goaltender. If you place yourself on a proper angle early, then the second angle is easier to get. He sets himself and he just goes to what the play develops, and he's there again."
From the start of last season's playoff success, Brodeur listened to the comparisons with Roy and smiled. "He did it all the way," Brodeur says now. "I did it halfway, so far."
He listens to the talk about his accomplishments, and he answers with the work that remains to be done. "One thing I want to be able to do," Brodeur said, "is after my career, that they'll be able to say, 'This kid's going to have a career like Martin Brodeur.' "

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Mexico's Garage Sale;
In a Third Round of Privatization, Will a Nation Learn From Mistakes?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: COATZACOALCOS, Mexico

 BODY:
Under pressure from the United States and other creditors to cut spending and raise cash, Mexico is planning a garage sale. The idea is to unload Government-owned enterprises, from airports and communications satellites to the entire Mexican railroad system, including a creaky line that chug-chugs from this city on the Gulf of Mexico to the Pacific Coast at a seat-numbing speed of 12.5 miles an hour.
The sale will be Mexico's third big round of privatization since the mid-1980's. It is being watched closely here and in the United States -- from which many buyers will presumably come -- to see if it will be managed better than the earlier ones that were nonetheless able to raise more than $22 billion. In those sales the Government, in its zeal to get top dollar to meet its needs, accepted bids that were not always the best deal for the businesses being sold or for their customers. And it failed to adequately regulate the newly privatized businesses to protect those customers and promote competition. 
 For example, when Mexico sold 18 commercial banks beginning in 1991, it prohibited bids from foreign banks in favor of bids from Mexican investors, even though few of the local investors had banking experience.
Keeping out foreign banks and limiting the number of new banks effectively reduced competition in the market, making it more attractive to the local bidders and therefore driving up bids. The Government also failed to make sure that local bidders had sufficient reserves to operate the banks in case of losses. A result was that many banks could not respond adequately to the financial crisis that began in December.
Or consider the telephone system. A state-run monopoly, it was simply turned over to a privately owned monopoly that has done little to improve Mexico's laughably unreliable service. Or, take the Government's two airlines, Mexicana and Aeromexico. They were sold to groups whose managers had little experience and insufficient capital, and within a few years were again on the brink of bankruptcy.
Privatization, Mexico has learned, is not a cure-all. To make a deal succeed, a growing number of experts say, a government must consider not only the price but the system being created. That means looking at the experience and financial strength of the bidder, insuring competition and a commitment to service. And doing so may mean accepting a lower price.
Many people worry that the Mexican Government may repeat earlier mistakes in the coming round. "There's a bit of a naive view of privatization that says just give the properties to private owners and that's enough," said a senior Government official who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "It's naive but it's pretty effective. And the pressure for that kind of thing to continue is very strong."
The sale of the railroads will provide an interesting study of whether the Government can balance a need to raise cash with a desire to improve an important industry.
But if Mexico sells the railroads in the same way it sold the telephone company, for example, the Government would give the whole system to a single bidder without expertise and thus create a privately owned monopoly no more efficient than the one the state has run so poorly for decades.
Some officials, as well as some potential bidders, want things to change. Under their approach, Mexico's railroads would be carefully split into competing systems. Qualifications of bidders would be scrutinized. And important questions about setting rates, cutting payrolls and dealing with unprofitable passenger routes would be addressed before bids were accepted.
So for many such reasons, the sale will not be easy. The Government's chances are not helped by Mexico being under even more pressure to raise money -- and to do so quickly -- than during the earlier rounds of privatization. In exchange for a $50 billion bailout package from the United States, the International Monetary Fund and other nations and organizations in March, Mexico agreed to raise $12 billion to $14 billion by selling money-losing state enterprises. Some say the United States Treasury demanded the sales to appease members of Congress who said that Mexico was getting a free ride.
President Ernesto Zedillo wants to show that he is committed to complying with the conditions. He also wants to demonstrate that despite the economic horrors that followed December's peso devaluation, Mexico remains on a modernization path.
The coming sales are also far more complex than earlier ones, because they require substantive changes in the law -- in some cases, the Constitution of Mexico. Railroads, for example, were considered strategic resources until the Constitution was changed a few weeks ago. Lawmakers also found that oil and natural gas were still strategic, but that natural-gas distribution was not and therefore could be sold to investors.
Then there are the emotional hurdles. Historically, the railroads are linked in many Mexicans' minds with Pancho Villa, hero of the Mexican Revolution who crisscrossed the country by train as he led the overthrow of a dictator. When it comes to nationalized property, perhaps only the oil monopoly Pemex raises more passion than the railroads.
On the surface, buying into the railways seems a good opportunity. Given the condition of the trains, the asking price, which has not been specified, is likely to be low. For another, the railroad offers land access to the United States, the biggest consumer market in the world. On top of all that, the cheaper peso is helping Mexican exports surge.
Kick the tires, however, and a wheel might fall off. Most of the country's 16,000 miles of rail werelaid under the Government of Porfirio Diaz, before he was ousted as President in the revolution of 1910.
Mexico has since spent little on the railways, and the equipment is horribly outdated. The work force of about 50,000 is three times more than necessary, by American standards, and a nearly equal number of retirees draw costly pensions. A Government official says some retirees use schemes to milk the system. One of the most creative, he said, is for aging railroaders to divorce their wives and marry younger women, who support the older women and keep collecting pension income long after the retiree has died.
The railroads now carry less than 15 percent of all general cargo in the country, and less than 2 percent of travelers. One Mexican shipper, the official said, prefers to bring containers from Asia to Long Beach, Calif., ship them by American railroads to Laredo, Tex., and then bring them into Mexico by truck rather than through the port of Lazaro Cardenas, on the Pacific in the southern state of Michoacan.
And many international investors, appalled by the poor condition of the railroads and some other Government properties, doubt that Mexico will realize as much as it expects from the sales in the current time frame of two to three years.
The Government is studying several options. One would give a 50-year concession for the entire rail system to one owner. Another would split the system into four regional and competing private systems. A third would break the system into even smaller pieces.
Based on Mexico's earlier experience with privatization, selling the entire system to a single bidder would probably bring in the most money. But it would probably do the least to improve service. Splitting the system into several parts would generate less money but would, according to some experts, do the most to create a more modern system.
Mexico's Minister of Transportation and Communications, Carlos Ruiz Sacristan, says the Coatzacoalcos line (pronounced kwahts-ah-KWAHL-kose), which crosses the narrowest part of the country, is the crown jewel of the privatization effort. It runs across the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, from Coatzacoalcos on the Gulf of Mexico, to Salina Cruz on the Pacific. He intends to wrap the line with the shipping ports at either end and offer them in a kind of three-for-one special with the notion of eventually competing with the Panama Canal.
That was essentially how the line started nearly 100 years ago, but the idea never caught on. For one thing, it has only a single set of tracks, so one train has to pull onto a siding so another heading in the opposite direction can pass. The line also twists around mountains and through the streets of the city of Tehuantepec.
Given the trains' sorry condition, it is a wonder they can make the 150 miles in even the 12 hours required. At that rate, a train would take 10 days to cross the United States instead of less than 4. And rates for freight and passengers do not come close to covering costs.
Several large American railroads have expressed interest in Mexican railroads, but their attention is on the better-used northern lines that run from Mexico City to the United States border and serve a number of automobile-assembly plants. Some European companies are also expected to bid.
Robert G. Thruston, managing director of Southern Pacific Lines' Mexico group, said two important issues must be settled before his company would decide to bid: whether the Government would give a new owner the freedom to reduce the work force and tighten the retirement system, and whether it would require that passenger service be preserved.
Officials said they were considering a buyout to reduce the number of workers, and an overhaul of the social security system to include railroad retirees. As for passenger service, the Government is studying a plan to use subsidized buses in place of money-losing lines.
The Union Pacific is also interested in investing in Mexican railroads, including the better-used south-to-north lines from Mexico City to Laredo and El Paso. It has already formed an alliance with a big Mexican construction and engineering company, ICA.
John Rebensdorf, vice president for strategic planning at Union Pacific in Omaha, said he had been concerned about whether Mexico would repeat past mistakes in these privatizations. "We've had some concerns," he said, "but from all the indications of the way the Government and the railroad itself are going about it, we think they're putting a pretty solid process in place."

HEADLINE: International Briefs;
VW Chairman Predicts A Tough 1995-96

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Volkswagen chairman, Ferdinand Piech, braced stockholders yesterday to expect lackluster performance in new-car sales this year and next. Mr. Piech provided no profit forecast in his pessimistic report to 3,000 shareholders in Hamburg, Germany, but warned that for all of 1995 they can expect only "a slight increase in the number of cars sold and the number produced." He predicted a "somewhat better demand for autos in 1996." 
 Deliveries of new cars to customers in North America dropped in the first five months of this year, compared with the corresponding period in 1994, Mr. Piech said. The fall was attributed to Mexico's economic crisis and a slowdown in United States economic growth, he said. New-car sales also declined in Germany and the rest of Western Europe.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Declines in New York, but Little Growth Is Seen

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Despite a decline in the state's unemployment rate last month, the economic outlook for New York remains gloomy, Labor Department officials said yesterday.
 The unemployment rate in New York declined to 6.3 percent in May, from 6.8 percent in April and 6.5 percent a year earlier, still laggging behind the national rate, which dipped to 5.7 percent in May from 5.8 percent in April. 
 In New York City, the unemployment rate in May was 8.2 percent, down from 8.6 percent in April and 8.4 percent a year earlier.
 Still, there was little or no economic growth in the state or the city, Labor Department officials said. The recovery that has lifted regional economies elsewhere in the country continues to skip New York.
 "New York is near or at the very bottom in terms of job performance," said Anthony J. Ferrara, acting regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "As a result," he said, "I don't see much significance in the drop in the unemployment rate." One reason, he said, was that the labor force in the city continued to shrink, causing the rate of unemployment to shrink with it.
 "There's no job growth," he said.
 For example, while the nation showed a 2.8 percent increase in available jobs last month, New York's measurement of employment growth was a skimpy five-tenths of 1 percent.
 New Jersey, one of the few states in the Northeast to keep pace with the national recovery, continued to show signs of economic weakness that appeared two months ago. The state's unemployment rate increased slightly last month, to 6.5 percent, from 6.3 percent in April and 5.8 percent in March.
 "We could see a negative trend developing in New Jersey," Mr. Ferrara said. For example, he said a 2.2 percent increase in jobs in April declined to 1.8 percent in May.
 May figures were not available in Connecticut. It is not among the 11 states for which the Labor Department provides separate figures when it releases the national jobs data each month. But the Connecticut Department of Labor said the rate of unemployment for April was 5.1 percent, down from 5.3 percent in March and 5.8 percent in February.
 Nationally, widespread layoffs in manufacturing and construction caused the sharpest drop in business payrolls in four years, generating new concern over a possible recession.
 But Mr. Ferrara said New York was relatively insulated from the stall in the national recovery because its biggest economic sectors are in finance, real estate and insurance, three businesses that had already suffered large retrenchments.
 A most recent concern, he said, was the continuing reductions of jobs in the health care sector, which accounts for about 10 percent of New York's economy.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

AGREEMENT REACHED ON A STATE BUDGET
Sixty-three days after the start of the fiscal year, Governor Pataki and the state's legislative leaders concluded their tortuous negotiations and declared a final agreement on a state budget that, by at least one key measure, will reduce state spending for the first time in a generation. The budget will also cut income and business taxes and impose modest new restrictions on welfare recipients. The finished product reflects a drastic reversal of New York's fiscal traditions. [Page 1.]
 
The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, called for the first tax increase in four years, proposing to raise property taxes on some houses used as rental properties. [25.]
 
The budget agreement just completed by Governor Pataki and the Legislature should leave its mark on virtually every resident of the state. [24.]
 
After more than two months of silence and secrecy, the first real evidence of a state budget was plopped down on legislators' desks yesterday afternoon. As the voting started, few even looked at the packages. [24.]
 
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
RABBI RETURNS TO BROOKLYN
A Brooklyn rabbi charged in Los Angeles with touching the breast of a 15-year-old girl on a flight from Australia returned home, but his assistant -- facing a more serious charge of sexually abusing the girl -- was ordered held pending an inquiry into his involvement in a 1991 sexual-abuse case. [23.]
 
SOLARZ'S WIFE SENTENCED TO PROBATION
Nina K. Solarz, the wife of former Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, was sentenced to one year of probation and 50 hours of community service for improperly taking money from a charitable group she ran and for intentionally writing a bad check on the House of Representatives bank. Mrs. Solarz had pleaded guilty in April to two criminal charges. [25.]
 
CIRCLING WARILY OVER A CAROUSEL
Perhaps fittingly, they have been going around in circles for months: the Parks Department, the Central Park Conservancy and the concessionaire who runs the park's landmark carousel, whose charging wooden steeds have been chasing one another around the wheezing band organ for decades. The concessionaire, Salvatore Napolitano, fears that for the first time in his longtime association with the carousel, it may go round without him. [23.]
 
 
REGION
 
HOW TO SUCCEED IN POLITICS
Michael E. Bongiorno was a complete unknown to the local power brokers in New City, N.Y. So he had to get his new job as district attorney of scandal-plagued Rockland County the old-fashioned way: he applied for it. After reading of the Federal investigation into his predecessor, Kenneth Gribetz, the earnest Mr. Bongiorno wondered whether he should bother making a bid for the job, given his abstinence from the intoxications of politics. His wife, Deanne, urged him to try. [22.]
 
Despite a decline in the state's unemployment rate last month, the economic outlook for New York remains gloomy, Labor Department officials said. [34.]

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: IN BELGRADE;
Milosevic Stiffens in Talks With U.S. Envoy

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 2

 BODY:
The President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic, insisted today on new concessions before he will sign an accord committing him to step up pressure on the Bosnian Serbs.
An American envoy, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Robert Frasure, met again today with President Milosevic to offer a deal to lift the crippling United Nations sanctions on Serb-dominated Yugoslavia. In exchange, Mr. Milosevic would have to recognize the Muslim-led Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, condemn the hostage-taking by the Bosnian Serbs, and take further steps to seal the border across which the Bosnian Serbs are smuggling supplies. 
 The day's talks took place before the announcement tonight that Mr. Milosevic had served as an intermediary in the release of 120 United Nations peacekeepers held hostage by the Bosnian Serbs.
One diplomat monitoring the talks said the release of the hostages was likely to stiffen Mr. Milosevic's bargaining stance.
The release of the hostages "is Milosevic showing his stuff," the diplomat said. "He's saying that he can get something done, that he does have some influence over the Bosnian Serbs. Certainly he would think of that as something that might strengthen his position in the talks with Frasure.
"It's a good sign, but the obvious response is that there are still 200 or so hostages still in the hands of the Bosnian Serbs," the diplomat added. "Even if there are just two, it's not an acceptable situation."
Officials close to the talks are cautious about predicting any deal. They say Mr. Milosevic seems to feel strengthened by the hostage-takings because they add pressure on the outside world to reach an accord. Mr. Milosevic evidently senses the desire among Western nations for a deal, and is trying to extract the best possible bargain.
According to diplomats in Belgrade, President Milosevic is seeking a permanent lifting of the sanctions rather than the 200-day suspension that Mr. Frasure has offered. He wants the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, to be responsible for deciding if Yugoslavia is meeting its commitments under any future accord, not the Security Council as Mr. Frasure has proposed.
Mr. Milosevic also wants a commitment that after the sanctions are lifted, Yugoslavia will have access to foreign credit. Mr. Frasure is believed to be offering credits, but only if the European Union agrees on providing them.
Finally, Mr. Milosevic is said to be insisting that Yugoslavia be allowed to import as much oil and petroleum as he deems necessary. Western governments are willing to give him access to fuel for factories and civilian vehicles, but are wary of providing a blank check for fear that some fuel may be used for military purposes.
Mr. Milosevic has been seeking relief from the United Nations sanctions since they were imposed three years ago, and has recently been told by his economic advisers that the sanctions could soon spark another round of hyper-inflation like the one that plagued the country in 1993.
Some experts here have predicted that an accord may be only hours away. Mr. Milosevic, they note, has often made major policy announcements on weekends in the belief that doing so minimizes the possibility of sudden adverse reactions from the public.
The government-controlled press, moreover, seems to be preparing people here for some kind of deal. Whereas in the past it was used to whip up sympathy for the plight of the Serbs in battle zones, the press has in recent weeks largely ignored their ordeals.
After the recent Serbian defeat in western Slavonia, for example, no pictures of destroyed Serbian homes or sobbing refugees were broadcast here. And when NATO planes bombed Bosnian Serb arms depots last week, the principal television station led its evening newscasts with a report on murals prepared for the planned Belgrade subway system, and mentioned the raids only briefly.
In a series of public statements, officials close to President Milosevic have taken an increasingly hard line against the Bosnian Serbs and their leader, Radovan Karadzic. In an interview with a leading German news magazine, Der Spiegel, released in advance of publication Monday, Mr. Milosevic's Foreign Minister, Vladislav Jovanovic, described the hostage-taking by the Bosnian Serbs as "irrational and unacceptable."
"I tell them that they can be paranoid as individuals or allow their families to be destroyed, but they have no right to destroy an entire people," Mr. Jovanovic said. "We are not going to allow a crazy man to prevent a clever man from arranging his international relations."

HEADLINE: ALBANY'S BUDGET: PROPERTY TAXES;
Vallone Urges Raising Taxes on Homes

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
With New York City receiving less financial help than expected from Albany, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone called yesterday for the first tax increase in four years, proposing to raise property taxes for owners of one- to three-family houses used solely as rental properties.
 Mr. Vallone, Democrat of Queens, said the increase would raise $80 million a year. That money, he said, could avert some of what he called the most "destructive consequences" of the budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and, possibly, lower property taxes for owners of cooperatives and condominiums. 
 The proposed increase would be limited to people who are drawing incomes from houses that they own but do not live in -- 100,000 of the 600,000 one- to three-family houses in the city.
 The proposal nonetheless represents a significant shift for Mr. Vallone, a staunch defender of middle-class homeowners who has held virtually sacrosanct their relatively low tax rate.
 For the affected homeowners the effective tax rate would rise 47 percent. The owner of an average house with an assessed value of $160,000 would pay $1,840 a year at a rate of 1.15 percent, compared with $1,248 now, at just under eight-tenths of 1 percent.
 The Mayor swiftly rejected the proposal, calling it a "mistake for the economy of the city."
 "I can't see my supporting it," Mr. Giuliani said. "This is an attempt to raise taxes in order to spend more money."
 Aides to Mr. Vallone said he would press ahead despite the Mayor's response.
 The Speaker said the decision to seek the tax increase reflected a realization that the state government would provide far less assistance than Mr. Giuliani had hoped for when he proposed a $31.1 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
 The state budget that Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders agreed to yesterday appeared to leave the city with at least $400 million less than the Mayor had hoped for.
 Mr. Giuliani had called for $950 million in new aid and savings from state cuts in Medicaid and welfare, as well as an added $106 million in aid for schools and foster care.
 That leaves a yawning gap in the Mayor's efforts to balance the city's budget. The Mayor's budget called for a $1.1 billion reduction in total spending, or 3.4 percent, and would gain concessions from the municipal unions and cut spending in ways affecting virtually every New Yorker.
 Mr. Giuliani, appearing in the Blue Room at City Hall after the accord on the state budget had been announced, said it was too soon to say exactly how he had fared in Albany. He has threatened to impose $400 million in service cuts on top of those already in his budget if the state figures fall short.
 But in recent days he has softened that warning, and the Council has pledged to resist those additional cuts, which would fall heavily on libraries, museums and day-care centers.
 At a news conference, Mr. Vallone said, "It certainly is time for the City of New York to take very seriously, both the Council and the Mayor, the devastating impact of many of the cuts that might have to take place unless we come up with some other ideas."
 He announced his proposal as the Council prepares to negotiate with the Mayor over his proposed budget, and the move appears to underscore a sense of urgency that many Democratic Council members feel, that the city's fiscal picture is becoming increasingly dire.
 In fact, the proposed tax increase is creating the sharpest division between the Council and the Mayor over the budget.
 Until yesterday, the Council, whose ranking leaders represent middle-class homeowning neighborhoods in Queens and Brooklyn, had resisted calling for any tax increase and had supported the Mayor's effort to cut business taxes modestly.
 The last tax increase was in 1991. At that time Mayor David N. Dinkins and the Council agreed to raise the property tax $400 million, or more than 5 percent. Part of that sum was allotted to hire 6,000 police officers under the Safe Streets, Safe City program.
 The Speaker's proposal would represent a 1 percent increase in the $8 billion in city property taxes. Still, for Mr. Vallone, it represents a remarkable shift for an elected official who has fiercely resisted any increases for homeowners like those who form the core of his district in Astoria, Queens.
 In proposing the increase, Mr. Vallone portrayed it as a question of fairness. For years owners of one- to three-family houses have paid among the lowest property taxes in the region, thousands a year less than in the suburbs of Long Island or Westchester County.
 Mr. Vallone said the city should begin to equalize the rates for the houses that are known as Class 1 and those for co-ops and condos in Class 2, which are taxed at a rate more than two times that of private houses. Although Mr. Vallone said the increased tax revenue could be used to lower the rate for co-ops and condos, he did not specifically propose a reduction.
 In his preliminary budget, the Mayor proposed a $70 million tax cut for co-ops and condos, but replaced it with cuts for business taxes in his final proposal.
 In recent years, a cross-section of elected officials and advocacy groups for co-op and condo owners has called for balancing the rate. Some of those critics argue that Class 1 owners have been given what amounts to a huge tax break at a time when the city is struggling to balance its budgets.
 Mr. Vallone emphasized that he believed that homeowners should receive a break, but that the benefits should not extend to "absentee landlords."
 "That was not the benefit or the intention of the break," he said.
 Councilman John D. Sabini, Democrat of Jackson Heights and Elmhurst, Queens, said he had supported raising the tax rate for people who did not live in the houses that they own, saying they had destabilized neighborhoods like his by renting the properties. "The retirees who move away and the real-estate companies are getting all the benefits of an Ozzie and Harriet tax break," he said.
 The Speaker's proposal would face a vote in the State Legislature, which established the complex system to classify and tax property in the city.
 Mr. Giuliani said even if he supported Mr. Vallone's plan, it would be highly unlikely that the change would be approved in the newly Republican climate in Albany in time to help this year -- or ever.

HEADLINE: Christopher Backs Free Trade With Europe

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: MADRID, June 2

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher praised the idea of establishing a trans-Atlantic free trade area today as he called for closer economic and political ties between Europe and the United States to prevent them from drifting apart now that they no longer face a common cold war enemy.
Responding to European proposals to set up a free trade area linking North America and Europe, Mr. Christopher said the United States would seriously study the proposal, which he said has "considerable potential" to bolster prosperity on both sides of the Atlantic. 
 Mr. Christopher outlined a vision for tighter trans-Atlantic ties that would rest on not just security concerns and NATO, but also heightened political and economic cooperation through such measures as increasing coordination in fighting drug trafficking.
State Department officials said Mr. Christopher gave today's address to reassure Europeans who fear that America is turning away from Europe. As evidence, Europeans say American policy makers are focusing on the fast-growing markets of Asia and Latin America, Congress is turning more isolationist and the Pentagon is reducing its forces in Europe.
Mr. Christopher said: "In the absence of a single unifying threat, and at a time of understandable focus on domestic concerns, some argue that the ties that bind us are fraying, and that America and Europe will inevitably drift apart. I reject that view."
Then, echoing something Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the House, said recently about the trans-Atlantic relationship, he said: "It cannot be sustained by nostalgia. Every generation must renew the partnership by adapting it to meet the challenges of its time."
The Secretary of State suggested that an American-European partnership was vital for leading the world on crucial issues, like extinguishing regional crises and stopping the spread of nuclear weapons.
"Our nations, working together, have the unique capacity to provide global leadership," he said. "We must resist the siren songs, heard in so many capitals, of isolation and withdrawal."
For Europeans, Mr. Christopher's speech was an eagerly awaited response to calls for tighter trans-Atlantic ties made in recent speeches by Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain, Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany and Sir Leon Brittan, vice president of the European Union's executive commission.
Sir Leon told the American Club of Brussels a month ago: "There is a widespread perception that the bonds between us are loosening. This must be taken seriously." He added that it was "time to revisit the relationship and adapt it to tomorrow's needs."
In his speech to the Casa de America, a center that promotes better relations between Spain and the Americas, Mr. Christopher called for broadening exchanges for students and legislators and for agreements to liberalize trade in movies, telecommunications equipment and financial services. He proposed more trans-Atlantic work to harmonize product standards and testing. And he proposed heightened cooperation to fight international crime and terrorism, by, for instance, establishing regular meetings of top American and European anti-narcotics officials.
Mr. Christopher said Europe and the United States should cooperate to integrate Turkey into the West and to settle the conflicts in Cyprus and Bosnia, which he said is the single greatest threat to peace in Europe. He also urged that the trans-Atlantic partners work together to expand NATO and aid former Soviet bloc nations in embracing free markets and consolidating democracy.
After attending a NATO ministers meeting in the Netherlands this week, Mr. Christopher came to Madrid to consult with Spanish officials about their plans when they assume the presidency of the 15-nation European Union next month.
Mr. Christopher said his new effort to break down trade barriers with Europe did not detract from Washington's plans to set up a trans-Pacific free trade zone by the year 2020 or complete talks by the year 2005 to create an Americas-wide free trade area.
"Our vision for the economic relationship between Europe and the United States must be no less ambitious," he said.
He laid down some caveats about establishing a trans-Atlantic free trade agreement, an idea that some foreign officials fear will create a new trading bloc that discriminates against outsiders, especially poor nations. Mr. Christopher said any trans-Atlantic trade accord must not undermine global trade liberalization and must not disadvantage less developed nations.
President Clinton is scheduled to discuss establishing a common agenda with Europe in a meeting on June 14 with Jacques Santer, the president of the European Union's executive commission, and President Jacques Chirac of France, which holds the European Union's rotating presidency.
"We must not take this relationship for granted," Mr. Christopher said. "It is our responsibility to build the partnership that will ensure that, by working together, our next 50 years will be as great as the last."

HEADLINE: PAYROLLS TRIMMED BY 101,000 IN MAY, THE MOST SINCE '91

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
In the most sobering evidence so far of the economy's abrupt slowdown, employers lopped 101,000 workers from payrolls in May, the biggest monthly decline since the end of the last recession in the spring of 1991, the Labor Department reported today.
At the same time, the Government index intended to forecast the economy posted in April its third straight decline, a development often interpreted as pointing to a recession six to nine months ahead. 
 Despite this grim convergence of reports, most private forecasters -- along with the Clinton Administration -- continued to maintain that the economic slowdown would probably stop short of an actual recession. In response to the unexpectedly bleak Government data, interest rates fell sharply while the stock market fluctuated wildly -- falling, then soaring, before falling again to end the day generally down. [Page 31.]
"The economy has obviously decelerated more sharply than we anticipated," said Paul W. Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore investment firm. "But it just doesn't seem to have the earmarks of a recession in the making."
Today's news, and the markets' reactions, led several analysts to predict that the Federal Reserve might soon agree to an official cut in short-term interest rates, perhaps as early as the next meeting of its policy-making group, right after the Fourth of July. But Fed officials have been strikingly upbeat recently in the face of other dour indicators, suggesting that they may not act unless there is even more evidence that the bottom is falling out of the economy. [Page 31.]
Pressure is building on the Fed on several fronts. Specialists noted that rates on some shorter-term Treasury securities had already moved well below the overnight lending rate among banks, which the Fed effectively controls.
"I've rarely seen the Fed this far behind the market," said Leif H. Olsen, a former chief economist at Citibank who now heads a Connecticut investment firm bearing his name.
The direction of interest rates, of course, has broad implications, not only for the markets but for businesses, borrowers and consumers at large. One Midwest bank even cut its prime lending rate today, but others did not follow its lead.
Today's reports also brought what were seen by some as the first hints that the Administration might seek to blame the Federal Reserve and its yearlong series of interest rate increases if the economy falls into recession. Administration officials have supported the Fed in its money-tightening efforts to pre-empt inflation, but they now appear worried that a result could be an economy stagnating, or worse, at the start of President Clinton's re-election campaign.
"The current slowing of the economy is in part the result of the rise in interest rates in 1994, which affected the interest-sensitive sectors such as durable goods and housing," the two current members of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Joseph E. Stiglitz and Martin N. Baily, said in a statement.
But they maintained that the worst might soon be over. "Since longer-term interest rates have declined substantially since the fall of last year," the White House economists said, "we expect that growth in the interest-sensitive sectors will resume in the second half."
A recession anytime soon would also severely jeopardize the reappointment of Alan Greenspan, whose term as chairman of the Federal Reserve expires in March.
Despite the generally unpleasant message of the job-market report for May, it did show that the unemployment rate inched down to 5.7 percent after jumping three-tenths of a point in April, to 5.8 percent.
This was largely a quirk, analysts said, reflecting a record 926,000 plunge in the labor force. Millions of students and teachers had left the classroom but had not yet begun to look for summer work. Although the figures are adjusted for such seasonal swings, the process seems to have failed to keep up with the trend toward earlier school closings.
Far overshadowing this bit of superficial cheer was the big drop in payroll jobs. Analysts had expected a modest-enough rise of 175,000, and many economists had also thought the May data would be accompanied by a sizable upward revision for April. Instead, payrolls shrank by 101,000 last month and the initial 9,000 decline reported for April improved only to a decline of 7,000.
Employment also skidded in the Labor Department's household survey, dropping by 753,000 on a seasonally adjusted basis, but without raising the unemployment rate because the official size of the work force -- people with jobs or actively searching for them -- shrank so much.
Among the most populous states, the jobless rate jumped in California to 8.5 percent from 7.9 percent, leaving that state with the nation's highest unemployment. By contrast, unemployment fell by half a percentage point in New York, to 6.3 percent, and was essentially unchanged in Texas at 6 percent. But those state-by-state figures are subject to even greater vagaries than the national data.
The payroll tally showed greater declines in manufacturing and construction than in previous months, with factories losing 56,000 jobs across nearly all industries, and construction jobs down 57,000. Heavy rains and flooding in the South added to the toll on construction.
The apparel industry continued to shed jobs, losing 7,000 more last month to bring the 12-month total to 41,000, the report also showed.
Just as worrisome, some analysts said, was tepid growth in the once-robust services sector. A 60,000 gain in jobs brought the two-month total to just 95,000.
Just as employers snapped up temporary workers all last year to meet heavy demand for their products and services, they appear to have moved quickly to shed them as the economy has cooled.
Reflecting lower demand, the private-sector workweek contracted 18 minutes, to 34.3 hours, in May, while the factory workweek was unchanged and factory overtime fell, by 12 minutes, for the fourth month in a row.
Average hourly earnings, meanwhile, eased 2 cents after rising 6 cents in April. Average weekly earnings declined 1 percent to cut the 12-month advance to just 1.5 percent.
"There's absolutely no sign of wage-push inflation," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview.
The average weekly hours worked dropped to 34.3 from 34.6, and overtime fell back to 4.3 hours, from 4.5, suggesting that factories were cutting back as they sought to shrink excess inventories.
The household tabulation showed a decline of four-tenths of a point in the jobless rate for adult women, while blacks were doing unusually well in job-market competition.
The black unemployment rate, which eased eight-tenths of a point, to 9.9 percent, was below the Hispanic rate, which climbed to 10 percent, for the first time in the two decades that such statistics have been kept. Moreover, the black rate was less than twice the white rate, unchanged at 5 percent, for the first time one department official could remember.
Geographically, the jobless rate eased in the Midwest by three-tenths of a point, to 4.6 percent; by two-tenths of a point in the Northeast, to 5.9 percent, and by one-tenth of a point, to 5.4 percent, in the South. But unemployment rose three-tenths of a point in the West, to 7.1 percent, heavily influenced by the rise in California.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said the index of leading economic indicators fell six-tenths of a percent in April, the third consecutive decline for the forward-looking gauge. Eight of its 11 components moved lower.
Historically, three consecutive declines in the index signal a recession. While the index has accurately predicted all nine of the country's postwar recessions, it posted three or more consecutive declines on five other occasions when no recession followed.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Economy Hits the Brakes As Payrolls Drop Sharply
Stark evidence of a rapidly slowing economy came in a report that employers dropped 101,000 workers from their payrolls in May, the worst decline since the spring of 1991 -- the end of the latest recession. The grim icing: the Government's leading indicators posted their third straight decline, which is often taken as a sign that recession lurks in six to nine months. But most private forecasters -- and the Clinton Administration -- aren't buying it; they insist the slowdown is likely to stop short of actual contraction. The Labor Department report did show that the unemployment rate inched down to 5.7 percent from 5.8, but that was seen as largely a statistical quirk as millions of students and teachers surged out of classrooms but had not started looking for summer work. One thing seems increasingly likely, though: that the Fed will loosen the screws a bit, perhaps by July 6. [Page 1.]
 
New York State's unemployment rate fell to 6.3 percent from 6.8, and New York City's dropped to 8.2 from 8.6, but the good news stops there. There was little or no economic growth in the state or the city, the Labor Department said; the recovery that has lifted other regions keeps missing New York. [34.]
 
A Mixed Wall St. Verdict
The stock market gave a split verdict on the whiff of recession in the job numbers. In a volatile end to a volatile week, the Dow industrials lost 28.36, to 4,444.39, as some investors recoiled at the thought of a slowing economy. But others saw a silver lining in the likelihood of a rate cut by the Fed, with high-tech stocks on Nasdaq showing gains. [35.]
 
Treasury securities prices leaped, sending the 30-year bond yield down to 6.53 percent from 6.61. [44.]
 
Favored Trade for China
President Clinton renewed trade privileges for China, despite objections to its human rights record. He acted on the recommendation of Secretary of State Warren Christopher. [3.]
 
Dates Set for Auto Talks
The dates are set for talks between the United States and Japan on access to Japan's auto market: June 12 and 13 in Geneva, then June 20 and 21 in Washington, in the latest compromise. The deadline they're racing against: June 28, when those 100 percent tariffs on Japanese luxury cars kick in. [32.]
 
Inquiry Ended on Annuity Sales
The Justice Department's antitrust division dropped an investigation into efforts by the insurance industry to prevent banks from issuing annuities. [33.]
 
Tax Rise for New York City?
A tax increase for New York City -- the first in four years -- was called for by the City Council Speaker, who proposed higher property taxes for owners of one- to three-family homes used solely as rental properties. [25.]
 
Prodigy, Manhattan-Bound
Prodigy is moving its corporate headquarters from White Plains to lower Manhattan, an emerging multimedia mecca, showing that even in the age of e-mail and modems and faxes, the high-tech folks still like to look one another in the eye occasionally. [21.]
 
Younkers: Not for Sale
Younkers is not for sale, the board of the department store chain said, defying shareholder votes solicited by a hostile suitor, Carson Pirie Scott. The board also expanded its membership to reseat Tom Gould, Younkers' chairman, who had been defeated by a Carson-backed candidate. [33.]
 
Ruling on Labatt Bid
John Labatt's American shareholders do not have to be included in Onex's $1.68 billion hostile bid for Labatt, a judge ruled. [33.]
 
The Dollar Is Mixed
The dollar was mixed, rebounding from early losses amid concern that central banks might start buying dollars again, as they did on Wednesday. It was last quoted at 84.32 yen, down from 84.65 yen on Thursday, and was up a fraction against the mark. [41.]
 
Weather Lifts Corn Prices
Corn prices rose sharply as rain and cold weather added further delays to an already late planting schedule. [41.]
