HEADLINE: In Japan's Showrooms, Barely;
U.S. Big 3 Find That Dealers Are Hard to Find

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 2

 BODY:
Yutaka Kobayashi's auto showroom in the Tokyo suburb of Chiba switched in November from selling Toyotas to Fords. In the six months since, he has sold 45 vehicles -- what a Toyota dealer typically sells in a month.
 The difficulties that American makers have in selling cars in Japan have been a focus of the bitter trade dispute that prompted the United States to decide it would impose 100 percent import tariffs on 13 models of Japanese luxury cars unless an accord with Japan could be reached by June 28. 
 Washington says Japanese auto dealers are restricted from carrying American cars because of their close ties to Japanese car makers. The Japanese respond that auto dealerships are independent businesses and that the reason so few of them carry American cars is that Detroit's products are ill suited to the Japanese market.
 Visits to two dealers that have taken on American cars -- Mr. Kobayashi's dealership and a Nissan dealership in western Tokyo that switched to Fords -- found some truth in each nation's view of the situation.
 American cars generally do not sell that well in Japan, so a dealer taking on an American line can expect two or three years of losses before there is any hope of profit. But even after these dealers make the commitment to carry foreign cars, their ties to Japan's auto makers seem to prevent them from putting their best effort into selling the American vehicles.
 "We are in a way Nissan employees, so it's rather hard to aggressively sell cars that compete against Nissan cars," said Yasutaka Ohata, a manager at Ford Tohnichi in western Tokyo. Ford Tohnichi was set up a year ago by Tokyo Nissan, a huge dealer in which the Nissan Motor Company holds a one-quarter stake. "Emotionally, we still have the feeling that we hope the customers will buy Nissan," Mr. Ohata said.
 One obstacle, for instance, is that both Nissan and the Toyota Motor Corporation pressed the dealers to set up separate showrooms for the Ford Motor Company products rather than sell them alongside Japanese cars. That makes it more costly for dealers to take on a new brand.
 "Toyota has been telling us we cannot mix Toyota cars and Ford cars," said Takashi Makino, general manager of Ford Chiba, which sells Fords but is owned by a huge dealership that sells Toyotas. In showrooms offering both brands, Toyota has been insisting that a wall be built to separate them, he said.
 Another obstacle is that both dealerships are reluctant to sell the smallest, least expensive Ford models, which might have the broadest appeal. Those Ford vehicles are made by the Mazda Motor Corporation, a rival of Toyota and Nissan.
 Yet another problem is that the two dealerships do not have access to the customer records from the days when they sold Toyotas and Nissans. When Ford Tohnichi switched to selling Fords, all records of existing customers were given to other Tokyo Nissan dealers and the salesmen were replaced by an entirely new crew.
 In Japan, dealers often sell cars by visiting their regular customers at their homes. Without the records, Ford Tohnichi and Ford Chiba had to start from scratch, waiting for customers to come to the showroom.
 But if the way the dealers do business presents obstacles, so, too, do the cars themselves. American cars still have a reputation in Japan for poor quality and for being large, expensive and fuel inefficient, the dealers said.
 They say the cars are inferior to Japanese cars in the fit and the finish -- the doors do not close as snugly, for instance -- giving fastidious Japanese consumers the impression that the cars are roughly made.
 "We have to explain the weak points of American cars before they buy, by saying the American view toward cars is different from the Japanese view," Mr. Kobayashi said in his showroom, which was bedecked with American and Japanese flags. They said, however, that customers who had bought Fords had not had major problems.
 Toshio Nakano, the president of Ford Tohnichi, said the biggest problem is that most Fords have steering wheels on the left instead of the right, as Japanese cars do. The exceptions are the Probe, a sporty car that does not have wide appeal, and the made-in-Europe Mondeo. But the Mondeo uses premium gasoline, a drawback in a country where gasoline costs three to four times what it does in the United States, he said.
 Mr. Nakano also said Ford's cars do not have retractable side-view mirrors, which many customers want for parking in tight spaces.
 In full-page advertisements placed in American newspapers, for example, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association asserts, "The Big Three have been ignoring Japan's auto market for years." The ad notes that Detroit does not offer a single "midget" model although 20 percent of the Japanese market is midget cars and that Detroit does not offer any small cars built in the United States although that niche is 60 percent of the market.
 How well Ford Chiba and Ford Tohnichi fare could help determine the number of other Japanese dealers who will sell American cars. "If the dealer selling Fords in Chiba is making money, others will get on the bandwagon," said Hiroshi Okuda, an executive vice president of Toyota. "With this exchange rate, the American cars should look very reasonable and cheap. The Japanese dealers should be jumping at them, but this doesn't seem to be happening."
 Konen Suzuki, the president of Ford Japan, said that it took time for new dealers to turn a profit and that longtime Ford dealers in Japan were making "huge profits."
 Neither Ford Tohnichi nor Ford Chiba is making money yet.
 Ford Tohnichi, which began selling Fords a year ago, has been selling about 15 cars a month, one-third of the number it sold when it was a Nissan outlet. And since there are so few Fords on the road, repair and service work -- a big source of revenue -- is scarce, Mr. Nakano said.
 Still, he said, the profit margin on Fords is higher than on Nissans and he hopes to make a profit in three years. Once that happens, Tokyo Nissan will add new Ford outlets.
 Ford Chiba sales are a little bit behind expectation but have been growing month to month by 20 percent. Toyota has no ownership role in the Katsumata Group, the huge Toyota dealer that set up Ford Chiba. Katsumata is the only Toyota dealer offering Fords so far, and it is thinking of adding Ford outlets.
 In the trade talks, the United States contended that one reason Japanese cars succeeded in America was that American dealers sold Corollas and Accords alongside Chevrolets and Dodges.
 Washington said that the high real estate prices in Japan made it prohibitively expensive for American companies to set up their own dealership networks, so they had to rely on existing Japanese dealers.
 But Japanese officials countered that some European car makers like BMW and Volvo had set up dealer networks in the 1980's and had done fairly well. Also, compared with Detroit's offerings, the European cars tend to be smaller and many more have steering wheels on the right.
 Some 182,000 cars and trucks from Europe were sold in Japan last year, five times the 34,000 imports from the Big Three's American factories. Still, European cars hold less than 3 percent of the vehicle market here.
 Japanese officials also point out that Ford itself generally insists that its cars be sold through showrooms that carry only Fords, so it should not criticize the Japanese. Mr. Suzuki, the president of Ford Japan, said the company preferred exclusive showrooms but was willing to make an exception because requiring separate showrooms made it less economical for Japanese dealers to begin carrying Fords.
 Despite Washington's aggressive posture, only Ford among the Big Three is pushing hard for dual dealerships. Mr. Suzuki said that so far the company had persuaded 17 Japanese dealers, mostly selling Mazdas and Nissans, to sell Fords.
 The General Motors Corporation has been selling almost exclusively through Yanase & Company, a dealership that specializes in foreign cars. This week, officials of G.M.'s Saturn subsidiary said that right-hand-drive versions of various Saturn models would be sold through exclusive dealerships in Japan as soon as 1997. The Chrysler Corporation has been selling Jeeps through some Honda dealers and through Seibu, another dealership that specializes in foreign cars. A spokesman said Chrysler planned to try to recruit Japanese dealers soon.
 A study commissioned by both the United States and Japanese Governments and released last year concluded that until 1980, franchise agreements in Japan prohibited dealers from handling another manufacturer's cars. Through 1990, the franchise agreements of some manufacturers still had a clause requiring advance consultation before a dealer could add another brand.
 While such explicit prohibitions have been removed, the United States contends that there are still close relationships with manufacturers that tie the dealers' hands. In many cases, the manufacturer owns part of the dealer.
 Even Japanese officials acknowledge that a word from the manufacturer can help smooth the way for dealers to add foreign cars.
 It seems clear, for instance, that the Nissan dealers that have started to sell Fords are not acting completely independently.
 "Nissan made the decision, not the dealers," said Atsushi Oi, the director of the automobile division at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "I think Nissan can easily convey their intent to dealers to increase carrying of Fords."
 All this raises another concern: If Japanese dealers have such close ties to Japanese manufacturers that it is hard to recruit them, then is it wise for an American auto company to rely on them for sales? Isn't that entrusting sales to a competitor?
 Mr. Suzuki of Ford Japan said he was sure the new dealers would become loyal to Ford in a year or two.

HEADLINE: Detour on Journey to Democracy;
Survivor of Beijing Massacre Arms Himself With Economics

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Wearing a dark suit and sitting in front of a computer screen in a windowless cubicle with financial data stacked on a desk beside him, Li Lu, 29, appeared to be exactly what he is: an ambitious graduate student in business and law at Columbia University working as a summer intern at Allen & Company, a midtown investment firm.
 He'd finished "doing diligence," checking the figures on the sale of Premiere magazine. And now, on Thursday morning, he was awaiting word from his boss about his analysis of a paging company's proposal to raise venture capital. 
 But many in this city are not simply who they appear to be, and few have so dramatic a life cloaked by so conventional a mien as Mr. Li.
 Remarking on the fax machine beside his desk, he noted that the first time he had ever seen one was 1989 in Beijing, where six years ago this weekend he was one of the student leaders of the democracy movement that was crushed in Tiananmen Square.
 The students, he recalled, used their fax to send policy statements to supporters in other cities. In a country where information is controlled by the Government, the fax was a weapon.
 "It was our radio, our T.V.," he said. "When I learned this little machine could do this, I said 'Jesus, we got it.' "
 It was at that moment, perhaps, that Li Lu began consciously negotiating an extraordinary path through history that would transport him from his student dissident life in China, to a harrowing sea crossing to France, conducted by smugglers, and finally to Columbia University, where he arrived barely able to speak English but soaring nonetheless.
 In his mind, his journey continues today, aimed at a return to China, where he hopes to lend his hand eventually in drafting a Chinese constitution. "That would be the dream," he said.
 Though it does not seem so at first, Mr. Li, the young upwardly bound professional in Manhattan, is very much the logical extension of Mr. Li, the Tiananmen Square protester. His theory is that freedom will come to China through the creation of an independent judiciary, which will happen as the Chinese economy grows and the middle class is sizable enough to demand change.
 "It all begins with business," he said. "Through business law, you build an independent judiciary."
 For him, his journey is a path that began before he was born. He is at Columbia, he said, because that is where his grandfather, Zhu Qixian, studied in the 1930's. Zhu, a writer, philosopher and advocate of individual freedom, died in a Chinese prison in 1967, a victim of the Cultural Revolution.
 "I don't know how it happened that he has a grandson who read his books, learned his ideas," Mr. Li said. "But I have always known I wanted to be like him."

 
 
On China's List Of 21 Most Wanted
 This young man pursuing an education in banking, law and technology remains on the Chinese Government's list of 21 most wanted activists. Here, his career path could not be more establishment. Two years ago, his summer job was as a clerk to Judge Pierre N. Leval of United States District Court in Manhattan. Last summer, he was an intern at the law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett.
 This year, he chose Allen & Company for his internship because much of its business involves the communications media. "No dictatorship can be sustained within the context of an information revolution," he said.
 To be a leader of such a movement, he said, "you better be prepared to show people you've been there yourself, that you can back your words with concrete action, that you know what you're talking about."
 Mr. Li said he did not know when he could return to China or whether Deng Xiaoping's imminent death would make that easier.
 In the meantime, he has had something of a hero's welcome from several of New York's elite. Mary Daly, an activist who has organized benefit rock concerts for human rights, introduced him to Sting and Peter Gabriel, the musicians. Jason Epstein, the Random House editor, took him to what Mr. Li now says is the only restaurant he knows in Chinatown. Tomorrow, the anniversary of the massacre, he is scheduled to speak at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights.

 
 
Willingness To Take Hard Route
 He has traveled a jarring distance from the Tiananmen Square hunger strike that he helped organize at age 23 in the weeks before the massacre. As hundreds of Chinese citizens, many of them students, were being killed in the square, he was among the last 3,000 demonstrators to leave, beginning his own harrowing flight to safety.
 At Tiananmen, as can be seen in a new documentary film, "Moving the Mountain," Mr. Li was lean and long-haired, a fiercely hopeful, youthful figure. Today, he is sturdy looking and well groomed, a bespectacled man with a shy demeanor. But he is still fervent.
 Those who know him in this country say that what distinguishes his character is his determination to return to China with tools that he did not have when he left.
 William Theodore deBary, an emeritus professor of East Asian studies, said: "I've been teaching at Columbia since 1948, and I've rarely seen anybody with his willingness to take the hard route. One thing that struck me about him was that he was conscious of the need for some long-term service to society. He wasn't just another escapee exploiting his experiences at Tiananmen Square."
 Mr. Li testified about the massacre in 1990 in Geneva before a United Nations subcommittee on human rights, which issued a resolution rebuking the Chinese Government.
 "He was superb," said a human rights activist who still travels to China and who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "There were 400 or 500 people in the room, 42 countries represented, and you could hear a pin drop."
 It was in the late summer of 1989 -- Mr. Li doesn't remember exactly when -- that he arrived in New York, after months of adventures, first in China and Hong Kong,then at sea, transferring from boat to boat, operated by professional smugglers.
 "I don't know who they are, and they didn't want to know me, either," he said.

 
 
Looking for Tofu, And a Thesis
 He spoke no English and for the first two weeks was so discombobulated in New York, he said, that he has no recollection of where he stayed or where he went. He remembers being unable to eat American food and craving tofu.
 "It was the blandest thing I could think of that I was familiar with," he said. "I was throwing up all the time."
 There were many in the human rights community who helped him, he said. He has had Thanksgiving dinner every year since his arrival with Robert L. Bernstein, the former chairman of Random House Inc., who is chairman of Human Rights Watch.
 The thing he wanted most was to go to Columbia, as his grandfather did. Indeed, his first act when he finally arrived there, Mr. Li said, was to go to the library, seek out his grandfather's thesis -- a comparison of the philosophical writings of John Dewey, Confucius and Dr. Sun Yat-sen -- and steal it. "I'll return it someday, but I figured I could take better care of it," he said.
 Columbia, it turned out, was a nourishing home.
 "For Li Lu the human being, not the dissident, a person dropped into the middle of an alien country, it was a good place to land," said Ms. Daly, the human-rights advocate, who gave Mr. Li a place to live, helped him find money for his education and took him to see the Rolling Stones.
 For his part, Mr. Li, who tends to marvel at the turns his life has taken, said: "Rock and roll was a revelation for me."
 Mr. Li was ushered quickly into a language program at Columbia, where, by all accounts, his progress was remarkable.

 
 
Striking Perspective On Adam Smith
 "My first impression was that he wouldn't survive," said Ruth Levenson, then the assistant provost, who is now retired. "He was all bone. He didn't have much vocabulary. My role was to keep his nose to the grindstone, and in less than a year, he moved into college level courses. His ability to comprehend the discussions and the text was phenomenal."
 Walter P. Metzger, a history professor for 42 years, recalled Li Lu's contribution to his Contemporary Civilization class with admiration.
 "I still remember it, and I don't have an outstanding memory," said Professor Metzger, who retired in 1992. "When we talked about Adam Smith, and the question arose, 'What was Adam Smith trying to advance or defend?' some of the students said he was defending the market economy. Li Lu said he was defending competition. He said the signal mark of a Communist regime was its fear of competition, and that Smith was talking about how an unplanned economy, by virtue of being unplanned, can produce results that a planned economy cannot."
 Much of Mr. Li's life has been chronicled in the movie "Moving the Mountain," which played in New York and Los Angeles last month and opened yesterday in Washington. It was adapted from Mr. Li's memoirs (published in England but not yet in the United States).
 Mr. Li's parents, both scientists, were sent to labor camps at the start of the Cultural Revolution, shortly after his birth in 1966. He lived in the industrial city of Tangshan with a dozen different families, including one that was wiped out in the earthquake of 1976, which killed 242,000 residents. He was reunited with his own family just afterward, when Mao died.
 Mr. Li, who said he adores New York, nonetheless has been somewhat frustrated by Americans who "believe they can understand a completely different situation, a different culture, anything new, by logical inference." Another difference between him and many Americans, he said, is ancestor worship. "Whatever you are is because of what your ancestors have done," he said.
 That is why, at the most fearful juncture of his fearful escape, Li Lu thought of his grandfather. Cast overboard and clinging for several hours to a small, open raft off Hong Kong, Mr. Li didn't expect to survive. When the smugglers returned hours later, he explained, it was only because they did not want to forgo the second half of the fee, which would be paid for his safe delivery.
 "At no time in my life was I more desperate," said Mr. Li. But he kept thinking, he said, of the pride he had felt when he had addressed the Tiananmen demonstrators. He had felt his grandfather speaking through him, and that in a way he had helped Zhu achieve his goal: to outlive Mao.
 "So I thought, at that time," he said, "this is a noble end."

HEADLINE: A New Tack at the Fed: Chin Up! Think Positive!

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2

 BODY:
Even as figures indicating possible economic trouble ahead have piled up in recent weeks, Federal Reserve policy makers have shed their usual gloom and Clinton Administration officials have been steadfastly optimistic.
 Their motivation is clear: The difference in the months ahead between a "soft landing" and a recession may well lie in preventing a sudden drop of business and consumer confidence. 
 If millions of Americans start worrying about the next paycheck or profit and stop spending money, both institutions face a problem. Federal Reserve officials would face the embarrassing task of lowering short-term interest rates just a few months after raising them. President Clinton could face an even tougher re-election fight next year.
 The soothing comments from the Fed come as a growing number of economists now believe that the Federal Reserve may have raised interest rates too high over the last year to fight a threat of inflation that has scarcely materialized. "I think the Fed has overdone it," said Preston Martin, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. "The last one or two increases were not necessary."
 Fed officials acknowledge that their upbeat comments are partly aimed at soothing consumers and business executives, but emphasize that the statements are based on a firm belief that the economy will continue growing. "There is truth to that, but there's truth that we genuinely believe this is a likely scenario," said Alan S. Blinder, the current vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. "The likely scenario is a period of, I would guess, a couple of quarters that look kind of rocky and then a restoration of something that looks like sustainable growth, say 2 1/2 percent."
 Janet L. Yellen, a Federal Reserve governor, was also optimistic today, but cautiously so. "I'm not going to say I'm unconcerned with the risks -- only history will tell us for sure whether the Fed has overdone it," she said.
 These and other comments by top Fed officials suggest that the central bank will be reluctant to cut interest rates unless further economic indicators in the coming weeks and months show a similarly gloomy picture. Although Fed officials declined to discuss specific indicators that might be important, the June unemployment report scheduled for public release on July 7 seems likely to be one of them.
 The Fed's top interest-rate committee is scheduled to meet again on July 5 and 6, and to receive a private copy of the June unemployment report on the afternoon of July 6.
 If the Fed does decide to go beyond jawboning to an actual cut in short-term interest rates, it has one big advantage: Inflation has barely risen this year, either because the Federal Reserve has been successful in its pre-emptive strike on inflation with higher interest rates last year or because the threat of inflation was never serious to begin with.
 Investors in financial markets have shown little concern about inflation and have driven down interest rates for three-month notes to five-year bonds below the level of the overnight rates that the Federal Reserve controls. That gives the Fed some freedom to cut rates soon.
 Yet any sharp reduction in interest rates could also hurt the value of the dollar in international currency markets. Just two days ago, the Federal Reserve joined with other central banks to buy dollars in these markets to support the dollar.
 Any interest rate reduction now would also put Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in the position of pursuing the same stop-and-go monetary policy that he has tried to avoid. Indeed, the point of raising interest rates last year before inflation became a visible threat was to break with the Federal Reserve's past pattern of raising rates too late to stop inflation and then lowering rates too late to stop a recession.
 In interviews today, top Fed officials offered several reasons for their belief that while the economy might slow sharply this summer, it would not fall into a recession. They pointed to the fall in long-term interest rates, which is making mortgages cheaper for would-be home buyers; the rise until today of stock prices, which has left many households with profits to spend, and the likely recovery of American exports this summer after a dip this spring because of financial troubles in Mexico.
 But the same officials also mentioned several concerns: a possible faltering in consumer confidence, a possible weakening of business investment and the large inventories that many companies have accumulated.
 Ms. Yellen said that she honestly felt that the disappearing jobs and falling earnings described by the Labor Department today would not disrupt consumer confidence, although she acknowledged that a loss of confidence could send the economy into recession.
 "A loss of consumer confidence is a mechanism by which that could occur, but I don't believe there is a reason for a loss of consumer confidence," she said. "The fundamentals in the household sector are excellent -- we probably will have a slow quarter or two, but the ingredients for strong consumer spending are in place."
 But if Ms. Yellen and her colleagues are wrong, the Clinton Administration made clear today that its response would be to blame the Federal Reserve for the economy's problems. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich emphasized in an interview today that many of the jobs lost were in manufacturing industries that are sensitive to short-term interest rates. And in a departure from recent practice, the Council of Economic Advisers included an indirect criticism of interest-rate policy in an otherwise upbeat statement today.
 "The current slowing of the economy," the statement said, "is in part the result of the rise in interest rates in 1994, which affected the interest-sensitive sectors such as durable goods and housing."

HEADLINE: Manhattan Emerging Hub Of Multimedia

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, June 2

 BODY:
The Prodigy Services Company, one of the country's leading on-line computer services, is relocating its corporate headquarters from White Plains to the emerging multimedia mecca of lower Manhattan, its president and chief executive, Edward A. Bennett, said today.
 Prodigy's move says much about the way business is conducted in the age of cyberspace. For all the efficiency of communicating by E-mail, modem and fax, even high-tech companies still put a premium on old-fashioned, face-to-face contact. 
 "Yes, this world is about people working anywhere because of computers and connectivity," said Mr. Bennett, who joined Prodigy less than a month ago. "But to have a group of hard-working, dedicated employees living and working in the creative community of New York -- which has become the Silicon Alley in this multimedia world -- is very important to our future."
 Mr. Bennett said he hoped to spruce up Prodigy's on-line offerings by relocating the company's programmers, producers and marketing executives to lower Manhattan, where they can draw on the talents of a growing subculture of graphic artists, writers, software designers and film makers. The area, called Silicon Alley by some, Multimedia Gulch by others, is fast becoming a national center of the fledgling multimedia industry, which takes animation, video and music and combines them into CD-ROM's and virtual reality.
 Prodigy, which has two million subscribers and is jointly owned by the International Business Machines Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company, is struggling to keep pace with its two leading competitors, America Online and Compuserve. The on-line landscape is expected to become even more crowded later this year, when the Microsoft Corporation and AT&T are scheduled to introduce similar services.
 Of the 550 employees who work at Prodigy's leased headquarters in downtown White Plains, about half will be relocated to Manhattan by early 1996, Mr. Bennett said. The rest will continue to work in White Plains.
 Mr. Bennett said he had no plans for further layoffs -- the company let go nearly 400 employees in 1993 and 1994 -- nor did he intend to move the company's mainframe computers from Yorktown, in the northern part of the county.
 Mr. Bennett, who was interviewed by cellular phone between visits to prospective offices, said he had yet to decide on a specific location, but was looking in TriBeCa, the Flatiron District and SoHo. He said that his own circumstances -- he lives in Chelsea but is planning a move to the West Village -- had no influence on his plans for the company.
 Word of Prodigy's move, first reported today in the Gannett Suburban Newspapers, drew mixed reactions among analysts who follow the industry.
 Peter Krasilovsky, who follows on-line services for Arlen Communications in Bethesda, Md., said he doubted that the move's effect would be more than cosmetic.
 "I think his mission there is to remake Prodigy into a more youth-oriented service," Mr. Krasilovsky said of Mr. Bennett, who is a former president of the VH-1 music video network. "Today's Prodigy is more of a family service that might appeal to watchers of 'My Three Sons.' He'd like to capture more of the 'Beavis and Butt-head' crowd."
 But Michael Rinzel, an analyst at Jupiter Communications in Manhattan, said he thought it was essential for Prodigy, which is a decade old, to be in New York City if it hoped to develop into a world-class information technology company. As part of its transformation, Prodigy is expected to dress up its on-line presentations with an array of new graphic illustrations.
 "This medium is starting to reach the level of a mass market," Mr. Rinzel said. "To get the right talent to produce a higher level of product, it's becoming more important to come back to the major cities where entertainment and information is produced."
 Prodigy's move is the latest in a year of comings and goings in Westchester County commercial real estate.
 Since last June, Nynex has announced that it would move its executive offices from White Plains to Manhattan; Mastercard International has prepared to move its headquarters in the opposite direction, from Manhattan to Purchase, and I.B.M. has said that it will abandon its glass-and-concrete honeycomb in Armonk so that it can build a more intimate headquarters just down the road.
 Local economic development officials and brokers described Prodigy as one of Westchester's largest commercial tenants, and conceded that the departure of its headquarters was a blow to the area's corporate self-esteem.
 Mr. Bennett said he regretted any pain he might be causing, but said he was intent on tapping fresh sources of creativity elsewhere.
 "White Plains can supply it," he said, "but I think you can do a better job and be more empowered by being in New York."

HEADLINE: Remarks on Airport Link by Port Authority Head Surprise Albany

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The nomination of George J. Marlin to head the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey nearly failed earlier this year because he lacked government experience and had a reputation as being combative and outspoken. Three months on the job, Mr. Marlin is running into that same criticism, only this time from an unlikely source: the Pataki administration, which sponsored his appointment.
 Senior aides to Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that the Governor and his top transportation advisers, including Charles A. Gargano and Louis Tomson, were surprised and angered by Mr. Marlin's comments on Wednesday that the Port Authority had abandoned a plan to build a 22-mile railway between Manhattan and its airports in Queens. 
 Mr. Marlin said the Port Authority had scuttled the proposal because of rising costs and was considering alternatives like building just one section of the railway. Although authority officials had been saying for months that the full plan was in trouble, Mr. Marlin was the first to say publicly that the agency would not go forward with it.
 The Pataki administration's displeasure did not stem from the decision to kill the project, a move that had seemed increasingly likely in recent months, but rather from how he overstepped his purview by announcing it without having first received the Governor's permission, officials said.
 "Not only did he not have our support, he didn't give us any notice," said a senior aide to Mr. Pataki who agreed to speak on condition that his name not be used. The aide said he was astonished by Mr. Marlin's statements, adding that he feared that the Governor would have to monitor Mr. Marlin closely because his inexperience appeared to be showing.
 Mr. Marlin did not respond yesterday to messages left for him.
 After he was nominated, Mr. Marlin was attacked by some former and current authority officials because he had never worked in government and had little management experience. Mr. Marlin, a longtime executive in the municipal-finance industry, ran as the Conservative Party candidate for New York City mayor in 1993 on a platform that stressed conservative positions on social issues.
 His political style at the time is perhaps best captured by his writings, in which he railed against the "Albany gang," meaning politicians from both parties who, he said, had no fiscal discipline.
 "This is truly an example of grassroots tyranny," he wrote in an article in The Bond Buyer about the state's budget practices. "In the name of 'progress,' the hacks arrogantly ignore the will of the people and the Constitution. And on the rare occasion when they get nailed, what's their attitude to the voters? 'In your face!' "
 Apparently aware that he would be scrutinized in his first year at the Port Authority, Mr. Marlin had declined interviews with reporters until this week, saying that he needed additional time to familiarize himself with the agency's vast operations, which include the three major airports, bridges, tunnels, the World Trade Center, marine terminals and the PATH rail lines.
 When he did meet with reporters on Wednesday, his remarks seemed as conciliatory and tentative as those in the 1993 campaign were provocative and witty. He said repeatedly he would not take stands on issues like toll increases for bridges and tunnels until he had studied them further.
 His only mishap, it appeared, was in assuming that his predecessor, Stanley Brezenoff, had announced before leaving the authority that the agency would not pursue the full 22-mile rail plan.
 Effectively, only the governors of New York and New Jersey can kill the rail proposal, and they have not formally done so. Though it is highly unlikely that the Port Authority will ever build the full 22-mile line, officials in the Pataki administration said they wanted to delay the formal announcement of its demise to put the best face on what is clearly a blow to efforts to improve access to airports.
 In other words, Pataki officials said, the authority should have had another proposal ready to take the sting from the announcement that the 22-mile plan was, as Mr. Marlin put it on Wednesday, "dead."
 A person more seasoned in the often fractious politics of agencies like the Port Authority would not have made that mistake, said a Port Authority board member who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If he had more experience in the public sector," the board member said, "he would have cleared this with the Governor before he said it publicly."
 The aide who oversees the Port Authority for Governor Pataki, Mr. Tomson, declined to comment.
 Mr. Gargano, who is Mr. Pataki's top economics adviser and a board member of the Port Authority, declined to say whether Mr. Marlin had erred. He emphasized that there had been no final decision on the railway, although he expressed strong reservations about the price for the full 22 miles, which could run as high as $5 billion to $7 billion.
 "The statement that the project is dead, this is not a statement that was made by the Governor's office or by my office," Mr. Gargano said.
 Such assurances seemed intended to blunt the response to Mr. Marlin's comments, which were assailed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other municipal officials like the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman. They had accused the Port Authority of favoring projects in New Jersey.
 "I am very, very hopeful that this does not reflect the thinking of the Governor and that the Governor was just as surprised at this precipitous action, which is harmful to both New York City and New York State," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday.
 He added that he thought that it might be time to dismantle the Port Authority, contending that it wasted "enormous amounts of money" on items like executive salaries.
 Yet even as Mr. Pataki's advisers were backpedaling, other Port Authority officials acknowledged that formal cancellation or not, Mr. Marlin was basically correct.
 "We are not going to be building anything 22 miles long any time soon," said the chairwoman of the authority, Kathleen A. Donovan, who was appointed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. "That is not going to happen. 'We just don't have the money for it."

HEADLINE: Drop in Jobs Shifts Outlook For Economy

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
Bad luck for many Americans turned into good luck for others yesterday as Wall Street learned that the number of people with jobs plunged last month, and reacted by pushing interest rates down sharply.
 That was good news for consumers, who will face smaller interest payments on their mortgages and car loans, analysts said. But it is a mixed blessing for companies, which may gain from lower interest rates but lose as a slowing economy hurts sales and earnings. Indeed, the stock market kept changing its mind about the news, falling, soaring, and falling again and ending generally down. [Page 35.] 
 Yesterday marked a sharp shift in many investors' thinking about the economy, interest rates and, perhaps, equities. "We had been expecting the U.S. economy to slow, but we didn't expect it to go from 80 miles an hour to 0 miles an hour," said Lawrence L. Kreicher, chief economist for Alliance Capital Management, a large New York money manager. He called the employment drop "just boggling."
 The number that startled economists across the country was the 101,000 decline in the number of people on payrolls in May, according to the Labor Department. The decrease did not mean unemployment went up; the percentage of Americans looking for work actually fell, to 5.7 percent from 5.8 percent.
 But it did signal a contraction in employment, and therefore weakness in the economy. So much so that Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist for the Wall Street firm CS First Boston, who had been expecting the economy to grow a little in the second quarter, cut her forecast to zero -- at best.
 And she joined some other economists in predicting that Federal Reserve policy makers would cut short-term interest rates by as much as half a percentage point at their next meeting on July 5 and 6. "I can't see what the downside is if they do it," she said. "The downside is much worse if this thing falls into a recession and they get blamed."
 The possibility of recession -- what Wall Street coyly calls the R-word -- and the prospect of a Fed easing, were clearly behind the bond market's sharp rally. The yield on the long-term Treasury bond fell as low as 6.44 percent, from 6.61 percent, before climbing back to 6.53 percent. [Page 44.]
 That is the lowest yield since mid-February 1994, shortly after the Federal Reserve began raising rates to slow economic growth and prevent inflation from heating up.
Coming on the heels of May's steep declines, yesterday's drop in rates will probably make it possible for more Americans to buy their first homes, and will allow others to save money on their mortgage payments by refinancing. "I think we'll start seeing companies offering 7.5 percent mortgage rates," said David A. Lereah, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. Rates now average about 7.75, he said.
 Car loans, and indeed all kinds of borrowing, could become more affordable. The Southwest Bank of St. Louis lowered its prime rate, a bellwether that affects many corporate and consumer rates, to 8.5 percent from 9 percent, though analysts said few other banks were likely to follow suit unless and until the Fed acted.
 The dollar initially fell against the mark and the yen, as traders worried that lower interest rates in America would repel foreign investors. The dollar then staged a sharp recovery, on the expectation that governments would act to prop it up. Those gains eroded, however, and the dollar ended down against the yen, though up slightly against the mark.
 But the stock market could not make up its mind about whether the economic news was good or bad. This is always a tricky question for equity investors, because when the economy slows down, so do corporate profits, and that is bad for stock prices. On the other hand, a weak economy usually means lower interest rates, which help corporate profits and attract investors into the stock market.
 As the day began, the Dow Jones industrial average fell out of bed, dropping more than 40 points. But the Dow, an average of 30 blue-chip stocks, quickly recovered. The gain was egged on by market gurus like Barton Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley's money management arm, who told the firm's clients to buy stocks.
 "I think the market's reaction to the weak employment numbers was crazy," he said later in the day. "The Street is worried about lower earnings, but much lower interest rates are much more important."
 The stock market's sunny mood did not last, and at the end of the day turned abruptly darker; the Dow closed down 28.36 points at 4,444.39. The Standard & Poor's 500 index of large companies also ended the day down, although issues of smaller companies, as measured by the Russell 2,000 index, ended the day with modest gains.
 But yesterday's losses did not wipe out the market's gains earlier in the week, and Dow ended the four-day stretch up 75 points. Stocks' strength in the face of bad economic news strikes some analysts as unrealistic, but they note that the market has a dynamic of its own, apart from the overall economy.
 "It's the press of money," said Michael Metz, chief strategist for Oppenheimer & Company. Huge sums are concentrated in mutual funds, and for portfolio managers, "the wisdom so far has been to spend that money as soon as you can," he said. That appetite for stocks, combined with a supply shrunk by corporate buybacks and takeovers, overwhelm economic factors, he said.
 But that does not mean the market will completely ignore the economic outlook -- indeed, it would not be healthy if it did so, said Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates. Concern about recession "is in the background," he said. "Sometimes it is Recession with a capital R, sometimes it is recession with a small r."

HEADLINE: James Shapiro, 85, Innovator In the Home Sewing Industry

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
James J. Shapiro, who helped revolutionize the home sewing industry as a founder and president of the Simplicity Pattern Company, died yesterday at his home at the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan. He was 85.
The cause of death was cancer, said his younger brother, Robert M. Shapiro. 
 Mr. Shapiro, who was born in Russia in 1909 and brought to the United States as a toddler, was a teen-ager in 1927 when his father, Joseph M. Shapiro, a magazine ad salesman, had an idea that would transform their lives.
At the time, producing dress patterns for the home sewing market was the exclusive province of McCall's and other women's magazines, including one long-forgotten publication that the elder Mr. Shapiro worked for in New York.
When the magazine failed, the father, recognizing the strong appeal of its pattern offerings, decided to form an independent pattern company with his elder son as his partner.
Given the entrenched competition of the women's magazines, the idea was daring, but as implemented by the Shapiros, it had an irresistible appeal.
For the first time, women interested in making their own clothes did not have to buy a magazine, then send off for a pattern that might cost as much as 25 cents. Instead, they could riffle through an open-top box on the counter of a local store, pay a dime for a pattern and, as often as not, buy the required fabric in the same store.
As a result, Simplicity, which started off using a single designer and relying on commercial printers, soon dominated the home sewing market. At its peak in the 1970's, the company, which went public in the 1930's, had 4,000 employees, its own paper mill and printing operations, factories in several countries, an extensive catalogue business, 20,000 retail outlets in the United States alone, and a flourishing sideline supplying patterns to fashion magazines.
It also sold more than 150 million patterns a year, accounting for more than half the international home sewing market. It was, in effect, the world's largest dress manufacturer, one whose vast home-based work force actually paid the company for the privilege of turning its patterns into finished garments.
James Shapiro was given much of the credit for the success.
"He was a marketing genius," Sidney Greenman, a former Simplicity director and general counsel, said yesterday, noting that it had been Mr. Shapiro who conceived the idea of enlisting chain stores as outlets and who then signed up Woolworth's, a major coup in the 1930's.
He also created a full-scale education department, which supplied high school home economic departments with equipment so millions of teen-age girls could learn to sew using Simplicity patterns.
"We were the first to introduce color," Robert Shapiro said. "We were the first to use photography, the first to go to four colors, the first do to a lot of things."
Robert Shapiro acknowledged that his brother had been an appropriately demanding executive in a business in which perfection must be standard (women buying patterns cannot try on a dress before buying), but he denied a widespread report that his brother had fired him as company president. "I retired," he said, citing failing eyesight.
After selling most of his stock in the company, James Shapiro himself retired in 1976, which turned out to be the peak year for the industry. It has shrunk considerably as women have flooded into the work force.
In addition to his brother, Mr. Shapiro is survived by a daughter, Paula Lund of Jupiter, Fla.; two grandchildren, and five great grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: James J. Shapiro (1968)

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Jump on U.S. Labor Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities leaped higher yesterday, as a Government labor report stunned economists, showing a loss of 101,000 jobs in May in contrast to an expected gain of 166,000.
 Doug Burtnick, senior analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said, "The data cleared out any thoughts that the economy really isn't slowing down," and consequently traders priced the slowdown into the bond market, which, hating inflation, tends to rise as the economy slows. 
 Another analyst quipped, "The batteries were recharged, and the ever-ready bond rally continues." The latest data raised the probability that the Federal Reserve could ease credit. Some market participants said that rates could be trimmed a quarter of a percentage point between now and the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee right after the Fourth of July.
 With some analysts seeing a recession as a possibility, the 30-year bond rose 16/32 points, to a price of 1148/32 , for a yield of 6.53 percent, down from 6.61 percent on Thursday. By the close of the New York market, investors taking profits gave back more than half the day's gains.
 Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, however, takes a more cautious view. "The sharp and unexpected decline in payroll employment during May strongly suggests that the second quarter's sluggish economic growth involves more than just inventory correction, and that it may not be limited solely to the industrial sector," he said.
 "At the same time," Mr. Fine continued, "signs of recession are hard to find, and economic growth during the second half of the year is still pointing to a soft landing." He said this certainly did not preclude a Fed easing, but a move in that direction seemed a little premature. The Fed is likely to be very cautious, Mr. Fine said, and will want to examine data for both June and the early part of the third quarter before undertaking its first easing since late 1992.
 "While the bond market has clearly built in future Fed easing," Mr. Fine said, "the Fed does not have to necessarily ease in July for the bond market to hold on to its gains. So long as the market believes that the next Fed move is ease, the rally is justified."
 He predicts the Fed is likely to move a quarter of a percentage in its initial easing move, which will come at the earliest in August. "If an inflation-fighting Fed moves more quickly and to a greater extent when the economy is heating up, it stands to reason that the Fed is likely to move a bit more cautiously and to a somewhat lesser extent when the economy is slowing down, particularly if a recession is not foreseen," he said.
 Mr. Burtnick of Technical Data said the short end of the market was prepared for an ease of more than a half a percentage point sometime this summer, or in the early fall -- "a huge switch from just a couple of months ago when the Street expected the Fed to keep tightening."
 Treasuries have outperformed most of the market for the last few sessions, Mr. Burtnick noted, and as a result mortgage and corporate traders have worked their way out of bad hedges by buying Government securities.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Steadier With Traders Wary of Further Interventions

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady yesterday against most leading currencies, rebounding from early losses as currency traders became concerned that central banks might again intervene to support the value of the dollar.
 A surprise round of dollar-buying by the Federal Reserve and a dozen other central banks sent the dollar sharply higher on Wednesday, punishing investors who had bet against the dollar by selling it for other currencies. 
 Traders still smarting from that attack were hesitant to push the dollar too low today after two reports provided more evidence of weakness in the American economy.
 "Everybody sold dollars this morning, but people were quick to buy them back for fear of Fed intervention," said Paul Farrell, manager of strategic currency trading at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
 In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar edged up to 1.4089 German marks from 1.4055 marks on Thursday. The dollar slipped to 84.32 yen from 84.65 yen. Earlier in the day, the dollar fell as low as 1.3928 marks and 83.50 yen.
 News that a United States F-16 jet fighter flying a NATO mission was shot down over Serb-held northern Bosnia yesterday contributed to the dollar's recovery, traders said. Investors sometimes buy dollars as a haven in times of international turmoil.
 The downing of the jet "certainly brought the dollar up when it came across the screen," said Jim Raphael, currency trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City. "It's something everyone is thinking about."
 The dollar fell in early New York trading after the Labor Department reported a sharp drop in the number of workers on payrolls in May. The data fueled speculation that the Federal Reserve might be compelled to cut interest rates to revive the economy. A rate cut could hurt the dollar by making deposits denominated in the currency less attractive.
 "It's clear the economy is slowing much more quickly than expected, and that's being perceived as not good for the dollar," said Earl Johnson, foreign exchange adviser at the Bank of Montreal/Harris Bank in Chicago.
 While concern about another Fed dollar-buying spree helped the dollar yesterday, that supportive effect might not last much longer given the slew of recent economic reports suggesting slowing growth in the United States, traders said.
 "Right now the dollar is under a magnifying glass, and the numbers coming in just don't look good," Mr. Raphael of NatWest said.

HEADLINE: Bosnia: Not America's War

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration drops hints about the possible involvement of United States ground troops in Bosnia, the White House and some Republicans have started resorting to cold-war shorthand about NATO solidarity and the need for American leadership in Europe.
War is too important to be driven by such sloganeering, as the downing of an American F-16 fighter plane over Bosnia yesterday makes clear. The real issue in Bosnia is not one of the United States living up to its NATO responsibilities nor of continued American engagement in European security. Neither of those is in any doubt. The relevant question is whether the United States has a strong enough interest in the outcome of the Bosnian conflict to risk its troops in ground combat. In the view of this page, it does not. 
 At several points in recent history, special circumstances have invested the fate of the Balkans with worldwide significance. Today, no such circumstances prevail. The United States has no interest beyond a humanitarian one in the outcome of Bosnia's bloody three-year war.
When Austria-Hungary and czarist Russia wrestled for influence in the Balkans early in this century, nationalist quarrels there sparked the First World War. A generation later, when Hitler dominated Europe, threatening Britain and the United States, the Allies supported Marshal Tito's Partisans as part of their military strategy.
After the war an ideological iron curtain descended across Europe, as Churchill put it, "from Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic." The Balkans again stood on the front lines of global conflict. That gave Washington a strong stake in keeping Tito's Yugoslavia outside the Soviet orbit.
The Hapsburgs, the czars and the German Kaiser are long gone. The Nazis were defeated 50 years ago. Tito's Yugoslav federation has been torn apart. The cold war has been over for nearly a decade. Moscow now struggles to control outlying areas of the Russian Republic and constitutes no threat to Trieste. Britain, France and Germany, whose clashes on the western front helped draw the United States into two world wars, are now partners in the European Union and NATO.
These changes do not mean the United States can return to the isolationism of the Republic's early days. For more than a century, American prosperity has been premised on peace and prosperity in Western Europe and access to the growing markets of East Asia. Without Middle East oil, the United States economy would grind to a halt. Upheaval in Latin America or Canada could send refugees streaming across this country's borders and even threaten its physical security.
But while America's interests are global, its ties to Europe are especially strong. NATO is the United States' most extensive and most binding alliance. It integrates American forces into joint training and command structures and solemnly commits Washington to come to the military defense of other member countries if they come under attack.
That pledge remains fully reliable. It does not, however, extend to the automatic protection of allied military units when they operate outside the NATO area. Britain and France and other nations involved in the U.N. operation in Bosnia have the military capacity to reinforce and protect their own troops. Should they need to evacuate those troops, the United States stands ready to help. Otherwise, American ground forces should be kept strictly outside the conflict.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Investors in Withdrawal From Stock Funds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Investors pulled money out of equity funds in the week ended Wednesday as stocks hit record highs, AMG Data Services said yesterday. It was the first weekly net withdrawal of assets from these funds in four months.
 Equity funds lost a net $107 million for the week. 
 "Investors want to maintain more of a neutral strategy because of the uncertainty in the economy and the prospects of a soft landing," said Michael Kristin, an account executive at Stein Roe Mutual Funds in Chicago, which manages about $25 billion.
 AMG, a company in Arcata, Calif., that tracks cash flows in the mutual fund industry, said the asset decline in stock funds was the first since the week of Jan. 25.
 Investors, who invested as much as $2.1 billion a week into stock funds during April, have pared their purchases of stock funds steadily since then. Net purchases of equity funds totalled $1.2 billion in the week ended May 24.
 Much of the decline for the latest week was caused by money flowing out of international funds, AMG said. Investors yanked $238.9 million out of funds that invest in stocks outside the United States.

HEADLINE: Deficit Threatens America's Treasures

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Other Countries Thrive on Unbalanced Budgets" (letter, May 29) by Walter J. Moore:
Since the 1980's the annual budget deficit of the United States has been growing faster than its gross domestic product. The main problem for the United States is that the money that must be borrowed by the Government because of the deficit is being used to pay for current expenses, not for capital expenditures, such as the building and repair of highways and bridges and other infrastructure. 
 The deficit has got so out of control that Congress is now considering selling off precious assets such as the Presidio, described as "a spectacular section of the waterfront" in San Francisco (news article, May 29).
Most of the other countries mentioned by Mr. Moore are borrowing money to finance the purchase of productive assets. Italy is an exception. The Italian national debt surpassed 100 percent of gross domestic product at the end of 1990 -- interest on the debt is now the largest item in Italy's budget.
The interest the United States pays on debt is also our biggest budget item after "entitlements," which consume 52 percent of the budget, and the military, which consumes 22 percent. If not for interest on the debt, which is about 20 percent of the annual budget, our budget could be put almost into balance.
Mr. Moore is correct when he states that all the mentioned countries provide more in social services than the United States, but a main reason is that none of those countries spend anywhere near the percentage of their budgets that the United States spends on its military. The countries of Asia and Europe that have prospered under the umbrella of the American military got and continue to get a mostly free ride.
Are there any others out there who recall the story of the grasshopper and the ants? While the grasshopper relaxed in the warm summer sun, the ants industriously stocked up on food for the winter. When the snow, hail and sleet set in, the grasshopper found himself cold and hungry, while the ants were safely ensconced in their tree house, where music played and food warmed on an open fire.
For decades the United States has been acting like a grasshopper. The time has come to begin acting like ants.
 
GEORGE RAYMOND TYNDALL
Los Angeles, May 30, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: ALBANY'S BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
Pataki and State Legislators Say They Have Agreed on a Budget

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 2

 BODY:
Sixty-three days after the start of the fiscal year, Gov. George E. Pataki and the state's legislative leaders concluded their tortuous negotiations today, declaring a final agreement on a state budget that by at least one critical measure will reduce state spending for the first time in a generation.
The budget, on which both houses of the Legislature began to vote this afternoon, will also cut income and business taxes and impose modest new restrictions on welfare recipients. 
 The finished product reflects a drastic reversal of New York's fiscal traditions. For nearly four decades, governors of both parties have imposed steep taxes in an effort to sustain generous spending on social programs -- while at the same time they created structural deficits year after year.
While this year's budget is not everything that the state's new Republican Governor wanted, it largely follows the blueprint he sketched in last year's campaign, and in the budget he proposed in February.
It also sets a pattern of austerity for at least the next two years of the Pataki administration, and possibly far beyond. Because the cost of the tax cuts will grow significantly from now through 1997, and because the Governor did not succeed in cutting state spending as much as he wanted, many fiscal analysts believe that next year's budget battle may make this one look like a minor skirmish.
The impact of the state budget on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's fiscal plans for New York City is unclear. The Mayor was relying heavily on help from the state to balance the city's budget, but it seems clear today that the new state budget will leave a significant hole in the Mayor's own proposed budget for the fiscal year that starts on July 1.
Although Mr. Pataki said he was pleased with today's budget agreement, he acknowledged his need to seek deeper cuts in the future.
"We are going to have to have fiscal restraint in this state government going forward because we have not had it in the past," he told reporters. "We have made an enormous start this year, but we are going to continue to look for ways to reduce the cost of government."
Mr. Pataki said that the state's general fund budget, which consists of revenues from state taxes and fees that are not committed to specific purposes, would drop by 1 percent, or $334 million less than last year's $33.1 billion. The Governor had proposed a 3.5 percent cut in general fund spending, a drop of about $1.17 billion.
That 1 percent decrease would be the first decline in general fund spending since 1943, according to Mr. Pataki's budget division. Spending also decreased in 1990, but only after the Legislature was forced to make midyear cuts in the budget as the recession dried up state revenues.
This year's total state spending, however, would increase by about $1.5 billion, or 2.5 percent, to $63.5 billion. That figure includes Federal funds that pass through the state budget and other money that is not included in the general fund. Mr. Pataki had proposed an increase of less than 1 percent.
State officials could not be specific about a third calculation that is used to measure the budget, known as state funds. But that figure, which includes the general fund, debt service, capital projects, and several special dedicated revenue funds, is expected to remain flat at $42 billion, said Patricia A. Woodworth, Mr. Pataki's budget director.
The officials could not be specific about the aid to New York City either.
Mr. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver both estimated that Mr. Giuliani would receive about $650 million of the $1.05 billion in financial assistance he was seeking from Albany. That would leave the Mayor $400 million short.
And City Council officials warned that some of the savings that Mr. Giuliani expects from state cuts in Medicaid and welfare programs may be unrealistic as well. State cuts in those so-called entitlement programs save local governments money, because required local spending is pegged to state spending.
Assembly officials said that virtually all the savings in the state budget for Mr. Giuliani would come from the Medicaid and welfare cuts. The Mayor apparently will not receive any items he lobbied for on a last-minute trip to Albany last week, including unrestricted revenue sharing for the city and state money for prekindergarten programs for handicapped children.
Speaking to reporters at City Hall this afternoon, Mr. Giuliani declined to comment on how the city had fared in the state budget or to speculate on how he would close the budget gap left by Albany. He said he would do so only after the state budget had been enacted.
After Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, announced their agreement in a series of news conferences, the Democratic-controlled Assembly and the Republican-controlled Senate began passing budget bills this afternoon and evening. Both houses enacted the tax cut package and the part of the budget that finances state agencies. Some bills are still being drafted, however, and the voting is expected to conclude on Monday or Tuesday after a weekend break.
Today's agreement did not seem to heal many of the passionate political and ideological divisions that prolonged the negotiations, as the Assembly floor debate on the tax cuts demonstrated.
"This is a sad day for God Almighty," said Deputy Speaker Arthur O. Eve, a Buffalo Democrat. "God is not pleased today. So I ask Him to forgive each and every one of you."
Assemblyman Philip B. Healey, a Massapequa Republican, responded: "We're trying to encourage people to have jobs; don't leave New York State. If you want to quote the Bible, that's what St. Paul said: 'Everyone must work, and then we'll have a great future.' "
Legislators from both parties broke into muffled laughter, with several asking, "St. Paul said that?"
Mr. Pataki said the arduous negotiations, in which Mr. Silver strove to restore much of the money that the Governor proposed to cut, had produced "dramatic change."
"I am extremely confident that this begins the process -- it is not the end -- but begins the process of restoring people's confidence in the future of this state and restoring economic opportunity for this state," he said.
Among the final issues the leaders negotiated was a decision to review major changes in the state's sentencing laws after 10 years. A commission will evaluate the impact of the changes, particularly on the demand for prison space, and the Legislature will have to vote then to extend the laws.
Mr. Pataki said the budget would include $900 million in nonrecurring revenues -- or one-shot revenues, as they are called -- up from the $650 million he proposed in his original budget. Credit rating agencies and other fiscal monitors have criticized the state's reliance on those measures.
In another last-minute maneuver certain to generate criticism, the leaders agreed to help balance the budget, and those of local governments, by borrowing $230 million from a $360 million fund that is supposed to be used to increase pensions for state and local government retirees, legislative aides said. The remaining money in the fund will be used to increase pensions.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, the sole trustee of the state's pension fund, said the move "sounds like another gimmick, another one-shot, another example of the kind of fiscal irresponsibility that has given New York State the lowest credit rating in the nation."

HEADLINE: Russian Wise Guys

BYLINE: By Serge Schmemann; Serge Schmemann, a former New York Times bureau chief in Moscow, is completing a book about Russia and will soon begin an assignment as bureau chief in Jerusalem.

 BODY:

COMRADE CRIMINAL
Russia's New Mafiya.
By Stephen Handelman.
398 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $27.50. 
THE image of Russia has taken many a twist since those now-distant days when Boris Yeltsin defied Communist die-hards from the top of a tank. We have had Russia the starving giant, Russia threatened by civil war, Russia lurching toward fascism and Russia the empire rampant, crudely crushing Chechnya. Now we have Russia the state hijacked by organized crime. The picture is of hit men with zoot suits and Kalashnikovs operating brazenly in the heart of Moscow, of politicians amassing huge fortunes in bribes and army generals peddling anything from rifles to nukes.
This image, Stephen Handelman argues in "Comrade Criminal," his chilling study of what the Russians call the "mafiya," is deserved. Virtually every small business across Russia pays protection money to some gang; former Communist bosses snap up lucrative properties; vast fortunes in raw materials are smuggled out through the porous borders of former Soviet states; ministries and municipal governments peddle property and favors. Some 30 million unregistered firearms circulate in the former Soviet states -- one million of them in Moscow alone.
Moscow has become the new international Klondike, Mr. Handelman says. Shady millionaires in glossy suits with broad shoulders cruise about in motorcades of imported sedans with armies of bodyguards; foreigners in search of fast fortunes pack hotels; casinos and glitzy nightclubs sprout like mushrooms through the city center (replete with metal detectors and hulking bruisers at the door); guns are everywhere, often smoking. "The second great Russian revolution of this century," Mr. Handelman writes, "is awash in corruption, opportunism and crime."
A REPORTER who was in Moscow from 1987 to 1992 for The Toronto Star, Mr. Handelman takes us into places that few know of, and where even fewer have ventured. He meets with racketeers and gunmen, police officials and politicians, new millionaires and former dissidents. He guides us around the roots of Russian crime -- the old Soviet prison culture and the tolkachi, the specialists who found short cuts through socialist inefficiency; the greedy commissars and the Communist Party's secret bank accounts; the state monopolies that emerged as private monopolies. The problem, Mr. Handelman warns, is not only Russia's: Russian hit men have struck in London; Russian raw materials smuggled out of the country have played havoc with Western markets; Russia's underground millionaires are acquiring pricey chunks of Western real estate; Russian arms and nuclear materials have surfaced the world over.
This book is a sobering and chastening voyage for those in the West who were, in Mr. Handelman's words, "quick to claim 'victory' in the cold war." Yet terrible as Russia's crime problem may be, it has remained a confusing phenomenon for Westerners and Russians alike. For one thing, street crime, though far more visible and prevalent than under Communist rule, is no worse in Russia's cities than in many major cities elsewhere (a reasonably careful visitor is probably safer in Moscow than in New York). For another, Russians reared in Soviet ethics, which classified any form of private enterprise as evil, are quick to label any group dedicated to making money "mafiya."
The problem is that technically they're right. The collapse of the Soviet Union has left such a legal and economic mess behind that I doubt whether anyone who has lived in Russia in recent years, much less anyone who has tried to do business there, has not broken one law or another. A legal system constructed for a socialist police state has proved hopelessly inadequate for modern commerce -- there simply were no laws for facilitating private enterprise, and courts designed to handle domestic quarrels and street crimes were not prepared to handle complex economic cases. At the same time, the torrents of decrees and laws issued over the past three years by the President and his parliaments have often been crude, contradictory and utterly inconsistent. The inevitable result: Russians, as a wise man noted in the last century, "compensate for the severity of their laws by disregarding them."
In general, it is hard to imagine a society less hospitable to modern commerce than the old Soviet Union was. Everything belonged to "the people," and therefore to no one. The structures of efficient business -- banking, communications, credit, computerization -- were rudimentary. Money was less useful in obtaining scarce goods than were connections or rank, and rampant inefficiency and shortages relegated a major portion of the nation's economic activity to a gray zone.
In fact, when Communism crumbled, I often thought that the spread of crime and corruption was less amazing than the fact that the whole system did not collapse into anarchy. But Moscow today is in the grip of a dramatic boom of building and restoration. New shops and hotels open daily. More and more Russians are being drawn into private enterprise, many in legitimate businesses. However they obtained their fortunes, the newly rich are investing in schools, in culture, in the restoration of old buildings, in politics.
That, in the end, is the most intriguing question posed by Russia today: How is it, with all the crime and chaos, that most Russians are really not doing so badly? Is it like some Ponzi scheme, an illusion that will culminate in disaster? Is it a robber-baron stage of capital accumulation that will develop into a real market economy?
MR. HANDELMAN may be wise not to prophesy too much. Russia is a moving target, and it moves quickly and unpredictably. He does note hopefully that the "frontier capitalism" of Russia demonstrates at least that "ingenuity and grit are very much alive behind the old Soviet borders," and that "the second Russian revolution is not over." But more often his reaction is one of dismay -- he speaks repeatedly of that second revolution as having been hijacked or betrayed by "comrade criminal."
Dismay and hope, indeed, are the stock reactions to what is happening in Russia. Dismay, because so many in the West were certain that a red-blooded democracy was lurking just behind the cold Communist facade, only waiting to be loosed, and instead we find politicians still locked in old Soviet habits, entrepreneurs prepared to kill and steal, and a nation suspicious of our ways. Hope, because once we began to appreciate how far Russia has to go, we realized how far it had already come.
It is that tension that renders Russia's emergence from despotism so gripping, and that leaves us, after concluding Mr. Handelman's tour through the underworld, still hungry for more guidance on its meaning. Mr. Handelman has done a masterly and very courageous job of reporting, and he reveals a side of the new Russia that we overlook at our peril. But it is precisely because Russia is moving so fast, and in so many complex ways, that even something as sinister as organized crime must be treated both as a blight and as a clue.
 
 
 
THIEVES WORLD
 For decades, the prisons of the Soviet Union had been home to the world's most extraordinary criminal society. For almost a century, it had been known as vorovskoi mir, the Thieves World. From their cells, crime bosses planned and organized their operations across the country. . . . Lieutenants, often called brodyagi (vagabonds), conducted formal dealings with the outside. The so-called vagabond brotherhood provided the network for transmitting orders and collecting profits. In the Soviet era, the gangs operating from their prison bases were no threat to ordinary civilians. Their enemy and rival was the Communist Party, for which they bore an old and longstanding grudge.
Once the Soviet Union had collapsed, however, criminal organizations emerged from their lofty isolation. It was no longer necessary to guard against Communist infection. A modern gang leader could manage his empire from outside prison walls without shame; in fact, the new opportunities available for profit made this nearly a requirement. And even for those who remained inside, there was no risk of embarrassment or censure in bargaining with straight society. Like caged lions who suddenly realized their strength, the leaders of the Thieves World were ready to take what they considered their rightful place in the pecking order of the New Russia.
 From "Comrade Criminal."

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ATHENA, by John Banville. (Knopf, $22.) In this wickedly mannerist novel, a murderer turned "art expert" runs smack into his own past when he has to catalogue a batch of stolen Old Masters.
 
DEEP RIVER, by Shusaku Endo. (New Directions, $19.95.) Mr. Endo's novel follows soulless modern Japanese travelers to the Ganges, where they encounter the humanity and suffering of a few who have found faith.
 
THE HAUNTED LAND: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism, by Tina Rosenberg. (Random House, $25.) A moral, political and psychological investigation, by a wise journalist, of four post-Soviet societies struggling with their conduct under the old regimes.
 
IN THE TIME OF THE AMERICANS: FDR, Truman, Eisenhower, Marshall, MacArthur -- The Generation That Changed America's Role in the World, by David Fromkin. (Knopf, $30.) F.D.R. stars in a historian's incisive account of the men who made the 20th century what it is.
 
THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend.
 
THE LOVE LETTER, by Cathleen Schine. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Helen is 42, capable and loves Edith Wharton. Johnny is 20, acne-spotted and -- like, excellent! -- a big Tom Robbins fan. In this comic novel they fall in love.
 
THE MAN WITHOUT QUALITIES, by Robert Musil. Translated by Sophie Wilkins and Burton Pike. (Knopf, two volumes, boxed, $60.) A magnificent new version of the unfinished and unfinishable novel by an Austrian contemporary of Proust and Joyce whose acknowledged greatness has always exceeded his acknowledged readership.
 
OF LOVE AND OTHER DEMONS, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $21.) An exorcist becomes infatuated with the possessed 12-year-old daughter of an 18th-century marquis in this magical, fatalistic novel.
 
ONE BY ONE FROM THE INSIDE OUT: Essays and Reviews on Race and Responsibility in America, by Glenn C. Loury. (Free Press, $25.) An African-American economist tackles race and poverty in a collection of biting pieces that emphasize black self-help while also calling on the Government to aid the nation's poor.
 
THE ROMANTIC GENERATION, by Charles Rosen. (Harvard University, $39.95.) A professor and pianist offers a fond, accessible analysis of the works of Schumann, Mendelssohn, Chopin and others during the period from 1827 to 1849. Mr. Rosen furnishes musical illustrations on the accompanying compact disk.
 
WALT WHITMAN'S AMERICA: A Cultural Biography, by David S. Reynolds. (Knopf, $35.) An intensive historical excavation, aiming to show how Whitman, an enthusiast for almost everything, transmuted into his poetry images from all aspects of American culture.
