HEADLINE: FORWARD TO THE PAST

BYLINE: By Walter Russell Mead; Walter Russell Mead is the President's Fellow at the World Policy Institute at the New School. Research assistance was provided by Adam Feibelman.

 BODY:
With Speaker Newt Gingrich and his Republican allies in the House set to dismantle as much of the Federal Government as they can, we seem to be watching the twilight of the nation-state. A wave of change is sweeping across national governments worldwide. Regional governments everywhere, and state governments in the United States, will gain in strength relative to federal units as voters keep power closer to home. And international institutions like the European Union, the International Monetary Fund and the newly established World Trade Organization will, with the help of market forces, erode national sovereignty from above.
Nations are being overwhelmed by markets. Transnational corporations have no allegiance to any government and sail the seas of the global economy under no flag but their own. An international culture is taking shape. Young people everywhere listen to the same music, wear the same clothes, watch the same movies. At the level of elites, professional communities of knowledge know no national boundaries; Russian, American and Swiss physicists have more in common with each other than with their lay neighbors. 
 It's all true -- but life isn't that simple. The nation-state may be sickly and pale, but nationalism is thriving, robust and rambunctious. Those Russians and Chechens fighting in the ruins of Grozny aren't rootless cosmopolites. The Hungarians and Romanians and the Bosnians and Serbs show that nationalism -- the desire of people who speak the same language and share a common history to form a common state -- is far from dead in international affairs.
The new nationalism isn't limited to the old Communist world. In Western Europe and the United States, anti-immigrant feeling testifies to the enduring power of national identity. In East Asia, the conflicting claims of various nations to the oil-rich Spratly Islands are more than alarming; the conflict in East Timor shows just how hard people will fight being ruled by those they consider culturally alien. Border skirmishes between, of all places, Ecuador and Peru show that Latin Americans are still willing to kill one another for the sake of a flag.
Nationalism is on the rise. During the cold war, people tended to kill each other for international ideas like freedom and socialism; today, the carnage is over ethnicity and national status. Ask the Bosnians and the Tutsis.
Even the Republican majority in Congress testifies to the paradox of rising nationalism in declining nation-states. Not all of the Federal establishment is coming under Newt Gingrich's knives. The Defense Department budget is, after all, being spared. Conservatives may want to scrap the Department of Energy and turn welfare back to the states, but don't wait for them to haul down the flag -- or ask American soldiers to serve in United Nations peacekeeping operations under foreign commanders. Even further on the right, the militia movement hates, with equal passion, the Federal Government, the United Nations and foreigners generally. This apparent paradox -- nationalism rising as nation-states decline -- is part of a larger pattern. The future is starting to look like the past; the 1990's are starting to look like the 1890's.
THE OMNIPOTENT nation-state of this century is a historical anomaly and was born in turmoil and blood. Before 1914, most states -- even sprawling autocracies like czarist Russia -- were small and weak by today's standards. Furthermore, many government functions that even conservatives now accept, like central banking, were private. The Bank of England was private until 1946. Before the Federal Reserve was established in 1913, the private House of Morgan functioned effectively as the central bank of the United States. International money markets were more closely integrated in some ways then than now. The international gold standard, for example, was an effective monetary union. Major currencies -- the pound, the dollar, the franc and the mark -- were pegged to gold and fluctuated only slightly against one another.
All this changed with World War I. In all the major powers, governments asserted unprecedented, even unimagined, power to control the production and the distribution of strategic goods. Government consumption shot up -- in money terms and as a percentage of gross domestic product. The Federal Government spent $572 million in 1902 and $12.6 billion in 1918. Taxes rose accordingly. The 16th Amendment established the basis for a national income tax in 1913. Families with incomes of $25,000 were in a 1 percent tax bracket; those with incomes of $1,000,000 were taxed at 6 percent. Four years later the nation was at war, and an income of $25,000 was taxed at 14.7 percent; $1,000,000 at 70.3 percent.
Once the shooting stopped, most governments retrenched -- but even so, governments everywhere played a larger role after the war. The Federal budget dropped back in the 1920's, but never to its prewar levels. By 1927, Washington was still spending $3.5 billion, seven times the 1902 budget.
Much of this increase arose directly from the war. Governments were saddled with huge debts; the war forced expensive social reforms on many countries. Politicians were alarmed by the specter of Communism and the danger that alienated soldiers would find they had more in common with their fellow workers on the other side than with their own national government. That created pressure to create better, more open societies after victory. These vows were only partly kept, but still they cost money and they began to change people's beliefs about what government could and should do.
Governments did more to control the international economy after the war. The collapse of the gold standard left governments managing currencies, and therefore price levels, and therefore international capital flows as never before. As part of the Versailles system, international government commissions set economic policy for Germany; for the first 10 years after the war the Allies essentially controlled the German central bank.
World War II and its aftermath completed the story; governments throughout Europe and North America grew to a size and power that no one would have dreamed possible in 1900. In 1943, British Government expenditure reached an astonishing 82 percent of gross domestic product. After 1945, governments were even more committed to economic management and welfare state policies. The Depression had shown how prone the private economy is to disaster without government support. And the war brought devastation of such scale that nothing smaller than national governments could hope to respond effectively.
Government remained powerful after 1945. The cold war perpetuated exceptional security costs for the next 40 years. Ever-expanding welfare states and ever-expanding entitlements for the citizens of the Western democracies helped prove the superiority of the Western system over its Communist alternative. Few questioned the desirability or the inevitability of the mixed-market economy, with its ever-expanding government.
But other factors were at work. The long peace among the Western democracies after 1945 allowed the private economy to recover. The severed trade links among nations were re-established; investors once again felt safe enough to put their money in international markets. Governments gradually lost the ability to control currency values and to dominate international capital flows. The collapse in 1971 of the Bretton Woods system of fixed exchange rates ended the domination of the international economy by nation-states.
In the 24 years since, private business and private capital have steadily returned to the commanding heights of the world economy. Governments today must obey markets, not the other way around. It is difficult to say how far this process will continue, but the 1990's already in some ways look like the 1890's -- an era of weak national states, free international capital flows and strong national passions. If so, we'll have to fasten our seat belts. History is about to enter a region of turbulent air currents.
A return to the conditions of the 1890's does not mean an era of serenely buoyant capital markets. The 19th century was an era of spectacular growth in some places, but it was also a time of disruptive booms and crashes, and of prolonged economic stagnation and depression. The stock market collapse of 1987 and the Mexican crisis of 1994-95 could be harbingers. The panic of 1893 that prostrated the American banking system started as a crisis among Argentine banks; numerous other American depressions and stock market crashes were touched off by international financial crashes throughout the 19th century.
INTERNATIONAL POLITICS WILL BE as turbulent as international markets. The French, British and German Governments before World War I were small and weak by present standards but public opinion in all three countries was much more chauvinistic than it is today. One possible explanation: If political leaders cannot control their economies to assure rising living standards they must and will play the nationalist card in the contest for power. This is obviously true today in the case of countries like Russia and Serbia. But it could well be true tomorrow in places like Germany, France and the United States if the inherent instability of an international economy dominated by unregulated private capital flows should plunge the world into a series of major economic crises.
Finally, in the long run, the pendulum will swing back toward strong government. A good analogy is flood control. Recent floods along the Mississippi and in northern Europe generated a consensus for dismantling the structures that "regulate" the rivers in the interest of flood control. Laissez faire is our new attitude toward the rivers -- let them flow; human interference just makes things worse.
But we should not forget, as we busily dismantle economic dikes and dams created to protect national economies from rampaging international capital flows, why we built those dikes in the first place. Tearing down the levees on the Mississippi may, in Lincoln's phrase, allow the Father of Waters to flow unvexed to the sea, but the chances are good that some of the communities in his path will be considerably vexed by the normal fluctuations of his course. Before long, some of the structures now being carted away will be rebuilt in haste when we rediscover the virtues of national governments strong enough to protect both individuals and nations from the ravages of economic and social catastrophe.
When that happens, there will no doubt be plenty of pundits and politicians who will hail the new trend toward strong and assertive national governments as a permanent feature of international life. They will probably be wrong.

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Airfill

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
FOR JUST A MOMENT, THINK OF IT as landfill, like 20 percent of modern Manhattan. Imagine a vast stretch of valuable real estate suddenly added to your city. As you might expect, its creation has set off a mad scramble for possession. The owners of old land claim priority to annex the new. The designers of the landfill say no, it was promised to them. A few people shout, "Save some for parks and playgrounds!" Some dare to suggest an auction to help reduce the budget deficit.
If the argument were really about land so obviously worth billions, the public would surely recognize its stake in the debate. The struggle at hand, however, concerns not landfill but airfill -- vast new space in the broadcast spectrum. The imminent availability of that space has arisen from what is murkily called the Digital-HDTV problem, as if to make sure that only a few thousand comprehending Americans will bother to decipher the technical, economic and political issues involved. But that new airspace is precious real estate indeed. It is worth billions. It was created at government initiative and its disposition should not be left to lobbyists and the legislators they routinely bribe with campaign contributions. 
 Here's the situation: About eight years ago, Japan was threatening to make all television equipment obsolete by leading the world into the era of "high-definition television" -- HDTV -- a wider picture, built of twice the present number of lines and therefore twice as clear and more beautiful than anything now available. The public, it was feared, would find the new pictures irresistible, forcing broadcasters to invest in expensive new equipment without the prospect of offsetting new revenues. Indeed, because the HDTV signals required more space in the spectrum, broadcasters feared that some stations might be crowded off the air altogether.
To meet the threat, the Reagan Administration risked a rare deviation from its free-market ideology and organized a competition to invent an American HDTV. And as incentive, the Federal Communications Commission promised to give broadcasters new channel space to transmit the sharper images. The competition was won by a little-known lab belonging to General Instrument, which stunned the world by abandoning the current analog transmissions -- radio waves that are analogous to the sound and light waves of the original image -- and creating its better picture with digital transmissions -- impulses that represent sound and light with the 1's and 0's of the digital computer code.
That breakthrough led to the creation of a consortium of seven major companies and labs, called "the Grand Alliance," to exploit the new technology. Lo and behold, the Grand Alliance's system, now almost complete, can do much more than send elegant pictures. In the spectrum space now used by one analog channel, it can transmit not just one high-definition image but five or six digital television signals as good as current ones. Airfill! And it can use those extra signals not just for television pictures but also to carry Internet computer files, two-way paging systems, electronic mail and much, much more.
Because the new system surpassed all expectations for HDTV, and also because they'd prefer not to bother any longer with an unprofitable conversion to HDTV, broadcasters have taken to calling the new technology by its alternate name, Advanced Television, or ATV. And as Reed Hundt, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, considers the policy decisions that ATV will require starting this year, he calls this "a true watershed moment for the broadcast world."
"Broadcasters are just now commencing the process of converting to the digital age," he observes. "In a few years, broadcasting in most parts of the country will start to be digital transmission. And TV will become fanatically diverse and complex, merging with the computer and communications industry to create the multimedia experience you've all been reading about."
Hundt wants commercial broadcasting to evolve competitively, with little or no government intervention and he has angered some members of the Grand Alliance by not forcing a conversion to HDTV. The alliance has invested heavily in the new technology and feels betrayed to see it diverted to other uses. But Hundt has also annoyed the broadcasters, who want the extra spectrum space once set aside for HDTV to be given to them for profitable services.
The F.C.C. chairman looks upon all the airwaves as public property, to be rented or bartered for commercial uses and to some degree reserved for public purposes. He recently earned nearly $8 billion for the United States Treasury by auctioning off space on the radio spectrum. And he is now seeking public support for the idea of making broadcasters pay for spectrum space with cash or contributions of time or a mixture of both.
"Who among us thinks it was a bad idea to set aside 843 acres in Manhattan to create Central Park?" he recently asked. "Does anyone think Teddy Roosevelt erred in proposing the National Park System that left us the treasures of Yosemite, Yellowstone and so many others? Surely not all the Western wilderness needs to be turned over to commercial development."
At the least, Hundt obviously intends to protect the investments already made by wireless phone and paging companies at his spectrum auction by charging comparable fees to broadcasters who would now compete with them. He has also suggested that broadcasters be required to set aside some of the huge new spectrum capacity for both educational children's programs and free political discussion. He suggests creating a "bank" of reserved free time for politics to be withdrawn with vouchers given to political parties and candidates. The free broadcasts and electronic mail that these vouchers would provide would, in a stroke, greatly reduce the costs of campaigning -- and therefore the influence -- of campaign contributors.
The question now is whether Congress will feel free enough from industry pressure to lay claim to the public's stake in the spectrum. For half a century, television broadcasters have paid nothing for their highly profitable use of the airwaves. Their promise in return to operate "in the public interest" was shown long ago to have little meaning and, in any case, to be unenforceable. And their campaign contributions almost succeeded last year in sneaking into law, without even a public hearing, an amendment that would have given them unrestricted use of the spectrum's new airfill.
These issues are not so technical that they defy public understanding. They ought to be the subject of a full and fair debate. If broadcasters want to demonstrate the responsibility that entitles them to the airfill bonanza, they could begin by offering generous time for a proper airing of the subject.

HEADLINE: High Ceilings And High Tech On the Triple 7

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS; SETH MYDANS is a correspondent in the Los Angeles bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
IN recent years, designers have set aside their attempts to make commercial aircraft faster and concentrated instead on improving the quality of the time passengers spend in the air. The latest advance in this direction is the Boeing 777, which makes its inaugural passenger flight on Wednesday. When the first Boeing 777's go into service for United Airlines, passengers will be riding the world's largest twin-engine plane, with the most powerful aircraft engines ever made for commercial flying and some of the roomiest seats and aisles available.
And once it is fully equipped, perhaps as early as next year, the aircraft will offer both a work station and an entertainment center at each of its 292 seats. 
 United Airlines is the first buyer, having placed an order for 34 of the planes, with an option for 34 more, and until 1997 it will be the only United States carrier to fly the 777.
The first three planes have been delivered, and service will begin with Flight 921 between Heathrow Airport near London and Dulles International Airport near Washington. The other initial routes will be Denver-Chicago, Chicago-Washington and Chicago-Frankfurt.
The offering of the trans-Atlantic route has been accelerated because, in an unusual effort, the airline completed the Federal Aviation Administration's flying-hour requirements before going into service, qualifying it for extended flights over water. These requirements are usually fulfilled over about two years after an aircraft has already begun passenger service.
With faster commercial aircraft like the Concorde proving not to be economically viable on a broad scale, enhancements in passenger service now focus on offering more entertainment, in making flying time more productive and on improving the physical comfort of the flight, said David S. Stempler, executive director of the International Airline Passengers Association. In these terms, he said, the Boeing 777 demonstrates "what we are going to be seeing throughout the industry in the future."
But technical problems, which have plagued other airlines as well, have delayed the completion of all the planned entertainment and communications components on the aircraft. The airline's glossy literature touting the features of what it calls the "triple seven" contains small stickers pasted over two sections that read "Coming this fall."
On a recent tour of the aircraft here, airline officials pointed out a range of comforts, some of them still on the drawing boards. In addition to the planned entertainment and workplace features, the new planes offer a big, bright cabin with one of the rarest luxuries in the sky: space.
Among its attractions are higher ceilings, with 6 feet 4 inches of headroom in the center aisle, an inch more than is offered by the largest 747; large, accessible retracting overhead storage bins, and broader aisles that the airline says will allow a passenger to "squeeze past" when a flight attendant has a cart in the way. Coach seats are the widest available, in rows of nine -- an inch and a half wider than the economy class on the larger B747-400's.
In a key detail, the 777 as configured by United offers more legroom with extended seat pitch, the distance between a point on one seat and the same point on the seat behind it. In first class, seat pitch is 64 inches, compared with the 60 inches more common on international flights. In business class it is 49 inches, compared with the 40 inches that is standard in the industry. In economy it is 33 inches, versus the more common 31, an airline spokesman said.
Originally configured for 303 seats, the plane was reconfigured at 292 seats when United decided to provide more comfort in business class (the greatest revenue producer), according to a spokesman for the airline.
United worked closely with Boeing over the past five years to develop the 777, offering input from the cabin crew, the flight deck, engineers and maintenance staff.
Powered by two giant Pratt & Whitney PW4084 engines, the planes have a range of 4,350 miles, allowing transcontinental domestic flights as well as trans-Atlantic flights from the East Coast. United is preparing to upgrade future orders to include longer-range aircraft with a more powerful version of the engine, capable of making trans-Pacific flights. (The 747-400, the newest in that series, can fly from Chicago to Japan or from Los Angeles to Sydney.)
So far, Boeing has sold 144 of the aircraft, which fill a niche between its 767-300 and 747-400 aircraft, and optioned another 99 to a total of 15 customers worldwide. British Airways is the second customer, with 30 aircraft bought or optioned and with its first delivery scheduled for September. The next American customer will be Continental, which will take delivery of the first of 10 bought or optioned aircraft two years from now.
When the first aircraft go into service this week, a United spokesman says, passengers will have access at their seats to 6 video channels and 19 music channels, and to 2 telephones per cabin.
United expects that passengers will eventually be able to "call anywhere in the world from anywhere in the world," said Bob Ketelsen, manager of aircraft interior planning for United.
"Interactivity on a plane has been a difficult thing to make happen," he said, citing problems with weight, power, heat dissipation, miniaturization and electromagnetic interference aboard highly complex and electronically sensitive aircraft.
The hardware, already in place, includes five-and-a-half-inch video screens that, in first and connoisseur (business) class, deploy on little necks from the armrests. In economy class the screens are built into the backs of each seat.
At all seats, a small handset will eventually serve as a telephone, program selector, game controller and credit card reader (for using the telephone). On one side are all the buttons that will make it a telephone receiver. On the other are controls that will serve as a computer mouse and, when held horizontally, as a video-game joystick.
THE handset also includes a jack for a personal computer to allow the sending and receiving of faxes and electronic messages, once the telecommunications programs are complete, perhaps as early as this fall.
Once the full service is in place, built around GTE's Genstar Telecommunications System, passengers will also be able to participate in three-way conference calling and to talk to each other from one seat to another.
The six video channels will offer a choice of two feature films as well as situation comedies, video news magazines, sports, business and regional programs. In the future, perhaps in early 1996, Mr. Ketelsen said, passengers will be offered six categories of video games including card and board games, arcade offerings, puzzles and children's games. Plans are under way to add video shopping and flight information.
The new aircraft is not the first to offer individual video screens, said Rob Brookler, a spokesman for World Airline Entertainment Association, an industry group. Virgin Atlantic offers them on all its planes.
 Virgin is also among the airlines developing telephone, fax and other communications capabilities for trans-Atlantic passengers.
Mr. Brookler said he was not surprised over delays in installing all the features in the Boeing 777, as the industry wrestles with the complex new systems. "The technology is quite new and there's often a great deal more involved in getting something up and running at 35,000 feet than it might seem," he said. "We understand that with these new systems there is always a period of trouble-shooting, a period of modifications, and that's pretty much par for the course."
As the world grows smaller and the airplane becomes an extension of both the living room and the office, passengers will gain a measure of comfort and efficiency, but they may also lose one of the last, albeit cramped, retreats from an ever more interconnected world.
"Some people say, 'I'm not sure I want to be reached. You're taking away my last sanctuary,' " said Mr. Ketelsen, contemplating one of the little handsets that, if everything works, promise to change the experience of air travel.

HEADLINE: Building a Business-Friendly New York

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
AMBASSADOR is the title that most of his associates still use when speaking about Charles A. Gargano, in deference to his three-year posting to the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago during the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
But the 59-year-old Republican fundraiser and former Long Island contractor added a string of other important titles to his name this year: chairman and chief executive of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, commissioner of the New York State Department of Economic Development and vice chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 
 Now, after assuming this governmental empire, Mr. Gargano has set out to shrink it, rename it, relocate it and -- taking his cues from Gov. George E. Pataki -- make it more responsive to business interests.
The strategy has brought some successes in recent months. In February, for example, the International Business Machines Corporation announced it would remain in New York State and build its new world headquarters in Westchester County, not far from its current Armonk headquarters.
"I.B.M. is encouraged by the Governor's approach and attitude toward business," said Louis V. Gerstner Jr., its chairman and chief executive. A spokesman, Thomas Beermann, quoted Mr. Gerstner as saying he "had never seen a government move as quickly as the Pataki administration in working to keep a business in the state."
Three months later, after Mr. Gargano intervened personally, the Pyramid Companies of Syracuse cleared a long-standing regulatory maze and received the last state permits needed to construct a 1.2 million-square-foot, 160-store mall called the Palisades Center in West Nyack, in Rockland County. Work is to begin in two weeks.
"If our case study is any indication of what the new administration will do, we believe they will get the economy going," said Joe C. Mareane, a Pyramid executive who was director of development for the City of Syracuse from 1987 to 1993.
"What we want to do is really reach out to the business people around this state," Mr. Gargano said in a recent interview. "Phase 1: retain them here, retain jobs. And then hopefully, with the Governor's new budget, his tax-cutting program and eliminating a lot of unnecessary regulations, try to make it easier for the business person to operate in this state."
At the same time, Mr. Gargano adopted a go-slow approach toward projects that he says would rely too much on scarce government financing and too little on private investment. Among these undertakings, several of which were championed by former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, are a waterfront park along the Hudson River, from Battery Park City to 59th Street; an international trade center and hotel on West 125th Street in Harlem and a 22-mile railway linking Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports to mid-Manhattan. (Indeed, George J. Marlin, the new executive director of the Port Authority, said on Wednesday that the "full 22-mile plan is dead," although segments of the railway may yet be constructed.)
In a major real-estate transaction, the development corporation and department are to move out of 100,525 square feet in 1515 Broadway, between 44th and 45th Streets. "The space we now occupy is much too expensive," Mr. Gargano said -- $42 a square foot per year. Even worse, he said, the state Job Development Authority pays $60 a square foot for 17,700 square feet at 605 Third Avenue, between 39th and 40th Streets.
"These costs are prohibitive," Mr. Gargano said. In addition, the Mortgage Loan Corporation, an affiliate of the Urban Development Corporation, occupies 26,610 square feet at 11 West 42d Street, and the Hudson River Park Conservancy, another affiliate, has 7,500 square feet at 141 Fifth Avenue.
All of the offices -- 152,335 square feet in all -- are to be consolidated in 118,206 square feet over five floors at 633 Third Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets. The space is to be purchased as a commercial condominium from the Travelers Insurance Company over the course of 12 years, at an annual cost of $3.9 million, or $33 a square foot, including operating expenses.
"The new building will bring all the agencies together and will save us several million dollars per year," Mr. Gargano said, "and we'll operate more efficiently."
The physical consolidation will also mirror the organizational changes that Mr. Gargano has initiated. He has already reduced the staff of the Urban Development Corporation to 304 from 408, or 25 percent. He has also reduced the staff of the Department of Economic Development to 344 from 445, or 23 percent.
The Harlem Urban Development Corporation and the Western New York Economic Development Corporation are being eliminated. The Job Development Authority is being merged into the development corporation and the Science and Technology Foundation is being merged into the development department.
Mr. Gargano is even changing the name of the Urban Development Corporation, to the Empire State Development Corporation. The change reflects a decentralizing of the corporation in which the staffs at its regional offices will be "beefed up," Mr. Gargano said, to make these centers "one-stop shops" for businesses seeking development assistance. Outside New York City, the offices are in Albany, Binghamton, Buffalo, Fishkill, Ogdensburg, Plainview, Rochester, Syracuse and Utica.
"Our regional offices should be able to use their specialized knowledge to make independent decisions," Mr. Gargano told a recent breakfast seminar sponsored by the law firm of Zetlin & De Chiara.
At the seminar, which was attended by leaders in the real estate and construction industries, Mr. Gargano was introduced by Richard T. Anderson, president of the New York Building Congress, who declared: "Ambassador Gargano has had every position I can think of except one -- he's never been a Democrat." After the applause subsided, Mr. Anderson added, "I knew some of you would like that."
Mr. Gargano, who lives in Manhattan, arrived in the United States as a boy from Sant'Angelo de' Lombardi in the Avellino province of southern Italy. He holds a bachelor's degree in civil engineering technology and a master's degree in business administration from Fairleigh Dickinson University, as well as a master's degree in civil engineering from Manhattan College.
From 1963 to 1981, he was vice president of the J. D. Posillico Engineering and Construction concern in Farmingdale, L.I., a public-works construction company.
In 1981, Mr. Gargano was named deputy administrator of the Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration, a position he held until 1983. In 1984, he was selected by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato to direct President Reagan's re-election campaign in New York State. Four years later, he was named ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago, where he served through August 1991.
Last year, Mr. Gargano was named finance chairman for Mr. Pataki's gubernatorial campaign, for which he raised more than $14 million.
Mr. Pataki did not wait for his inauguration to launch an economic development campaign, Mr. Gargano said, but reached out quickly to Mr. Gerstner to express concern about the closing of I.B.M. operations in East Fishkill and Kingston.
I.B.M.'s new corporate headquarters "could have been built anywhere in the world," Mr. Gargano said, since 60 percent of the corporation's business is overseas.
Ultimately, I.B.M. decided to remain in Westchester, which Mr. Gargano attributed to a chain of events beginning with the Governor-elect's phone call. The new headquarters will be smaller than the current building, which has 420,000 square feet, said the corporate spokesman, Mr. Beermann. It ought to be completed in 1997, he said, and the existing headquarters will be sold.
New York State has agreed to buy portions of vacant I.B.M. properties in Kingston and Endicott and to lease part of the East Fishkill property, into which it will consolidate data-center operations.
To further assist I.B.M., the state agreed to a provide lower-cost power and to forego some sales taxes on purchases like office furniture. Mr. Beermann said he could not put a figure on those incentives, as the details had not yet been worked out. He said I.B.M. was also counting on the state for help with traffic improvements and sewer hook-ups in the area.
In his speech at the breakfast seminar, Mr. Gargano vowed to provide financial incentives "only to firms where such assistance will make a tangible difference in job creation and retention."
"We will not blindly throw money, as past administrations have, at highly visible firms that try to incite bidding wars between our state and others," he declared.
In the interview, Mr. Gargano declined to identify those firms at which he believed money had been thrown. But he distinguished I.B.M. from the crowd, saying: "They came and said: 'We have made a decision to stay here because of you reaching out to us. We're saying that in advance because we're not here to bargain with you but we need some help.' And I thought that was real class. The Governor directed me to look into any kind of assistance programs. And we did just that."
The $250 million Palisades Center in West Nyack presented a different challenge. "That project was being held up as a result of bureaucratic problems and little issues in different agencies," Mr. Gargano said. "One of the things that Governor Pataki wants us in his cabinet to do -- and specifically me -- is to coordinate and say, 'Where is the problem?' And we did just that."
Besides 160 stores, the four-level mall, designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, is to have a 2,100-seat food court, a skating rink, a 16-screen movie theater and more than 6,000 parking spaces. It is being built on two landfills bounded by the New York State Thruway and Routes 59 and 303. Because of its size and location, the project has faced much opposition over the years from environmentalists and town residents.
Having spent a decade trying to emerge from the regulatory maze, Pyramid executives came well prepared May 2 to make their appeal to Mr. Gargano. In fact, they came a bit too well prepared, having put together a slide show for his benefit. "He let us know that we could call him when it was over," Mr. Mareane said. With the show canceled, Mr. Mareane said, the discussion "very quickly boiled down to a question of where the gridlock was focused." The Pyramid executives said they were awaiting permits from the state Transportation and Environmental Conservation Departments.
By the time the executives got up to leave Mr. Gargano's office, on the 52d floor of 1515 Broadway, the chairman was already on the phone to other state officials. By the time they returned to their headquarters in Syracuse that afternoon, the Pyramid executives had received a call from the Transportation Commissioner, John B. Daly, assuring them that he would look into the matter. By May 17, the permits were in place. And Pyramid plans to begin construction this month.
Thomas J. Valenti, a partner in Pyramid, said that Mr. Gargano's predecessor, Vincent Tese, and Mr. Tese's executive deputy commissioner, Alan C. Sullivan, "gave us great attention."
"I can't say enough about the effort they tried to give us," Mr. Valenti said, "but the fact is that we didn't reach a conclusion." In contrast, he said, "Mr. Gargano cut through politics, he cut through jurisdictional lines."
To judge from the Pataki administration's handling of Palisades Center, Mr. Valenti said, "they're going to turn the trend around from where businesses are fleeing New York to where businesses are going to want to come in."
AS an example of the business he would like to draw, Mr. Gargano cited a semiconductor plant that Motorola plans to build in Virginia to serve the northeast. "Why wasn't New York chosen?" he asked. His own answer: taxes, wages and energy costs are lower in Virginia and state officials "show -- by their actions -- that they really want major employers to create jobs."
"There's no reason why New York can't be as successful as Virginia and other states in attracting businesses," Mr. Gargano said.
David Shaffer, president of the Public Policy Institute at the Business Council of New York State, said he was encouraged by Mr. Gargano's interest in Motorola. "This is the kind of thing New York ought to be able to get," he said. "The past attitude was that these things don't happen or that you have to give away the store to get them."
Mr. Gargano does not believe that the state and city are giving away the store by subsidizing the redevelopment of 42d Street. Instead, he has been very visible in his embrace of a project that began under the Cuomo administration.
THE keystone is seen as a plan by the Walt Disney Company to lease the landmark New Amsterdam Theater, which is owned by the state, and renovate it for live productions. Disney would put $8 million of its own money into the reconstruction, which would cost at least $29 million. The state and city would lend the balance, at interest rates of 3 percent for the first $21 million and at 3.5 percent for an additional $5 million contingency fund.
"Sometimes when you need particular participation, you make an investment to attract others," Mr. Gargano said. "And I think Disney was an important element for 42d Street; the image of Disney, as compared with the image that's there today."
Moreover, he said, the city and state would be paid part of the gross sales every year -- 2 percent of the first $20 million and 3 percent on sales above that. "There will be a return over time," Mr. Gargano said. "The money will come back in ticket sales. It's not like we're giving a grant."
By contrast, he said, the Hudson River park project depends primarily on money from the state. "If we had deep pockets, we could forge ahead with that," Mr. Gargano said, "but I think we have to move ahead slowly because the budget doesn't allow us to do what we want to do."
Another major waterfront project that Mr. Gargano has inherited is Queens West, a commercial and residential development on Hunters Point, along the East River. He said he was pleased that construction might begin this fall on the first apartment building. "But we're going to need more private commitment in order for that project to move apace," he said. "And there has to be a market for the type of facilities and structures that are being planned."
Mr. Gargano said he will also apply the market test to the 22-story Harlem International Trade Center, planned at 125th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard (formerly Lenox Avenue). "To support an $85 million facility takes a lot of business, hotel business, office rental," Mr. Gargano said. "You don't build something unless you really know that there's a market for it."
Mr. Gargano has already antagonized development officials and politicians in Harlem with his decision to close the Harlem Urban Development Corporation. "It has not been a productive office," he said.
But Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, said the local corporation had "done a lot of good and is important to the Harlem community."
"If indeed there were problems with the board or the personnel," Mr. Rangel said, "the community is always open to suggestions as to how we could redesign it or shape it in a way that the Governor would find more consistent with his ideas."

HEADLINE: An Unconventional Course Tries to Fly

BYLINE: BY JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
A GROUP of 50 Fairfield University students and faculty members had good reason to feel discouraged as they huddled together on a remote airstrip in Stratford this month. On an afternoon that was to have culminated in an unusual business course project, just about everything seemed to have gone wrong.
The weather was atrocious: a cold and steady rain had pelted the group for almost two hours. Because of the weather, apparently, they had been unable to launch any of the eight Piper J-3 Cub model airplanes that 83 Fairfield University students had built. Then when one of the planes was launched, it rose only about 20 feet before diving and crashing upside down. 
 But aided by members of the Connecticut Model Airplane Club, who had helped the students throughout the school year, the group remained undaunted.
And finally, almost two hours after launch time, the same yellow and green plane, undamaged despite its mishap moments earlier, soared skyward.
Only this time it rose about 50 feet, made two loops and came in for a smooth landing as the students and professors cheered.
"It was a poignant moment," said J. Michael Cavanaugh, an assistant professor of management at the university, whose decision it was to use model airplane building as an integral part of a business course for Fairfield University sophomores. "The project certainly would not have been considered a failure if none of the planes got off the ground, but getting one in the air was a significant, symbolic gesture."
It was also the climax of an innovative business course that had given students a hands-on learning experience about the business world.
The airstrip, in a field close by the Sikorsky Memorial Airport, was in a sense an extension of the classroom that for eight months had been a spacious basement in Dolan Hall, a campus building that had been used for storage purposes in recent years.
There, the students, divided into eight classes of about 25 students each, had built eight six-foot-long model planes that weigh about 10 pounds and have 10 1/2-foot wing spans.
A drastic departure from conventional business courses, BU 100 is reflective of a reorganization of the university's School of Business under the new dean, Russell Boisjoly, that stresses interdisciplinary courses. A gift of $250,000 from the General Electric Company, whose world headquarters are in Fairfield, aided in the development of the new curriculum.
The course, Dr. Cavanaugh said, was "an act of desperation" when he first offered it in the summer of 1993 at the University of Massachusetts, where he has taught summer courses. A member of the Fairfield University faculty for the last five years, Dr. Cavanaugh contends that no one has been happy with the content and format of traditional business course curriculums.
"There's been a real panic among many business schools because of the drop-off in enrollment, which has been about 15 percent since 1989," he said. "We feel there's been a gap between what is being taught and what students really need to know to connect with the business world. And we have to make the curriculum more exciting."
Many business school graduates, Dr. Cavanaugh said, have lacked communications skills and an ability to comprehend "political situations" in the business world.
"We haven't been preparing students adequately for the dynamic environment that exists in a global economy, and we've had to rethink what we've been doing," he said. "You have to take the principles of the course out and actually live them. If you don't do that, they just stay in the notebook. And we, as teachers, are accountable and have to back up what we're teaching."
"In this case, the planes are a means to an end," Dr. Cavanaugh said. "The objective was to turn the classroom into a laboratory, and to stress the active rather than the passive."
In effect, the students in BU 100 built their own business organization. Along the way, they determined how much each plane would cost and established an overall cost schedule. Then, on their own, they decided how various tasks would be done and who would do them.
As Dr. Cavanaugh explained it, the project required student involvement in accounting, finance, marketing, business law and operations management. "It was a daunting project, a real challenge," he said.
Dr. Cavanaugh concedes it would have been difficult, if not impossible, to have built the Piper J-3 Cub model planes from balsa wood without the help of the Connecticut Model Airplane Club, which operates out of a small trailer off Lordship Boulevard in Stratford.
"They were our aero-mavens, and they were indispensable," Dr. Cavanaugh said. "Along the way, they kind of adopted us." Indeed, some of the members went often to the classes on campus to lend their expertise in the building of the planes, which were built to one-quarter scale.
Not all of the classes worked at the same pace. "Some paced themselves while some had to cram near the end of the course," Dr. Cavanaugh said. But all of the planes were ready by launch time.
Dr. Cavanaugh conceded that gender issues did arise at times in some of the classes. "In a couple of instances there were disagreements, but over all everyone worked together pretty well," he said. "I don't think either gender had any advantage or disadvantage."
Oscar Jensen, one of the professors who taught the course, said he thought that the women among the students "stayed at it a bit more while some of the boys stayed away from classes for a while."
"Some of the girls became the leaders," he said.
Dr. Jensen said there had been some resistance to the new concept. "Like grown-ups, some students don't like change," he said. "They wanted to learn about business the old way."
But Dr. Cavanaugh and Dr. Jensen said they thought that most of the students were receptive to the new approach. Laurent Painchaud of Southport, a coordinator for the team whose plane was successfully launched, said he felt that the model airplane project helped bring the students closer together.
"Working with your peers helped a lot," said Mr. Painchaud, adding that he believed that the course already had benefited him in his outside job as the sales manager at a Westport store that sells sailboats and sailing accessories. "The course taught you how to work as a team and the importance of planning and meeting deadlines," he said.
Mr. Painchaud said he was looking forward to seeing his team's plane on display at the Barone Campus Center, where it is scheduled to be hung for all to see.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Owning Shares In a Co-op
 
Q Are individuals the only ones who can own shares in a co-op? Or can other entities, such as corporations and limited partnerships, also own shares? . . . Mike Lichtman, Manhattan.
 
A Until 1986, only individuals could own shares in a co-op, said Arthur I. Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer who is also chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives. But since the enactment of the Federal Tax Reform Act of 1986, Mr. Weinstein said, any legal entity can become a shareholder in a co-op. 
 "That includes corporations, partnerships, limited partnerships and trusts," Mr. Weinstein said.
He added that co-op boards should exercise caution before permitting the sale or transfer of co-op shares to any "legal entity" other than a human being.
"The identity of the occupant of the unit should be known and agreed to by the co-op, and the co-op should be assured that the owner of the unit has the financial resources to pay maintenance charges," Mr. Weinstein said. "Many co-ops require a separate occupancy agreement and a personal financial guarantee before they will consent to ownership by an entity other than a person. And that is absolutely a wise move."
Breach of the occupancy agreement, Mr. Weinstein said, could be grounds for cancellation of the proprietary lease. "If someone else moves in, and the right documents are in place, that could be treated as an illegal sublet," he said.
 
When Amortization Is Negative
 
Q What is meant by "negative amortization?" Under what types of mortgage formats will it occur? . . . Erica W. Potts, Manhattan.
 
A "Negative amortization occurs when the monthly payments a borrower makes do not cover the full interest payment on a mortgage," said Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services, a mortgage broker in Manhattan. "The amount of the difference -- what the bank is owed for interest -- then gets added to the principal of the loan."
Typically, Ms. Scott said, negative amortization loans are used when borrowers want the benefit of low-interest, adjustable-rate mortgages, but also want to keep their monthly payments constant.
"It's only a problem when interest rates are going up," Ms. Scott said, explaining that when interest rates rise on a ordinary adjustable-rate mortgage the monthly payments change to cover the increase. On the other hand, she said, when interest rates rise on a negative amortization adjustable-rate mortgage, the monthly payments stay the same while the principal balance on the loan increases to cover the difference between the old interest rate and the new one.
"It's not necessarily a bad thing," Ms. Scott said. "I've sold mortgages like this to Wall Street types who know exactly what they're doing. They say, 'I don't care if I get $10,000 less when I sell my property. I'll invest the money in the meantime.' "
Such mortgages, however, are not appealing to "Wall Street types" alone. Kevin McConnell, a Manhattan lawyer and former Assistant Attorney General in the Real Estate Finance Bureau of the New York State Attorney General's office, said that negative amortization loans are appropriate for other borrowers as well.
"You see elderly folks doing it," Mr. McConnell said. "In many cases, the equity in their home at the time of their death is not of particular concern to them. And it keeps down their mortgage payments."

HEADLINE: THE COMPETITION;
NJN: High Energy, Low Ratings, Little Cash

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
AT a local commercial station, the news director will say, 'Give me the pictures, and we'll do a story around it,' " said Michael Fairhurst, the news director at New Jersey Network. "We say, 'Give us issues, and we'll do a story around it.' "
In a state where television coverage almost invariably originates somewhere else and tends toward the hit-or-miss, the state-financed public television network -- created in 1971 expressly to provide New Jersey programs -- is a sober and comprehensive exception. 
 With the gravity that viewers expect from CNN or a national network, NJN's 30-minute evening newscast covers political and economic developments in Trenton and in the counties. Special reports focus on visually unexciting topics like tort reform.
The news is broadcast at 6 P.M., and rebroadcast at 7 and 11, on the network's four UHF channels, in Montclair, New Brunswick, Camden and Trenton. The PBS station WNET/Channel 13, which is based in Newark, also carries it at 6 P.M.
"When I watch it, I learn something," said Cliff Zukin, a professor of politics and mass media at the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers. "I can find out what government did that day. I can't say that about any of the New York stations. When I watch them, I learn about fires, rapes, arsons."
But NJN's future is in peril. Squeezed by low ratings and reductions in the state budget, the newscast was cut last year from an hour. Five staff members from the news division have been laid off in the last three years, leaving seven full-time and two part-time reporters in the main office in Trenton and bureaus in Newark and Camden.
And Governor Whitman has proposed cutting off all state financing for the network over six or seven years. Right now the network gets nearly half its $13 million annual budget from the state; the rest comes from private corporations and foundations and from viewers. Whether it could survive without any funds from the state is unclear.
Even those who favor the Governor's plan typically support the network and its newscast, saying it fills a vital gap. (And even Mrs. Whitman has appeared on NJN fund-raising shows.)
In a 1994 study, two researchers from Rutgers found that the New York stations, when they covered New Jersey at all, focused primarily on accidents, disasters and crime. By contrast, during the week of May 22, 1995, NJN carried reports on everything from domestic-abuse legislation in New Jersey to former Gov. Thomas H. Kean's endorsement of Lamar Alexander in the Republican Presidential race, from a business initiative in Mercer County to a report on the state's economic health. Crime coverage was generally condensed in a brief overview of the day's events.
As NJN News loses state financing, it will also face the problem of chronically low ratings. In the New York market area, which includes 16 out of 21 counties in New Jersey, the 6 P.M. newscast is watched by just 4,000 households, according to Nielsen Media Research, and the 7 and 11 P.M. rebroadcasts by 5,000 each. Bill Jobes, NJN's general manager, said the network would survey viewers to find out what they want to see and what they think of the newscast.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
As Tax Debate Simmers, Senate Counts Dollars

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON; Iver Peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
June has arrived, which means that the Whitman administration has less than a month to overcome the grumbling among its fellow Republicans in the Senate and get its 15 percent tax cut passed in time for the budget deadline, June 30.
Not to worry, the administration says. Last year's 10 percent cut was not even introduced until the second week in June, and it passed with days to spare. Still, there are only two voting sessions and two committee hearings scheduled for the rest of the month, and there are plenty of worried noises coming from the Republican Senate leadership itself, once again demonstrating the knots that powerful people can tie themselves into while trying to maintain a rigid public posture on an important issue. 
 The drama this month will all be in the Senate, since on the matter of tax cuts, the Assembly's assent is a foregone conclusion. All 80 members are up for re-election this fall, and even the Democrats will swallow their warnings and vote yes, just as most of them voted last week for Mrs. Whitman's Transportation Trust Fund refinancing, after first warning, correctly, about the huge increase in debt the measure will cost.
But the Senate's members are not up for re-election until 1997, and some of the upper chamber's most important members are grumbling loudly about being pushed to pass a tax cut they consider premature and of doubtful fiscal wisdom.
One is Robert Littell, chairman of the Senate Budget and Appropriations Committee, the starting point for all fiscal measures, who as everyone knows by now is worried about the potential impact of Federal budget cuts on the $5 billion New Jersey receives annually from Washington.
Then there is Senator Peter Inverso, Mr. Littell's vice chairman and a certified public accountant, who fears that, even without Federal cuts, the numbers don't add up. Almost two months ago the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services issued an analysis of state revenues for the coming year that concluded that New Jersey would take in half a billion dollars less than the amount forecast by the Whitman administration, even if every nuisance tax and fee that the Governor is depending on is enacted.
The disparity was a matter of misunderstanding and methodology that would soon be resolved, said the treasurer, Brian W. Clymer, at the time. And indeed the discrepancy has been narrowed, a little, to $385 million, which is still a huge gap.
Given the uncertainty, Mr. Inverso has been going around asking, "What's the rush?" The tax cut would not take effect until the start of the tax year in January anyway, he reasons, so why not delay passage of the cut until Congress has decided what to cut, the President has decided what to veto, and the economy has decided if it wants to resume last fall's modest rate of growth or if it wants to stall, as some fear?
In an attempt to accommodate Mrs. Whitman's desire to press on regardless, Mr. Inverso has suggested "revenue triggers," a series of 5 percent tax cuts totaling 15 percent that would click sequentially into place as the revenue to cover their cost comes in. But still, the answer from the Governor is "no." Under the constitution, the Legislature may work only from the Governor's revenue forecast, not someone else's, Mr. Clymer reminds the stragglers, and the Governor's numbers say the books are balanced with the tax cut first.
Why such intransigence in the face of such uncertainty? Especially considering that, last fall, the Governor was willing to admit that the economy might not support another tax cut for a while?
One reason is probably just personal -- that after having signed off on Mr. Clymer's assurance that the money would be there, Mrs. Whitman would find it distasteful to climb down and offer a delay. After all, her signature phrase is "I keep my promises."
The Democrats and even some Republicans complain that the Governor is being rigid to protect her national reputation and her prospects for national office, but that hardly makes sense. Mrs. Whitman's standing with the national Republican Party is already cemented, while balancing her liberal positions on abortion, affirmative action and gay rights on a national ticket would take someone so right wing that Mrs. Whitman wouldn't run with him anyway.
No, the politics of Mrs. Whitman's intransigence is local in nature, and its logic is simple: Delaying tax cuts could risk derailing them entirely as the Legislature comes under more and more pressure to maintain the status quo. Public employee unions are driving hard to prevent the layoffs that will pay for part of the tax cuts; the families of patients at the big psychiatric hospitals slated for closing are similarly organizing a counter-offensive, and normally friendly school district officials are eager to pick apart a budget that offers them no new aid money and plenty of aggravation from stringent new fiscal rules.
The ace up the Governor's sleeve is sticking out so far that everyone can see it: the $500 million surplus she has budgeted for. Chances are that when push comes to shove, the Governor will give up some of that money to reassure nervous senators, save a few jobs, and postpone until a little later the final reckoning of what the tax cuts will really cost.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 2; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1291 words

HEADLINE: New York Philharmonic? Not to Worry, Says Caramoor

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: KATONAH

 BODY:
WHEN the news broke that the New York Philharmonic might make its summer home in the fields of Purchase College, the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts here was preparing to celebrate its own milestone: 50 years of summer music making in the county.
Howard Herring, Caramoor's executive director, said he did not fear the competition the Philharmonic might pose. To the contrary, he said: "Their presence would define us even more vividly as an intimate music festival that relies only on the acoustic properties of its theaters and is on a human scale." He added: "If they choose to come to Westchester, we would welcome them to the region." 
 The Caramoor Music Festival, which runs from June 24 through Aug. 13 this year, has long shared artists like Yo-Yo Ma, Kathleen Battle and Andre Watts with other major festivals and has gained new vitality under the artistic leadership of Andre Previn, who is also a frequent guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic. Yet even a short visit to the former Walter and Lucie Rosen estate conveys Caramoor's distinctive tone.
The main house, which displays the late Mr. and Mrs. Rosen's collections of paintings, sculpture, ceramics, textiles and furniture dating from the Middle Ages to the 19th century, was opened to the public as a museum in 1970. The estate's 100-acre grounds have been rejuvenated in recent years by the mostly volunteer Garden Guild, under the direction of its administrator, Candida Fitts, and the staff horticulturalist, Eileen Burton. Their efforts can be seen at every turn, in the greenhouse where plantings are cultivated and in colorful beds designed to attract butterflies and yield flowers all summer long.
The Mediterranean-style Garden Guild Courtyard will be open for the first time this year with patio tables, new paving stones and a array of plants for sale. Nurtured by a staff that has felt the sting of cutbacks to the arts, sites like the Sunken Garden and the Italian Pavilion have become popular with concertgoers, who stroll among the begonias at intermission and gaze beyond the lilies at the stars.
The intimacy Mr. Herring spoke of was not hyperbole, despite the seating capacity of 1,650 in the tented Venetian Theater, which surpasses by 300 the largest theater at Purchase College. Mr. Herring runs a tight ship, not permitting picnickers to remain on their blankets once a concert has begun and staging one performance at a time. The festival might prefer to present a chamber music concert in the Spanish Courtyard, which is enclosed by the main house, at the same time as an orchestra is playing in the Venetian Theater, but the acoustics won't allow it. "The sound travels, and you can hear the music in the other theater," the director said.
The Rosens presented concerts for their friends in the Music Room of the house, and in 1946 began to give a limited number of concerts for the public. After Mr. Rosen, a lawyer and financier, died in 1951, his wife remained at Caramoor, taking the music outside to the Spanish Courtyard and initiating construction of the larger Venetian Theater in 1957. When she died in 1968, the couple's daughter, Anne Bigelow Stern, continued the festival and introduced the Orchestra of St. Luke's to Caramoor. The ensemble will begin its 16th season in residence here this summer.
Mr. Previn, a formidable musician whom Mr. Herring described as "a runaway train" of energy and ideas, became part of the scene after moving to nearby Bedford Hills six years ago. Mr. Previn, a conductor, composer and pianist who displays all three facets at Caramoor, heightened the presence of jazz here and began a program called Rising Stars, which provides a chance for emerging talents to work with accomplished classical artists and perform chamber music with them here after 10 days of intensive coaching.
Rising Stars heralded Caramoor's expansion into a year-round arts center with spring and fall concerts, an opera series, book readings and educational events like Renaissance Days, which immerse sixth graders from disadvantaged areas in Renaissance culture at no expense to the students or the schools. One recent morning strolling musicians, jesters and a falconer captivated a group of youngsters from the Bronx.
Mr. Herring said he hoped to replicate Renaissance Days as an arts and education program linked to social studies curriculums nationwide, and as a first step has arranged for the Harvard University Graduate School of Education to evaluate the program.
But even as Caramoor has expanded, raising its budget to $1.9 million today from $1.3 million when Mr. Herring arrived in 1986 and increasing its number of visitors to 60,000 a year from 20,000 during the same period, the center has also faced cutbacks. "With the recession, we tightened our focus," Mr. Herring said. "At a 1993 board retreat we reached a watershed. We said that making music at the highest possible level is what this institution is about -- in the context of the gardens and the house.
"We agreed to be proactive in searching for the best young players. Whatever was outside that focus was left behind. We shortened the staff -- hired fewer in the summers for the box office and grounds -- and used more volunteers. Either we did things with volunteers or we didn't do it."
The center also reduced its marketing budget, cut its advertising in half and scaled back other promotions, convinced that "our product would stand on its own," the director said. "But we didn't cut our artist budget," he added. "It was a strategic decision: the last thing you do is touch your product."
Mr. and Mrs. Rosen left what Mr. Herring called a "modest cash reserve," which dwindled with upkeep of the estate, making an endowment campaign critical to Caramoor's survival. "We are up to $1.5 million now," he said. "Our goal is $3.5 million." Some of the fund-raising events planned for the near future are an anniversary gala on June 15 featuring Tony Bennett and Mariah Carey, a benefit concert on July 15 and an antiques show from Sept. 15 through Sept. 17.
Among the limitations and, possibly, the charms of Caramoor, are its relative remoteness. Situated on a country road off Route 22, it is accessible by car or bicycle. Public transportation is nowhere in sight once passengers alight from the Katonah Metro-North train station two miles away.
The center touts the fact that the American Bus Association named the summer festival "one of the top 100 events in North America in 1995." Surprisingly, though, neither the Caramoor administration nor the County Department of Cultural Affairs has been moved to make the center a stop on the Bee Line.
An attempt was made several years ago to link Metro-North riders from Manhattan with a shuttle bus from the Katonah station, but that effort was "a victim of the recession," Mr. Herring said. "Looking to the future," he said, "I would love to come up with a way to make Caramoor as easy for a New Yorker as Grand Central Station."
As it is, 25 percent of Caramoor's audience drives here from Manhattan, while 50 percent are from Westchester, 20 percent from Connecticut and 5 percent from elsewhere. Cars line the fields on concert nights, as ticketholders move along lighted paths toward their seats in the open air.
Mr. Herring and others here believe music lovers will continue to come for what they call "the Caramoor experience" no matter what new attractions settle in the county. "One of the primary reasons we're still here after 50 years is that we're a whole lot more than just great music," the director said. "Aspen has the mountains, Santa Fe has its sunsets, and here it is verdant and fragrant. We make great music in an extraordinary setting."

HEADLINE: MOVIE EARNINGS;
Inflationary Times

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Had Pat H. Broeske bothered to check the Consumer Price Index over the past few decades, she might have drastically revised her list of the 50 highest-grossing films ["The Top Money Makers, for Now," May 14].
Of course, the totals indicated in her list probably include receipts over a number of years (from overseas distribution, videos, etc.), but it is likely that for films of the 1960's and early 70's, most income was generated within a very few years of release. 
 In terms of 1994 dollars, "Close Encounters" made $406 million, "The Sting" made $535 million, "The Exorcist" made $550 million, "E. T." made $614 million and "The Sound of Music" made $790 million.
As for "Snow White" and "Gone With the Wind," keep in mind that a 1945 dollar represents more than $8 today.
 
FRANCOIS VELDE
Catonsville, Md.
