LENGTH: 2598 words

HEADLINE: Banging a Tin Cup With a Silver Spoon

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
THERE was a time in municipal finance when troubled cities, like New York, Philadelphia and Cleveland, that teetered on the brink of bankruptcy did everything they could -- cut jobs, raise taxes and issue new bonds -- to keep themselves afloat and pay off their debts.
But Orange County, Calif., is doing something far different -- and, many say, unthinkable. This county, one of the wealthiest in the nation, is seeking to use every legal option to wriggle out of its financial obligations. First, there was the stunning decision to file for bankruptcy to protect itself from those to whom it owed money after the county made a wrong-way bet on interest rates with billions in public dollars. 
 And since then, the county has hired platoons of corporate bankruptcy lawyers to challenge in court the basic underpinnings of municipal finance -- the moral and legal obligation of a municipal borrower to pay its debts. Unlike the Clevelands and the New Yorks, which underwent considerable pain to protect their names, Orange County is trying to avoid both pain and payments.
"Remember when governments paid their debts?" asked Daniel N. Heimowitz, director of public finance for Moody's Investor Service, the bond rating agency. "When New York City had trouble, it was difficult, but it was a neat package. Orange County is just concerned about avoidance. They are part of a new game. They are violating the trust that holds up this market and this will seriously jeopardize all bond issuers and buyers."
Indeed, the Orange County bankruptcy is turning into a broader tale of morality and money, where many experts see primal notions' of honor and duty being ignored. At first, it was thought that Orange County's bankruptcy filing on Dec. 6 was merely a way for stunned officials to gain some breathing room after a sudden financial debacle. But now, analysts say, it is clear that the filing was just the first of several steps in an entirely different direction. So far, no other municipality has tried to emulate what Orange County has done and there is little evidence yet that the overall market for municipal bonds has been drastically altered by its actions. But clearly, Orange County is testing the rules of engagement.
"You are not looking at a destitute entity," said Joseph Deane, a managing director at Smith Barney. "What you are looking at is a wealthy deadbeat. In anybody's mind, they have the ability to pay."
On Friday, Orange County completed an agreement that its short-term noteholders will be asked to accept and filed it with the bankruptcy court. The proposed deal requires investors to wait another year before getting back $975 million in short-term borrowings --if at all -- and to receive less in interest than they expected.
In the world of municipal finance, this is a default: failing to provide timely and full repayment of borrowings. While this pending agreement gives Orange County some immediate financial relief, investors see this as typical of Orange County's dealings with them. Rather than come up with ways to repay this debt, the county came up with a plan that bondholders may have no choice but to accept. Moreover, the plan itself gives them little comfort that they will even be repaid a year from now.
Where other troubled municipalities avoided bankruptcy, Orange County has embraced it. Where other troubled municipalities lacked money, Orange County has plenty. And where many other troubled municipalities never defaulted on their bonds, Orange County already has failed to meet its obligations to some of its bondholders and is threatening to take even more drastic actions against other noteholders.
Shortly after the bankruptcy filing, Orange County began siphoning money that had been set aside to pay off bondholders and used it to cover continuing expenses. With that money gone, the county ha no choice but to seek accommodation with its short-term noteholders. And, in a move many in municipal finance say would be unconscionable, several county officials are also talking about possibly repudiating, or not paying back at all, $600 million in taxable notes the county issued last summer.
This attitude is roiling the municipal bond markets, and it is troubling to many of those intimately involved, including Orange County's chief executive, William J. Popejoy. "I think there is a need to revisit what is right and what is wrong," said Mr. Popejoy, a former savings and loan executive who was brought in after the bankruptcy. "It is right for a county, especially one as wealthy as this one, to pay its obligations."
But that does not seem to be the prevailing attitude within the county and even among some of Orange County's most prominent political leaders. A proposal to raise the sales tax by half a cent to help the county out of its financial mess is unpopular, and its chances of passage in a June 27 election are unclear. Even if the measure is approved, the vote will come too late to stave off the default. And the measure may still not raise enough money to solve the county's fundamental problems.
Add to all that the continuing antitax sentiment in California that first produced the 17-year-old Proposition 13, which placed a 1 percent cap on property tax rates and limited the ability of local governments to borrow for public projects. The result, county officials say, is their hands are tied.
"The county may be wealthy, but the county government is not wealthy," said Bruce Bennett of Hennigan, Mercer & Bennett, which represents Orange County in the bankruptcy proceeding. "Even though the tax base of the county is very wealthy, the county government doesn't have unrestricted access to it. The municipality has the ability to pay, but the county government does not have the power to raise taxes."
The Orange County bankruptcy is being handled much more like a high-stakes corporate bankruptcy than a bailout of a troubled government entity. The county is being represented by top-flight bankruptcy lawyers -- its legal costs have already reached $25 million -- rather than municipal finance experts. Those involved say negotiators for the county, instead of focusing on ways to meet the general obligation pledge to repay all of Orange County's bonds in full when they come due, are pursuing a cents-on-the-dollar strategy.
The treatment of the noteholders serves as an example of that. "It's a cram-down," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer, a trade publication. "Even at the best, most optimistic interpretation, it's far from a done deal and the county still has to come up with the money a year from now."
Orange County may look like a corporate bankruptcy, but there are some unusual twists. "This is an area that's largely untested," said Paul S. Maco, director of the Office of Municipal Securities at the Securities and Exchange Commission. "What does it mean once you cross into bankruptcy with someone who issues general obligation bonds? What are the municipal bondholders to do? They can't seize the courthouse. All you have is the word of the state or the county behind these bonds."
Orange County's actions turn municipal finance on its head. The entire $1.2 trillion municipal bond market -- which finances schools, roads, sewers and other civic projects -- rests on general obligation debt. This debt, the most common kind in the market, is based on the issuer's promise to do everything within its sovereign power to pay off its bondholders.
General obligation municipal bonds are considered second only to United States Treasury securities as the safest form of debt and are typically bought by the most conservative investors.
Unlike the corporate bond market, holders of municipal bonds have little recourse beyond a municipality's good word. Troubled municipalities cannot go out of business like failed corporations, which then can be carved up, leaving their assets to be used to pay creditors. This concept has been set forth in case law: municipal creditors cannot foreclose on the courthouse or any other essential government service. As a result, issues like trust and honor are more fundamental to the functioning of the municipal bond market than to the market for corporate securities.
"Until Orange County, no one ever questioned the moral obligation of municipal debt," said James E. Spiotto, a municipal bankruptcy expert with Chapman & Cutler, a Chicago law firm. "Rather than paying off their debts, they are using the same techniques as high-yield corporate debt bankruptcies of the late 1980's. No one in Orange County is saying that their creditors will be paid in full."
Besides the county's decision to delay repayment on its $975 million in short-term debt, experts in the municipal market are even more concerned by the county's latest maneuver. It has taken legal steps that lay the groundwork for it to repudiate a $600 million taxable note issued last summer. While an option only if the sales tax proposal is rejected by voters, even raising the possibility of repudiation is almost unheard of in municipal finance.
"This story keeps unraveling from worse to worse," said Mr. Mysak. "This is just one big, big mistake. No other municipality has taken this route."
Municipal bankruptcies and defaults are extremely rare. Most took place during the Depression, when some municipalities literally ran out of money. There have been about 120 municipal bankruptcies since 1979, but most were special tax districts or tiny local governments. Even the nonpayment of some of the billions of dollars in debt issued by the Washington Public Power Supply, which was unable to complete construction of some nuclear power plants, resulted from a 1983 court decision and involved bonds backed by specified revenues from running the power plants rather than general obligation bonds.
The celebrated near-bankruptcies -- New York City, Philadelphia, Cleveland, and, now, Washington, D.C., -- affected governments that were practically broke. Yet, even in these cases, the municipalities solved their problems outside of bankruptcy court and avoided the stigma of widespread default by coming up with complicated rescue packages requiring new taxes, severe municipal belt-tightening, and the imposition of outside fiscal overseers. In the case of New York, all short-term debtholders were paid in full, some immediately and some only slightly later.
Institutional buyers of municipal securities have been particularly outraged by Orange County's approach. In a strongly worded letter, representatives of 33 different municipal bond mutual funds, with nearly $25 billion in California tax-free securities, wrote California Gov. Pete Wilson on May 15 that Orange County's "apparent equivocation" in paying its bonds could undermine investor confidence in all California securities.
This comes just as California's "borrowing season" is about to begin -- when hundreds of municipalities borrow for short periods to tide them over between their outlays for government expenses and their receipt of tax payments.
"Orange County is making the whole municipal market less efficient," said Randy Mercer, a senior vice president at the Benham Group, a mutual fund company based in Mountain View, Calif. "Parties that once trusted one another don't any more. All the small cities and school districts won't die. But they will face higher borrowing costs and that will cause them to bleed."
Mr. Mercer predicts that California municipalities that want to borrow may well have to pay higher interest rates in the future to cover this greater uncertainty. As far as Orange County specifically, investors say their future appetite for Orange County debt will depend on how this crisis is resolved. Investors are likely to remain interested -- but at a higher price -- if the county only defaults on its short-term notes. If it repudiates some debt entirely, investors might have a frostier response.
Public finance in California is based on an extremely complicated web of legal theories, most of which have evolved from court decisions over the last century. Nearly three-quarters of all California borrowings do not fall under the state's Constitution, but are done by cities, counties and special districts that offer the same legal protections as Orange County's debt was supposed to provide. Mr. Heimowitz of Moody's said Orange County is "starting to pull on this one thread and by doing so threatens to unravel the complicated fabric of California public finance."
Another big question is what will happen when Orange County seeks to re-enter the municipal bond markets. New York, for instance, could not borrow on its own behalf for six years after its financial crisis. Cleveland was shut out of the market for five years, Philadelphia for three. Meanwhile, all new financings were handled through special financial control boards, like the New York Municipal Assistance Corporation, with the power to intercept tax revenues to pay off recovery bonds. But Orange County is already talking about trying to borrow while it is still in bankruptcy.
Under any circumstances, disclosure of risks, which is required by the Securities and Exchange Commission before any municipal issuer comes to market, would be tricky. "It's the whole issue of willingness to pay," said one municipal bond industry leader, who asked not to be named. "When you borrow money, do you have to disclose that you might not pay it back?"
Jane Eddy, a municipal bond analyst at the Standard & Poor's Rating Group, said that the county's "lack of willingness" to repay debts will haunt it for years. She said the county will face higher borrowing costs and will never regain the trust it once enjoyed. "It would be naive to assume that, once out of bankruptcy the county would never again choose that option should tough times arise," she said.
Already, the county is finding the going tough. A planned $275 million recovery bond issue is in serious trouble. The county was trying to sell these bonds to repay the approximately 200 different school districts, cities and county agencies that lost money in the collapsed investment fund run by Robert C. Citron, the former treasurer, who pleaded guilty to fraud in the matter.
The MBIA Insurance Corporation, however, has refused to insure these bonds because it does not trust Orange County's willingness-to-pay promise. The county now faces the uncomfortable choice of either abandoning the plan or paying as much as $50 million more by restructuring the deal to lure investors to accept the paper.
Some local officials speak of a bailout by the state. And it may come to that if the sales tax increase fails, though any such bailout would undoubtedly include imposition of a strict fiscal regimen by outside monitors. So far, legislators in Sacramento have been reluctant, on moral grounds, to provide aid to a county that has plenty of resources of its own.
With most Orange County politicians unwilling to give up any control to state monitors, reluctant to tighten their belt further or challenge the antitax spirit of local voters, state officials see no reason to help out. "I cannot jeopardize my state's overall credit rating," said Matthew Fong, the state Treasurer, "to bail out Orange County."
That leaves Orange County to the mercy of bond buyers. But why should investors be particularly accommodating toward the county's complex new recovery borrowing plans, asks Mr. Heimowitz of Moody's, when at the same time it "threatens to stab existing bondholders in the back?"

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Once-Humbled Thrifts Are Outrunning the Pack

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
TECHNOLOGY is hot, but savings and loans are hotter.
S.& L.'s? The same institutions whose recklessness personified the excesses of the 1980's? Whose penchant for risky loans nearly caused a financial meltdown? And whose bailout, at last tally, cost American taxpayers more than $200 billion? 
 Yep. Savings and loan companies are enjoying a terrific year, thanks to more predictable interest rates, an increase in mergers and acquisitions and, at last, a recovery in the moribund market for California real estate.
What's more, even though the stocks of these thrifts have come a long way, there are good buys for the investor, said James J. McDermott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a New York investment bank specializing in commercial banks and thrifts.
"A lot of the good news is built into the valuations at these levels," Mr. McDermott allowed. "But there are stocks that are still valued attractively." The takeovers that are accelerating in the industry are another force that can propel stocks upward.
But there is no question that S.& L. stocks have traveled far already. As tracked by Standard & Poor's, the savings and loan industry has gained 39 percent from January 1 through the end of May. That outstrips all of the 87 other industries tracked by Standard & Poor's, except for semiconductors, whose 41.8 percent gain barely edged out the S.& L.'s. And the thrifts' 1995 performance far exceeds both the 27.6 percent gain of those headline-grabbing technology stocks, as measured by the S.& P. high technology composite index, and the 16.1 percent gain of the S.& P. 500.
Of course, financial companies of all stripes got a boost this year as interest rates stabilized after many months of aggressive rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. But thrifts easily outpaced the 24.2 percent gain so far in 1995 of the broad S.& P. financial industry group, whose members range from banks to insurance companies to specialty financial-service providers.
In part, the thrifts' solid performance this year rests on the rocky one of last year. In the 17 months since January 1994, the savings and loan industry's 11 percent gain is about the same as the S.& P. 500's for that period. But unlike the broad market, S.& L. stocks underwent huge swings in that stretch, losing 20 percent from September through mid-December, then regaining that and more this year.
Thanks to the Federal Reserve, rising rates were responsible for a large part of 1994's difficulties -- and their absence explains much about 1995's about-face. In general, financial institutions cannot raise rates on outstanding variable-rate loans as fast as they must lift the rates they pay on money market deposits. As rates move higher, therefore, profit margins get squeezed -- sometimes very tightly. For instance, at Golden West Financial Corporation, a large California thrift, this phenomenon led to a fall in first-quarter earnings from $1.02 a share in 1994 to 87 cents this year.
More recently, however, interest rates have stabilized. And, for savings and loans, level rates both avoid the squeeze and reduce the pressure on thrift managers as they try to predict interest rate spreads.
The industry has also gotten a boost from mergers and acquisitions, which have accelerated over the past 9 to 12 months, Mr. McDermott said. "Banks view thrifts as entry points into certain markets, and as fillers in markets where banks are already represented," he explained. But whatever the reason, these takeovers add "scarcity value" to the stock prices of the thrifts that remain, Mr. McDermott said.
To stay competitive, S.& L.'s are even acquiring each other. Last week, two large Midwestern institutions, Charter One Financial of Cleveland and First Fed Michigan Corporation of Detroit, agreed to merge in a $1.1 billion stock swap.
Finally, the recent S.& L. stock boom is fueled by the late but large recovery of the real estate market out West.
"The California market has been blistering," Mr. McDermott said. "The state was one of the last to recover from the poor real estate market that plagued so many different parts of the country."
Which S.& L.'s look particularly good for investors? Mr. McDermott recommends H.F. Ahmanson & Company, whose shares were trading at $23.25 at Friday's close. Ahmanson sells at only about 1.1 times its net worth per share, and at about eight times estimated 1996 earnings of $2.70 a share. Both measures suggest the stock is relatively cheap.
He also thinks Great Western Financial Corporation and Golden West Financial are attractive, although they trade at slightly higher valuations than does Ahmanson. At Friday's close, they were selling at $22.50 and $49.25, respectively.
All three of these thrifts are from California, where the industry has come a long way from the regionwide depression that formerly characterized it. In its regional breakdown of thrift-stock performance, SNL Securities of Charlottesville, Va., found that while the whole industry is up an average of 26.5 percent this year through May 31, Western region stocks are up 34.5 percent. The next best-performing region, the Southeast, is up only 23 percent, said Philip Colaco, a senior research analyst at SNL.
Indeed, the three big recommended California thrifts happen to be the components of the S.& P. thrift industry index -- which helps to square that measure's finding of a 39 percent return for the thrift industry through May with SNL's 26.5 percent figure.
The late recovery of California real estate is not the only reason the state's thrifts have done better than other thrifts. Rising interest rates had squeezed the Western S.& L.'s very severely because they are in sharp competition for customer deposits with big commercial banks, including Bank America, First Interstate and Wells Fargo.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Bargain Prices in Bonds, Again

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
SOMETIMES opportunity knocks twice. When rising interest rates felled the bond market last year, investors were able to snap up some municipal bond funds at bargain prices. Now, uncertainty in the municipal market -- induced by talk of a flat tax, debate about where rates are headed and Orange County's failure so far to make good on its debt -- has conspired to push the prices down again.
The best deals can be found in closed-end funds, which issue a set number of shares and trade on stock exchanges. Unlike their more plentiful open-end cousins, these funds sell at prices that don't always reflect the value of their underlying assets. 
 When the market is most pessimistic about municipal bonds, as it was toward the end of 1994, the shares of these closed-end funds can trade at sizable discounts to their net asset values. Last year, the median discount on the funds approached 10 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services, the New York research firm. Investors could therefore buy a dollar's worth of assets for only 90 cents. If the underlying portfolio increased in value or the fund gained in popularity, those investors could sell at a profit.
Despite the astonishing rebound in the municipal bond market as long-term rates fell this year, the closed-end funds are once again trading at steep discounts. After shrinking to 6 percent earlier this year, the discount is now hovering at 9 percent. Dozens of funds sport tantalizing discounts of 15 percent to 20 percent.
George Foot, a partner in Newgate Management Associates, a New York investment firm, is convinced now is the time to "jump in with both feet and grab everything you can get your hands on."
Why aren't there more eager buyers, willing to pay full freight for these funds? Municipal bond funds are a tough sell on Wall Street right now. For one thing, there's a lot of discussion on the flat tax proposal by Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas. The proposal would exempt individuals from paying tax on any dividends or capital gains. If the measure should become law, municipal bonds, now prized for their tax exemption, would lose their edge over other types of bonds. The possibility that Orange County, Calif., will not make its debtors whole has also sent shudders through the market.
Some investors, who saw bond funds plummet in value last year, continue to be wary of putting money in the market, while others have decided to cash out after this year's rally. No one, it seems, wants to bet too heavily on the direction of interest rates, which could always defy conventional wisdom and head higher again.
People who share some or all of these fears will be rightfully wary of the market. But Mr. Foot peers through the dark clouds and sees dollar signs. He points to much improved net asset values on the closed-end funds and argues that the share prices will catch up sooner or later. Many of the funds' yields are close to those on 30-year taxable bonds, which throw off taxable income.
Even Joe Mysak, the not-so-optimistic editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer, concedes the wide difference between net asset values and share prices could be attractive. "Whenever they widen out, you've got to take a look," he said.
But before you rush out to buy, remember that there is no guarantee the discounts will shrink or disappear. While closed-end municipal bond funds have tended toward small discounts or slight premiums over the last few years, investors could see even deeper discounts than now if the talk about a flat tax grows louder or if the overall bond market turns south.
"You may get to buy them cheaper," warned Ron Olin, the president of Deep Discount Advisors, an Asheville, N.C., investment firm. He predicts more discounts of 20 percent in the months to come.
"There's no point in buying anything not in the double digits," Mr. Foot said. But investors should make sure the fund's discount is abnormally large and likely to narrow. The best way to do that is to compare the current discount with the fund's average discount for the last year or so. Plenty of funds trade at a consistent discount. The Municipal Advantage Fund, for example, has traded at an average discount of 13 percent for the last year.
Some funds trade at steep discounts because they are very sensitive to moves in interest rates, meaning significant losses if rates climb. Such funds generally went public within the last few years and have portfolios filled with low-yielding bonds. "The younger the portfolio, the more volatile the fund, the deeper the discount," said Tricia Oehme Rothschild, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the Chicago research firm. The net asset value of the Paine Webber Premier Tax-Free Income Fund, begun in late 1992, had an 18 percent gain in 1993 when interest rates fell. But the fund lost nearly 12 percent of its value last year. It now trades at a 19 percent discount.
Among the funds trading at an unusually high discount and worth considering, according to Mr. Foot, is Intercapital Quality Municipal Securities. The fund, with a yield of nearly 7 percent, is trading at a discount of 17 percent, while its average was 11 percent last year. Ms. Rothschild likes the Muniyield Fund, which has among the best three-year returns of the group. It is selling at a discount of roughly 13 percent, compared with 10 percent last year.
Anyone who decides to buy should check out the prospective fund's borrowing habits. Unlike their open-end cousins, closed-end funds can borrow heavily to add to the cash supplied by investors. "That can really boost returns in a rallying market," Ms. Rothschild said. "But the downs are greater in a falling market."
Most closed-end funds leverage their assets by borrowing and thus are much riskier investments than open-end funds. In the drubbing of the municipal market last year, leveraged closed-end funds fell in net asset value by 10 percent on average -- twice the loss of their open-end counterparts.
Investors who can withstand volatility, though, can make more money with leveraged municipal funds. The average leveraged closed-end fund gained 9 percent annually over the last three years, which included a serious bear market, compared with just 7 percent for the average open-end fund, according to Morningstar.
A leveraged fund may have trouble, though, maintaining its dividend. If the difference becomes too narrow between what the fund pays to borrow and what it makes investing in municipal bonds, the manager may see no choice but to cut the dividend.
Two funds that have already cut their dividends are the Van Kampen Merritt Select Sector Municipal Trust and the Nuveen Insured Premium Income Municipal Fund. The Van Kampen fund, which has traded at an average discount of 11 percent over the last year, is now available at a discount of 16 percent, which Mr. Foot finds attractive. Ms. Rothschild steers investors to Nuveen Insured Premium Income Municipal Fund, trading at a discount of 15 percent, almost twice its average discount last year.
If you like bargains but want to skip the leverage, one possibility is the Managed Municipals Portfolio, run by the same manager as Smith Barney Managed Municipals, the top open-end fund over the last three and five years. Investors can tap into Joseph Deane's expertise at a 10 percent discount by buying shares of his closed-end fund.
Although there's no way to be sure a discount will disappear, some bets are better. Mr. Foot recommends shares of Putnam Investment Grade Intermediate Municipal Trust, trading at a 7 percent discount. The funds' trustees have voted to merge the fund into an open-end fund, an action that would entitle investors to a full dollar for a dollar's worth of underlying assets. Shareholders have yet to vote on the proposal, and would have to sit tight for at least six months after the merger to avoid a 2 percent redemption fee. Still, it's one good shot at buying low and selling high.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: OFF THE SHELF;
Some Light Summer Reading: Human Failings, Moral Decline

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE 

 BODY:
THE business best-seller list has settled into summer somnolence, with few changes since last month. The naughty American public continues to spend no small portion of its ever-flattening wages seeking wisdom between the covers. The hard covers, that is, of "The Seven Spiritual Laws of Success," which remains at No. 1. 
 Sneaking into the fray, at No. 14, is John Allen Paulos's latest contribution to his innumeracy oeuvre, "A Mathematician Looks at the Newspaper" (Basic Books, $18), in which the author continues to encourage readers to beat up on themselves for having skipped out on higher math. It is a rich, but as the current book shows, exhaustible topic.
Apparently inexhaustible is anxiety over the moral decline and fall of the American people. This concern comes from an unusual source in "Silent Sabotage: Rescuing Our Careers, Our Companies and Our Lives From the Creeping Paralysis of Anger and Bitterness" (Amacom, $19.95). The author, William J. Morin, runs Drake Beam Morin, a "leading organizational and individual transition consulting firm," it says on the book jacket. This means Mr. Morin most likely meets people who are most likely quite fearful about the future -- "organization and individual transition" often being a euphemism for dismissals. He observes rudderless, untrusting and untrustworthy institutions and individuals.
On the plus side, he talks about values without once mentioning Newt Gingrich, the Christian Coalition or the nefarious influence of rap music. On the minus side, he thinks business is the only major institution in a position to salve the nation's soul, curiously underestimating the role the companies have played the last few years in undermining middle-class faith in the social contract. In one way he may be right, however; Americans feel best about themselves when they're fighting a just war or when the economy is booming. In this country, only business can drive that boom.
While we're on a decline-and-fall theme, isn't it enough of an insult to the English language that buzzwords exist? Do we really need a guide likely to encourage their dispersal? Actually, Charles B. Wendel and Elaine Svensson, the authors of "Business Buzzwords: Everything You Need to Know to Speak the Lingo of the 90's" (Amacom, $16.95), do perform a valuable service. They synopsize the work of the leading management gurus, thus sparing readers the cost of going to the sources.
Readers may romp through Drucker, Senge, Handy, Peters and everyone else lickety-split, much as undergraduates once did when they read Bertrand Russell's great "History of Western Philosophy" in lieu of the draggy, impenetrable originals. The book gives instruction on how to recognize a meaningful buzzword as well as how to create one. And you thought great buzzwords were pure inspiration.
The entry on "downsizing" is instructive: related words include "de-massing, denominator management, early retirement, reductions-in-force, re-engineering, restructuring, retrenchment" and, a personal favorite, "right-sizing." George Orwell, phone home.
Employees who feel they have been unfairly right-sized may want to consult "Your Rights in the Workplace: An Employee Guide to Legal Protection," by Richard Strohm (Career Press, $8.95). The book includes a good basic introduction to employment law and includes a survey of workplace regulations. The pep talk at the beginning about hiring a lawyer is probably focused too heavily on potential litigation; most people seeking justice from their former employers would be better off pursuing an equitable settlement rather than litigation. A good negotiator's price is far above rubies.
Clearly, a great deal of energy went into "Cracking the Corporate Closet" (Harper Business, $23), possibly most of it into constructing a subtitle so long that the authors -- all three, count 'em -- must have thought that if they just kept writing, a focus for the book would emerge.
Daniel Baker, Sean Strub, Bill Henning and the gang at the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force surveyed some 200 companies on lesbian and gay issues on whether they provided things like domestic-partner benefits and AIDS education and had gay and lesbian employee groups. The result is typical of "best companies" books: old news, lists, no interpretation and no context. Hearsay is a lot more useful.
Also not very satisfying is Kevin Maney's "Megamedia Shakeout: The Inside Story of the Leaders and the Losers in the Exploding Communications Industry" (John Wiley, $24.95). But it has the virtue of being unsatisfying largely because the story is unfinished. Somewhere out there, people are getting rich on new technology and a vision of a wired world. A whole vast area of wealth is being created by the public's thirst for more talk-show channels! America in decline. Sorry, Mr. Morin. You gotta love it.

HEADLINE: COPING;
Dose of Vitality From 'The Other America'

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
ON the Union Square subway platform, a Zimbabwean opened his duffel bag to show us watches and flashlights. He picked them up in Brooklyn, he said, and was on his way to sell them in the Bronx. In a richly insincere voice that recalled childhood visits to Jewish clothing stores on the Lower East Side, he told us that he was practically giving the flashlights. Such a good deal.
"That man is a red-blood corpuscle," said Joel Millman, once we were on the train to the Bronx. "Immigrants are pumping oxygen and money into the city. They do jobs no one wants to do, they create markets that weren't there, they're replacing older immigrant groups." 
 Mr. Millman, an old friend, is writing a book for Viking Penguin about the impact of immigration. He may call it "The Other Americans," an homage to and an update of Michael Harrington's 1962 classic on poverty in the midst of plenty. Mr. Millman is finding wealth and hope in poor neighborhoods. He took me on a tour of his thesis.
If the Zimbabwean is a corpuscle, Heinz Vieluf is a transfusion. He is the son of a German wurst maker who migrated to the Dominican Republic, married, and founded Cibao Meat Products in New York. The father's portrait hangs in the office of the plant on St. Ann's Avenue. The brass plate reads: Don Siegfried Vieluf, Fundador.
Heinz, 36, was educated in prep schools, married a Dominican and lives in Rockland Country with his three children. The 8,200-square-foot plant employs 25, mostly Dominicans (many at the minimum wage, no union or benefits), and grinds out between 50,000 and 85,000 pounds a week of spiced meats under various brand names to appeal to different ethnic and age groups; Dominicans like it hotter than Italians, said Mr. Vieluf, all people prefer less spice as they grow older. He is alert to the subtle differences between Mexican and Colombian taste buds (so far, Ecuadorians and Peruvians will buy sausages aimed at the Colombian market), and to the nuances of the job market.
"Ten years ago, I'd lose five employees every couple of months," he said. "They could make a lot more money dealing drugs. Now there's a big pool of unemployed, and a lot of dead drug dealers."
Outside, in a gray drizzle, there were no yellow cabs, but we found a licensed old Ford cruising illegally. For $6, which he said he would not share with the dispatcher, the Dominican driver took us to a section of Bathgate that may someday be Golden Krust City. Lowell Hawthorne, who came from Jamaica in 1981 with his entrepeneur father and eight of his 10 siblings, is expanding their bakery and pattie factory, and opening retail outlets.
"If Taco Bell can do it, so can Golden Krust," said Mr. Hawthorne, 35, who attended Lehman College and has the immigrant go-getter's disdain for those on welfare. "It would be degrading to go home and tell people you are getting food stamps."
With the help of a saving cooperative, called a "su-su," Mr. Hawthorne bought a $19,000 home in the Bronx 14 years ago. He has since moved his wife and four children to Rockland County.
The Golden Krust plant has 68 workers, mostly Jamaicans, making seven types of patties; older Jamaicans, he says, need that "ding" on their tongues, younger Jamaicans and Americans prefer milder hits.
It was raining harder, and we couldn't find even an illegally cruising cab, so we got into an unlicensed jitney driven by a Nigerian who recommended a new African Restaurant (that was its name) at 1987 University Avenue. The place was packed with Africans and Mr. Millman, his enthusiasm fueled, talked about the optimism and sense of community that immigrants bring, an essential for American progress. The manager, Mohammed Abdullay, a Ghanian, came out of the kitchen for compliments on the kingfish, the cow's feet and the okra stew.
We worked off lunch ducking into store-front hair-braiding salons. The African women inside were wary; hair-braiding, sometimes done on house calls, is a booming ghetto business that often operates without the burdens of taxes, licenses or inspections.
At a warehouse on Jerome Avenue, Felipe Chavez opened a can of the Del Carmen brand tender cactus in brine imported by his cousin, Felix Sanchez, who came to New York from Mexico 20 years ago and sold tortillas in Brooklyn, door to door. Mr. Sanchez expanded to supply bodegas and on this day was off preparing to confront Gruma, the Mexican tortilla empire, in a battle for the New York market.
Mr. Millman threw himself at the day's first yellow cab, fresh from the garage en route to Manhattan. The driver refused to tell his story, so Mr. Millman described his latest find, a Senegalese who stripped off the European-style clothing from dark-skinned dolls she bought from China and re-dressed them in African fashions she sewed herself from kente cloth. The dolls sold so well on 125th Street that she sent 50 to Dakar to test-market them on American tourists.

LENGTH: 1149 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: Cosmetic Surgery;
When Health Care Cuts Cost More

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
REPUBLICANS have boiled down their Medicare proposals to a number and a sound bite: They can wring more than $250 billion from the national health insurance program for the elderly over the next seven years, they say, even while "preserving, protecting and improving" it.
 No big, comprehensive, Clintonesque health care overhaul for them. Just smart, targeted, money-saving reforms of outmoded government programs. After all, the Clinton Administration discovered the danger of over-reaching, right? 
 Right. But now the Republicans face the danger of piecemeal reform, of trimming and tinkering with a program that covers 37 million beneficiaries and is the lifeblood of many if not most of the nation's hospitals, doctors and academic medical centers. It will, like it or not, have big consequences, intended and unintended. Efforts to save money in one part of the program can end up costing money somewhere else.
 "Physicians understand reimbursement realities and they understand their patients," said Mike Brown, the administrator of a tiny, 30-bed hospital in Wahoo, Neb. "They do what is best for their patients."
 In other words, medical needs usually have a way of getting met. And, if they are not, those needs have a way of popping up later -- more serious, more advanced, more expensive to treat. Unlike private employers, who are much praised on Capitol Hill these days for controlling their health costs, the Government ultimately ends up with responsibility for the oldest, poorest, sickest Americans, which are the groups that Medicare and Medicaid cover. Efficiencies do not come easily. Miscalculations matter, immensely.
 As Republican leaders in Congress try to find the huge savings they seek in Medicare and as states struggle to control their own health care costs, nothing exemplifies the challenge facing them more than Medicare's home health program. It offers a case study in the potential ripple effects of seemingly simple little money-saving reforms.
 Every policy maven who looks at Medicare's escalating costs jumps on the home health program as a major culprit. Home health care accounts for about eight cents of every dollar spent on Medicare. But spending on these services -- like physical therapy, skilled nursing or the assistance of a lesser-skilled home health aide -- has soared over the past five years, from $2.5 billion in 1989 to $13.7 billion in 1994. Not only did the number of beneficiaries increase; the number of visits per beneficiary jumped from 27 in 1989 to 58 in 1994.
 In 1995, an estimated 3.46 million people will receive home health care benefits from Medicare; the average visit costs just under $65. Critics warn that what began as a cost-effective way of caring for and rehabilitating people after an illness or an operation has gotten dangerously out of control.
 One answer, to many on Capitol Hill, seems obvious: require clients of home health care to pay part of the bill. As a planning paper from Republicans on the House Budget Committee put it, "Requiring beneficiaries to share the cost of these services would help to discourage over-utilization and reduce the Medicare subsidy." That plan contemplates a 20 percent copayment, with an exclusion for those whose incomes are below 150 percent of the official poverty line (meaning elderly couples, for example, with incomes below $13,446).

 
 
'Quicker and Sicker'
 This, of course, is sound economic theory; it assumes that people will stop requesting or receiving all but the most necessary services if they are forced to pay for part of the costs. And that some of the services being rendered are indeed unnecessary or could be paid for by the beneficiaries.
 But there are big demographic and technological forces behind the rise in home health costs, which are unlikely to change much as a result of simply requiring the client to pay a fee.
 One reason for the increase in home health services was a decision by policymakers over the past 10 years to cut down on hospital stays. People are released from the hospital "quicker and sicker," as some health planners put it, with the understanding that they will get more cost-effective care at home or in a skilled nursing facility.
 "When you have outpatient surgeries and shorter inpatient stays, you'll have more home health care," said Representative Nancy Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, an influential member of the Ways and Means subcommittee on health. "We need to be very mindful of rising home health costs as a consequence of other actions we've taken."
 Home health beneficiaries are getting care for longer and longer periods of time. The program's scope has expanded in part because of a lawsuit in the late 1980's, in which the Government was accused of applying this benefit far too narrowly and arbitrarily. But behind the increase, of course, is the growth in America's aging population. Hundreds of thousands of old, disabled and chronically ill people need help to stay in their homes.
 Congress over the years has debated the establishment of a major new long-term care program, but never passed it. Nonetheless, home health care "has become sort of a backdoor way of expanding long term care," said Stuart Altman, a health economist at Brandeis and a member of a Medicare advisory committee.
 Call it the "push it down here, it pops up there" phenomenon, which gives some analysts pause when they think about the implications of simply redefining the home health program to tighten its eligibility requirements. What if squeezing home health care ends up putting more people back into hospitals or into nursing homes, where their costs are picked up by Medicare, which is fully financed by Washington, and by Medicaid, which is only partly?
 And speaking of Medicaid, Joshua Wiener, an analyst at the Brookings Institution, warns that Republican cuts in projected spending for that program fail to take into account the growth over the next five years in the population 85 and older. While Medicaid is usually thought of as a program for low-income younger people, 30 percent of its spending goes for nursing home and other long-term care, in part because people deplete their assets to qualify.

 
 
Kindest Cuts
 It would be simpler if spending could be reined in by cracking down on waste, fraud and abuse -- typically the most popular and painless solution to budget-cutting. But that saves only so much.
 Actually reducing services is fodder for the ripple effects game. What if Medicare payment restrictions force some already teetering rural hospitals into insolvency? What if reducing the Medicare subsidy for medical education is a body blow to the nation's big teaching hospitals? The questions spin on, and help explain, perhaps, what drove Ira Magaziner, the Clinton health czar, to produce a health plan that filled 1,342 pages.

HEADLINE: The World;
French Annoyance At the U.S. Comes In Several Courses

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THE French have always been prickly allies good to have on your side in a fight but ready to pick one as well, particularly if you come from an Anglo-Saxon country like Britain or the United States.
 These days, Britain is on France's side in the European-American disagreement over what to do about the war in Bosnia, but regarding the United States the French are in a disgruntled mood. 
 They were decidedly unimpressed last week, for example, when President Clinton sent an aircraft carrier to the Adriatic and said he might finally, if only temporarily, commit American ground troops to Bosnia in a plan to better protect the French, British and other United Nations troops already there, hundreds of whom were taken hostage by Bosnian Serbs. The daily Liberation said dismissively of the Americans, "Probably they will continue to quietly smuggle arms to the Bosnian Government."
 So what else is new? is the question likely to be asked by anyone old enough to remember how de Gaulle barred Britain from the European Community and kicked NATO headquarters out of France to Brussels.
 De Gaulle's political heir, Jacques Chirac, elected to the French presidency on May 7, has fond memories of a summer at Harvard in 1953, and will be able to use his good American English when he sees President Clinton in the White House this month before the world economic summit meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
 Mr. Chirac will probably tell him then that France, and Europe, cannot tolerate the United States using the value of the dollar on currency markets as a trade weapon against Japan -- and that Europe doesn't think much of American trade sanctions against Japan either.

 
 
A Threat, Not a Leader
 While Americans lately are fixated on Japan, the French are still fixated on America, which they see not as a leading trade partner -- far more French trade is with Europe, and in particular Germany, than with the United States -- but as a threat to true European independence.
 A truly independent Europe has been the goal of French policy ever since de Gaulle, and it goes without saying that the French see an independent Europe as one guided by their ideas. France led the fight two years ago between the European Union and the United States over European subsidies for farm exports, movies and TV, and France now sees itself leading the fight for an independent European defense policy.
 Germany and other European allies are increasingly aligning themselves with the Gaullist view that the United States cannot be relied on as Europe's main guarantor of security, because America has other interests in Asia and the Western Hemisphere.
 That is why France has its own independent nuclear deterrent and one of the world's most important arms industries. It is sounding increasingly competitive about that industry these days. "The Americans have launched into an enormous effort to restructure their arms industry, accompanied by great commercial aggressiveness that is helped by the fall of the dollar, and they are eliminating us from the world market," said Pierre Lellouche, one of Mr. Chirac's advisers, during the election campaign.
"At the moment, in the trans-Atlantic arms trade, there are six times more arms in the United States-Europe direction, and the Americans control about 60 percent of the NATO market," Mr. Lellouche warned. "Europe is way behind the curve."
 In the past, this competitive urge has often fixed on symbols. France and Britain cooperated in the 1960's to build the supersonic Concorde, only to have the plane declared too noisy to fly supersonically over American soil and thus doomed to economic failure in its most important market. Pierre Cochereau, the late organist of Notre Dame Cathedral, barred American guest artists for years on the ground that up close, the organ was louder than the Concorde and thus too much for tender American ears.
 With the lumbering American-made Boeing 747 dominating the intercontinental aviation market in the 1970's, it took Europe years to catch up, with the Airbus. But one of the biggest problems Airbus Industrie now, and of European exporters generally, is the competitive disadvantage caused by the weakness of the dollar, which makes American exports cheaper.

 
 
Coin for the Realm
 So one of Mr. Chirac's most important campaign pledges was a promise to prepare quickly for European monetary union to free France from dependence on a fluctuating dollar as the medium of international trade. "The day we have a strong European currency is the day we can finally stand up as equals to the United States," said Franc David, a French economist.
 All this French defensiveness reflects a national inferiority complex. Germany, France's real rival for European leadership, does not suffer from it, but the Germans, too, are more inclined than they used to be to define their interests as Europeans rather than as trans-Atlantic partners.
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher tried to respond to these concerns in a speech in Madrid on Friday, emphasizing that political and economic cooperation have to become the binding ties of the North Atlantic alliance in place of military links.
 But in Spain, France and Germany, much like in the United States, political leaders worry more about how to create jobs in their unemployment-stricken economies than about how to keep up the alliances that got them through the cold war.
 For the French and most other Europeans, building up European trade and protecting it from the Americans and Asians is the answer to the jobs question. Mr. Chirac has made jobs the major theme of his Presidency and, like his predecessor, Francois Mitterrand, he is bound to put a Gallic edge of competitive tension on his relations with America in diplomacy as well as trade.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Morality Play;
Now, Social Engineers Design at Right Angles

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
THE phrase "social engineering" has long been a pejorative fired off in the heat of argument to suggest government manipulation run amok. Conservatives have invoked the phrase to attack liberal policies ranging from busing to affirmative action, from health care reform to lifting the military's ban on gay soldiers. Mostly, the charge has been lobbed from right to left.
 But when the Christian Coalition recently unveiled its platform for shoring up the family and re-tethering America to certain moral moorings, some conservatives seemed to be committing the very sin of which they had accused the left. Here were self-styled defenders of individual liberty, proponents of getting government off people's backs, asking the government to subsidize housewifery, decide who -- if anyone -- can get a legal abortion, enable more parents to send their children to private or parochial schools and to let them pray in public ones. 
 "When it comes to government, no one's a pure libertarian," says Jerome L. Himmelstein, a sociologist at Amherst College and the author of "To the Right: The Transformation of American Conservatism" (University of California, 1990). "Another way to say that is: Everyone's a hypocrite. Everyone wants the government to do something. It just depends on what."

 
 
Meddling
 And on when. Last November, Representative Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican who is Speaker of the House, assured Republican governors that the party's goals for the economy and welfare would take precedence over potentially more divisive social issues. "We can't be here suggesting the social engineering of the right will be more clever than the social engineering of the left," he said then.
 As some conservatives see it, they are only responding to decades of meddling by liberals in government. Advocating a platform already largely supported by many -- though surely not the most libertarian -- conservative elected officials and politicians, the Christian Coalition weighed in only after having watched the government get involved in moral and social issues that the religious right believes belong outside government's reach.
 "Many fundamentalists and evangelicals got into politics because they felt imposed upon," said Michael Cromartie, a senior fellow at the Ethics and Public Policy Center, a conservative research organization in Washington. "The debate becomes not whether these people ought to be meddling but what is the most prudent and principled way to be involved."
 Now comes the Contract With the American Family, the Christian Coalition's social and cultural agenda for Congress, billed as "a bold plan to strengthen the family and restore common-sense values." Unveiled in Washington last month, it calls for a constitutional amendment allowing student-sponsored prayer in schools and tuition tax credits to encourage school choice.
 The coalition is also calling for "family-friendly tax relief" to encourage marriage and to honor "the valuable role" of the homemaker in society. It wants to cut Federal funding for family-planning agencies that promote abortion and a "Parental Rights Act" to empower parents in attempting to control their children.
 A number of critics say the contract violates the separation of church and state. But some critics -- many of them liberals -- also say it is hypocritical.
 "They use the rhetoric of small government," said Ira Glasser, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, who contrasts what he calls the "authoritarian right" with libertarian purists. "But in fact they present the most pervasive program of government intrusion into personal freedom."

 
 
Off Your Back
 Erwin Chemerinsky, a constitutional law scholar at the University of Southern California Law Center, called the contract "the antithesis of getting the government off people's backs," adding, "to the extent that they want greater government regulation of abortion, that's putting the government directly in one of the most intimate and important aspects of people's lives."
 And Rabbi David Saperstein, director of the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism, said: "There is really a serious contradiction in what they're asserting. It sounds like they want the government to be involved when it supports the position that they believe in."
 Government intrusion, it seems, is in the eye of the beholder. While liberals like to say they use government simply to create opportunities, conservatives describe the liberal agenda as social engineering. And while conservatives say they want government simply to protect the rights of, say, students to organize prayers, liberals see conservatives using government to foist their values on everyone else.

 
 
'Under Siege'
 "Is it government intervention to deny benefits to poor women who need family planning -- or is it government withdrawal?" Rabbi Saperstein said of the Christian Coalition's agenda. He sees it as government manipulation -- using "the power of the purse to prevent women from exercising their right to reproductive health."
 But many conservatives insist the contract would impose nothing on anyone. They say they want only to eliminate disincentives to moral behavior.
 "There is a big perception difference," said Gary L. Bauer, president of the Family Research Council, a conservative research group. "I think a lot of the popular culture and elites see fundamentalists and evangelicals suddenly organizing and attempting to impose narrow dogma. But when I talk to people who fall into those categories, they say, 'We've been under siege.' "
 Mr. Bauer calls the conservative "pro-family" platform "a defensive agenda," one, he says, that "merely is trying to reassert what was pretty much the norm as recently as 25 years ago."
 For both sides, it matters deeply which views the government appears to endorse, even if much of what is at stake may be less tangible than actual resources or rights and when some of the behavior being debated may be beyond government's ability to legislate.
 In the end, each side wants the government's endorsement. And it may be just plain disingenuous when the other side indignantly objects. Whatever they call it, most conservatives and liberals alike don't mind social engineering when it is a means to their ends. They don't mind legislating morality as long as it's theirs.
 "Both the right and the left care very much about socializing people to the appropriate moral positions," said John C. Green, a political scientist at the University of Akron who studies grass-roots politics and the Christian Right. "Whether it's respecting people regardless of sexual preference or honoring God, those are moral positions."
 To which Tom Minnery, vice president of public policy for Focus on the Family, a conservative religious group, said: "Of course government legislates morality. The only question is: whose morality?"

HEADLINE: The Nation;
America's Opportunity Gap

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AMERICA'S Jeffersonian ideals of equality and its reputation as a land of opportunity have been battered recently by evidence of a widening gulf between the rich and the poor. And now a growing body of research is showing that, at the same time, it is becoming more difficult to move into the economic elite.
 Social mobility has not risen, the latest studies show -- notwithstanding conservatives' assertions that modern Horatio Algers still abound. Indeed, social mobility has diminished for many, particularly the poor. Most troubling of all, the trends toward widening income inequality and reduced opportunity appear to be more pronounced among young people today, suggesting that the country is headed toward a more stratified society. 
 The most dramatic evidence comes in recent research by Professors Greg J. Duncan of Northwestern University and Timothy Smeeding of Syracuse University. They looked at surveys of the personal finances of 5,000 households, conducted every year since the late 1960's by the University of Michigan.
 Comparing the 1980's and early 1990's with the late 1960's and the 1970's, the researchers found that the poor were becoming more likely to stay poor and the affluent more likely to stay affluent. They found the middle class, defined as households with after-tax incomes of $24,000 to $72,000, is increasingly pulled apart: the odds of becoming affluent or poor have increased while the odds of staying in the middle class have dwindled.
 The study also found that young men's chances of attaining a middle-class income by age 30 is dwindling. While 60 percent of those turning 30 before 1989 managed to do so, only 42 percent have succeeded since then. The pattern applies regardless of race, parents' income or education.
 "What's striking is how uniform this fall in upward mobility has been across all demographic groups in the labor market," Professor Duncan said.
 One possible explanation is that income inequality has become particularly pronounced among the young. A few young lawyers, doctors, financiers or entrepreneurs have prospered while many others struggle for low-wage jobs. People who did not go to college in the 1960's were still able to find high-paying manufacturing jobs and have kept them. But high school graduates today find fewer such jobs as technological advances and growing foreign trade have reduced the need for unskilled and semi-skilled labor in factories.

 
 
'Borne the Brunt'
 "To the extent that the widening of distribution of income has occurred, it really is true among the younger people rather than older, and younger people have borne the brunt of the changes," said Barry Bosworth, a Brookings Institution economist.
 As always in economics, some researchers have come to different conclusions. Professors Peter Gottschalk of Boston College and Robert Moffitt of Brown University concluded in a paper published by Brookings last year that earnings have become much less stable.
 Many people rocket up in the earnings rankings because of a particularly good year of sales commissions or bonuses or consulting contracts. But the same people are also increasingly likely to see their earnings drop dramatically the following year, Professors Gottschalk and Moffitt found. The overall trend remains toward more permanent differences in earnings. And at least for the poorest Americans, those earnings are going steadily down after adjusting for inflation.
 "Your chance of escaping the bottom has not gotten better, but conditions at the bottom have gotten much worse," Professor Gottschalk said.
 In that regard, some other countries are doing better. One study found that the children of poor families in Sweden are more likely to prosper than the children of poor American families. And three Syracuse University professors have concluded that the United States had no greater social mobility than Germany from 1983 to 1988. Moreover, while the gap between well-paid workers and low-paid workers did not change in Germany during those years, in the United States the gap grew. Here, a worker in the top 10 percent of wage-earners had 4 times the earnings of a worker in the bottom 10 percent in 1983. By 1988, the ratio had climbed to 4.33.
 All of this evidence has prompted both Republicans and Democrats to begin quoting their favorite philosophers on matters of wealth and fairness. The Republicans are currently citing Friedrich A. von Hayek, an Austrian-born economist and Nobel Laureate who championed free-market ideals. "All societies have unequal wealth and income dispersion, and there is no positive basis for criticizing any degree of market determined inequality," the Republican majority of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress said in a report on May 9.
 Democrats prefer John Rawls, the American philosopher who contends that a society is fair if its level of inequality appears acceptable to a hypothetical individual who is about to join the society and does not know if the inequality would work for or against him. Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said that young Americans who are poor or ill-educated increasingly know that they will occupy a place in society in which inequality works against them.
 If they refuse to accept the inequality, that could strain the nation's social and political fabric, Mr. Reich said. "The moral core at the heart of capitalism," he said, "the faith that if you work hard you can get ahead, is being eroded."
