HEADLINE: The Debate on Diversity in California Shifts

SERIES: Affirmative Action: The Issue on Campus

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif.

 BODY:
The photograph in Sproul Hall of the 10 Cal "yell leaders" from the early 1960's, in their Bermuda shorts and letter sweaters, leaps out like an artifact from an ancient civilization. They are all fresh-faced, and in a way that is unimaginable now, they are all white.
But here on the flagship campus of the University of California system, the epicenter of the affirmative-action debate in higher education today, the popular arguments that often frame the debate in images of black versus white seem as out of date as the ducktails and bouffant hairdos of those 60's cheerleaders. 
 The University of California's Berkeley campus was among the first of the nation's leading universities to embrace elements of affirmative action in its admissions policies, and now boasts that it has one of the most diverse campuses in America, with whites accounting for only 32 percent of the student body. Asian-Americans are the largest ethnic group on campus, accounting for 39 percent of all students. Hispanic students account 13.8 percent and blacks for 5.5 percent.
But Berkeley may soon become one of the first campuses in the nation to abandon the cornerstone of affirmative action in higher education: admission preferences based on race. The university board of regents expects to consider a proposal to prohibit the use of race and ethnicity as factors in admissions.
At their July meeting the regents, who are appointed by the governors on staggered terms, are likely to vote on the proposal being drafted by a black regent, Ward Connerly, to end the affirmative-action admissions policy.
[Gov. Pete Wilson's order last Wednesday curtailing affirmative-action programs in state government does not affect the University of California system.]
There are two unusual twists to the assault on affirmative action in the University of California system that defy stereotypes. First, the race-based preferences are being attacked by a black member of the board of regents and defended by Berkeley's Asian-American chancellor. Second, the racial makeup here has extended the fault line in the debate to minority versus minority as well as black versus white.
Fairness, many Asian-Americans in California argue, demands that admissions be based strictly on merit as defined by grades and test scores.
Many black and Hispanic residents argue that fairness requires sticking with programs intended to counter the effects of racial prejudice.
Some critics of affirmative action assert that the success that Asian-Americans have achieved without being given preferential treatment raises questions about the necessity of race-based preferences as a remedy for overcoming historic prejudice.
These same critics argue that affirmative action to aid historically disadvantaged black and Hispanic students has become a new form of discrimination against Asian-Americans, although black and Hispanic students are still underrepresented at Berkeley as measured by their share of the state's population.
The regents have a good idea of what effect an admissions policy based strictly on grades and test scores would have on racial diversity throughout the university system. A report commissioned by the board and completed recently determined that dropping race-based preferences in admissions would result in a precipitous drop in black and Hispanic freshmen and an increase in admissions of Asian-American and, marginally, white students.
Berkeley's Chancellor, Chang-Lin Tien, a Chinese-American and an enthusiastic supporter of affirmative action, said in an interview that the widespread discrimination that still existed against Asian-Americans in the United States should make them especially sensitive to the need for programs to compensate for past discrimination.
But more important, he said, affirmative action at Berkeley represents an essential and healthy adaptation to a changing California and a changing nation.
"People like to say that affirmative action is kind of a way to redress past wrongs; I don't see it that way," Mr. Chang said. "Especially in a university, it's about creating the best educational atmosphere for all students. Affirmative action isn't for underrepresented minorities. It's for the benefit of the larger society."
The debate over how to balance diversity and fairness has already become contentious.
In a broader political arena, a proposed statewide ballot, supported by Governor Wilson, would prohibit all state programs intended to promote race-based preferences in hiring, promotions, university admissions or the award of public contracts.
The last time the regents discussed race-based admissions, on May 18, about 200 student demonstrators showed up to protest any change in the current policy, temporarily disrupting the meeting. While there have been no direct threats of campus disruptions if the system's affirmative-action goals are rescinded, the issue has long been a trigger for volatile passions.
"I'd say that 70 percent of Asians look at affirmative action and see a system in which they get the shaft," said Andrew Wong, Berkeley's student body president in the 1994-95 academic year. "I believe in a meritocracy, not in preferences, and if that produces a less diverse place, well, that's the social cost you pay."
 
The Experience
Who Is Admitted And Who Is Not
 Few places have had more of a commitment to diversity than the Berkeley campus, rated as perhaps the most prestigious public university in America. Beginning with the admission of women in the 1880's and with an early form of affirmative action called the Educational Opportunity Program in 1964, Berkeley has aggressively promoted inclusion.
The University of California was also the target of the lawsuit in the late 1970's that created the current legal standard for affirmative action; Allan P. Bakke argued that he had been denied admission to the medical school at the University of California at Davis because a space had been reserved for a less-qualified minority student. In a 5-to-4 ruling in 1978, the Supreme Court said that it was permissible to take race into account in admissions so long as there were no quotas and race was not the sole or primary factor.
Affirmative action on a university campus can play out in different ways, from recruiting students to hiring faculty. The most contentious questions at Berkeley have had to do with admissions: Who gets the sought-after acceptances? And what are the best criteria for judging applicants?
The university says that it seeks to enroll a student body that "encompasses the broad diversity of cultural, racial, geographic and socio-economic backgrounds characteristic of California."
It also says there are no admissions quotas, reflecting the decision in the Bakke case.
Berkeley can afford to be choosy; it attracts more applicants with perfect 4.0 high school grade-point averages than it has slots in its freshman class. But as the university has become ever more selective the competition for admission has raised questions about the costs of diversity. Last year the campus received 22,500 freshman applications. It accepted 8,400 students to fill 3,500 freshman slots.
Administrators say affirmative action in admissions has been a success, maintaining educational excellence as Berkeley has become more diverse.
As late as 1984, whites made up 60 percent of the undergraduates at Berkeley. Now, the student body is 39 percent Asian, 32 percent white, 14 percent Hispanic, 6 percent black, 1 percent American Indian and 8 percent other groups or people who did not identify their race.
In 1984, the mean grade-point average for freshmen was 3.62 out of a possible 4.0, and the mean combined score on what are now known as the Scholastic Assessment Tests was 1,155 of a possible 1,600. In 1994, when whites constituted only a third of the undergraduates, the mean grade-point average was 3.84 and the mean S.A.T. score was 1,225.
Those numbers have risen for every ethnic group, according to data released by campus officials. The percentage of students who graduate within six years is also at an all-time high -- 79 percent compared with 55 percent in the mid-1950's.
"There's the myth that in the course of diversifying the campus we've lowered our standards," said Bob Laird, director of undergraduate admissions. "By any measure, the opposite is true. If you divide the freshman class in five parts and you compare any of the quintiles, the current freshman class is stronger than the one 10 years ago."
Moreover, the proportions of so-called underrepresented minorities -- primarily black and Hispanic students -- are not close to their numbers in the population. Black and Hispanic students now constitute about 37 percent of the high school graduates in California but only about 19 percent of the students at Berkeley.
Many black and Hispanic students complain that Berkeley is drawing back from the kind of outreach and openness needed to attract minorities. Black enrollment, which peaked at at 1,647, or 7.7 percent of undergraduates, in 1989, currently stands at 1,127, or 5.5 percent. Hispanic enrollment, which peaked at 3,158, or 15.1 percent of undergraduates, in 1991, is now 2,800, or 13.8 percent.
"What they call affirmative action is mostly just an appeasement, and now they're taking away what's there," said Mireta Khalil, a black 21-year-old junior from Los Angeles.
Under Berkeley's complicated admissions system, about 95 percent of the freshmen admitted come from the top eighth of high school students. Half of the applicants are accepted on academic merit as measured by high school grades. About 45 percent are picked using a combination of academic merit and more subjective factors, including essays, extracurricular activities and whether the student has overcome cultural or economic disadvantages or physical disabilities.
Up to 5 percent are admitted as "special action" admissions. They are not among the top eighth but are admitted because they are athletes, have special talents or fit the university's diversity needs and are deemed to have the ability to succeed at Berkeley. Of this group, 34 percent are black and 38 percent are Hispanic, 10 percent are Asian and 17 percent are white.
Mr. Laird said it made no sense to say that all the other preferences the university uses are acceptable but that increasing racial and ethnic diversity among undergraduates is not.
But critics of affirmative action point out that the policy means that black and Hispanic students with poorer credentials than whites and Asians are being admitted to Berkeley.
Whites admitted as freshmen in 1994 had a mean grade-point average of 3.86. For Asians the figure was 3.95. Blacks averaged 3.43 and Hispanic students averaged 3.65.
The gap in S.A.T. scores was wider. Blacks averaged 994, Hispanic applicants 1,032, whites 1,256 and Asians 1,293.
Graduation rates differ sharply, too. Six-year graduation rates for undergraduates are 59 percent for blacks, 64 percent for Hispanic students, 84 percent for whites and 88 percent for Asians.
But officials say the differences have narrowed over time, and it is not clear how much they reflect academic problems and how much they reflect differences in financial resources that could lead more minorities to fail to graduate.
 
The Attitudes
Resentments On All Sides
 Troy Duster, a Berkeley sociologist who has studied affirmative action for years, said it was being made a scapegoat for rejection.
"You've got 9,000 kids with 4.0 averages competing for 3,500 places," Professor Duster said. "Now, obviously, they can't all fit. But every one of them who gets turned away believes they got turned away because of affirmative action."
To Professor Duster, the furor over affirmative action is fueled by two illusions. The first is that opportunity today can be divorced from the historical conditions that created huge gaps in resources and achievements separating ethnic groups. The second is that there is a simple, quantifiable way, like test scores, to assess merit.
"There's an arrogance in the idea that you can put people on an ordinal ranking system," he said. "I'm not opposed to people getting straight A's. But I don't want society to see that as the only thing worth talking about."
But if the goal of affirmative action is to move toward a more equal society, many students assert that the effect is to create a campus obsessed with racial and ethnic divisions.
"It's created a stigma," said Darren Cook, a white graduate student planning to go to medical school. "I'm tall. If they decided there were not enough tall people here, I'd walk around and people would think, 'Oh, there's one of those tall admissions.' It sounds cruel, but that's how people think."
Many black and Hispanic students dispute that argument, saying the affirmative-action debate has become merely a socially acceptable way of voicing already existing stereotypes.
"When I was an undergraduate at Yale, there were all these looks that said, 'Why are you here?' " said Kristin Weber, a black first-year Berkeley law student. "When I made it through and graduated with honors, I had people come up and say they didn't know I was so smart. Well, I knew I was smart. There's a lot of hostility that's playing out in this whole debate over affirmative action."
Still, it seems everyone has a story of a friend who is one-eighth Cherokee and was admitted as an American Indian or one parent who is Mexican-American and was admitted while others of similar socio-economic backgrounds and better grades were not.
There are questions whether underrepresented Asian-American groups, like Vietnamese and Cambodians, should be compared with Chinese- , Japanese- and Korean-Americans and whether there should be enrollment goals for each separate Asian-American category.
And some skeptics say affirmative action in admissions contributes to a Balkanized campus of racially divided dorms and friendships that make the benefits of diversity more theoretical than real.
"This place is so racially polarized it's like a Spike Lee movie," said Alex M. Weingarten, a junior from Los Angeles and the outgoing executive vice president of the student government organization. "I'm not deriving any benefit from other groups on campus. I'm a white Jew from Los Angeles living with three other white Jews from Los Angeles."
 
The Proposal
Black Challenges Diversity's Value
 The biggest challenge to affirmative action in admissions is the one being mounted by Mr. Connerly, a black businessman from Sacramento, who says diversity is a worthwhile goal, but not at the cost of fairness in admissions.
Mr. Connerly has called for an end to race-based preferences in admissions, saying it has created unfair and discriminatory standards.
He said he would be more comfortable with taking socio-economic class into account rather than race or ethnicity.
"If you start with diversity as the objective in admissions you can end up doing some rather undesirable things, which is where we are now," he said. "We have a system where we're turning away white and Asian kids with 4.0's on a wholesale basis and admitting blacks and Chicanos with 3.3's."
But critics of Mr. Connerly's proposal say that no university admits solely on test scores and grades, and that none should.
"Who has the more promise, a student where there's been a tremendous economic investment put in by affluent parents, or the poor kid whose G.P.A. may be a little bit lower, who hasn't had the kind of preparation for the S.A.T.'s, but who has struggled and been relatively successful?" asked Ralph Carmona, a regent of Mexican descent. "Which holds more promise for California and America? That's the kind of question the admissions process has to address."
And Mr. Duster and others say race is such a fact of life in America that a youngster from a black middle-class family still faces numerous barriers that a white youth from a similar background does not.
The stakes were raised by the study prepared for the regents that indicated that a plan like Mr. Connerly's would sharply decrease the number of black and Hispanic students at the most desirable schools throughout the state university system.
The study found that across the University of California system, 40 to 50 percent fewer blacks would enroll, as would 5 to 15 percent fewer Hispanic applicants. The number of Asians could increase by 15 to 25 percent.
At Berkeley, if admissions were based on grades and test scores alone, Asian-Americans would account for 51.6 to 54.7 percent of the freshman class, compared with 41.7 percent this year. White freshmen, now 29.8 percent of the class population, would account for 34.8 percent to 37.3 percent. The figure for Hispanic freshmen, who now make up 15.3 percent of the class, would drop to 3 percent to 6 percent. Black freshmen would account for less than 2 percent of entering freshmen, down from 6.4 percent now.
Factoring in socio-economic background would change those figures only slightly. There are relatively small numbers of poor black and Hispanic applicants with academic records and test scores high enough for admission to Berkeley.
Mr. Connerly disputes the findings of the regents' study, saying that since essays are a major part of the admissions decision for half of those admitted to Berkeley, no one really knows how racial balance would be affected.
"I felt the timing was questionable and may have had some political motivation," he said. "They dug in their heels and want to keep the system as it is."
But he said that if the end of race-based preferences meant fewer blacks and Hispanics, so be it.
"If the system is fair, my only response is, 'Let the chips fall where the may,' " he said. "I don't give much of a hoot about diversity for its own sake. I want to see us better educate more kids."
But many board members and most of the leading educators in the state say it would be terrible social policy to have an increasingly diverse state shutting out minorities from its elite schools, particularly from law and medical schools that could prepare them to help serve their communities.
"In a few years, there will be no majority in this state; we're nearing 40 percent underrepresented minorities -- African-Americans, Hispanics and Native Americans," Chancellor Chang said. "If we don't educate some of the future leaders from that constituency, it's going to be very bad for all of us."
Mr. Connerly, who was appointed to the board by Mr. Wilson in 1993, said he believed that Governor Wilson's position could influence the regents when they take up his proposal in July. As Governor, Mr. Wilson is president of the board and one of 26 voting members.
"It's very close, but I have to believe that the Governor's leadership will help persuade some of my colleagues who may have been on the fence to join us in this journey," Mr. Connerly said.
 
Affirmative Action
 Later articles will examine affirmative action in various areas of American life.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Lawmakers Approve Strict New Welfare Rules

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 3

 BODY:
A welfare overhaul that would give Connecticut, the wealthiest state in individual income, some of the toughest restrictions on benefits for the poor, has passed the Legislature and is heading to the Governor's office for signing.
The House of Representatives voted, 132 to 16, on Friday in favor of a measure that would shut off benefits to families after 21 months, roll back benefits to levels of the late 1980's and require all welfare recipients to be electronically fingerprinted. The measure passed the Senate on Wednesday, 21 to 15. 
 The plan, which would save about $133 million over two years, would give Connecticut the shortest time limit on benefits in the country. Earlier this year, Massachusetts enacted what was then the toughest welfare changes by imposing a two-year limit on benefits.
The welfare overhaul in Connecticut was pushed to the forefront earlier this year by Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, who said he wanted to end the cycle of welfare dependence from one generation to the next. The state does not now impose a time limit on benefits.
The most hotly debated amendment, to fingerprint all recipients in a computerized process of digital imaging known as "biometric accountability," passed, 86 to 62.
Proponents said an identification system would help cut down on fraud, particularly among recipients who collect benefits in more than one community.
Critics said fingerprinting anyone, particularly the poor, had Orwellian overtones. They argued that it was just as wrong to consider all welfare recipients as potential cheats as it was to regard all politicians as dishonest.
"Let's not forget what people think of us," said Representative Marie Kirkley-Bey, Democrat of Hartford, who said the four years she spent on public assistance and in a housing project was "one of the hardest things I had to do."
"I was shunned, not because of the quality of my character but because of the source of my income," she said. "Until you've walked a mile in my shoes, don't judge me."
Some critics of the fingerprinting plan in Connecticut said that if welfare recipients must go through the process, so should others who receive government help. An amendment that would have required doctors and others who supply goods and services to welfare recipients to be fingerprinted was rejected, as was a proposal to require fingerprinting of recipients of unemployment compensation.
In New York, the budget currently under consideration in the Legislature includes a proposal for electronic fingerprinting of all welfare recipients.
The Connecticut legislation also calls for scaling back monthly cash benefits to late-1980's levels for families and childless individuals. To encourage recipients to find jobs, the state would enhance its child-care benefits and health insurance coverage.
The bulk of the plan calls for a reduction in the monthly cash benefit to a family of three on Aid to Families with Dependent Children to a range of $500 to $540, from $581. Payments would be cut off after 21 months, but recipients would be given an opportunity to apply indefinitely for six-month extensions.
Childless recipients in the General Assistance program could be on the rolls no more than 16 months total over a two-year period -- 10 months in the first year, and 6 months in the second year.
New arrivals to Connecticut would receive 90 percent of the usual benefit level for their first year in the state.
Women giving birth 10 months or more after going on public assistance would receive $50 extra each month, which is half what new mothers now receive for each additional child.
The state would also increase the amount it spends on day care for recipients from $28 million to $85 million over five years, and it would allow recipients who found jobs and dropped welfare benefits to continue to receive health coverage under Medicaid for two years.

HEADLINE: A Tribe Sees Hope In Whale Hunting, But U.S. Is Worried

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: NEAH BAY, Wash., June 1

 BODY:
The children of this American Indian village at the far western edge of the continent struggle with the usual demons of modern life, drugs, alcohol and violent videos among them. And like parents elsewhere, Makah tribal members say that a return to old-fashioned values might be just the thing to bring their youth around.
But in this case, tradition means going out in fierce Pacific Ocean swells to chase and kill gray whales, which have not been hunted legally in American waters for more than 40 years. 
 Citing an 1855 treaty that makes them the only Indian nation with whale-hunting rights guaranteed by the Federal Government, the Makah have announced plans to kill up to five whales every spring, beginning next year.
A whale hunt, they say, would provide focus for a tribe where unemployment is running at 50 percent and the fishing fleet has been hit hard by declining salmon runs.
"Right now, there's a real frustration among the kids with what's happened to fishing," said Andrea Alexander, general manager of the 1,700-member tribe. "They thought they could grow up and be fishermen, like their parents. With whaling, they would get to participate in something that has real cultural and spiritual value, and they could put food on the table as well."
The Makah plan has caused an international stir, and poses an acute problem for the State Department.
For more than a decade, the American Government has led the campaign to outlaw commercial whaling around the globe. But this week, at the International Whaling Commission's annual meeting in Dublin, the Americans have been on the spot from an Indian nation within its borders.
The Makah say there is a big distinction between their proposal and commercial whaling. The Indians want to take whales for subsistence and ceremonial purposes, not as part of a commercial operation. But opponents say it smacks of hypocrisy to allow one group of people to hunt whales as an indigenous right, but to condemn others claiming the same right, as do those in Iceland and Norway, for example.
All of this comes at time when the campaign to save whales is proving to be one of the major success stories of wildlife conservation. Playful leviathans that weigh up to 40 tons, gray whales, which are found only in the Pacific, are flourishing and have prompted a boom in tourist and recreational services.
There are about 21,000 gray whales -- the highest number in nearly a century -- according to the National Marine Fisheries Service. Last year, they were taken off the Federal list of endangered species.
Taking a mere five whales, the Makah argue, would not dent the population. The Government agrees, but has yet to sanction the hunt. Among other things, State Department officials are worried about setting a precedent. In western Canada, for example, more than a dozen tribes can show a tradition of whaling. If the Makah are allowed to kill gray whales, why can't natives in Canada, the argument goes.
The Federal Government is also worried about black-market trading in whale meat, which can fetch high prices in Japan.
The Makah, who have held to this rugged corner of the Olympic Peninsula for nearly 2,000 years, would prefer that they not get enmeshed in environmental politics or international disputes. A return to whaling is simply a way to bring back a sense of cultural cohesion for the young, they say.
Twice a year, thousands of migrating gray whales pass this coast of wind-savaged cliffs and storm-sculpted rocks called seastacks.
"Re-establishing a ceremonial and subsistence whale hunt would be a catalyst which would allow us to instill in our young people the traditional values which have held our people together over the centuries," wrote Hubert Markishtum, the tribal chairman, in a recent letter to the State Department.
Although this reservation, 27,000 acres of heavily logged forests and extensive archeological sites, bans alcohol, there are drinking and drug problems among the young, tribal officials say. Whaling, which wouldrequire months of training and study of ancient techniques, is seen as way to ground youths in a tradition that has been nearly forgotten.
If the Makah do begin taking whales next spring, an environmental group with a record of sinking whale-hunting ships has vowed to intercept the Indians at sea.
"We have a 95-foot vessel and a submarine, and if we have to, we would put them between the Makah and the whales," said Paul Watson of the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, based in Marina Del Rey, Calif. In 1986, the group scuttled two of Iceland's four whaling boats.
The Makah have long been known for their whaling skills, celebrated in centuries of native art and the photographs of Edward Curtis from the early 20th century. Up to 80 percent of their food once came from whales. They fashioned eight-person canoes from cedar, and used the crafts to hunt whales on the high Pacific.
Today, with the decline of fishing, this reservation has few prospects for reviving itself. Neah Bay is considered too remote -- about a four-hour drive from Seattle -- to support a casino, a business other tribes have turned to.
The Makah last hunted a whale in 1926, although their treaty specifically grants them the "right to take fish and of whaling," a provision unique among Indian treaties, Government officials said.
The whaling commission passed a global moratorium on commercial hunting in 1986, but Norway, Iceland and Japan continue to hunt. The commission does allow some killings by native people in northern latitudes, where there are few other sources of food.
Opponents say the Makah are a long way from a subsistence life style. They are building a 300-boat marina, and a new general store has just opened. Several small motels cater to fishermen and tourists.
"There isn't anyone alive today on that reservation who can go out there and kill a whale in a traditional manner," Mr. Watson said. "They used to keep slaves, as well. Do we go back to that? I don't see the point in making a distinction between natives having more of a right to kill whales than nonnative people."
But another environmental group, Greenpeace, which made its reputation fighting whalers, does draw a distinction. It is withholding comment on the Makah request, pending meetings with tribal officials.
The Makah say they do not need permission to start hunting next year. But they have filed a formal request to have the United States seek approval for them from the whaling commission.
"We'd like to follow the rules, and have the blessing of all government agencies," said Dave Sones, a tribal fisheries manager.
The State Department has yet to settle on a position, said Eileen Kane, a spokeswoman. But should the Makah end up selling some of the whale meat they take, the hunt is likely to be condemned.
"Our official position is that we are opposed to all international commercial whaling," Ms. Kane said. "We have supported limited whaling by indigenous people, but only for subsistence reasons."
The Makah have not decided exactly how to go about reviving a skill that has not been practiced here in nearly 70 years. They hope to gain some knowledge from oral histories in archives of their grand museum here, a major tourist attraction with thousands of whaling artifacts.
The Makah would hunt with harpoons that explode on impact, which they say is one of the more humane ways to kill whales. And they plan to work with the fisheries service to develop hunting guidelines to help conserve the gray whale population.
For now, this reservation, isolated from the world for so long, seems elated to be on a small piece of the international stage.
"We may look back on this, 50 years from now, and see it as the turning point for the Makah," Mr. Sones said. "People are really excited."

HEADLINE: Reviews by Weekend Moviegoers Are In. Dole Gets a Thumbs Down.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, June 2

 BODY:
It hardly mattered whether they had come to the Showcase Cinema to see "Casper," "The Bridges of Madison County" or rough-and-tumble films like "Braveheart," "Johnny Mnemonic" and "Die Hard With a Vengeance."
Most moviegoers interviewed today as they filed into the theater complex, west of downtown, disagreed with Senator Bob Dole's finger-pointing at Hollywood and the recording industry as causes of a morality meltdown in the United States. 
 If society has gone awry because of "casual violence and even more casual sex," as the Senate majority leader asserted in a speech on Wednesday in Los Angeles, people of all ages were more likely to blame parents and family breakdowns stemming from economic causes than to blame movie makers and recording artists.
And most, as they waited to see one of the 12 films showing, agreed that in general the violence and the sex in movies and songs imitated life, rather than vice versa.
"I thought his speech was really bad," Kristy Larsen, a 17-year-old high school junior, said as she and two friends waited to see "Johnny Mnemonic."
"People can make up their own minds," she said. "I saw 'Natural Born Killers' seven times. I really liked it. But I didn't go out and shoot someone after seeing it."
"Natural Born Killers," the story of a couple on a killing spree as they cross the country, was one example of films and recordings cited by Mr. Dole as "nightmares of depravity" for their depictions of gratuitous sex and violence. He also attacked the film "True Romance" and the rap groups Cannibal Corpse, Geto Boys and 2 Live Crew. Aides to Mr. Dole said he had not seen the movies he cited but had read about them and had also read offending rap lyrics.
Mr. Dole, the leading Republican Presidential candidate, maintained that the entertainment industry's portrayals of sex and violence had so permeated the country that they were eroding morals, civility and, as a result, the family structure.
While many moviegoers interviewed here said they agreed that the country was suffering a moral decline, most also said that little impetus for it was coming from the industry.
But several suggested that the movie rating system should be updated to include more detailed warnings on films with unusually graphic violence and sex. Marlena Mitchell, 28, an optometrist who had just seen "Braveheart," said she would have welcomed such an alert for "Pulp Fiction," which she found too gory. "I would like to have known it was going to be that violent," she said.
Like Mr. Dole, neither she nor anyone else interviewed favored any form of censoring entertainers. Several suggested that film and record producers "tone it down," but none proposed anything stronger. Discretion, they said, should be exercised by individuals, and guidance for young people should be provided by parents.
"Entertainers can't control what you do," said Alex Donovan, a 15-year-old friend of Miss Larsen. "Politicians blame things on movies because they can't control what's going on. They use movies as a scapegoat."
"They want to say it goes back to family values," Miss Larsen said. "But family values have been shot to hell."
"Like with my family," Mr. Donovan interjected. "My mom passed away two years ago, and my father's struggling with a third-shift job, starting work at midnight. I'd like to see him more, but he's just trying to get by, trying to survive."
"Same with my father," Miss Larsen said. "He's a boilermaker. He starts work at 5 P.M. and gets one day off a week. I don't see him much at all. I'd like to."
Marian Tomaszewski, a 40-year-old health and physical education teacher who had come to see "While You Were Sleeping," said she had not read about Mr. Dole's speech. But like other middle-aged people interviewed, she said she agreed with his contention that movies were too violent and that morality in America was slipping. The evidence, she said, is right there in her school, where boys who are not yet teen-agers bring guns into classrooms.
Still, that behavior occurs not because of violent films or suggestive lyrics, she said: creative efforts only mirror the real world, in which she sees parents who have abdicated their responsibility to provide their children leadership, guidance and discipline.
"The breakdown of family life came first," Ms. Tomaszewski said. "When I was younger, there was more of a family life. Parents watched their children more closely. But now there are more single-parent families. Kids do whatever they want, and parents let them. If parents don't want their kids to see these movies, they shouldn't let them."
Annette Shively, 36, said that having three children -- ages 6 years, 5 years and 22 months -- had made her think about what they might become exposed to. Taking them to see "Fluke," a family film about a dog, she said she did not favor any infringement on freedom of speech. But, she added, five years from now, when her children might be less inclined to heed her instructions, she would like to see that the entertainment industry is making more prudent decisions about sex and violence.
For now, she said, "I definitely control, or try to control, what my children see."
William Moore, 40, a supervisor at a children's home, and Darnetta Perry, 38, a retail manager, had come to see "Crimson Tide." He contended that most movie watchers and rap fans could distinguish between real life and the fantasy of entertainment, a point echoed by others.
In any case, he said, the responsibility for young people's exposure to the creative efforts that bother Mr. Dole rests with parents, not entertainment executives.
"You can't blame the movie industry for what children watch," Mr. Moore said. "You need to be doing more as a parent. If you let them watch that stuff, you have to watch it with them and tell them what's real. But a lot of parents just put their children in front of the TV and have no idea what they're watching, no idea what they're ingesting."
A few people said they were certain that art was influencing behavior. Jennifer Jablonski, a 14-year-old student who was seeing "Forget Paris" with three friends, said she had noticed a marked difference in her older brother's conduct since he began listening to rap and watching R-rated movies.
"He changed," she said. "Just from listening to rap, he is starting to use bad words. He calls me bad names all the time, like 'ho' and 'whore.' He never swore like that before."
Ray Kushner, a salesman from McKeesport, Pa., just southeast of Pittsburgh, worked as a volunteer for more than four years in the forensics unit of Mayview State Hospital and said he strongly agreed with Mr. Dole. Mr. Kushner said he was struck by the degree to which young people without parents or those with only minimal adult supervision were affected by what they saw and heard, especially on television.
"I don't believe in censorship, but there should be some ethical standard," he said while walking out of "Die Hard With a Vengeance," which he described as "extremely violent."
"Not that I was squeamish or uncomfortable," he added. "But the problem is with people who see these kinds of movies and want to act out their fantasies. They don't realize that the movies are not real."

HEADLINE: Facing Cuts in U.S. Contributions, U.N. May Rejuggle Its Books

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 2

 BODY:
Aware that United States contributions to peacekeeping and other United Nations expenses are certain to be cut this year, a group representating more than 80 countries is preparing to recommend major changes in the way nations are assessed for contributions.
Among the suggestions being considered is a formula that would return the level of American peacekeeping contributions to the 1973 rate of 27 percent of total costs. For peacekeeping, the United States is now assessed about 31 percent, which amounted to $1.07 billion in 1994, a figure that varies according to the number of operations each year. Like all permanent members of the Security Council, the United States pays a surcharge because of concessions for developing nations. 
 Congress has already passed legislation to put a ceiling on America's contributions to United Nations peacekeeping payments at 25 percent of their total costs this year. There is no certainty that other nations will meet the shortfall created by Washington's lower contributions in the near future. But many diplomats here agree that a number of nations with rapidly growing economies are now underassessed for peacekeeping costs, and ways are being sought to determine appropriate payments.
"A 22-year-old scale does not capture what has been happening," said Ernst Sucharipa, Austria's delegate here and a deputy chairman of the group that is to recommend changes in the assessments. "There is a growing awareness here that something has to be done."
The group was established late last year by the General Assembly and is expected to complete a report by July.
The United States is perennially in arrears on payments to the United Nations, both to the regular operating budget and to the peacekeeping costs. This has generated sharp criticism from other nations, particularly in Europe, where there have been calls for punitive actions.
The European Union -- whose members, along with Australia, Canada and New Zealand, always pay promptly -- has proposed that assessments paid on time could be discounted and that interest would be charged on late payments. Europeans say that the American reluctance to pay its bills is especially annoying given the large number of contracts that go to United States suppliers and contractors every year from a range of agencies and departments. There are some diplomats who propose penalizing countries that do not pay by withholding such contracts.
Time lags also contribute significantly to the problems of assessment, Mr. Sucharipa said. United Nations regular budget contributions are assessed for seven-and-a-half-year periods, based on information that may be a year or two old, so that changes in national economies are not reflected quickly enough.
Countries that emerged from the breakup of the Soviet Union argue that they are especially at a disadvantage by this system, since their current assessments are based on inflated Soviet-era economic figures. At the same time, countries like South Korea and Singapore pay at a rate that does not mirror their rapid growth, and China is widely considered to be undercharged.
"If you are a country moving up, you are safeguarded against increases for a period of time," Mr. Sucharipa said. "If your economy is stagnating or going down, you are still paying at the old figures when you should be paying less."
A separate group of financial experts have suggested reducing the period for which payments are fixed to three years.

HEADLINE: A Study in Budgetary Realities

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 3

 BODY:
Throughout last year's campaign for governor, and continuing with this year's budget negotiations, Gov. George E. Pataki promised "dramatic change," "sweeping change," even "fundamental change." And in many ways, he delivered with a budget that will reduce spending and taxes, toughen welfare requirements and lengthen sentences for hardened criminals.
But in a host of lesser ways, many of them central to the process of budget-making in Albany, the more things change, the more they seem to stay the same. 
 Experts on the state's finances said the 1995-96 budget agreed to on Friday is laden with one-shot revenue measures, backdoor borrowing, pork barrel spending, unfinanced spending requirements, a pension fund raid and questionable estimates of revenues and the costs of benefits. These are all, in short, the kinds of fiscal transgressions that have discredited past budgets and that Mr. Pataki vowed would no longer be acceptable.
Cynthia B. Green, a fiscal analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit business group, said the budget could easily fall out of balance. "It's likely that this budget will finance recurring spending with one-shots and gimmicks, a prescription for a future budget crisis," she said. "That's not very different from what we've been used to."
As in each of the previous 10 years, the Governor and legislative leaders missed their budget deadline, this time by more than two months. And despite Mr. Pataki's January declaration that "the practice of back room budget making must end," the budget was negotiated completely in private.
Much else of what happened this year is at odds with the oratory used by Mr. Pataki and other Republicans in last year's campaign against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
It was only 362 days ago, after all, that the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, issued a news release blaming the Governor for last year's budget tardiness. "The bottom line is that as chief executive officer of this state, it's Mario Cuomo's responsibility to give New York an on-time budget," he wrote, adding, "It's time for a change in New York, a Republican change."
When passage of the budget is completed next week, Mr. Pataki may manage to do better than last year's June 8 record, but only by a day or two.
But Mr. Pataki discovered that as long as one house of the Legislature is dominated by the opposing party, a quick consensus is difficult to reach.
And as a Governor who was elected with 49 percent of the vote and without a clear mandate, Mr. Pataki found himself in a poor position to bully the Assembly Democrats into submission. The primary tactic he used, withholding the pay of lawmakers and their aides after the April 1 budget deadline passed, fell flat after it was challenged successfully in two lawsuits.
The need to negotiate with the Legislature, and particularly with the Assembly Democrats, forced Mr. Pataki to compromise his fiscal values on several fronts.
"I pledge to you that as Governor I will not use fiscal gimmicks to close any deficits in operating budgets," Mr. Pataki told the Citizens Budget Commission last year. "I will not sell any more Attica prisons or state highways to state authorities."
Mr. Pataki stopped short of using such egregious quick-fix solutions from the past. But he did agree to use the State Urban Development Corporation to sell bonds to finance $125 million in stadium construction projects and other capital improvements.
Many state officials, including Mr. Pataki, have expressed skepticism about the economic development value of the stadium projects, making them questionable enterprises for the development corporation.
By using an authority as the bonding entity, the state will avoid the unpredictability of a public referendum, as is required for general-obligation bond issues. But while the bonding will save the state money this year (last year's budget appropriated cash to pay for the stadium construction), the additional costs in interest will make the projects far more expensive in the long run.
The budget also calls for the development corporation to sell bonds to finance the state's purchase of two New York City prisons for $120 million. The corporation has been used in the past for prison construction, but many fiscal monitors, including State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, said they believe it violates the authority's economic development purpose.
Mr. Pataki campaigned last year against "member items," the pork barrel spending appropriated each year in a lump sum and later distributed by legislative leaders to local groups like Little Leagues and museums. But the budget agreement includes $24 million for such projects, which have been given the new euphemism "program initiatives." Legislative leaders have promised to itemize each appropriation in the budget, but they have yet to provide a list.
In another pledge made in hisspeech last year to the Citizens Budget Commission, Mr. Pataki said, "I will not burden local governments with unfunded mandates," requiring them to undertake costly programs but not providing the money.
But a plan to increase pensions for state and local government retirees will impose such a burden on New York City. The plan, which is still being worked out, is expected to require the city to increase pension levels beginning in 1997 or 1998 at an estimated cost of $80 million to $100 million in the first year.
Mr. McCall also said he believes the pension plan may constitute an illegal raid because the state plans to help balance this year's budget by borrowing money from a $360 million fund that is dedicated to increasing pensions.
State leaders, in effect, created other revenue for the budget by devising new projections for anticipated tax revenues and Medicaid costs during the negotiations. Tax revenues were adjusted upward by $335 million and Medicaid costs were adjusted downward by $150 million. It will not be known until the end of the year whether those projections are accurate.
Mr. Pataki has also railed in the past against one-shots, the nonrecurring revenue measures that leave the state with a hole in the following year's budget. He proposed $650 million worth of them in his budget and accepted a total of $900 million in the final $33.1 billion general-fund budget.
Among the one-shots is a new requirement that any company with an annual sales tax liability of at least $1 million must pay actual and estimated taxes to the state by electronic transfer. The previous level for such a requirement was $4 million, meaning that hundreds of additional companies will have to pay taxes electronically.
The key to the measure, which is expected to produce $45 million for this year's budget, is that companies that do not pay taxes by electronic transfer must pay each month's taxes within 30 days after the end of the month. Those that pay electronically must pay before the end of the month. That means that the newly affected companies will have to pay taxes for the last month of the fiscal year, March 1996, in March rather than in April, the first month of the next fiscal year, providing the state with a 1996 windfall.
George W. Leung, managing director of Moody's Investors Service, which rates New York's bonds lower than every state but Louisiana, said his agency will look closely at nonrecurring revenues when judging Mr. Pataki's first budget.
"The use of the one-shots is a measure of the degree of willingness to deal with the budget problem," he said.

HEADLINE: On a Beleaguered Block, Success Never Smelled Sweeter

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
It stands out -- with its tan woodwork facade and its 70-foot mural of cotton fields back home -- as a respite from the strips of pennant-draped auto parts stores and the sullen cinder-blocked windows of Atlantic Avenue in East New York, Brooklyn.
In the 25 years since the Carolina Country Kitchen came into being -- as a hot plate in a storage bin behind a bar -- it has become a source of pride in an otherwise beleaguered neighborhood, a landmark beckoning to people from near and quite far who yearn for a memory and a taste of the South, for hominy grits and ham hocks, collard greens and candied yams. 
 And in a community hobbled by poverty, where residents say there are too few small businesses and too many with plastic barriers between the proprietor and the public, the restaurant's humble origins and years of success offer a glimmer of possibility.
Almost literally, the country kitchen at the corner of Saratoga Avenue fell off the back of a truck.
Its owner, Patricia Lee, 42, was a college student working toward a business degree back in 1970 when her father, George Lee -- a strapping farmer in Magnolia, N.C. -- began loading up sweet potatoes and watermelons from his 200-acre spread for weekly, 12-hour drives to Brooklyn.
There was an old gas station with a rutted parking lot at the corner of Saratoga and Atlantic, and from there Mr. Lee, now 75, would sell produce off the back of his truck.
"He needed a storage room because he didn't want to go back to North Carolina with the stuff," Ms. Lee said last week while nursing a neophyte through the subtleties of soul food in her cafeteria-style restaurant.
There was a storage shed beside the corner bar across Saratoga Avenue, and Mr. Lee rented it. "He couldn't set up early enough in the morning and people would come into the shed," Ms. Lee said.
What started as a small personal convenience for Mr. Lee -- a hot plate to cook breakfast for himself and a hired hand -- became the source of a burgeoning business. "In the morning, he would fry up a piece of ham or something like that," Ms. Lee said. "And when customers came in they would say, 'Oh, can I buy a piece of that ham?' So he would fry a piece and sell it. Word spread, and that's really how we got started."
Mr. Lee and his daughter were about to ride the curl of a wave of immigration from the South, through the 1940's, '50s and '60s, that transformed Brooklyn -- particularly its central and eastern sections -- into one of the largest black communities in the nation. In 1940, there were only 107,000 blacks among the 2.7 million residents of Brooklyn. In 1990, blacks, including a significant number from Caribbean countries, accounted for 872,000 of the borough's 2.3 million people.
By 1972, after the hot plate had been rendered obsolete by two large grills, Mr. Lee bought the building with the bar and hired his daughter away from her job as an insurance agent to run the fledgling business. A year later, after the bar owner missed one too many rent payments, his premises became the North Carolina Country Store -- a produce market across the street from the restaurant that now has hams hanging in net bags, a shelf lined with snuff and chewing tobacco, pecan logs, a "Standardized, Family-Sized, Galvanized No. 2090" washboard on the wall and bin after bin of turnip greens, mustard greens, stone-ground cornmeal and dry sage sausage.
"We still did ham sandwiches, sausages and chopped barbecue," Ms. Lee said. "But more and more people said, 'Why don't you make dinners to sell? We can't find anywhere to eat.' So I started selling dinners to go -- fried chicken, ribs, macaroni and cheese, potato salad, collard greens, corn bread. We had people lining up."
People were also parking in the lot at the old, closed gas station across the street. "One day I thought about a cafeteria, because of the lines in the store," Ms. Lee said. In 1982, she bought the station. "It took me a few years to put it together, getting the loans, getting the drawings and the approvals." The Carolina Country Kitchen opened in November 1988.
And no one could be much more pleased than Minnie Shannon, 42, and her sister, Linda, 40, sitting on the stoop of their building down the block. "It's a neighborhood store," Linda Shannon said. "It brings up the neighborhood. Every day they have somebody cleaning up all the time."
East New York "does have a rough reputation," Minnie Shannon said, "but there ain't no rowdy people here. It helps to have a nice restaurant on the avenue."
It has not always gone smoothly for Ms. Lee. "We've had a lot of downs," she said. And she has been robbed, a fact Ms. Lee does not like to discuss. But her father, up from North Carolina on one of his regular runs, said: "It was black guys, our own people, who did that to her. I don't understand that."
Despite the difficulties, Mr. Lee is profoundly proud of the way his daughter has built a business that employs 45 people. "I never had no dreams of it, that's the truth," he said.
Diane Bonaventure, program director for the East New York Economic Development Corporation, wishes there were many more small and mid-sized businesses in her hard-pressed community. "Unfortunately, there are only 600 or 700 businesses this size in East New York -- little bodegas, mom-and-pop operations," she said, "and really not many African-Americans who own businesses."
"Latinos own the bodegas," Ms. Bonaventure said. "There used to be Jewish store owners along Pitkin Avenue. Now we have a lot of people from the Middle East on Pitkin. Looks like African-Americans got lost in the transition."
So, in more than one way, Ms. Lee's enterprise offers a haven of sorts. James Neal, 47, a trucker, drives over from Red Hook three or four times a week, not just to savor the barbecue, the cheese grits, the salmon cakes, the stewed apples, the hash browns, the chitterlings or the pecan, peach or sweet potato pies.
"I'm from North Carolina -- Raleigh," Mr. Neal said, seated in an airy dining room that is decorated with a wagon wheel, a butter churn, an old lantern, a hay bale and a hoe. "I used to love working in the fields when I was a kid; driving the tobacco sled with the horses after they piled it up, the dirt roads, the country living."
"This place is like being in the country," Mr. Neal said. "All the things that remind."

HEADLINE: Gingrich's Welfare Vision Ignores Reality, Charities Say

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
What America needs, Speaker Newt Gingrich says, is a dismantling of the welfare state, with many of its functions turned over to private charities. But from the Union Gospel Mission of Seattle to the Forest Hills Community House in Queens, charity leaders say they are already hard pressed to meet existing needs.
And they say the Speaker's ideas are unworkable because his vision of what charities do and how they are financed is a page out of Norman Rockwell, a far cry from reality. 
 Although Mr. Gingrich has not offered details on how private charities could take over public functions, he has tossed out some proposals: One calls for every church and synagogue in the United States to adopt a homeless person for six months, while another calls for all Americans to contribute three hours of voluntary service a week.
He argues that helping the truly needy requires nothing less than a transformation of the American culture, shifting the responsibility from bureaucrats to missionaries. "It requires the person who will sit there at 3 o'clock in the morning holding the hand of the person who is about to commit suicide," Mr. Gingrich said.
But the cornerstone of American charity today, his critics in charities say, is not built on neighbors caring for neighbors in tight little communities. Instead, it rests on a vast array of organizations -- from neighborhood settlement houses and soup kitchens to national entities like the Salvation Army and the American Red Cross -- that are run largely by professionals. And the services they are able to provide are but a fraction of what government itself provides.
Also, while most charities depend heavily on volunteer labor and on billions of dollars in donations from the public, they are even more dependent on government money for their survival. Indeed, many charities themselves are major recipients of Federal Government aid that may be eliminated.
Mr. Gingrich and others argue that if government reduced its role in helping the needy, private citizens would pick up the slack, but many experts dispute that contention.
"We don't know for sure that they are wrong," said Robert Putnam, a political scientist at Harvard University. "But it seems completely implausible that if you shut down the Government that individuals and charity could compensate."
Government spending for a whole host of social services far outstrips what private charities offer, points out Lester Salamon, a professor at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. For example, in a comprehensive study he found that in 1989 Federal, state and local governments spent about $96 billion on basic social services like welfare, housing aid and child nutrition. He estimated that if Social Security, Medicare and other government spending for pension plans, health benefits and education were included, the government spent almost $1 trillion that same year.
And although total charitable giving in the United States amounts to almost $130 billion annually, nearly half of that goes to churches and other religious groups. Last year, less than $12 billion was aimed at human services, where government cuts are expected to be heaviest, and the figure has been shrinking steadily for more than a decade.
Most private charities themselves depend heavily on government money, awarded through a combination of contracts and grants. The Forest Hills Community House, for example, draws $2.1 million of its $3 million budget -- or 70 percent -- from government financing.
Even big national charities rely on government aid. Last year, Catholic Charities USA, a network of about 1,400 social service agencies, received about $1.3 billion, or two-thirds of its revenues, from Federal, state and local governments.
The Salvation Army draws about 17 percent of its revenue from government nationally, although in some areas the figure is 66 percent, or higher, said Raymond Peacock, a lieutenant colonel in the group. He calls a government role necessary.
"This is more than a private charity responsibility," he said. "It is a societal responsibility. We can address some of it alone, but we cannot address all of it."
That view is expressed again and again by leaders of charitable organizations, whether they provide food and shelter, education or counseling. Many contend that government not only has the responsibility to continue to meet the human needs of society, but that in many fields, is the only entity capable of assuming that burden.
Fred Kammer, president of Catholic Charities, said, "We believe that only government has the resources -- not to mention the final moral and political responsibility -- to promote the general welfare."
The idea that government should contribute to the well-being of those in need is not new. Even in the early 1800's, when Alexis de Tocqueville remarked on the role played by American charitable associations in fulfilling many of the social functions carried on by European governments, government in the United States was already playing a significant role as a partner in supporting private education, hospitals and service for the needy.
Some predict that if government's involvement in these matters fell, people's sense of responsibility, and their giving, would rise.
"The philanthropic urge has been muted because of the growth of the welfare state," said Robert A. Sirico, president of the Acton Institute for the Study of Religion and Liberty in Grand Rapids, Mich., who asserts that this urge will blossom if the welfare state shrinks. "Do we have it in us? I think we do."
And Leslie Lenkowsky, president of the Hudson Institute research group, argues that the close relationship that has grown between charities and the government has been a "dysfunctional marriage." A separation, he suggested, that could leave some groups scrambling for money. But it could also give them more freedom to innovate, he said, and might make it easier for them to raise financing.
Others are more skeptical. While charitable contributions grew in the 1980's, when government cuts were threatened, most analysts attribute the rise to generally increasing economic prosperity. Many predict that while some increase in giving might be forthcoming now, it is likely to be limited.
A recent survey by the United States Trust Company of people with an adjusted gross incomes above $200,000 or a net worth greater than $3 million found that 68 percent of the respondents said they would donate more to charities if government spending and taxes were both reduced. But only 19 percent said they would give more if social spending were reduced but taxes were not.
Even if Americans are willing to give more, there are questions about where it will be directed.
In a study for the 20th Century Fund, Julian Wolpert, a professor at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University, found that higher levels of giving often go to services enjoyed by the donors -- like museums, symphonies, private universities and public television -- rather than for social services. "We haven't had a test yet to show whether there will be a shift if we have stingier state and local governments," he said.
Yet another concern among fund-raisers for charities is that while cuts in government funds are already occurring, raising more money takes time -- years rather than months.
"This has been a 50-year-history of Government taking on added responsibilities," said John Thomas, senior vice president for development for the American Red Cross. "To try to undo that in a year or two is unrealistic."
One way to speed the process, some suggest, is to use tax policy to encourage more giving. But many tax experts consider any tax overhaul unlikely. And some of the tax plans that are under the most active discussion in Washington now, like a flat tax or a consumption tax, would actually raise the cost of giving, by removing the tax incentive that occurs when donors take their charitable contributions as deductions on taxes.
Adding to the uncertainty for many charities is the question of whether tougher rules for welfare and other social services will, in fact, reduce need or expand it. In New York City, for example, Mayor Rudolph Guiliani recently hailed the sharp falloff in the number of childless able-bodied adults accepting benefits when tougher screening for welfare was imposed.
But most executives in social service agencies say the needy are not there simply because money is available, and express doubts that they will simply disappear if the barriers are raised.
"The needs are not going to go away," said Emily Menlo Marks, executive director of United Neighborhood Houses of New York. She said that the 37 settlement houses that are her members have already lost money from New York City budget cuts, and that one of the biggest fears among settlement house clients is the possibility of losing child-care services.
"If they don't have day care, they can't work," she said. "And if they can't work, they have to go on welfare. But the budget cutters don't want people on welfare."

HEADLINE: Fearing for Desert, a City Restricts Mountain Bikes

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOAB, Utah

 BODY:
A decade ago, this mining town of 5,000 was rescued from economic collapse by mountain bikers who found gold in the miles of rugged trails in the surrounding rocky desert. But in recent years, residents and the managers of public lands have come to regard mountain bikes as running roughshod over their land. So, Moab is getting tough.
"Something needed to be done," Clark Minson, an assistant manager at Kaibab Bikes, said of the restrictions imposed this spring. "This is where we live. We didn't want to see people trashing our home." 
 For years Moab has attracted the "been there, done that" adventure-sport crowd with events like the Fat Tire Festival in October. While not every one of the 20,000 mountain bikers who may be in Moab on a busy weekend are environmentally incorrect, it takes only a few with the pioneer attitude of continually pushing into new country to cause problems.
Among those worried about the damage is Jayne Belnap, a researcher with the National Biological Survey who studies cryptobiotic soil, or the crust, which is the living web of lichens, mosses and algae that forms the ecological anchor of this desert ecosystem. It is the crust that stores moisture, provides nutrients to plants and prevents erosion.
"If I want really good crust, I'm hard pressed to find it," Ms. Belnap said. "Everywhere I go, all the roads have been ridden off or walked off. It wasn't like that five years ago. It's gotten astronomically worse."
To halt the damage from off-trail riding and camping, the Bureau of Land Management and the National Park Service this spring curtailed mountain bike and four-wheel-drive access to some areas and began monitoring others. Since March, the bureau, along with Grand County, which includes Moab, has been charging riders and campers to use the Sand Flats Recreation Area, where the Slickrock Bike Trail is located. The fees help to pay for the upkeep of the trail and a 120-site campground.
By early May, the fees had brought in $65,000, said Commissioner Bill Hedden of Grand County. The fees are $1 for one person to ride on the trail for three days and $4 for an overnight campsite. Officials expect 120,000 people to use the trail this year.
While a majority of mountain bikers and Moab residents approve of the fees, Bill Groff, co-owner of Moab's oldest bike shop, Rim Cyclery, said that by restricting access and numbers of bikers at Sand Flats, the bureau was pushing problems into other public lands not already degraded.
"I tried to tell them to leave Sand Flats alone." Mr. Groff said. "Let them camp out there. It's been ruined for years. They ruined that when the grazing came through 100 years ago. Leave it for a sacrifice area because it's already sacrificed. This way, people are not going out everywhere else and making camping spots."
Kate Kitchell, the Moab district manager of the land-management bureau, disagreed, saying that illegal camping by mountain bikers and others had been going on for years because there were not enough private and public campgrounds available on busy weekends.
To combat problems of overuse in nearby Canyonlands National Park, a 527-square mile sweep of labyrinthine canyons, airy mesas and remote back roads, officials started a new management plan on Jan. 25, after studies showed environmental damage from recreation.
"I think we took some bold moves to protect the park," said Larry Frederick, a park spokesman, citing the plan's strategies of reducing the number of concessions, like those that rent bikes, in the park, eliminating back-country campsites, closing some natural areas and increasing patrols. At the popular Angel Arch area, for example, park officials have eliminated 24 of 36 campsites and reduced the size of groups allowed at each.
"You talk to park managers today," Mr. Frederick said, "and they will tell you this: they're going to err on the side of protecting park resources because if they don't protect the park resources, 100 years from now there isn't going to be anything for future generations to come back and see."
But Ms. Belnap of the National Biological Survey said she doubted that such restrictions and public education would be enough to preserve the natural integrity of Canyonlands and other public lands. She said her research was finding increasing systemic damage to the desert, beginning with cattle grazing in the 19th century and continuing this century first with mining and now with recreation. Four-wheel-drive vehicles had greatly contributed to the degradation, she said.
"Probably the biggest problem is that people can go a lot farther on a bike than on their feet," Ms. Belnap said. "Bike travel has a lot more potential to wreck stuff. The soils here take 5,000 to 10,000 years to form. The damage we're doing in our management scheme is irreparable. You're not going to get that soil back."
Futile or not, most people around Moab, even mountain bikers, believe that restrictions and public awareness are a step in the right direction.
Dennis Finnegan of Jackson Hole, Wyo., has come to Moab for five years to backpack and explore by mountain bike. On his visit this May, Mr. Finnegan said he was pleased with the stronger emphasis on environmental protection. Still, he said, he knew that any use of the fragile desert could create problems.
"No matter how conscious you are in the back country," Mr. Finnegan said, "you always end up making some sort of impact."

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
Improvisations Are a la Mode If Money Isn't

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
"WHAT'S the budget? Zero!"
The students in Barry Canovas's visual merchandising class at the High School of Fashion Industries have learned that basic business lesson all too well. With minimal supplies from the Board of Education, students have to depend on fashion-industry angels and their own creative wits in designing and building the school's window displays on West 24th Street. 
 A few months ago, when public school students descended on City Hall in a helter-skelter rally against cuts in the education budget and increases in college tuition, Mr. Canovas's students did the professional thing instead. Like window dressers for their Chelsea neighbor Barney's, they created a six-window tableau of sight gags poking grim fun at the cuts.
A library with four books is open for two minutes a day. A student holds a tray with two lonely beans for lunch. Tryouts are announced for new team sports: kick the can, dots and freeze tag. Mr. Nomo's economics class is taught by one Mr. "Potacky." Say the names out loud. You get the idea.
"Instead of going to City Hall and getting into trouble, the windows were our silent way of protesting," said Lesley Pamblanco, a senior. "We were looking at low-budget games and stuff. We wanted it to be something people could look at and laugh."
THERE has been little to laugh at in the budget figures, however. Charles Bonnici, the principal, told parents earlier this year that the school could lose more than a quarter of its financing next year. Systemwide, he reminded them, $1 billion has already been cut over the last four years.
As far as he's concerned, double-digit markdowns belong in Seventh Avenue back rooms, not classrooms.
The school itself has changed drastically since the era of shoemakers, furriers and milliners whose labor history is chronicled in two impressive Works Progress Administration murals in the auditorium. In the years after its foundation in 1926, the school offered hands-on manufacturing courses in those trades, but it has changed its focus to financial, artistic and marketing instruction.
"Our students are training to be designers, patternmakers and the higher-paid jobs that are still in New York" said Bill Daniel, the school's assistant principal for organization. "The manufacturing jobs are out of the city or are still in the sweatshops."
SCHOOL administrators are concerned that future cuts could claim as many as 15 teaching positions, eliminate many after-school activities and lead to fewer advanced vocational courses. Those are the courses they had hoped would give their students the edge in the job market or college.
Even supplies for those courses sometimes aren't easy to come by, Mr. Daniel said: the merchandising department, which has some 700 students in its courses, gets a yearly supply budget of $6,000. The Board of Education catalogue doesn't exactly meet the needs for special tools and art supplies or finer fabrics.
"They give fabric you use for tablecloths," Mr. Daniel said. "We're making evening gowns here!"
The city's fiscal problems have given students material for humorous windows. But behind the jokes are real fears.
Denise Ruiz, a senior whose play "The King" was among the winners of a young playwright's festival at the Public Theater, insisted that the arts were not a marginal luxury.
"A lot of people come to this school because it's a vocational high school for fashion," she said. "But they want to cut back on the arts."
Many were worried that the students in lower grades would lose their bus or train passes.
"It's going to be really hard for people to get to and from school," said Victoria Evertsz. "Some are going to drop out."
What really upset them was the mixed messages from politicians who urged them to get an education yet want to cut school budgets. Some students said that while Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was telling his youthful critics to get a job, many of them were already working.
Emily Domena said her family would not be able to help her once she graduates, so she has decided to work for a few years and save up college tuition money.
"They want us to be educated for jobs, but I need a job just to stay in school," she said. "The politicians are being selfish. We're supposed to be the leaders of the country. They're just belittling our intelligence."
Ms. Evertsz, her classmate, piped up.
"The next President could be sitting in this class," she said. "Or mayor."
