HEADLINE: Hitching His Star to the Bronx;
Ferrer's Career Mirrors Fortunes of His Often-Neglected Borough

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
The Bronx is still a reliable punch line in many crowds.
At the Yale Club in Manhattan on Tuesday night, after Fernando Ferrer delivered a lengthy political pitch to the Protestant Lawyers Association, the group's president tactfully wound down the evening by saying that some of the lawyers had long commutes home "to the outer boroughs -- like the Bronx." 
 The lawyers laughed, as if on cue.
Without missing a beat, Mr. Ferrer rose to the defense of his battered borough. "There are those of us who think the Bronx is the center of the universe," he said.
Snickers aside, Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, was surely describing himself. The often-neglected, perennially poor borough is both Mr. Ferrer's pride and his burden.
Mr. Ferrer's life has tracked the ills that defined the borough's reputation. He was raised in the South Bronx, which became the national symbol of urban devastation, and he is a product of the Democratic machine whose corruption disgraced the borough.
But his timing has been impeccable. When he became Borough President in 1987 at age 36, the fires that ravaged the South Bronx had been doused, and city money was available to rebuild thousands of residences. The era of corruption at Borough Hall ended with the jailing of his predecessor, Stanley Simon.
Now, with the city's Hispanic population projected to outnumber the black population by the year 2000, Mr. Ferrer is the city's most visible official with Hispanic roots, and he is considering a run for mayor. But projecting himself citywide will be a challenge. Whatever success he can point to in the Bronx, the borough is still seriously troubled. His vision of the city's future appears to be in its formative stages. And Hispanic New Yorkers can hardly be expected to vote as a bloc.
Mr. Ferrer, known by his disarmingly boyish nickname, Freddy, presents a relaxed image. Invariably well groomed, with a full, neat mustache, sharp suits and matching pocket squares, he is attractive and likable.
Even as a teen-ager, friends say, Mr. Ferrer had political ambitions. After college, he became a soldier in the Bronx Democratic machine, was elected to the City Council at 32, and five years later assumed the borough presidency. With the new City Charter in 1990, the borough presidents lost considerable power, and Mr. Ferrer has clearly become itchy.
Gingerly, Mr. Ferrer, 45, has begun field testing a possible mayoral bid in 1997, speaking to a range of groups outside the borough (from Protestant lawyers in Manhattan to black Democrats in Queens) and, for the first time, aides said, hiring a professional fund-raiser.
His contacts with developers and contractors have proven fruitful. For example, a Connecticut firm, Worth Construction, and its president, was his largest donor last year, giving $10,000. The Worth company recently completed a $25 million school in the Bronx for the Schools Construction Authority.
"I don't obsess about it," Mr. Ferrer said of his plans. "I don't wake up in the morning and shave the next mayor." But, he said, "I'm thinking about it more now. I'm upset about the direction of the city. It's taken a mean and angry turn."
The election is more than two years off, and there is likely to be a competitive field of Democrats challenging Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Yet a strong showing by Mr. Ferrer would signal the emergence of citywide politicians of Hispanic extraction, similar to the earlier political rise of the Irish, the Italians, the Jews and the African-Americans.
"Down the road," said Richard C. Wade, a professor of urban history at City College, "as perfectly as an historian can see things, there's going to be an Hispanic mayor." The Bronx is likely to produce that mayor, he said, since it looks most like the future New York City, with a 40 percent Hispanic population and white and black residents each constituting about 25 percent.
Mr. Ferrer chafes at the suggestion that he is a Hispanic politician any more than the Mayor is an Italian politician. Mr. Ferrer, who was born in New York City, draws support from the Jewish neighborhoods of Riverdale and the blacks areas of the north Bronx.
Indeed, his biggest political challenge will be to unify minority leaders. Some black leaders view Mr. Ferrer with suspicion because of what they saw as his halting support for Mayor David N. Dinkins. Mr. Ferrer and Jose E. Serrano, the South Bronx Congressman, have occasional rifts. And Herman Badillo, a former Bronx Borough President, United States Representative and mayoral candidate, said he would oppose Mr. Ferrer in any mayoral try since Mr. Ferrer did not support his run for city comptroller last year on Mr. Giuliani's ticket.
 
Attacking Those Who Attack Bronx
 Ethnic politics aside, transforming Mr. Ferrer into a citywide figure will take work. If there is such a strain of politics as Bronx-centric, Mr. Ferrer has it.
He tells audiences that the rest of the city can learn from the Bronx how to combat economic disinvestment and physical decay, seemingly oblivious to the popular perception of the borough as a landscape of desperation.
And he seems most animated -- and intemperate -- when attacking those who attack the Bronx. His favorite target is George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the principal owner of the New York Yankees, who has threatened to move his team out of the Bronx because, he said, fans are afraid to go there. In Mr. Ferrer's view, the Yankees are holding up city officials for increased and expensive concessions.
"If you have a better deal in New Jersey, George, go to New Jersey," Mr. Ferrer said at the Yale Club last week. "Go to Tampa. Or go to hell."
He promotes the borough with an arsenal of defensiveness and affection collected during his life in the Bronx during its toughest era.
Mr. Ferrer's description of his youth in Hunts Point sounds like a romantic movie about tenement life:
"Four- or five-story walk-ups teeming with people. Candy stores with a jukebox playing. Delicatessen, grocery stores. I shined shoes on 149th and Southern Boulevard. Played stickball."
His parents, both born in Puerto Rico, attended high school in the Bronx. His mother was a bookkeeper at hotels in the city, and his father worked at a variety of jobs from truck driver to insurance salesman. His parents were divorced when Mr. Ferrer was 8, and he and his sister lived with his mother.
At Cardinal Spellman High School, Mr. Ferrer became a member of Aspira, a service organization for Puerto Rican youths, and became a citywide leader.
"What always struck me about Freddy was that we always knew what he wanted to do: he wanted to be a politician," said Gladys Carrion, the former commissioner of the city's Community Development Agency, who knew Mr. Ferrer in high school.
At New York University's Bronx campus, Mr. Ferrer studied philosophy and classics and took graduate courses in public administration. After college, he worked four years on the staff of the State Assembly Committee on Government Operations. In 1978, Mr. Ferrer opened a district office for the Democratic Party in the Soundview section of the Bronx, where his family had moved, and was appointed district leader by the legendary party boss Patrick J. Cunningham.
Mr. Badillo, a longtime opponent of the Bronx Democratic organization, said that when Mr. Ferrer joined the organization, the party "was looking for young Puerto Ricans" as it tried to adjust to the demographic shift.
 
Young, Loyal And Untainted
 In many ways, Mr. Ferrer has played a transitional role in the Bronx ever since.
When Mr. Simon resigned as the Borough President in 1987 in the Wedtech military contracting scandal, Mr. Ferrer, then a Councilman, was picked by Bronx officials to take over. He was everything the party needed -- young, Hispanic, untainted by corruption, and a party loyalist.
When Mr. Ferrer took office, the South Bronx was in ruins and the courthouse, covered with graffiti calling for Mr. Simon's resignation, was a symbol of the borough's physical and moral decay. On the first weekend in office, he went back to where his boyhood home once stood and he found himself up to his knees in weeds.
"I had an incredible sense of anger and frustration about what had happened here," Mr. Ferrer said. "I came from the South Bronx, and I saw it disintegrating under my feet."
The money for rebuilding the South Bronx, and other rundown city neighborhoods, had been dedicated by Mayor Edward I. Koch, but Mr. Ferrer's arrival as Borough President was a significant development. "He had a vision for how the Bronx could come back," said Mark A. Willis, who was a Koch-era redevelopment official.
"He came in with a map and said these are the buildings people see every day from the Cross Bronx and the Deegan, and we need to do these first," Mr. Willis said. "He said no one will believe anything good is happening if we don't do these buildings. He was absolutely right."
Defeats Mingled
Among Victories
But some of Mr. Ferrer's biggest plans remain undone. In 1989, he declared victory in a fight for a new Police Academy to help revive the lower end of the Grand Concourse, but six years later he appears to have lost the fight.
His attempt last year to attract a sizable chunk of the $100 million Federal Empowerment Zone grant for the South Bronx failed, a sign of his subordinate status in the arena of mayors and Congressmen and Federal Cabinet secretaries.
Since the City Charter revisions of 1990, when the borough presidents lost their control over city spending, their jobs have become largely parochial, lobbying City Hall and the Council for the needs of their constituents and doling out a portion of the city's capital budget. Now, said Norman Adler, a political consultant, "Borough presidents are like the public equivalent of Chamber of Commerce presidents."
Mr. Ferrer's hankering for a larger arena is understandable. But on the stump, his vision for the city remains only a sketch. He said he was helped by programs to aid the less fortunate and that the city must continue to "hold the door open" for the poor. His message that there is waste, fraud and duplication in government seems to fall short of addressing the larger problems behind the city's chronic budget deficits.
Back home in the Bronx, however, Mr. Ferrer is lovingly involved in each of his borough's tiny steps back from the moribund.
On a recent day, Mr. Ferrer was called in to check the color of the new bronze doors in the grand ceremonial hall on the ground floor of the county courthouse. Mr. Ferrer's predecessor built temporary office space in the hall, covering murals depicting the history of the Bronx, and installed roll-down security doors on the arched doorways. The bronze doors were the final touches of a renovation that Mr. Ferrer initiated. The defiling and the revival of the room are a symbol to Mr. Ferrer of the struggling Bronx.
"When we get this place finished," Mr. Ferrer said, "people will say, 'This place is not without grace.' "

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI 

 BODY:

Politics
 
Mr. Dole Goes to Hollywood
Bob Dole knows a big target when he sees one, so when he went after Hollywood in a speech in Los Angeles on Wednesday it wasn't exactly a big surprise. Dan Quayle tried the same thing a few years ago. Mr. Dole railed against the "nightmares of depravity" coming out of California, at first sounding like he had just about enough of the O.J. trial. He criticized the movies "Natural Born Killers" and "True Romance," but praised such family fare as "The Lion King" and "True Lies." You know, that's the one where the very Republican Arnold Schwarzenegger wins back his estranged daughter by killing lots of bad guys. It sure beats having to sit through her school play. Dole aides said he actually hadn't seen the movie. We could tell. 

Taxes
 
What's in a Name? A Refund
It has been said that a computer is only as smart as the person entering the information into it. So it is sad to have to report that much of the Federal Government is run by computer, and, more crucial, so is the part of the Internal Revenue Service that handles tax refunds. The I.R.S. has decided to use its processing power to match the names and Social Security numbers on tax returns with Social Security computer files in an attempt to combat tax fraud. That is delaying some refunds by up to eight weeks. So if your name is Jon Smith but a Social Security clerk typed John Smith on your file, your check goes into some sort of refund purgatory. Washington bureaucrats gave us much fewer problems when we only let them use pencils.
 
Automotive
 
If at First You Don't Succeed...
Oh, never mind. Investor Kirk Kerkorian used fancier words on Wednesday to end his hostile bid to take over the Chrysler Corporation, but that's what he meant. In the month since he made his $55-a-share offer, Mr. Kerkorian lined up no investors to supply capital and no banks to finance the debt. For a man used to be taken very seriously, Wall Street pretty much had dismissed his offer for lacking, how shall we say, muscle. Well, maybe Mr. Kerkorian just needs more time to pump up his bid. He said last week that, "Withdrawing our offer will permit us to take a fresh look at the situation and evaluate our alternatives." That's a fancy way of saying, "We're still looking for the money."
 
Hot Dogs
 
Permit Me, Please, Say Vendors
So maybe we're all in the wrong business. The entrepreneurs who run the food carts around New York City are seething at the city's plan to limit the permits to run the carts. The city's rather revolutionary plan would allow one permit per customer. Naturally, Frank Cissio, with 200 permits, is upset. So is Dan Rossi. His 499 permits help bring him revenue of between $1 million and $2 million a year. That is not a typo. In the city of Rockefeller and Morgan, there are people who make their millions by selling hot dogs and pretzels to New Yorkers. No wonder David Letterman hasn't moved to Hollywood, he must be waiting for a permit. The last time New York handed out permits people waited in line days to get one. Now we know why.
 
Real Estate
 
King Kong Had a Better Beef
How can anyone resist a story that features both the names Trump and Helmsley, especially if lawsuits are involved. And better, all the fuss is over the Empire State Building, one of the few things in New York that can tower over both personalities. Donald Trump and his partners own the building, and Harry Helmsley and his partners lease and operate it. The Trumps sued the Helmsleys, saying the building was infested with rodents. Helmsley sued Trump on Tuesday for "irresponsible and unfounded actions to disparage" the building and hints that one of Trump's partners is a Japanese gangster. Stay tuned. Now, if we could just find a story with Trump, Helmsley and Steinbrenner.
 
Tobacco
 
Now Will You Stop Smoking?
This may be insignificant, but Philip Morris just said cigarettes can be hazardous to your health. Not all cigarettes, just about eight billion of its own. The company spent the past week recalling several of its brands because of a problem with the filters. It seems they contain contaminants that can form a chemical that is the basis for a pesticide sold as a soil fumigant. Yum. It is unknown whether soil fumigants cause cancer in laboratory mice, but for that macho smoker, pesticide-flavored cigarettes could have a cachet. Smokers who used the tainted filters said they didn't really notice. Anybody surprised?
 
Entertainment
 
Mr. Ovitz, We're Still Waiting
So is he or isn't he? Everyone has been saying, "Of course he is," but Michael Ovitz continues to deny he is leaving Creative Artists Agency to head up MCA for its new owner, Seagram. Word is that Mr. Ovitz and several of his Creative executives are all set to make the move, but they're still haggling ovrt just how rich Seagram is going to make them. Seagram's annual meeting passed last week with still no announcement, so the smart money is betting it will come when Seagram officially takes over MCA this week. Watch this space.
 
Trade
 
Let's Meet at My Place
Can we talk? That's what the Japanese have been asking since the United States imposed trade sanctions against Japanese luxury cars last month. But the Americans are playing coy, telling Japan, "We'll check our calendar and get back to you." The Japanese suggested meeting May 29 in Geneva. The United States said, nope, we're busy, how about June 21 and 22 in Washington. The Japanese wanted a more neutral site. On Friday, the United States agreed to Geneva, which specializes in neutrality, but said it has to be on June 12. And it still wants to meet later in Washington. That's called a compromise. Which is what everyone expects to come out of the talks no matter where they are held.
 
The Economy
 
Sure Enough, It's a Slowdown
Everyone expected Friday's unemployment report for May to show that the jobless rate had fallen to 5.7 percent. It did, but nobody was ready for the sharpest drop in business payrolls since April, 1991. Payrolls, which had been projected to rise about 175,000, plummeted 101,000 instead. And if that weren't bad enough, the Federal Government heaped on more bad news by reporting that the Index of Leading Economic Indicators fell 0.6 percent in April, the third consecutive decline. That often signals an impending recession. So now we know the train is coming. The question is, will the Federal Reserve ease it into the station or will the train just crash through it?
 
International
 
Giving Peace a Chance
Thirty years ago, it was the staging area for the Vietnam War. The Subic Bay Naval Station housed the Seventh Fleet, and the adjoining town, Olongapo, entertained its thousands of sailors. It was a big business: about 42,000 Filipinos worked on the base. But in 1992, the United States gave up Subic, and there was much hand wringing over what the Philippine economy would do without the United States military. Not to worry. The mayor of Olongapo, Richard Gordon, has turned the abandoned base into a zone for economic growth and development and has attracted such companies as Federal Express, Enron and Coastal. About 19,000 jobs have been created. So there.

HEADLINE: One in Six in County Suffers From Hunger

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
DESPITE Westchester's status as the 11th-richest county in the United States, with a median household income of $48,405, according to the 1990 census, a recently released study on hunger revealed that one out of every six residents faces hunger on a regular basis. This translates into about 150,000 people, 45,000 of whom are children, who used the services of a food pantry, a soup kitchen, a shelter or some other program. In a recent Federal study prepared by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the county's estimated median income of $66,900 for 1995 ranks it third in the country.
The study was commissioned by the White Plains-based Westchester Community Foundation, a nonprofit affiliate of the New York Community Trust, which administers a variety of philanthropic funds. The study, "A Growing Hunger: A Study of Food Inadequacy in Westchester County, 1993," was made between January and August 1993 by 180 students and 10 faculty members from the Volunteers in Action/Pace group, a program sponsored by the Dyson College of Arts and Sciences at Pace University. 
 Those researchers conducted close to 500 telephone surveys and more than 400 personal interviews. Food-Patch and the Westchester Coalition of Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens also took part in the research. Kraft General Foods underwrote the printing of the survey.
"Here in Westchester, where the cost of housing is so high, I was really surprised at how low people's incomes were," said Dr. Priscilla Denby, director of the Children's Institute and the Volunteers in Action, who supervised the study. "Seventy percent of the people we surveyed had incomes under $10,000. Only 8 percent were employed, and only half of those were fully employed."
The face of hunger in Westchester is directly linked to other economic factors, including the lack of affordable housing and employment.
"Everything is interconnected," said Dr. Gus Karam, an economist at Pace University in Pleasantville. "Hunger stems from poverty. Either people do not have the job skills they need or they have skills and don't get paid enough. Someone in Westchester who earns $4 an hour would still be in poverty. In an area that is as expensive as Westchester, a full-time job at $4 an hour wouldn't leave someone with enough money to eat. It becomes a vicious circle. Poverty and hunger are not randomly distributed. There is an over-representation among children, women and minorities."
The study found that nearly a third of all households had to choose between rent buying food. "People are spending a lot of income to avoid being homeless," said Patricia Larson, executive director of the Westchester Community Foundation. "They have to make these terrible choices, of giving up medical care or giving up meals. Actually, those who are declared homeless do better foodwise."
Most of those who use emergency food services are elderly, unemployed or single mothers and their children who live in the county's southern cities like Yonkers, New Rochelle, Mount Vernon and White Plains. "We knew there was a lot of hunger, but we were surprised at how much like the rest of the country Westchester is," Dr. Denby said. "One out of three people in our survey said they knew of somebody who wasn't getting enough to eat."
More than three-quarters of the adults surveyed reported missing between 1 and 10 meals a month; close to 10 percent missed between 11 and 30 meals. "Almost nobody said that children in the household missed meals," Dr. Denby said.
One of the study's more surprising findings was that many of those entitled to food stamps didn't apply for them. "Only about 52 percent of those who needed them were receiving food stamps," Dr. Denby said. "People don't want to go to the government first. Older people don't get food stamps because of the bureaucracy and the stigma attached. And many fall just above the cut-off line in terms of income."
The study found that most of those who use emergency food services do so at church- or synagogue-sponsored soup kitchens and food pantries. "Houses of worship have been the birthplace of the feeding programs in the county," Ms. Larson said. "Many feel it's part of their mission to take care of neighbors, but people feel that they won't be judged when they go there."
But the plethora of food pantries and soup kitchens doesn't mitigate the growing problem for many residents. "We're lucky in the county to have these resources," Dr. Denby said. "But the lines are getting longer at the food pantries and soup kitchens, and many aren't open full time. It's hard work figuring out how to put food on the table."
Still, Ms. Larson cautioned: "Hunger is a fairly widespread problem in the county. It could be that someone elderly doesn't go to a feeding program in Scarsdale but might go up to one in White Plains."
School lunches, which are currently under attack in Washington, were used by more than 40 percent of those surveyed in this study. "With Washington looking for ways to cut almost any entitlement, it's going to get terrible," Ms. Larson said. "It can't help but get worse."
And however disturbing the study's numbers are, in the current climate of social service cutbacks on the state and national level, few experts are sanguine about the situation's improving.
"Everybody is frightened and waiting for the other shoe to drop in Albany and in D.C.," Ms. Larson said. "Right now is very iffy."
Copies of the study can be ordered from Volunteers in Action/Pace for $15. Call 773-3539 for more information.

HEADLINE: More Budget Battles;
This Year's Fiscal Fight Is Over in Albany But Squabbling May Be Worse Next Year

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 4

 BODY:
Having just ended one of the longest and most bitter budget fights in state history, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature have now embarked on a course toward an even more caustic and protracted conflict next year.
The reasons lie buried in the budget agreed to by the Republican Governor and legislative leaders late last week. The spending plan fails to address many of the state's long-term financial problems and has created new pitfalls that could significantly worsen future budget shortfalls. 
 Earlier this year, Mr. Pataki predicted that the state would have a budget gap of between $1.4 billion and $1.8 billion in 1996. The Governor now acknowledges that the shortfall will be larger by an unspecified amount because the Legislature rejected his major welfare and Medicaid cuts, restored nearly $900 million in spending and approved a three-year tax cut that is larger next year than what he had originally proposed.
The new budget, which totals $63 billion for all funds, includes a range of measures to transfer the cost of this year's spending to future budgets, including borrowing to pay for new stadiums and using $900 million in so-called one-shot revenues. For that reason, many fiscal analysts and legislators think next year's shortfall could be as large as this year's $4 billion gap.
Though state spending plans traditionally contain questionable budget-balancing measures, Mr. Pataki had vowed to avoid them this year. But analysts for bond raters and business groups said he has not succeeded.
Without a strong economic recovery, which few economists predict, the Legislature and Mr. Pataki will probably be back at the budget table next year revisiting the most thorny cuts that the Governor proposed but failed to gain this year, particularly in the area of welfare.
"The size of the multiyear tax cut is the largest that we've seen, and it's by the state with the largest accumulated deficit," said George W. Leung, managing director for Moody's Investors Service, which has given New York the second lowest bond rating in the nation, after Louisiana. "It will make the achievement of structural balance that much more difficult and accordingly will necessitate more spending cuts."
Election-year politics are also likely to make next year's budget fight more volatile and ideologically sharp. The state's Republican Party has already singled out 21 seats in the Democratic-controlled Assembly, all of whose members are up for election next year. Those races could affect the budget negotiations by making both parties even more intransigent and the process even more nasty, brutish and longer than this year, which saw the third longest budget negotiations on record.
"This year was a battle; next year is a war," said Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., a Brooklyn Democrat. "You're going to see a whole lot of political posturing."
Mr. Pataki said he is not overly worried about a more protracted and politicized budget battle next year because he believes the state's economy will improve this year, partly due to tax cuts in the budget. Historically, it has been easier to resolve budget fights when the economy has been strong.
"I'm optimistic about it," the Governor said at a news conference on Saturday. "I believe that as the message gets out that New York is serious about cutting taxes, about reducing the cost of government, about lowering the regulatory burden the state places both on the private sector and local governments, that we are going to begin to see us creating the jobs and opportunity that have we've missed out on for the past four years."
But Mr. Pataki's assurances seem to conflict with the expectations of his strongest allies in the Legislature, who foresee a ferocious budget fight in 1996. Assemblyman John J. Faso, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee and a leading party strategist, said the Republicans will seek to close the anticipated shortfall by cutting social programs that the Democrats traditionally protect.
"We'll go after the same things the Assembly Democrats refused to do this year, like setting time limits on Home Relief and making further changes to Medicaid," Mr. Faso said. Home Relief is a welfare program mainly for able-bodied, childless adults. There is currently no limit on how long a person can collect it, and Assembly Democratic leaders rejected Mr. Pataki's proposal this year to limit Home Relief payments to 60 days per year.
State Senator Kemp Hannon, a Long Island Republican, said anticipated Federal cuts for Medicaid this year would make it harder for the state to reduce its Medicaid spending next year, but would increase the likelihood that Mr. Pataki will seek even larger savings from welfare.
"The Governor will definitely push for time limits and benefit reductions next year," Mr. Hannon said. "It's a hot-button issue."
Several independent financial analysts said the new budget seems to be balanced on some precarious assumptions. For instance, it predicts that Medicaid spending will actually drop this year, even though it has risen at double-digit rates in recent years. Several analysts called that prediction optimistic.
Mr. Pataki has also projected savings of more than $245 million from anti-fraud measures in welfare and Medicaid programs, although some of the programs have limited track records and could be challenged in court.
The spending plan also includes costs that will grow significantly in following years. A cut in personal income taxes will reduce state revenues by $555 million this year, but $2.2 billion next year. Reductions in business taxes will grow from $50 million this year to $160 million next year. And the budget calls for tougher sentencing laws that critics say will drive up prison costs, though Mr. Pataki's aides deny that.
In March, an analysis of Mr. Pataki's budget by J. P. Morgan Securities concluded that the state's economy would probably remain flat, that the tax cuts were "too deep" and "ill timed" and that the state "may experience chronic financial imbalances that could match or even exceed those evident at the height of the recent recession."
Since then, the Legislature has only worsened things, financial analysts said, by approving most of the tax cuts while also increasing spending sharply.
"They'll be fighting over the same issues next year," said Cynthia B. Green, deputy research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit business group.

HEADLINE: Mandaue Journal;
They Plow the Waves for the Squire of Seaweed

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: MANDAUE, Philippines

 BODY:
Benson U. Dakay hefted a tangled, soggy gray-green clump and shook it slightly.
"This is what it's all about," he said. "Seaweed." 
 The man known in the Philippines as the Seaweed King grinned, glanced around the warehouse piled with bags of the ocean's greenery and declared: "Seaweed is growing. Seaweed is growing fast."
One of eight children who inherited a small trading business and a company that makes mosquito repellent from his father, who was an orphan from Fujian Province in China, the 40-year-old Mr. Dakay has built an empire on seaweed here in the southern Philippines. Not only has he created a family conglomerate involved in the processing of seaweed, but he also owns a California-based food company, marketing and research centers in Canada and Denmark and even the original family business making mosquito repellent.
And like many of the success stories on this palm-tree island, Mr. Dakay has replicated the experience of hundreds of other Chinese-Filipino families, the descendents of those who came here over the last two centuries to make their fortunes, in his family's case a fortune built despite two decades of political uncertainty, occasional upheaval and, until recently, national economic disarray.
Today, Filipinos of Chinese ancestry make up barely 1.5 percent of the country's 70 million people, but Chinese-Filipinos have, as have Chinese throughout southeast Asia, been a dominant presence in the world of business and trading.
"My father was an orphan from Fujian," Mr. Dakay said. "He started the business, trading like everyone in Cebu, like all the Chinese here. Cebu has always been a trading center, a center for export, and that's what the Chinese did when they came here."
But trading alone could only take the Dakay family so far. During the late 1960's, Mr. Dakay said he wondered about the European companies that were increasingly interested in buying seaweed harvested from the ocean, packing it up and shipping it to Europe for processing. Here in Cebu, seaweed had been part of the local diet for generations, but there seemed little use for the stuff beyond an appearance in a salad bowl.
"We were dealing with the Europeans," he said, of his father's trading company. "We were supplying the French and some to the Danish. The Danes were putting up a buying station. I started organizing farmers to gather wild seaweed. But the whole thing became depleted after five years. There wasn't any more seaweed."
About the same time, a researcher from the University of Hawaii was experimenting here with the idea of seaweed farms, examining whether seaweed could be raised like any other crop.
" The Government began providing some support for seaweed farming," said Filipina Scott, who heads the marine biology section at the University of San Carlos here. "It began very slowly, but then began to take off."
For Mr. Dakay, the success of seaweed farming marked the beginning of the real commercialization of the seaweed industry in the Philippines, the transformation from gathering natural seaweed to organized farming. "Farming was the key," he explained.
Beginning with the farmers who had earlier gathered wild seaweed, Mr. Dakay and Government fisheries and aquatic resources agents began urging farmers throughout the archipelego to create and tend sea farms of about two and a half acres each. The farms were created by stringing nylon cord from stakes and tying seaweed seedlings to the cords. By the beginning of this year, nearly 100,000 families were engaged in seaweed farming.
Every day, from dozens of islands across the Philippines, bags of seaweed arrive at Mr. Dakay's sprawling warehouses. The seaweed is dried and processed into a powder called carrageenan, an ingredient in dozens of food products from hams and hotdogs to jellies, breads, beers, noodles, chocolate milk and ice cream. Increasingly, the world's supply of carrageenan is coming from the Philippines, and a growing percentage of that from Mr. Dakay's company, the Shemberg Marketing Corporation, its name derived from the first initial of the elder Dakay's eight children.
While Shemberg is the largest of the seaweed producers and refiners, nearly a dozen other companies here in Cebu are involved in the processing of seaweed. Last year, it commandeered nearly half of the $65.6 million Philippine market in seaweed products, or about 10 percent of the global demand for refined and semi-refined seaweed products.
With seaweed processing at the core of the Dakay businesses, the family has expanded its interests throughout the Philippines, including car-care products, foods and beverages, textiles, plastics and handicrafts.
Mr. Dakay pulled his sunglasses from his shirt pocket. "Finally things are going right in the Philippines," he said, alluding to economic reforms under President Fidel V. Ramos. He turned before heading out into the blazing Cebu sun and added: "Everything has changed in the last three years. Now everyone can do business. That's what we're doing."

HEADLINE: Pataki's Visions for Medicaid and Welfare Run Into Albany's Hard Knocks;
Assembly Democrats Took On the Governor Over Benefits

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

 BODY:
Even as other Republican governors are pushing through ideologically charged laws to reduce welfare benefits and strictly limit how long people can stay on the welfare rolls, New York's Democratic-controlled State Assembly has defended the state's liberal tradition and forced Gov. George E. Pataki to settle for incremental change.
To win the Assembly's support for a deep income tax cut, Mr. Pataki abandoned both benefit reductions and time limits. 
 The compromise welfare agreement, outlined by state officials, includes several anti-fraud measures, like electronic fingerprinting of all welfare applicants, as well as a handful of policy changes that range from the significant to the relatively inconsequential.
"The biggest story is what was not done," said Russell Sykes, deputy director of the State Communities Aid Association, a nonprofit advocacy group. "The Assembly drew a line in the sand on time limits and benefit cuts. They prevailed on the two largest, most publicly trumpeted pieces of the Governor's plan."
The most important measure Mr. Pataki won would require 95 percent of the able-bodied recipients of Home Relief, the welfare program that serves mainly single, childless adults, to work for their benefits or lose them. Now, only about 20 percent of such recipients participate in workfare programs.
But Mr. Pataki jettisoned his proposal to nearly double the number of single parents, to 50 percent from 27 percent, who would be required to join job-related programs in the larger welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
He bowed not only to political pressure, but also to the fiscal reality that putting parents to work costs much more than it does for singles because of the expense of child care.
He did, however, persuade the Assembly to require teen-age parents under age 18 to live at home to qualify for welfare unless they can show they have a legitimate fear of abuse -- a proposal that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had endorsed but failed to get through the Legislature.
But the other change in Aid to Families With Dependent Children that Mr. Pataki extracted from the Assembly -- docking the benefits of parents of truant schoolchildren -- appears far more substantial than it is. Mr. Pataki had wanted the new rules to apply to all children on welfare, up through high school. But faced with impassioned opposition in the Assembly, he settled for first through sixth graders, about 180,000 children.
That will make New York the only state with a "learnfare" program that applies only to such young children. Of the 23 states that have Federal permission for such programs, most cover all children on welfare or teen-agers, who have the most serious truancy rates.
State officials say there is no evidence that elementary-school children on welfare have bad attendance records. Poverty experts who have studied such programs say it is likely that only a small fraction of parents will end up being financially sanctioned for their children's truancy. County officials who will have to carry out the new policy say it will be costly and burdensome because of the complexities of matching welfare records with the school attendance files of so many children.
 
Home Relief
 Mr. Pataki had to abandon his push for a 90-day limit on benefits to able-bodied Home Relief recipients, but largely succeeded in fulfilling his pledge to put them to work.
Throughout his campaign for governor, Mr. Pataki held up Westchester County's Home Relief program, which stresses workfare and fraud prevention, as a model for the state. That approach will now be copied statewide.
By the end of next year, local governments that administer the state-regulated welfare program will be required to raise the percentage of employable recipients working on public works projects or for nonprofit groups to 60 percent from 20 percent. And by the end of the second year, 95 percent, an estimated 120,000 people, must be participating.
State law has for years mandated participation in workfare, but the provision had no teeth. The new statute will allow the state to withhold up to 5 percent of state funds for administering welfare programs if a county fails to meet the workfare targets.
Recipients who fail to show up at their work sites and have no documented excuse -- like a doctor's note or proof of a job interview -- will be removed from the rolls for 90 days on the first offense, 150 days on the second, and 180 days on the third.
The state is actually counting on the workfare rules, combined with tougher eligibility screening, to generate substantial savings. In Westchester, the same combination helped the county hold the growth of its Home Relief caseload flat over four years, while it rose 11 percent statewide and by half in New York City.
The city, which began using a program much like Westchester's in January, has already seen large declines in the number of applicants found eligible for benefits.
 
New State Residents
 The compromise would mandate that welfare recipients who moved to New York would continue receiving the level of benefits offered in their previous home state for a year, if it was lower. Whether New York will ever be able to put this new rule into effect is open to serious question.
The Clinton Administration has refused to grant states permission to carry out such residency requirements on the ground that they infringe on the constitutional right to travel. And even if Republican welfare bills in Congress become law, allowing such policies, legal experts say they will certainly face serious constitutional challenges from advocates for the poor.
 
Aid for Children
 New York's learnfare program, which would financially penalize families with elementary-school-aged children who did not attend school regularly, would be phased in over three years. The state would have to obtain a Federal waiver exempting it from current rules before going forward, but such waivers have generally been granted routinely for learnfare programs.
State officials said the number of unexcused absences that would trigger the financial penalty -- from three to six days per quarter -- was still being negotiated. The sanction would lower the welfare benefits for a family of three in the city to $504 a month from $577.
To date, there have been no rigorous evaluations of whether financial penalties against parents improve the school attendance of young children, nor does New York have any data that show such children are, in fact, not attending school regularly.
A 1989 study by the Urban Research Center at the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee found that second, third and fourth graders on welfare were in school an average of 165 days a year, compared with 168 days a year for children not receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children, a relatively small difference.
The researchers concluded that poor children would benefit more from additional spending on education than from more intensive monitoring by the welfare system.
But state Republican leaders said they strongly believed that the state should use financial penalties to encourage school attendance by children on welfare and ultimately to lower the dropout rates for poor children. They said they were disappointed that the compromise did not go further.
"You have to start in kindergarten or first grade," said Joseph R. Holland, the chairman of the State Senate Social Services Committee. "You have to educate parents and children that you have to go to school. My desire was to run it through 12th grade."
But many Democrats in the Assembly, particularly those who represent poor and working-class districts in the city, said the learnfare program set up an unfair, stigmatizing distinction between the attendance records of poor and working-class children and gave children too much clout.
"For the first time in the history of child welfare, we're empowering children with the economic security of the family unit," said Assemblyman Roger L. Green of Brooklyn. "This proposal undermines the authority of parents."
From a more practical standpoint, local officials said they were disappointed that the learnfare compromise focused on the youngest children who were least likely to be truant and furthest from graduation and the demands of the job market.
"It would have been wiser to target teen-agers," said Deborah Merrifield, the Social Services Commissioner in Erie County.

HEADLINE: New York Builders Flouting Wage Law To Increase Profits

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Hard pressed by the deep recession in the construction industry, dozens of New York City contractors are increasing profits by illegally underpaying hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of their nonunion workers.
City officials say there has been a threefold increase in the last six years in the number of formal complaints by laborers contending that construction companies are shortchanging them. 
 And beyond that, labor officials and construction workers say, there are countless other workers who quietly accept wages that are a fraction of what is legally required, because they are so desperate for work that they are afraid to risk losing their jobs by complaining.
Dennis Stawkowski worked as a carpenter for a construction company that renovated a city-owned apartment building in East Harlem and public schools in Brooklyn and Queens. He was paid $12.50 an hour to put up walls and lay tile floors. By law, he was supposed to receive $32.27 an hour.
Worrel Thomas worked for a contractor who installed fire escapes, stairways and fences in 46 city-owned apartment houses being rebuilt in central Harlem. An ironworker, he was paid $10 an hour, but he was supposed to be paid $35.69.
The underpayments are on public-works projects. In New York City, contractors hired for such projects are required to pay predetermined wages, called the prevailing wage, based on state and Federal laws. In New York, the prevailing wage covers more than 100 job categories on billions of dollars of city construction projects that range from school repairs and hospital renovations to the building of new housing, schools, sewers and water tunnels.
Last year, more than 300 complaints of underpayments -- some of which involved 10 or more workers -- were filed with City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, who oversees the wage regulations. That was more than triple the number of complaints filed in 1989.
And in the first three months of this year, 103 new claims were placed with the city -- nearly double the 59 cases filed during the first three months of 1993.
More than 30 states have prevailing-wage laws similar to New York's. In several large industrial states, including California and Illinois-- hundreds of complaints of underpayments are filed each year. In these states, though, the number of complaints has generally declined somewhat in recent years.
No one knows precisely how widespread the wage violations are in New York City, but many construction industry officials, labor leaders and municipal officials say the rules are ignored much more often than the number of formal complaints would suggest. Some construction workers and labor lawyers contend that the law is violated at as many as half the small public construction jobs in the city.
"You'd be surprised how many guys are being paid $10 an hour," said a construction worker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It's a big thing going on."
The contractors' motivation is clear, many labor leaders and construction industry officials said. In the increasingly sharp competition for public construction projects, many companies have sought to win contracts by submitting unusually low bids. They then try to make the jobs profitable by slashing their labor costs, often by ignoring the requirement that they pay the prevailing wage.
Some construction workers, particularly those who do not speak English, are simply unaware of the prevailing-wage scale. Others are undocumented immigrants and are afraid to complain for fear of deportation.
But most workers who accept a wage below prevailing rates are American citizens or legal immigrants who are familiar with the law, many experts say. They tolerate a low wage because they are desperate for work.
Mr. Hevesi said he was surprised when he took office 17 months ago at how prevalent the practice was. "There was widespread cheating," he said.
Besides competing for a dwindling number of government construction jobs, some contractors apparently ignore the wage law because of a more crude motivation: profiteering. Some contractors have found it extremely profitable to accept $41.55 an hour in wages and benefits from the city for a cement mason, for example, and then pay a mason eager for work $10 an hour.
The Comptroller is responsible for setting the wage rates for masons and workers in more than 100 other trades at city construction projects and for overseeing enforcement of the rules. A bricklayer, for example, must be paid at least $29.10 an hour, plus an additional $12.33 in benefits. An asphalt raker must receive a minimum of $25.11 an hour, plus $11 in benefits. The prevailing wage is generally the negotiated union rate for a particular construction trade.
Critics have long argued that the wage laws seriously inflate the cost of public construction, both in New York and around the country, and that they are primarily intended to protect the unions.
But proponents, including some major contractors' associations, contend that the wage scale helps assure a stable and skilled work force. They say the laws prevent unscrupulous contractors from exploiting workers and driving out legitimate contractors by underbidding them on contracts.
"The issue for contractors is a level playing field," said Frank McArdle, managing director of the General Contractors Association of New York.
Most construction workers actually work only 1,200 to 1,500 hours a year, because of rain and cold weather, Mr. McArdle said. A worker making only $10 an hour, or $12,000 a year, would not be earning a living wage in a region as expensive as New York, he said.
After Mr. Hevesi took office last year, he hired more labor investigators, began clearing up a large backlog of cases and asked city agencies to enforce the prevailing-wage laws more aggressively.
"The notion that we were not enforcing a law is surprising," Mr. Hevesi said. "I really believe in prevailing wage. It's fair and it's the law. It also makes good economic sense."
Some city agencies, trying to keep down construction costs, have been lax for years about enforcing the wage regulations, many union leaders and municipal officials said.
"It's not a priority," said Edward J. Malloy, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, a union umbrella group. "Their goal is to get the job done, and that's all they think about."
Leonard A. Mancusi, the senior assistant comptroller, who is in charge of enforcing the prevailing wage, said that many city agencies had begun to be more vigilant about the law, in response to Mr. Hevesi's requests.
But many construction workers are afraid to speak up about being shortchanged, because they fear losing their jobs by pressing their legal rights. Even some workers who have filed wage complaints in the past and who have won back pay are quietly accepting underpayments at their current jobs.
A nonunion construction worker said he was currently getting paid $20 an hour -- a little more than half of what he was entitled to. But he was not willing to file a complaint or even talk for attribution about his current situation, he said, because of fears he would be dismissed if he did so.
"There's not a lot of work out there," he said.
Just four months ago, the worker won a large settlement -- more than $40,000 in back pay and interest -- for being underpaid by a previous employer.
The man had been paid $10 an hour for doing masonry and blacktopping on renovation projects in Central Park between 1991 and 1993. He should have been paid $30.08 an hour in wages and benefits under prevailing-wage regulations.
But now he is working for another contractor for $20 an hour. "I'm happy, even though it's not prevailing wage," he said. "All these companies, they try to pay you as cheap as they can."
Many other nonunion workers have made large settlements or have been awarded tens of thousands of dollars in back pay in recent years. During just the first three months of this year, 41 contractors agreed to settle with workers who had contended that they had not been paid prevailing wages. The settlements, which involved more than 130 workers, were worth a total of $486,000.
Seven other construction companies were found by administrative law judges to have violated the wage laws during the first three months of this year. They were ordered to pay a total of $375,000 in underpayments, interest and penalties to 22 workers.
In a case that wound through the Federal courts for three years, 35 Chinese immigrants who had renovated city-owned housing for a nonprofit organization, the Chinese-American Planning Council, said that both their employer and the city were responsible for underpayments. The workers, who were paid an average of $6.25 an hour, contended that they had not received prevailing wages because the city's contract with the planning council had specifically limited how much they could be paid each day.
An appellate court ultimately decided that the workers were entitled to sue both the planning council and the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The case was settled last July, with the workers getting $1.7 million in back wages and interest, said their lawyer, James Reif. Some individuals received more than $40,000.
But some construction workers who have won large awards in administrative hearings have yet to collect a penny, either because their former employers are fighting the awards in court or because the companies have gone out of business.
Mr. Stawkowski, the carpenter who worked for a Long Island construction company, Hollywood Commercial Ltd., repairing city-owned housing and public schools, was awarded $80,000 in back pay and interest last November by an administrative law judge.
"I haven't gotten any money yet," Mr. Stawkowski said. Hollywood Commercial has gone out of business, but he still hopes to collect some of what he is owed through a bond the company took out.
"Why should a contractor make out better than the workers?" he said.
In another recent case, an administrative judge ordered the Brooklyn Welding Corporation to pay more than $1.5 million last July to 23 construction workers whom the company had underpaid. The contractor was found to have filed false payrolls with the city to cover up the underpayments, and it was barred from bidding for city contracts for five years.
Mr. Thomas was one of the 23 iron workers who had installed fire escapes and stairways at city-owned buildings in Harlem for Brooklyn Welding. He was awarded $78,000 in back pay and an additional $50,000 in interest, but Mr. Thomas said he had not yet received anything from the company, which is still in business.
"I hope to get it eventually," said Mr. Thomas, who is now working on his own on private houses. "It's a lot of money."

HEADLINE: Shifting Public Opinion by the Turn of a Phrase

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
Advice to Republicans: Don't talk about "cuts" in Medicare spending. Talk instead about reducing the rate of increase. Emphasize the moral imperative of balancing the budget for "future generations." Stress that Federal budget cuts will spare no one and will be felt across-the-board.
Advice to Democrats: Do talk about "cuts" in Medicare spending, and do it often. Emphasize the pain that balancing the budget will cause to "real people" right now. Stress that the wealthy will be getting tax cuts, while children and the elderly will pay. 
 So runs the counsel that pollsters have been providing their clients in Congress these days. It sounds like plain old common sense, yet this sage political advice results from a huge research effort, and it is likely to play an important role in the coming weeks. Analysts for both parties acknowledge that the outcome of the current budget debate -- one of the most consequential in recent years -- will depend largely on which party manages to define the fight in its own words.
The debate, after all, involves complex issues, like whether budget deficits are compatible with long-term economic growth and whether entitlement programs for elderly people can remain solvent at their current benefit levels. But it is assumed by all concerned that Americans will invest only brief attention in these issues, and that they will make up their minds on the basis of key words and phrases that they hear and, for one reason or another, retain.
"It's a great test of communications in America," said a Democratic pollster, Keith Frederick. "Which side is going to be able to tell Americans that they are doing what they want done? And the jury is going to be out until 1996."
In addition to their own polling data, Republicans and Democrats are molding their communications strategies in accord with polls made public by news organizations and with surveys sponsored by lobbying groups. One of the most influential of these surveys, which measured public attitudes toward Medicare, was conducted earlier this year by the American Hospital Association, a lobbying group for hospitals and health organizations.
The challenge facing each party is illustrated by two routine polling questions that consistently yield opposite results. If Americans are asked whether they favor "balancing the Federal budget," more than two-thirds will say "yes." But if they are asked whether they favor balancing the budget if it means "cuts in Medicare," roughly the same proportion will say "no." Members of both parties acknowledge that it will be very difficult to balance the budget without reducing the growth of spending on Medicare.
In their spending plans, Republicans, who have pledged to balance the budget by 2002, call for the Federal Government to pare by more than $250 billion the projected growth in Medicare spending under current policy over the next seven years. For them, the challenge is essentially to convince Americans that this is not a "cut."
Indeed, so concerned are Republicans about the terminology that some pollsters have been calling reporters to try to persuade them to avoid the word "cut" when describing the proposed changes.
"When you say the four words -- 'cuts in projected growth' -- all Americans see is the word 'cuts,' " said a Republican pollster, Frank Luntz. "If it is phrased in those terms, Republicans lose the debate." Instead, Mr. Luntz has been urging reporters and Republican members of Congress to use the phrase "increase spending at a slower rate."
Current projections predict that Medicare spending will increase by about 10 percent a year. The House plan would reduce that to a 5.4 percent increase, while the Senate would hold it to 7.1 percent.
Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster whose clients include Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, a Presidential candidate, has been urging Republican lawmakers to "individualize" the Medicare debate. She has instructed them, she said, to tell voters that under their budget plan the amount of money spent each year on the average Medicare recipient will still increase to about $6,300 in 2002 from about $4,800 now.
"People know very little about the numbers behind Medicare," she said. "A lot of it is the phraseology and the information you provide."
In addition to looking for new ways to say "cut," Republican researchers have conducted dozens of polls and focus group interviews searching for arguments that would persuade Americans to change their minds about reductions in Medicare. One critical finding has been that voters are much more likely to say they believe change is needed if they are told that the trustees of the Medicare system have determined that, left as is, the system will run out of money in 2002.
"We have to make sure people are aware the system needs to be fixed," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who is working on Senator Bob Dole's Presidential effort. "If they know and believe that, they are much more receptive to a range of options."
For their part, Democratic researchers maintain that Republicans are facing an uphill battle in trying to persuade the public that they are not simply looking to cut Medicare to balance the budget.
"They could talk about restricting growth as much as they wanted," said Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster. "It's clear in the research that Republicans don't have perfect credibility in all of this. Voters are perfectly willing to believe Republicans would do mean things."
Some Democratic pollsters acknowledge that their party may seem to be at a disadvantage because it has not yet presented a plan to balance the budget, despite tremendous public support for the idea. But most cite a parallel to last year's debate over overhauling health care, in which many Republican lawmakers attacked President Clinton's proposals without providing concrete alternatives.
"If you had asked people, 'Should Republicans provide their own health care plan?' people would have said yes," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster whose clients include the House minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt. "And it probably would have been better if they did. But they didn't, and it didn't hurt them."
Democratic pollsters assert that they will win the debate over the budget if they keep it focused on the effect it will have on ordinary people -- for example, the higher out-of-pocket costs for medical care that elderly people will face. "Our challenge as Democrats is to talk about this in terms of real-world impacts," Mr. Garin said. "The challenge for Republicans is to talk about this in every way except that."
Research for both parties shows that Republicans are particularly vulnerable to the argument that they are cutting programs for children and the elderly in order to provide a tax cut that will benefit the rich. That is why Democratic pollsters have been urging their lawmakers to emphasize this theme. And it is why Republican pollsters have been urging their lawmakers to emphasize that their targets are corporate subsidies in addition to welfare for the poor. Some Republicans in Congress, for example, have been pressing for the elimination of tax breaks for mining and timber companies, although other Republicans are opposed.
"At the front end of all this has to be 'corporate welfare,' " said Steve Lombardo, a Republican pollster, referring to the tax breaks and other forms of subsidies given to businesses. In focus groups, he said, "public support unravels when people believe some groups aren't paying their share."
Republican and Democratic pollsters agree that the contest for public opinion is still in its early stages, and it is not yet clear which side is doing a better job of pushing its phrases into the public consciousness.
"Basically we're in the middle of this battle," said Ms. DiVall, the Republican pollster. "We'll see how it plays out."

 BODY:

IN CONSTRUCTION, ILLEGALLY LOW WAGES
Hard pressed by the deep recession in the construction industry, dozens of New York City contractors are increasing profits by illegally underpaying hundreds, and perhaps thousands, of their nonunion workers. City officials say there has been a threefold increase in the last six years in the number of formal complaints by laborers contending that construction companies are shortchanging them. [Page A1.]
 
IS BUDGET A BLUEPRINT FOR FUTURE ILLS?
Having just ended one of the longest and most bitter budget fights in state history, Governor Pataki and the Legislature have now embarked on a course toward an even more caustic and protracted conflict next year. The reasons lie buried in the budget agreed to by the Republican Governor and legislative leaders. By many accounts, the spending plan fails to address many of the state's long-term financial problems and has created new pitfalls that could worsen future budget shortfalls. [A1.]

SCHOOL POLICING: CONTROL AT ISSUE
In Los Angeles, school security officers are armed and receive as much training as regular police officers. In many other large cities, school systems are working more closely with police departments as parents and educators become alarmed by rising school violence. With school violence in New York City having risen sharply, Mayor Giuliani has called for the Police Department to take over school security. Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines fiercely opposes that plan. [B3.]
 
WAITING . . . AND WAITING . . . FOR THE TRAIN
It may be small consolation to people who found that their subway trains were more crowded than usual, made more stops than usual or did not run at all. But if the riders thought that something was amiss, they were right. The replacement of a major crossover switch in Queens forced changes in service on F, E, G and R trains through much of that borough and between Queens and Manhattan. [B3.]

Cost alone is rarely the entire reason something fails to happen in New York. The airport railway will not be built because not enough of the political establishment in New York and New Jersey wants to build it. The politics of the time mitigate against it -- a politics of shrinking government, reducing taxes and embracing policies that smile on the suburbs and their mostly Republican voters, not on Democratic cities. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B3.]

MANAGED CARE DELAYED A YEAR
In the new state budget, Governor Pataki left undone one of his most sweeping proposals to cut the cost of government: to require nearly three million poor and disabled people to receive their medical care from managed-care plans. While that might initially seem to be a major setback for the Governor, Mr. Pataki ultimately neither wanted nor needed to pick a fight with the Democrats this year on mandating managed care. [B4.]
 
A REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR SETTLES FOR LESS
Even as other Republican governors are pushing through ideologically charged laws to reduce welfare benefits and strictly limit how long people can stay on the welfare rolls, New York's Democratic-controlled State Assembly has defended the state's liberal tradition and forced Governor Pataki to settle for incremental change. [B4.]
 
CHALLENGING NEW YORK'S ADOPTION LAW
One couple appearing before the state's highest court is heterosexual, the other lesbian. But they have an issue in common: because they are not married, one partner cannot adopt the other's biological child. New York is the fourth state in the country to address the question of adoption by an unmarried mate. And by requesting that the cases of unmarried heterosexual and lesbian couples be heard in tandem, the Court of Appeals has shifted its focus away from sexual orientation and toward the state law's requirement that an adoptive couple be married. [B5.]
 
RAIL OFFICIALS REJECT RUMOR OF WALKOUT
For the second time in 10 days, rumors of a wildcat walkout by Long Island Rail Road engineers raced among commuters and transportation officials. But union leaders and transportation officials insisted that this time there would not be one. [B2.]

HEADLINE: Drug Smuggling Growing In Ex-Communist Lands

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 3

 BODY:
Acting on a tip from a Western anti-drug agency, Polish officials searched a Greek freighter when it docked at Gdansk on May 28. Lashed to the keel beneath the waterline were watertight bags containing almost 480 poinds of cocaine, worth $30 million on the street. It was the second-largest cocaine seizure in Polish history.
Five days earlier, customs officials had searched a fishing cutter and uncovered nine tons of hashish, worth $60 million on the street, secreted beneath a layer of herring. That was the largest seizure of hashish in Poland. 
 And two weeks ago, in the largest drug bust of any kind in neighboring Slovakia, border guards seized 225 pounds of heroin hidden in a panel of a truck crossing from Hungary.
These seizures were small victories in the war on drug smuggling in Central and Eastern Europe.
It is a war that the former Communist countries say they are losing. They have had little assistance from the West, even though these fledgling democracies are up against sophisticated international criminal syndicates that are better organized, financed and equipped.
"It is getting much worse," said Maciek Lubik, a senior Polish customs officer and the regional director of the Customs Cooperation Council, a Brussels-based organization, about drug smuggling in Eastern Europe. "The quantity and variety is growing pretty rapidly. And the big wave is still to come."
Officials say that at the moment, they believe that they are seizing only a small fraction of the drugs passing through their countries -- perhaps as little as 5 percent, Mr. Lubik said.
Most of the drugs being moved across Central and Eastern Europe are destined for Western Europe, not the United States. But American interests are at stake, analysts say, because criminal elements are undermining the development of democracy in these countries.
"We have other concerns besides what amount of drugs reach the streets in the U.S. each year," said Rensselaer W. Lee 3d, an American expert on organized crime in the former Soviet Union, in a telephone interview from Alexandria, Va. "It's not just a drug problem. It's an organized crime problem."
Polish officials say the Colombian cartels have established a beachhead here, which does not surprise Mr. Lee.
"Colombian traffickers are working very hard to develop ties with traffickers in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe," he said.
Polish law enforcement officials said they believed that the cocaine seized at Gdansk had come from Colombia and the hashish from Nigeria.
After reaching Poland, drug shipments are broken down into smaller packages, usually 20 to 45 pounds, then smuggled by individual couriers into Germany, Mr. Lubik said. The Polish-German border is lightly patrolled, part of Germany's effort to create better relations with its neighbor.
Western European and Russian gangs are also establishing themselves here, Polish law enforcement officials say.
Throughout the former Communist empire, from Poland to former Soviet republics like Tajikistan and Georgia, the stability and viability of states are being undermined by these international criminal organizations. The gangs are engaged in everything from car theft to smuggling nuclear materials and illegal aliens.
This could impair the integration of the former Communist countries with Western Europe.
In his speech at the Air Force Academy on Wednesday, President Clinton said combating drug trafficking and organized crime was a top priority, "to enhance our security."
Yet Washington is doing little to help combat the drug trade in the region. The Drug Enforcement Administration has no office in Poland or any other former Communist country in Eastern or Central Europe. The nearest offices are in Bonn and Athens.
Expenditures on combating the international drug trade by all American agencies -- like the Drug Enforcement Administration, F.B.I., Defense and State Departments -- have declined from $523 million in 1993 to $309 million this year.
The State Department's narcotics bureau has requested $213 million for foreign narcotics spending next year; only $4 million of that is earmarked for the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
"The U.S. commitments are minuscule compared to the dimensions of the drug and crime problems plaguing the region," Mr. Lee said. "For remarkably little money we could advance U.S. interests significantly."
Poland is not the only country where drug trafficking is on the increase.
Romania seized 350 pounds of heroin last year, up from about 55 pounds in 1993, said Mr. Lubik, the regional customs officer. Hungary seized almost 1,600 pounds of heroin last year, more than triple the quantity seized in 1990.
All of these countries have inexperienced, poorly trained and inadequately equipped law enforcement agencies. Many Polish police officers do not even know what cocaine looks like, Mr. Lubik said, and the Government has been able to send only 100 of its 5,000 customs officers to a two-week course in drug detection. Bulgaria has only eight dogs trained to detect drugs, officials there said.
Current laws also hamper the war on drugs. In Poland and most of the other countries, drugs must be seized as soon as authorities know about them. That means that officials cannot follow the shipment until it is delivered, which would help the authorities piece together the network and catch higher-ups.
Under these laws, it is also not a crime to possess drugs for personal use, which is a common defense of traffickers.
For nearly two years, a Polish committee has been studying needed changes in the law, Mr. Lubik said, and legislation has been introduced, but he said he did not know when Parliament might act.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
The Train to the Plane Turns to Pie in the Sky

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
SOMETIMES, the truth will set you free. Other times, especially if you're a public official, it will get you in trouble.
George J. Marlin, the new head of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, learned that the hard way last week when he said out loud what everybody in politics already knew: The ambitious plan to build a 22-mile "train to the plane" was dead. Of course it was -- probably had been for years. But saying so miffed Gov. George E. Pataki, because Mr. Marlin, his man, had got out ahead on a controversial issue. And it infuriated Rudolph W. Giuliani, who, being Mayor, would like to see his city treated a little more like the major capital that it is. 
 But thanks to Mr. Marlin's gaffe of candor, New Yorkers now know that they and their visitors won't be getting a cheaper, faster, less congesting rail ride to Kennedy and La Guardia airports. Why not? "We don't have the resources for it," Mr. Marlin said.
The authority expected to raise $2.2 billion for the rail line; it would come from bonds paid for by a $3 tax on all departing passengers out of the New York airports and a related charge from airlines. But estimates of the cost of construction now range from $4 billion to $7 billion. If there were a strong will to push ahead, the Authority could have resorted to several proposed strategies for raising additional money, including Federal transportation subsidies, as well as taxes on taxi fares and higher parking fees to further discourage the use of cars.
BUT cost alone is rarely the entire reason something fails to happen in New York. The airport railway will not be built because not enough of the political establishment in New York and New Jersey wants to build it. The politics of the time mitigate against it -- a politics of shrinking government, reducing taxes and embracing policies that smile on the suburbs and their mostly Republican voters, not on Democratic cities. This is not an era for grandiose government projects.
"This is risky, ambitious and politically difficult," said a former high-ranking Democratic official of the authority, who insisted on anonymity. "You need a whole different philosophy. You need a Bob Moses or a Nelson Rockefeller."
Any large government agency like the authority always has options. It can spend here rather than there. It can subsidize one project, over-tax the next. It can be more generous to New Jersey than to New York, or the other way around. "There's an endless tit-for-tat played at the Port, like an endless Talmudic argument," said Anthony E. Shorris, until recently the authority's first deputy executive director.
Vincent Tese, New York's former director of economic development and an authority board member whose term is about to expire, says that abandoning the project is a clear choice. It is a choice not only against the train to the plane, but for protecting the commuting suburbanites from higher bridge and tunnel tolls and higher PATH train fares. "They're cannibalizing the assets that make you money," said Mr. Tese. "Rather than raising tolls, rather than getting a handle on the PATH line, they're doing away with capital projects."
THE PATH commuter line between New York and New Jersey is heavily subsidized. Riders pay only $1 each way for a trip that would cost them $3.50 each way if not for the Port Authority's subsidy. The tolls on the Authority-run bridges -- which include the George Washington Bridge and three connecting Staten Island to New Jersey -- are $4, charged only in one direction. Most of the bridges and tunnels inside New York City charge $3 in each direction.
Increasing the tolls and PATH fares for trips across the Hudson would not raise enough extra money to pay for the airport railway. But money is money. Abandoning the railway would allow diversion of the surcharges collected for it to other airport projects, like rebuilding the International Arrivals Building at Kennedy. That would relieve the authority's budget, and reduce the pressure to raise the tolls and fares. In other words, canceling the train to the plane benefits the suburban voters who elected the Republican Governors of New York and New Jersey.
The Port Authority may still raise tolls. But Mr. Tese and others suggest that the decision has already been made unofficially, in keeping with a pledge Mr. Pataki made to Staten Islanders during his campaign. Nor is there any plan to raise the fare on PATH, which loses $200 million a year.
"It's politically difficult to raise tolls," said Mr. Tese. "Raising tolls gets people in Staten Island and Rockland County mad at you. Nobody wants to raise tolls. I don't, either. But we got into this box because we're subsidizing PATH to the degree we're subsidizing PATH. The fact of the matter is, Giuliani is absolutely right. We should be spending on mass transit in both places, New York and New Jersey. Otherwise, we're going to cripple the city."
