HEADLINE: Market Place;
Laura Ashley is spurning offers and hopes to revive itself.

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
OVER the last few years, Sir Bernard Ashley has received a procession of callers asking if he wanted to sell his controlling stake in Laura Ashley Ltd., the retail and fashion company he founded with his wife.
Last week was the turn of Georgette Mosbacher, the New York socialite and beauty products entrepreneur, who saw in Laura Ashley what other potential bidders had seen: a strong but mismanaged brand name and a depressed stock. 
 Sir Bernard politely turned away Mrs. Mosbacher, whose husband, Robert A. Mosbacher, was the Commerce Secretary in the Bush Administration. And today, with Mrs. Mosbacher's approach having been reported by a London newspaper on Sunday and speculation mounting about a possible takeover, Sir Bernard put out word through his advisers that he had no interest in selling his 34 percent stake to anyone, especially not with the stock in the doldrums.
Sir Bernard, his advisers said, is committed to seeing through the latest in a series of attempts to revive Laura Ashley, which until stumbling several years ago had prospered by capturing in its clothes and furnishings an idealized version of English country life. So far, he has the backing of the other big shareholder, Jusco, a Japanese retailer that acquired a 15 percent stake in 1990.
People working with Mrs. Mosbacher and her financial adviser, Paine Webber, said she would not make an offer over the objections of Sir Bernard. But some analysts think other bids will be forthcoming if the company cannot turn itself around quickly. And some industry executives said the 68-year-old Sir Bernard, who retired as chairman in 1993 and now holds the title of life president, might be better off selling now, especially if he could command a substantial premium to today's closing share price of 81 pence, up 5 pence, on the London Stock Exchange. The shares traded as high as 2.40, or $3.83 at today's exchange rates, in 1986.
(In the United States, Laura Ashley stock can be bought in the form of American depository receipts, but they are rarely traded.)
So far, the attempts of the British company to clarify and update its image and to slash its costs have faltered. It parted ways with one chief executive, Jim Maxmin, a year ago and has been run by an interim team since then while seeking a permanent replacement. Matters were not helped when its retailing director, Stephen Cotter, resigned last month.
The company was founded in 1953 by Sir Bernard and Laura Ashley, but it became a big international retailer only in the 1980's. Building on the image of its trademark floral print dress, it expanded into wallpapers, bed linens and other home furnishings, and by the late 1980's had built up a large presence in the United States.
But as it grew, executives said, the company became increasingly fragmented, with the British and American operations each having its own headquarters and merchandising strategy. The company opened lots of small stores -- sometimes three in a single mall -- instead of concentrating on fewer, larger stores. In 1986, the company was badly shaken by the death of Laura Ashley after she fell down a flight of stairs after her 60th birthday party.
When the recession came early in this decade in both Britain and the United States, the company was hit hard by its high costs. Its woes were compounded by its failure to project a clear image of how its fashions were changing to adapt to the needs of women who were looking for something more than floral dresses.
In the last few months, the company has centralized its management in a worldwide headquarters in Maidenhead, England, scaling back its Boston office. And it began closing smaller stores in the United States. It pressed ahead with its effort to reshape its image, concentrating more on popular categories like wallpaper and supplementing its traditional fashions with more slacks, blouses and suits.
But the company's survival efforts have a long way to go, analysts and industry executives said. People who work with the company said it could take a new management team two or three years to whip Laura Ashley back into shape, and several years longer to reap the full benefits of a turnaround. And some analysts even said it was optimistic to believe the company could ever fully recover its luster.

HEADLINE: The Quake That Hurt Kobe Helps Its Criminals

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: KOBE, Japan, June 2

 BODY:
When an earthquake toppled entire neighborhoods here in January, the most striking and impressive thing for many Americans was the almost complete lack of looting.
These days, the looting has arrived -- on a huge scale, but in a very orderly and Japanese way. There are no hoodlums smashing windows, but criminal gangs known as yakuza are muscling their way into the demolition and construction business: knocking down damaged buildings, putting up new ones and hauling their profits to the banks. 
 The reconstruction of Kobe may cost well over $120 billion, making the earthquake the most expensive natural disaster in human history. Japanese police and journalists who follow the yakuza full time estimate that the gangs pocket at least 2 or 3 percent of all construction spending in Japan, and in this case its percentage could be higher.
The biggest yakuza gang, the Yamaguchi-gumi, has its national headquarters in Kobe, where it is already active in the construction industry, and it knows the turf well. Experts say that the yakuza could therefore earn billions of dollars from the rebuilding work.
Thus one of the biggest beneficiaries of the Kobe earthquake, which killed 5,500 people and put the country's busiest port out of commission, could end up being Yoshinori Watanabe, the godfather of the yakuza. Mr. Watanabe, 54, is said to be positioning his gang to rake in a hefty share of the construction spending.
Mr. Watanabe's own home and headquarters, a closely guarded fortress occupying a full city block in a posh residential neighborhood, apparently was unaffected by the earthquake. One of his office buildings in another part of Kobe was burned to the ground, but by and large he emerged unscathed -- but not particularly talkative.
"There is no one here who can talk to you," said a bodyguard whose shaved head gleamed in the afternoon sun as he shooed away a reporter who dropped by the headquarters. The bodyguard, who emerged from behind a steel door guarded with video cameras and floodlights, wore a blue suit with a white shirt, and he bowed -- not quite low enough to be polite -- as he explained that no one would be back that afternoon. Or that evening. Or the next day. Or, perhaps, ever.
Then, as the bodyguard asked, then advised, and finally ordered the visitor to leave, a Mercedes with tinted windows hurtled down the street, and another bodyguard opened a steel garage door to admit it. As the Mercedes entered, a private parking lot with about a dozen luxury cars could be seen inside the compound.
At the other end of Kobe, in the leaning homes and rubble of Nagata Ward, one of the poorest areas of the city, the director of a demolition company watched proudly as one of his shovel cars tore apart a collapsed house to prepare the site for a new home. The man said his company owned six shovel cars and many dump trucks, and he seemed to know a bit about the yakuza.
"There are lots around, because they control plenty of demolition and construction companies," he said, adding, "Of course, I'm not one of them."
His hand, though, suggested otherwise: a fingertip had been sliced off. That usually means that someone is a yakuza, because gangsters show their remorse when they have done something wrong by cutting off a finger at the last joint.
The man said that demolition work is not so profitable in itself, because the city of Kobe set limits on how much can be charged for a truckload of rubble. "But unless you do these jobs, you can't get the construction jobs coming up next, building roads or working as subcontractors on building projects," he explained.
That is what the police worry about most these days.
"They'll do demolition jobs until around the end of the year, and they'll make some money, but not a huge amount," said Akifumi Hyakumoto, a police superintendent in Kobe. "But when they start building highways, ports and buildings, so much more money will be involved. We think the yakuza will go after the big money then."
The police say they have their hands tied, however, because much of the yakuza construction work is legal. To be sure, the yakuza may cut corners -- like threatening rival companies so that they do not offer lower bids -- but the construction business is both lucrative for the yakuza and much less risky than smuggling guns or narcotics.
The Yamaguchi-gumi has about 23,000 members around Japan, controlling the sex trade, gambling, protection rackets and narcotics. They insist that they adhere to a high moral code of protecting the weak, and for that reason they tend to kill only rival gang members and do not normally attack ordinary citizens.
Japan traditionally tolerated the yakuza's existence as an organization, while imprisoning members who became too bold or violent. This may have been in part because the authorities figured that criminals will always be around, so one might as well leave them in organizations that control them.
In the last few years, however, the police have used new laws to mount an offensive against the yakuza. In addition, the gangs were hurt by the economic slowdown that has pinched Japan for several years.
In a concession to the financial difficulties of some of his aides, Mr. Watanabe last year reportedly reduced the honorarium that he expects from each of a select group of lieutenants to about $8,000 a month from $10,000. In all, Mr. Watanabe gets about $1 million a month in such gifts from his aides, the police say.
The police say that the earthquake came at a perfect time for Mr. Watanabe. He has been trying for years to reorient the Yamaguchi-gumi toward business areas that are not blatantly illegal, and the yakuza have a longtime presence in the construction and demolition industry.
In addition to running their own companies, the gangsters are said to disrupt construction sites of other companies unless they receive substantial "greetings fees." The gangs also sometimes supply day laborers for construction sites, in exchange for a fee.
As part of the Yamaguchi-Gumi's effort to improve its public image, Mr. Watanabe ordered his aides in January to hand out free food and water to those made homeless by the earthquake. The police believe that the yakuza bullied businesses into giving them the food free or at a discount.
"Right after the earthquake, the yakuza came here and set up a stand to serve noodles for free, and I was kind of impressed," said one woman who was made homeless in the quake. "But then afterward, they asked for a written testimonial saying how great they were, so they could take it to city hall and get more construction business."
Now, according to that woman and several of her neighbors, the yakuza are quietly going around and buying up land at fire sale prices. With many families now short of money, some property in Nagata Ward is selling for just one-third of its price before the earthquake.
For those who don't want to sell, yakuza loan sharks are offering cash -- but the security is the land that people own. Neighbors said that one mobster is offering loans from his spectacular three-floor colonial-style home, evidently well built, for it is surrounded by the rubble of more fragile homes that collapsed.
"It's too frightening to take money from them," said one middle-aged woman who lived nearby, as she spoke in a hushed voice on her doorstep.
"There was a doctor living over there who guaranteed his brother's loan from the yakuza," she said. "Then the interest mounted very quickly, and they couldn't pay back the debt. So the doctor lost his clinic."
The yakuza found other ways to get money as well. Seventeen members were arrested for applying for emergency relief funds for which they were ineligible. One gangster received funds eight times before being arrested.
"The earthquake ripped apart society," said one Japanese journalist. "It created cracks so deep that you can see things that are normally hidden, like the way the yakuza operate."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Long Bonds Gain, But Short-Term Issues Slip

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury issues rose yesterday, but without the furor of the previous two sessions as activity seemed to stall and the overall market finished mixed.
The 30-year bond rose 4/32 , to 11415/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 6.52 percent from 6.53 percent on Friday. Much of the day's strength was focused on the longer maturities. 
 James Hale, a fixed-income analyst with MMS International in San Francisco, said the market had something of a negative spin even though the yield on the long bond was lower. He said prices of short-term bills retreated substantially, as investors began to realize that their expectations for an interest rate cut were a bit premature.
The expectations, he said, were fueled by Friday's weak employment report. He also cited the comments last week of the Federal Reserve's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, that there might be some bumpy quarters along the way in achieving a sustainable growth rate of 2.5 percent.
Mr. Hale thought the implications of the price drop pointed toward a rate cut sometime later this year.
"Right now yields on everything from a 10-year note down to a three-month bill are below the 6 percent Federal funds target rate," Mr. Hale said. "And to justify any further gains in bond prices the market will have to get more pieces of news about the economy that would make it more certain about the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates."
Yesterday's auto sales figures did not provide the certainty of a weakening economy, Mr. Hale said. While Ford auto sales were a bit disappointing, truck sales for the company and the industry as a whole were respectable. "Which means concerns of weakness in the economy were maybe a little exaggerated," Mr. Hale said.
Earlier in the day the Commerce Department reported that April housing completions fell 7 percent, to a 1.33 million annual rate. Some traders thought the numbers were too old to provide much useful information for the market.
Despite the weakness in housing completions, prices of Treasury securities pulled back from the session's highs on some profit taking by investors who did not want to overplay their hands as the market continued to move forward.
Price gains were probably exaggerated by the lighter-than-average volume of trades, but many market participants say they believe the bond market is still in great shape. And while profit taking did chip away at the day's gains, traders and dealers said overseas investors were once again quick to buy up Treasuries.
Joel Marver, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said that "for once, we are seeing a two-sided market, with neither buyers or sellers having the upper hand in the short run."
At yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills, retail participation came up a bit short. Traders said they were not surprised since after two big days in the market last week after the purchasing management and payroll reports, prices were at a premium, and small investors were finding securities steep. "That may account for the weaker-than-normal retail participation in yesterday's bill auction," Mr. Hale said.
The average rate for a three-month maturity was 5.48 percent, sharply lower than the 5.64 percent posted the week before. For the six-month issue, the average rate was 5.35 percent, compared with 5.61 percent a week ago.
Municipal bond prices gained. The recent surge in Treasury bonds has helped make municipals more attractive, traders said. Since tax-exempt securities have lagged behind the huge gains seen in Government issues, people are starting to believe that municipals are cheap by comparison.
General obligation bonds rated triple-A and due in 20 years were yielding about 5.45 percent, or about 87 percent of comparable Treasury bonds. Investors usually consider municipals attractive enough to buy when they yield more than 82 percent of similar Government issues.

HEADLINE: I.B.M.'S BIG MOVE: THE CORPORATE CULTURE;
Suddenly, the Hostile Takeover Is a Benevolent Act

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
With its stunning $3.3 billion hostile bid on Monday for the Lotus Development Corporation, I.B.M. did not so much alter today's rapidly evolving corporate ethos as lay down an historic marker for the deep changes already at work in an economy obsessed with efficiency and cost-cutting.
The bluest of blue-chip companies emphasized that the gentlemanly days when corporate giants operated through the Old Boy network and extolled the values of corporate citizenship have been replaced by a sense that competing, and competing aggressively, is a corporate executive's highest calling, whatever it takes. 
 Perhaps just as important, the country at large seems to accept the idea. Two other pillars of the corporate establishment, AT&T and General Electric, have initiated hostile takeovers. In neither those nor many other recent cases has there been a public uproar or groan of disapproval from board rooms, as often happened during the last takeover boom in the 1980's. Congress is not demanding hearings or an accounting of how the bids will affect the economy, as it did when the raiders of the 1980's pounced on their prey.
"Today, C.E.O.'s say: 'G.E. did it. AT&T did it. There's no reason we can't talk about it openly,' " said Richard I. Beattie, the managing partner at the Simpson Thacher & Bartlett law firm and a sought-after adviser on takeovers. "They feel it's good for everybody and it's good strategy. That allows them to distinguish themselves, at least in their own minds, from what was happening in the 1980's, when it was financially driven."
Joseph Flom, a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and another top takeover lawyer, said: "Hostile takeovers are a normal part of thinking about corporate growth now. Blue-chip companies think this is appropriate behavior."
Indeed, the entire debate has been recast. The question is no longer "Why would you do something so disruptive?" but "What else can you do to reduce costs and provide better returns to shareholders?"
Bill Lewis, director of the McKinsey Global Institute in Washington and an expert on competition policy, characterized the shift in thinking on takeovers as in keeping with the acceptance in the corporate world of other strategies that were once disparaged: rounds of corporate layoffs, the slicing of divisions in the interests of efficiency and the movement of facilities overseas, where costs are lower.
"There is less reluctance, less ambivalence and, frankly, less moral compunction about doing these things," Mr. Lewis said. "You have to do it to survive today. You don't worry about it as you once might have."
But perhaps the most striking aspect of I.B.M.'s takeover bid, and the one that says the most about these times, is that it defies the accepted wisdom on the difficulties of trying to acquire a company whose primary value isn't in its machinery or real estate but rather, in that most mercurial of assets -- people.
Lotus is a leader in producing computer software, an industry that relies on a delicate balance between powerful intellects, unconventional thinking, intense pressure and corporate discipline. It was once believed that the jolt of a takeover could scare off the talent, leaving the acquirer with an empty shell rather than a productive business.
The I.B.M. bid could well prove a landmark in challenging that assumption -- or, as some are warning, bearing it out. Either way, the merger will be watched closely, because it gets at the heart of how companies will navigate the economy as technology turns the markets into an electronic marketplace.
"There's no precedent for this," said L. John Doerr, a partner at Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers, a venture-capital firm that was one of the first investors in Lotus. "I can't think of a successful hostile takeover in this industry. Making the acquisition is easy. It's execution, making the combination work, that is the hard part."
He added: "Is this intellectual property valuable without the people who created it? Yes, I think to some degree it is. But over all I think the conventional wisdom is probably right. The competition is so great that you want to keep your team for developing these products together."
Still, Mr. Doerr and several other experts said the temptation to acquire businesses that are so dependent on ideas and people, whether hostile or friendly, would only grow. The reason is that the talent to produce good computer programs, or computer games, or music or film is in short supply.
Even traditional hardware companies, like I.B.M., are increasingly focusing their efforts on creating software of all kinds and changing their corporate culture as a result.
"With the growth of the whole information-technology area, increasingly a broader sector of the market has those characteristics," said Jon B. Kutler, head of Quarterdeck Investment Partners, a West Coast investment banking firm.
In fact, one counterargument to the belief that I.B.M. risks driving the most talented people away from Lotus rests on the reality of the computer business. It is an industry in which employees leave their companies all the time to form their own firms because of the demand for interesting new ideas and products.
"There have already been at least a dozen spinoffs from Lotus as people have left to form their own businesses," Mr. Doerr said. "The entrepreneurial fever and the entrepreneurial opportunities are abundant still. That's not going to change."
The acceptance of hostile takeovers as a normal part of the corporate repertoire has been bolstered by several important developments.
A key factor is that the country's largest investors -- pension funds, insurance companies and mutual funds, which manage hundreds of billions of dollars on behalf of individuals -- have been pressed by regulators and the courts to put returns ahead of corporate allegiances.
Another element is that corporate directors, who long fought to protect management, can face punishing and embarrassing lawsuits if they fail to put shareholders' interests ahead of management's.
There is also a more active market these days in senior corporate managers; it is increasingly rare for a company to be headed by an executive who has spent his or her entire career there. That means executives are less committed to holding onto a company, and the losers from takeover bids can move to other jobs.
That, of course, does not mean any hostile takeover will succeed. Kirk Kerkorian, who owns 12 percent of Chrysler, suffered a huge flop after making a $20 billion hostile bid for the automaker. Chrysler dismissed the offer out of hand and Mr. Kerkorian eventually folded.
But takeovers are still running at their highest level since the peak year of 1988, and far more than technology companies are involved.
An economic downturn could slow the deals, but it appears unlikely that public opinion or Congress will.

NO SIGNS OF BRAKING IN SUBWAY CRASH
 The motorman of a subway train that crashed on the Williamsburg Bridge on Monday apparently ran a red light and was still applying forward power when his train plowed into the back of another train, state transit safety officials said. [Page A1.] 
 The job is, by regulation, solitary. The tasks are mostly simple, repetitive, even boring. But each day, a subway motorman must neutralize the monotony with the realization that a single lapse could cost other people their lives. [B3.]
 On Monday, the riders talked of terror and hurt, joked darkly and endured. Twenty-four hours later, along with the thousands of others who often beat daybreak to the subway stop, they went back to work, at factories, hospitals, brokerages, coffee shops and schools. [B3.]
 A new day on the subway sees a brave rider jumping onto the tracks to rescue a woman who had tried to kill herself. [B2.]
 
JUDGES CANNOT STOP SENTENCING BILL
 Ignoring a last-minute plea from an organization representing the state's Supreme Court justices, the Legislature passed a bill that heavily revises criminal sentencing laws. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Chairman Proposes Redefining Tax Code

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
With some prominent Democratic support, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, opened a political drive today that he hoped would ultimately lead to the replacement of the Federal income tax with a tax on what people spend.
"Our challenge," Mr. Archer said, beginning the first of three days of hearings into new systems of taxation, "is to do no less than pull the current income tax code out by its roots and throw it away so it can never grow back." 
 Few issues beside taxes draw such swarms of lobbyists, and today's hearing had a standing-room-only crowd, as representatives of the main law firms and trade associations in Washington lined the walls.
Mr. Archer called the session "one of the most important hearing days in the history of the Capitol."
In an interview, he acknowledged that sweeping changes in the tax system were unlikely in the next year or two. But he said his intention was to begin a national debate on the best way to change the system and to have that debate become part of next year's Presidential campaign.
The prevailing view in Washington is that chances are remote that any completely new system of taxation will be enacted as long as the White House and Congress are controlled by opposing parties. It would be something of a long shot even if Republicans won control of both branches of Government next year.
Always working against big changes in the tax system is the large gap between tax theory and political reality. In theory, most Americans want a new tax system that is simpler, fairer and more economically efficient. But it is impossible that such a system would allow everyone to pay less taxes and still raise the same amount of money as the current system.
Theory aside, the people and companies that would owe more taxes under a new system would surely oppose it. And so would the politicians who represented them.
Mr. Archer said that he had not decided exactly what kind of system he favored, but that in general the taxes should be based on what people spent, rather than what they earned.
Presumably, that means either a direct national sales tax or a value-added tax like those in Europe and Japan, in which the tax is applied at every stage of the production process and is eventually passed along to the purchaser of goods and services. Among tax specialists, these are called consumption taxes. Mr. Archer said that such a tax would have to be 16 percent of the goods and services bought in order to raise as much money as the current income tax does.
Another form of taxation -- a flat tax, under which the income of individuals and businesses is taxed at a single, fixed rate -- is championed by Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, and is supported by many of his fellow Republicans in Congress.
Mr. Archer said he opposed a flat tax because it "leaves the roots of the income tax in the ground, and it will grow again."
The income tax system, Mr. Archer said at the outset of today's hearing, "is too broken to be fixed."
Mr. Archer's position was bolstered today by support from Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, the ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee. Another prominent Democrat on the committee, Representative Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland, also offered general support.
In a speech written for delivery on Wednesday morning at the National Press Club, Mr. Gibbons declared that he had long been convinced that the income tax and the payroll taxes that finance Social Security and Medicare should be replaced with a value-added tax. The income tax, he maintains, is complicated and unfair and "has not kept pace with the economic realities of the modern global marketplace."
The Clinton Administration remains skeptical about the Archer and Gibbons ideas.
The Assistant Treasury Secretary for Tax Policy, Leslie B. Samuels, is scheduled to testify before the committee on Wednesday. In an interview today, he read this topic sentence from the testimony he had prepared: "We are not at this time convinced that the case for completely replacing the income tax with a consumption tax is compelling."
Mr. Samuels said that the suggested benefits of such a change had not been proved and that a consumption tax would likely provide a windfall to wealthy people at the expense of other taxpayers.
Mr. Archer said that among the advantages of a consumption tax were these:
*The cost to American businesses and individuals of complying with the tax law, which he estimated to be as high as $300 billion a year, would be substantially reduced.
*Saving and investment would be encouraged.
*Fewer people and businesses could escape taxation through the underground economy.
*The United States would become more competitive in the international economy.
Mr. Archer said he would tax all goods and services when they were bought, except homes, which he considered an investment, and possibly medical care. Imported goods would be taxed; exports would not.
The debate on the relative merits of income taxes and consumption taxes has arisen often over the years in political and academic circles.
The main argument against consumption taxes is that they tend to be regressive, meaning that they are more burdensome on the less affluent and more favorable to the better off. That is because poorer people must spend a greater proportion of their income on necessities.
Mr. Archer said he was looking for a way to give poor people a tax credit to lessen the burden on them. No form of taxation is as progressive as the income tax, Mr. Archer said. That did not worry him, he said, because the way that progressivity is measured now, no account is taken of the economic growth that will result from his proposal to the benefit of everyone.
Mr. Gibbons said his proposal would include what he called "burden adjusters" -- a rebate to the poor and an additional tax on the rich. "Any new tax system," he said, "should result in the same tax burden on each income group as the current tax system imposes."
Another tax system, supported by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, is a hybrid between income taxes and consumption taxes. Its main feature is that it would allow a tax deduction for all investments. The two Senators are scheduled to testify before the Ways and Means Committee on Thursday.

He did so at the request of the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who held a hearing on fundamentally changing the tax system. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Republicans' Welfare Plan Is Again Attacked by Clinton

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6

 BODY:
With Congress moving aggressively forward on proposals to overhaul welfare, President Clinton today again attacked Republican-sponsored measures, saying they would cut spending on the poor to finance tax breaks for the rich. But he stopped well short of threatening a veto.
In a speech to a National Governors' Association meeting in Baltimore, Mr. Clinton used some sharp words but broke virtually no new ground on an issue he helped bring to national prominence as Governor of Arkansas. Indeed, his cautious remarks were a reminder that the White House has been so far overtaken by the Republican-controlled Congress that Mr. Clinton may be forced for political reasons to sign a bill he does not like. 
 "Don't kid yourself," Mr. Clinton told a special governors' meeting on children's issues. "From the point of view of the Congress, welfare reform has stopped being welfare reform primarily. Primarily, welfare reform is a way to cut spending on the poor so we don't have to worry about it and we can balance the budget in seven years and give a big tax cut largely benefiting upper-income people. That's what this is about."
Senior Administration officials have left no doubt that Mr. Clinton would veto the House-passed version of welfare overhaul as punishing children and being too easy on work requirements, but the President is hoping a plan passed by the Senate Finance Committee could yet be a basis for compromise. Senate Democrats are preparing to introduce their own bill, and many have been hoping for stronger signs of guidance from the White House.
The Senate Finance Committee plan, drafted by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, would replace the Government's main welfare program with a block grant to states and freeze spending at $16.8 billion for each of the next five years. Many governors support such provisions, arguing they would give states new flexibility to deal with their own welfare problems as they see fit.
But among other objections, Mr. Clinton said such measures could hurt states with growing populations of poor people, including California and Florida, "and put every state at risk in the next recession or natural disaster."
Mr. Clinton also contended that the Senate bill would so curb financing for child care, job training and incentives for job placement as to leave all but six states unable to meet its goals for moving people off welfare and into work. He called for a Federal bonus for states that do well in helping move people into jobs.
"We already do less for young children than most of our major competitors, perhaps all our major competitors throughout the world," Mr. Clinton said. "And I just believe that we cannot allow welfare reform to be a race to the bottom."
Mr. Clinton also warned that turning welfare into a lump sum payment to states -- with no Federal requirement that all people meeting certain income and eligibility tests receive benefits -- would leave poor children vulnerable to competition for money made all the more scarce by proposed cuts in the growth of other Federal programs, like Medicare. He said that would sharpen conflicts between generations.
"You tell me how the poor children of your state are going to fare when they have to deal with the nursing home lobby," he said.
Senior White House aides have said they believe that with Republicans in the House and Senate still sharply divided over many details of their own budget proposals, especially the size of tax cuts, welfare may well "sneak up the middle" to become one of the first major bills to land on the President's desk. Having vowed in his 1992 campaign to "end welfare as we know it," they acknowledge that Mr. Clinton would be hard-pressed to veto an overhaul, even one that did not meet all his requirements.
It is a delicate balance, and even with his words today, Mr. Clinton increased public expectations of some bold progress on the issue.
"You could not design a program that would be too tough on work for me," he said. "You could not design a program that would give the states any more flexibility than I want to give them, as long as we recognize that we, our American village, have a responsibility to our children, and that in the end, our political and economic policies must reinforce the culture we're trying to create."
One problem is that neither the Republicans nor Mr. Clinton in his own plan last year is willing to spend anything like the amount that most experts believe would be necessary to pay for the costly job training, child care and other support programs that could assure large numbers of welfare recipients were moved off the rolls.
And Mr. Clinton, who did much to make the issue a political centerpiece and has now found himself overtaken by more stringent Republican ideas, has another problem. "You know," he said today, "sometimes I think my big problem is that I was for some of these things before they were popular."

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Scenic Route on the Calligraphy Superhighway

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman 

 BODY:
FOR two decades, Nicholas Yeager, who likes to think of himself as a sort of medieval hacker, has been deeply committed to an ancient information storage and retrieval system.
"It is called the book," said Mr. Yeager, a binder and calligrapher, in his workshop at 51 Warren Street in lower Manhattan, where, despite the competition of powerful new computer and video-based technologies, he is producing more books by hand and making more money than ever. 
 "It's as if the computer has freed the book to become more of an art object," the 40-year-old craftsman said. "It's like what happened with calligraphy after Johnny Gutenberg invented movable type. Instead of striving for just legibility, calligraphers became free to be more creative."
HE pointed to examples of the calligraphers' art hanging in the space where he works and lives, and showed off bindings he recently fashioned from leather, fabric and metal.
Until about 1890, he said, all books had hand-sewn bindings. Their production was labor-intensive and they were expensive. "Certainly when manuscripts were written by hand they were meant only for the the very rich," Mr. Yeager said. "You know how many animals it took to make the parchment pages of a single book in medieval times? About 200 goats and sheep."
Mr. Yeager, who has a master's degree from Columbia University, knows all sorts of things like this about books, and he is enthusiastically willing to share them.
"The first king who knew how to read was Charlemagne, and that was already in the eighth century," he said.
"You realize the book is a machine," he added, taking out a Slinky and laying it alongside an open book with pages moving back and forth like the undulating stair-walking toy. "It has moving parts, which makes it a machine that is used to preserve and communicate data."
Mr. Yeager described his own romance with the book:
"I was born in Houston. My mother was a librarian and my father was a professor of economics. I was a terrible student. It wasn't until I was in graduate school that I found out I was dyslexic. My last name started with Y and the nuns seated us alphabetically, so I always ended up in the back of the room, where I had trouble seeing the blackboard. But when I was 6 years old, I found a book on my mother's shelf about the history of the book and I read it. In the Boy Scouts, I learned to work with leather and I loved that. All you needed was a needle and thread and a high threshold of boredom."
During the 60's and into the 70's he raced motorcycles and then dropped out of college after one semester. He hitchhiked around the country, making and selling belts and wallets. Eventually, he ended up in Chicago, where he saw medieval manuscripts for the first time. "I was a long-haired hippie who doodled, and when I saw the illuminated pages I decided I wanted to learn how to make a beautiful book."
As the rest of the world seemed to be learning word processing, he apprenticed himself for six years to Bill Minter, a bookbinder. He studied calligraphy and illumination. He read the works of William Morris, the English designer and printer who had advocated making ordinary objects as beautiful as possible. He learned paper making. He went back to finish college in Texas, and after graduating at 32, he went to New York to attend the Library School at Columbia.
Afterward, he worked for a while in the rare books division at the New York Public Library and served as the director of the Center for Book Arts, but he left because of disagreements with the board. By October 1992, he found himself burdened by debts, working as a mover and sleeping on a foam-rubber mattress on a kitchen table in a walkup apartment in Williamsburg.
"All I could think of doing was to make the beautiful books I had always wanted to make," he said. Using bits of copper and leather, he made several notebooks. "Bonwit's ordered 144, each different, and sold them at prices that ranged from $25 to $80."
PHOTOGRAPHERS started coming to him for individualized albums to show off their work. It turned out there were still plenty of people willing to pay for rich bindings for albums or diaries in which to keep the treasured details of private lives. Rolodexes and electronic notebooks may be fine for business contacts, but there are other kinds of numbers, and there will probably always be a demand for little black books, and shouldn't they be the kind of beautifully wrought and artistically designed artifacts that William Morris envisioned?
From little notebooks, Mr. Yeager's business grew. Designers like Donna Karan and Calvin Klein came to him to bind catalogues. He stopped sleeping on the kitchen table. Companies like Sotheby's and brands like Smirnoff commissioned him. He moved to Manhattan. His gross doubled, tripled, quadrupled.
"Now I'm doing what I was always meant to do do," he said, "making books."

HEADLINE: Plea by Judges Fails to Block Sentencing Bill

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 6

 BODY:
Ignoring a last-minute plea from an organization representing the state's Supreme Court justices, the Legislature passed a bill today that heavily revises criminal sentencing laws.
In a letter and attached resolution delivered to the State Capitol late Monday night, the justices urged the Legislature to delay approval of the bill, saying the changes could increase prison overcrowding and sharply restrict judges' control over sentencing. 
 The plan calls for increasing minimum sentences for many violent criminals and ending parole for repeat violent offenders. It would also repeal some laws requiring prison sentences for repeat nonviolent criminals.
The civil and criminal court judges said the proposed changes had been negotiated without their knowledge or advice, and they called on the Legislature to study them more carefully and hold public hearings before acting.
In recent days, other criminal-justice experts have expressed similar concerns. The Legislature passed the bill by a wide margin as part of the budget package.
Gov. George E. Pataki, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, agreed to the new sentencing guidelines during budget negotiations, perhaps the most secretive process in Albany.
In an interview today, Justice Norman E. Joslin, president of the Association of the Justices of the Supreme Court, said the Legislature had taken a "backdoor approach" by making the changes part of the closed-door budget talks.
Critics of the bill, who have included Democratic legislators, public defenders and criminal justice experts, said it would worsen prison overcrowding, cause unrest among inmates and force the state to build new prisons. One analysis by Assembly staff members said the state's prison costs would increase by $10 billion to $20 billion over the next 20 years.
In the letter, Justice Joslin wrote: "A move toward rigid determinate sentencing needs careful review in the light of serious economic and correctional realities."
The debate over the sentencing bill came as Governor Pataki and legislative leaders were negotiating several last-minute details on the budget, including how to allocate $9.7 billion in state aid to school districts and how to finance a pension increase for retired state workers.
Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno were also trying to complete their plans to divide up $75 million allocated to each house in discretionary spending. Much of that will go for local pork-barrel projects.
The $150 million total is $125 million more than the leaders had said last week that they would dedicate to so-called member's items. Their aides said today that the larger figure would include new items and old items that had been promised in past budgets but never paid for. The leaders also said they would use much of the discretionary money to restore spending in state programs that Mr. Pataki had cut, such as for alcohol treatment and mental health programs.
Mr. Silver said he would use $5 million of the Assembly's money to help Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse, Yonkers and Mount Vernon close budget shortfalls.
But Mr. Pataki and the leaders refused to say how all of the $150 million would be spent, saying a full accounting would not be released until just hours before the final budget bill is passed, probably on Wednesday.
The Senate and Assembly also passed legislation today appropriating $4.2 billion for public works projects, the cost of which would be spread out over several years. The bill provides $115 million to build or repair athletic centers around the state, including a $24 million Olympic swimming center in Nassau County that would be used for the 1998 Goodwill Games.
Assemblyman Greg R. Becker, a Nassau County Republican, said the capital spending bill almost inspired him to sing "Old McDonald Had a Farm," as Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato had done earlier this year in deriding a Federal budget bill from the Senate floor. "I think we all know what that was all about," Mr. Becker said. "It was about a budget bill that was laden with pork."
The Legislature also passed a bill that would require convicted rapists and other sexual offenders to be tested for H.I.V. if their victims requested it. Proponents said the bill would provide vital information to rape victims. But critics said the test results would be useless to victims because the tests might be done months, and possibly years, after the sexual offense was committed.
The sentencing bill passed in the Democratic-controlled Assembly today after an hourlong debate in which supporters called it a deterrent against crime and critics blasted it as a drain on resources.
"This bill is going to put more prisoners in the system, hold them there longer, just as surely as I think anybody can do the math," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat. "It's going to mean more prison cells and more money to run the prisons than we have anticipated."
Under the plan the Legislature approved today, parole would be virtually eliminated and sentences lengthened for many violent felons. The Federal Government uses a similar system, but many Federal judges, like their counterparts in New York, have objected to it.
Justice Charles A. Kuffner Jr. of State Supreme Court, vice president of the justices association, said many state judges object to any plan that "impacts on our discretion." The new sentencing plan would do just that, Justice Kuffner said, by requiring judges to impose fixed sentences instead of ones with a maximum and minimum.
He also said judges worried about prison crowding. "It would be a concern if conditions are overcrowded," said Justice Kuffner, who handles a large number of criminal cases in Staten Island. "Then it approaches that amorphous concept of cruel and inhuman punishment."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Mixed For Treasury Securities In Slow Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with bonds at times moving in tandem with the dollar and other maturities slipping lower on raised doubts about how soon there might be a rate cut.
Trading was slower than normal, as some investors waited for Friday's producer price data for direction. The 30-year bond was up 6/32 , to a price of 11422/32 for a yield of 6.50 percent, down from 6.52 percent the previous day. Meanwhile, shorter- maturity bills were mixed, and intermediate-term notes were down a bit. 
 Some analysts cite concern by dealers and traders about the market's ability to remain at these high price levels without a quick Fed move to ease interest rates. They say people are looking for the second quarter to be soft, and yesterday investors did receive more signs of a cooling economy that could keep inflation subdued.
Wholesale trade inventories built up in April, suggesting slackening demand that could lead to cutbacks in production and economic growth. The Government said wholesale sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April, while inventories for the month surged 1.2 percent. Both numbers were stronger than expected. That report along with private forecasts that balancing the budget could further restrain the economy's growth rate, lifted bonds a bit.
Congressional plans to close the budget gap could increase unemployment by 50 percent and tip the economy into a prolonged contraction, the WEFA Group, an economic research firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said.
Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said that yesterday for "the first time in days" the firm began getting queries from retail investors who were interested in selling bond holdings. One reason, he said, is that bonds are now approaching the levels at which they were bought, so investors "want some bids."
"As a portfolio manager, I've started to sell my low-coupon intermediate maturities," Mr. Roden continued, adding that he was either staying with the cash or buying a limited number of higher-coupon Ginnie Maes. "I'm doing this because interest rates have had a big run," Mr. Roden said. "I am talking now as a pure trader."
Mr. Roden said he had instructed his firm's traders to play close to the vest, implying that he does not want to be overly exposed in the event of a sharp unexpected move in rates, in either direction, "but especially upwards."
The Johnson Redbook report on retail activity out in the afternoon showed a 1.8 percent gain for the first week of June over the first week in May. That was considerably higher than the four-tenths of 1 percent gain reported last week and was up 8 percent over the first week in June 1984.
That was a bit stronger than expected, Mr. Roden said, and some traders sold off, but the market managed to close out on a better tone.
Carroll J. Delaney, managing director of Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said his firm still believed that Treasury prices were far too expensive. Thus, he expects a serious correction over the near term. "The lack of upward price movement will gradually encourage liquidation," Mr. Delaney said. "The best things in life are free, or at least cheap, and Treasury securities are definitely not in that category at the moment."
Municipal bond prices, on the other hand, had a fair day, as money managers looking to reinvest money from seasonal bond calls and payments showed good demand for yesterday's new issues. As a result, municipalities were able to sell much of the day's $1.6 billion in new securities at yields below existing issues.
Municipals outperformed Treasury securities for a second day. The yield on a 10-year insured revenue bond fell four basis points, to 5.01 percent, according to the PSA/ Bloomberg Municipal Bond Yield Table, which measures yields on insured revenue bonds. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Largely Higher on Hopes Of Support From Group of Seven

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against most major currencies yesterday on optimism that leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations would pledge new support for a stronger dollar when they meet next week.
In April, finance ministers and central bankers from the seven countries -- the United States, Britain, Germany, Japan, France, Canada and Italy -- said they would continue efforts toward economic cooperation that would stabilize currency markets. 
 Such coordination was evident last week when the Federal Reserve and about a dozen other central banks bought huge amounts of dollars to stem the currency's fall. The dollar has declined 15 percent against the Japanese yen and 9 percent against the German mark since the beginning of the year.
The Group of Seven is to meet June 15-17 in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Analysts predicted that the dollar would remain steady until then, anticipating a reaffirmation of a strong dollar. "Many market players are watching their positions ahead of the G-7 meeting because they don't want to get caught too low," said David De Rosa, a foreign-exchange director at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. "The dollar will be trapped in a narrow range until then."
Yesterday, in late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 84.71 yen, down from 84.77 late Monday, and at 1.4110 marks, up from 1.4105.
Other late dollar rates, compared with late Monday, were: 1.1635 Swiss francs, up from 1.1595; 4.9495 French francs, up from 4.9385; 1,633 Italian lire, down from 1,635, and 1.3818 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3772. The British pound was quoted at $1.5930, down from $1.5968.
The American currency was also buoyed by continuing rumors that the Federal Reserve and other central banks would orchestrate another big dollar-buying campaign before the Group of Seven met.
"The market is reluctant to take a position that's too low for fear that the central banks will move in again," said Christopher Low, a senior economist at HSBC Markets.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
SunAmerica hopes to prosper with annuities for baby boomers.

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:
ONE of the leaders in the race to exploit the requirements and interests of baby boomers these days is SunAmerica Inc., a financial services concern that specializes in tax-deferred long-term savings and investments.
As a result of this specialization -- and its corresponding determination to stay away from mortality-based life insurance -- the company has enjoyed five years of strong profits. And analysts are projecting even further earnings increases this year and next. 
 "It is, by far, the strongest buy in financial services on my list," said Charlotte A. Chamberlain, a vice president of Wedbush Morgan Securities. "They run their company to build shareholder value by focusing in laser-sharp fashion on the pre-retirement market."
This segment of the population -- men and women who are now 45 to 64 -- is estimated to total about 61 million by the end of the 20th century. Their perceived need for annuities, both variable and fixed, is the engine that currently drives SunAmerica's growth.
"The demand for annuities is going to be strong for the next decade, while the entitlements for baby boomers are declining," said John Zief, a vice president of Goldman, Sachs. "I believe that savings are inversely related to entitlements."
Operating earnings for SunAmerica, before net realized investment returns, in the year ended Sept. 30, 1994, amounted to $3.91 a share. According to First Call, which tabulates these data, the average of analysts' earnings estimates of operating net is $4.52 a share in the 1995 fiscal year and $5.10 a share in the 1996 fiscal year.
"Over the next five years, we expect SunAmerica's earnings to grow at 15 percent per year," said Weston M. Hicks, senior research analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "Given this outlook, we put the fair value of SunAmerica at $58 to $60." The stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $51.75, up 75 cents, and near its 52-week high of $55.50.
The company, originally known as the Kaufman & Broad Building Company, was formed by Eli Broad and Donald Kaufman in 1957 to build low-priced houses in California, where it is still based. It spun off the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation to its stockholders in 1989 to concentrate exclusively on financial services and then became SunAmerica, derived from the name of its largest unit, the Sun Life Insurance Company of America.
SunAmerica held its first meeting for analysts last month at its headquarters in Century City. Management is reported to have emphasized a desire to maintain its investment spread between the yield on portfolio assets and credited interest rates at a high level. With an investment portfolio of $9.5 billion, this spread was just under 3 percent in the last fiscal year and moved above 3 percent early in the first half of the current fiscal year.
"In 1993 and 1994, a lot its inflows were in variable annuities," Mr. Hicks said. "In 1995, SunAmerica has been going for fixed annuities in a big way."
Ms. Zief added: "SunAmerica has proven this year that it can shift its focus between variable annuities and fixed annuities. It has been able to convince its distribution system that had been selling variable annuities to sell fixed annuities." The company's annuities are sold by broker-dealers, insurance agents and commercial banks.
Among the factors that could put a damper on the earnings growth rate for SunAmerica, as well as its competitors, is projected new Federal legislation affecting insurance companies. For instance, proposals have been made to tax the income of annuities before the funds are withdrawn -- the so-called inside buildup -- and to establish a flat tax system. But this type of proposal has also been introduced in the past and nothing has yet come of it.
"SunAmerica is the purest play on a megatrend in demographics in the United States," Ms. Chamberlain said. "It is really at the cutting edge."

HEADLINE: Weak Dollar Can't Close Japan Trade Gap

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell (Economic Scene, June 1) states that the dollar-yen crisis "is really the indirect consequence of Japan's economic stagnation" to explain why the United States trade deficit hasn't fallen in response to the weaker dollar. This conclusion is badly flawed. 
 The dollar-yen crisis Mr. Passell refers to is apparently the weakening of the dollar and rise of the yen, during the last two years, the period during which the Japanese economy has been flat. However, the dollar has been declining against the yen for 25 years, from 360 yen in 1970 to just under 240 in 1985, to the recent level of about 85. The decline in recent years has been only a small fraction of the total in this long period. And before the last two years, Japan's economy grew much faster than the United States economy.
The economist Mr. Passell cites predicts that a modest additional fall in the dollar against the yen will sharply cut our trade deficit with Japan. But he has wrongly made that prediction for years, and the deficit has gone up as the dollar declined.
Not one reference was made in the column to Japan's closed markets and export promotion, which explain the persistence of its trade surplus, and is the only explanation consistent with historical trends.
Fiscal stimulus in Japan will by itself reduce its $130 billion trade surplus by $10 billion at most. Japan should stimulate its economy, but that is no substitute for market opening.
 
DONALD P. HILTY
Senior Fellow
Economic Strategy Institute
Washington, June 2, 1995

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The Big Three's lobbying arm is serious about its business and, apparently, about its gimmickry.

BYLINE: By James Bennet 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THESE days, the business of the United States auto industry is politics. And as the current trade fight with Japan attests, the industry has grown far more adept at that business since the 1960's, when General Motors clumsily hired private detectives in hopes of discrediting Ralph Nader.
The industry's newfound success is owed partly to a reinvigorated Washington lobbying arm, the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, which for about 18 months has been conducting a carefully targeted advertising and public relations campaign to alert policy- and opinion-makers to the industry's economic clout. 
 The association's latest attention-grabbing gimmick is a stack of 51 glossy, somewhat silly, cards being delivered by hand to every member of Congress and also sent to media organizations. The size of a postcard, each bears the name of a state and photographs of some treasure or emblem of that state along with an auto part that is manufactured there for the Big Three.
"California Lifeguards," says one card, with four pictures of sun-kissed bay watchers and one picture of a safety belt stretched across a seat. "The 'Golden State' makes occupant restraints for America's car companies," the opposite side of the cards reads in part.
Many of the cards are whimsical: "It's always springtime in Nebraska," says one, over a doctored photo of springs growing in a cornfield. Some confer a rather dubious-sounding distinction. A mock license plate from Connecticut reads: "Connecticut. Tilt-shaft state."
There are 51 cards because, in a bow to Michigan's automotive primacy, that state gets two.
"The postcards are designed to show that what happens to American car companies affects literally every state in the union," said Andrew H. Card Jr., president of the association.
The association started its image-building campaign after it surveyed Washington "decision makers" in 1993 and found a startlingly low opinion of the industry's importance. "That survey found we were rated just ahead of the local construction company," said Mr. Card, who was a secretary of transportation in the Bush Administration.
Meanwhile, facing tightening regulations on clean air, safety, and fuel economy -- not to mention the trade dispute -- executives at the Big Three say the Government has more influence on their business than ever. "The environment we operate in is as important as our overall competitiveness," Robert J. Eaton, chairman and chief executive of the Chrysler Corporation, said last fall, referring to the regulatory environment.
The association has so far spent about $2.5 million on the campaign, and said its recent surveys showed its message was getting across. The total includes $125,000 spent for about 7,000 sets of cards, Mr. Card said. Eisner & Associates, an agency in Baltimore, helped design the cards, which carry the lobby's tag line: "What America drives, drives America."
The lobby's hope is that the cards will catch the attention of people who are flooded with mail every day. To that end, last year the association mailed out thousands of apple pies to the same list, with instructions to cut the pies into 20 equal pieces and eat 19 of them. Those 19 pieces, the association claimed, represented the proportion of American auto jobs generated by the Big Three.
Mr. Card said that George Mitchell, then the Senate's majority leader, wrote to inquire what he should do with the 20th piece. Mr. Card -- who said he never gave Mr. Mitchell an answer -- is betting the cards will generate similar interest. Nine parts suppliers, he said, have requested customized versions of certain state cards to bombard their local opinion leaders with.
It may be hard to imagine that cards declaring "Kansas: Get along lil' drive shafts," or "In Nevada, everything's coming up hoses" or "Virginia is for steering" will ever change hands like Mickey Mantle's baseball cards. But Mr. Card can dream.
"We're already seeing a secondary market of trading springing up," he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Goodbye to Green Monster As a Hello to Progress?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
If the picture Gene Budig sees for the near future develops as he sees it, his league soon will blossom with new ball parks. Budig's picture encompasses new parks in Boston, Detroit, Milwaukee, Minneapolis, Seattle and Anaheim.
"I am optimistic that there will be commitments for new facilities in all six locations in the next 18 months," Budig, the American league president, said before leaving yesterday for the owners' quarterly meetings in Minneapolis. "I have talked with many community leaders. I have talked with representatives of the clubs. I have talked with representatives of the media. No one debates the importance of new facilities for the long-term well-being of these clubs. I believe the case is persuasive." 
 Enviously eyeing the success of Camden Yards in Baltimore, Jacobs Field in Cleveland and The Ballpark in Arlington in Texas, other clubs want to attain the same economic benefits enjoyed by the teams that play in those facilities. Budig has campaigned on behalf of the teams in those six cities to help sell the idea to officials and residents.
"A new ball park represents an investment in the future," he said in a telephone interview. "It becomes a matter of good business practice. A state-of-the-art facility reflects a community's confidence in its potential. Cities want to be regarded as big league or first-class. It is a matter of pride. Major league baseball remains a significant factor in the quality-of-life equation. No community today wants to lose a franchise. It would send the wrong message to business and industry that might have an interest in it."
Budig did not include the Yankees in his forecast because George Steinbrenner has not asked him to campaign with New York officials to help get the kind of park the Yankee owner wants.
"You'd have to ask them," Budig said when asked what he thought about the Yankees' chances of getting a new place. "I've been working with these clubs. They have invited participants."
The National League also has some teams eager to get new baseball-only parks. Cincinnati, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and San Francisco are in that group. The first three cities opened similar multi-purpose stadiums in the early 1970's. That type of stadium was considered state of the art at that time.
"Things are changing," Budig said. "Fans are demanding new and improved facilities. They want fan-friendly facilities. Camden Yards changed things forever. That facility set a new standard."
One major obstacle to the construction of new parks is taxpayer opposition to the use of tax funds to pay for them.
"Thoughtful leaders favor partnerships involving public and private funding commitments," Budig said. "They favor long-term agreements. A new ball park means security for many working men and women. It provides needed jobs and has a direct impact on the local economy. Major league baseball means millions of dollars for its member communities. Figures vary, but most clubs place economic impact at well over $200 million a year. This, in fact, is a conservative number."
New stadiums will become even more important as clubs struggle to raise their revenues, which have been seriously eroded by the labor dispute. When the owners began discussing revenue sharing nearly two years ago, the Indians would have been thought to belong in the low-revenue group, but their new park has elevated them into the high-revenue group.
The owners will meet in Minneapolis today and tomorrow. The executive council met last night. The owners are not expected to reach any major decisions, but are expected to discuss the comatose labor negotiations and revenue sharing.
The owners emerged from their last meeting on May 10 saying a new collective bargaining agreement was the best way to repair the strike damage. But four weeks later they still don't have a new chief labor lawyer or apparently a strategy to pursue.
Lawyers from both sides have met, most recently last Friday, to discuss possible ways to settle the National Labor Relations Board's unfair-labor-practice charges against the owners, but they are not close to a settlement. If no settlement is reached or sufficient progress made toward one, a trial before an administrative law judge will begin June 19.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Tracing the Routes Of the Irish in America

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
Happy groups of immigrants to America are all alike; every unhappy group is unhappy in its own way. "Out of Ireland," Paul Wagner's evocative two-hour history of almost two centuries of Irish immigration, captures the lows and highs of an emigration that depleted the population of the home country as it enriched the United States.
Moving back and forth between Ireland and America, the program finds its way into the lives of a few of the millions of Irish Roman Catholics who made the journey, most of them in the years after the terrible potato famine of the 1840's. The destruction of their subsistence crop seemed the final blow after centuries of political repression and economic exploitation by Protestant landowners under the protection of the British. An Irish historian sings: "She's the most distressful country/that ever yet was seen./For they're hangin' men and women/For the wearin' of the green." From 1845 to 1860, two million people emigrated (or, as many of them felt, went into exile) and their departure, along with the deaths from hunger and disease, reduced Ireland's population by a third. 
 The immigrants focused on here seem to have been selected mainly for their talent as letter writers, which works just fine. The Irish nation cannot be entirely composed of natural stylists, but you wouldn't know it from these resonant passages, read in zesty brogues by Liam Neeson, Brenda Fricker, Aidan Quinn and Gabriel Byrne, and accompanied by energetically fiddled home-grown melodies and rich old photographs from Ireland and America. Now and then Mick Moloney, a folklorist, delivers a song, including a rouser about everybody in America being named Kelly.
The language is so fresh that it makes the routine narration, spoken by Kelly McGillis as if she were competing in an enunciation contest, seem even flatter than it is. Unfortunately, Mr. Wagner does not write as well as he directs, despite his claim to an Irish grandmother.
As is pointed out more than once tonight, many of the immigrants found themselves paving the roads they had dreamed were made of gold. Irishmen became cheap labor for the toughest jobs of an expanding nation: building bridges, railroads and skyscrapers; digging canals, and cutting lumber. In a time of capitalism unconstrained, Ireland's shanties were replaced by America's slums and the newcomers had to endure the sort of discrimination that earlier immigrants have a way of extending to the latest batch of strangers.
The invigorating influence of the Irish-Americans on the Roman Catholic church, the emerging labor unions, the Democratic Party and big-city politics are duly noted. Particular attention is paid to Richard O'Gorman, who started out as a radical nationalist in Dublin and was Americanized as a Tammany big shot at the time of the Tweed ring. A sharp observer as well as an adroit player in the New York City political game, he wrote home that "our countrymen have their share" in what he called "the headquarters of political corruption." He died a judge.
Needless to say, the Irish, who made up the first of the great 19th-century migrations of huddled masses from Europe to America, have, like most of the others, prospered. This spirited appreciation ends with a telling statistic: fewer than 10 percent of these immigrants, much though they cherished memories of home, returned to Ireland. Instead they sent hundreds of millions of dollars back, to bring others to come and make it in America.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THE Napa Valley has been called everything from America's last agricultural frontier to an enological Disneyland. And in truth, it is a remarkable place.
An hour north of San Francisco, but really just a few miles beyond the San Francisco Bay Area's creeping urban spread, it presents itself as a bucolic paradise. Sheltered by two striking mountain ranges, the Napa Valley, with its picture-book villages, meticulously groomed vineyards and handsome wineries, seems like some pastoral Shangri-La where every prospect pleases and Martha Stewart heads the zoning board. 
 Yet, there is something schizophrenic about the valley. A commitment to sun, soil and the simple life is a given, but there is also a need for seared tuna and designer mineral water. When it comes to restaurants, St. Helena is as trendy as TriBeCa and just as expensive. Sturdy work clothes are never out of fashion, but they don't sell them at the Brooks Brothers outlet store on Route 29.
The valley, as its denizens call it, is a study in contradiction. The down-home Norman Rockwell aura is misleading. Good land sells for $50,000 an acre, and a disturbing amount of it is owned by multinational corporations and other foreign investors. For many others, the promise of a good life has turned sour or, at least, less sweet. Competition and a sluggish wine market have forced them to work harder and harder just to stay solvent.
In 1942, a novelist, Alice Tisdale Hobart, who is now mostly forgotten, wrote a best seller about the Napa Valley. Called "The Cup and the Sword," it was based on the life of Georges de Latour, the Frenchman who founded Beaulieu Vineyards.
Miss Hobart was not the first to write about the Napa Valley, but she may have been the first to recognize the dramatic potential in that hermetically sealed little world. Following her, writers have been as thick on the land as loan officers from the local banks -- and just about as welcome. Rare is the year that passes without another Napa Valley picture or guide book, history book or third-rate novel.
The latest to try her hand, with "Dreamers of the Valley of Plenty" (Scribner, $25), is Cheryll Aimee Barron, a former business writer and alumna of The Economist who was born in India and lived in England before moving to California about 15 years ago.
Ms. Barron is a sensitive writer of considerable erudition, with a fine ear for dialogue and nuance. She fashions vivid portraits of well-known valley people in search of some common thread or unifying theme. It doesn't happen, and she concludes that "the valley's hybrid society is unlikely ever to stay still for long enough to allow a cohesive and unmistakable local culture to form."
She is dead wrong.
America is a hybrid society; we long ago discovered that hardly anything melts in the melting pot. We have learned to live with that fact, and even to exult in it. Indeed, the Napa Valley is more heterogeneous than almost any community other than a Benedictine monastery. Certainly more so than New York or San Francisco or even blue-collar Vallejo.
People come and go in the Napa Valley, but compared with the average American suburb where faceless corporate types live for a few years and then move on to the next suburb, the Napa Valley is quite stable.
Ms. Barron's subjects include Joe Heitz, creator of the famous Martha's Vineyard cabernet; the Louis Martini family; Jack and Jamie Davies at Schramsberg Vineyards; Robin Lail, a descendant of the founder of Inglenook Vineyards; the late Andre Tchelistcheff, the Russian-born wine maker long associated with Beaulieu Vineyards, and an assortment of later foreign arrivals including Bernard Portet of Clos du Val, Francis and Francoise DeWavrin-Woltner, owners of Chateau Woltner, Christian Moueix of Dominus and Donald Hess of the Hess Collection.
For all her vividly expressed love for California, Ms. Barron is clearly more at ease with the Europeans. Her attempts to draw out the down-to-earth Mr. Heitz on the age of his house verge on the laughable, and she admits to having got nowhere at all with Robert Mondavi.
Mr. Mondavi does tend to talk in sound bytes, but some patience with him would have been infinitely more rewarding than the time spent with, say, the DeWavrin-Woltners, who, like most of the Europeans Ms. Barron interviewed, are decidedly marginal to life in the Napa Valley. Most of them, with the exception of Christian Moueix, don't even make particularly good wine.
Ms. Barron is at her best with the Martinis, a close-knit family that has never sought center stage and has clung to older ways and low prices, only to become lost in all the welter of glitz and marketing hype that currently is driving the wine industry.
She's good, too, on the Mexicans in the Napa Valley, the silent workers who form a rich subculture largely unknown to the wine makers who employ them. And she is good, too, on the fatuous San Franciscans, the "haute weekend crowd" that drifts up to the valley, trailing their decorators behind them.
There is very much of a local culture in the valley. It is made up of old-timers and newcomers who are genuine wine people: men and women who have risked all to be part of the wine business, who have dragged hoses in damp cellars, poured wine at a thousand tastings and helped one another when the need was there.
The culture is there but Ms. Barron seems to have missed it. On the other hand she does bring us Urania Ristow, an haute weekender who, we are told, "is built like a dainty, finely proportioned flower -- a freesia, say," and who displays "a marvel of a nose that is straight, but with the suggestion of being fractionally retrousse."
Now isn't that more fun to read than all that dull stuff about wine?

TASTINGS
Marimar Torres Chardonnay, Don Miguel Vineyard (Sonoma-Green Valley), 1992. About $20.
 
A long name for a bottle of wine? Yes, but that's the way it is in California these days. It's like those Russian dolls within dolls. Marimar Torres, whose family makes wine in Spain and Chile, planted her grapes near Forestville, on the Western fringe of Sonoma County, in a wine-making area called Russian River. Actually she's in a section of Russian River specifically known as Green Valley. And this wine comes from a special 30-acre vineyard within Green Valley named Don Miguel, after her late father. In the end there is something to be said for specificity. This is a first-rate chardonnay: rich, intensely flavored, long on the finish, obviously the beneficiary of the 10 months it spent in French oak. Oh, yes, there is 3 percent parellada, a Catalan grape, in the blend. Proud people, the Catalans.
