HEADLINE: Only a Paper Boon;
Consumers Aren't Spending Their Profits From Surging Stocks

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
With blue-chip stocks up 16 percent since January, many Americans are a lot richer today than they were on New Year's Day. This year's bull market, the strongest surge since late 1990, has been powered by lower interest rates and rising corporate profits. It has already added more than twice as much to the wealth of America's households as all the money families painstakingly salted away in savings last year.
So now that signs of an economic slowdown are multiplying, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is acknowledging the possibility of a brief downturn this summer, and anxiety is starting to well up, shouldn't all that freshly minted wealth help make the economy safe from recession?
Maybe, but don't count on it. When it comes to the fortune of someone like William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, or the outlook for specific companies, the stock market is a powerful force. But when it comes to determining the course of the overall economy, it is still just a bit player. 
 "People might feel better if the market's up," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, a Wall Street investment house, "but are they really checking their balance sheets?"
By one estimate, a rise in the stock market of the current magnitude -- if it is sustained for a year or so -- could mean a boost to spending of about $22 billion. That is worthwhile, but not enough to make a big difference in an economy that is expected to produce almost $7 trillion in goods and services this year.
Rising prices for assets like stocks, bonds and real estate do deliver a very real impact -- called the wealth effect by economists -- that shows up in a variety of ways. Higher stock prices increase the financial wealth of shareholders, who might be able to afford more, whether a Cadillac instead of a Chevrolet or an Ivy League education for the children versus State U. The most common reaction to a fatter portfolio is to save less from current income, since the market helps build extra savings without sacrifice.
Higher stock prices also enhance the purchasing power of companies. Corporations whose stock is rising face a lower cost of capital and thus have extra resources to invest in new technology or expansion. Wall Street firms, where salaries and bonuses are closely tied to the issuing of new stocks and bonds, turn more open-handed.
Indeed, if the wealth effect is visible anywhere, it is in and around the nation's major financial centers, like New York, Boston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago. And those are the same places where there are also heavy concentrations of affluent families with lots of investments in the market.
New York is typical. While the underlying economy in the metropolitan area remains tepid, there are plenty of signs of extra spending money among the upper crust in the crowded aisles at Barneys, hefty sales of luxury cars and expensive four-wheel-drive vehicles at local dealers, and the tighter summer rental market in some trendy beach communities.
"There are a lot of people looking at the higher end, over $1 million," said Patricia Patrillo, a broker at Sotheby's International Realty in Southampton, L.I. "The buyers are ready, willing and able."
And Karen Houghton, an interior designer in Nyack, N.Y., a suburb of New York City, said she saw evidence of the wealth effect in her own business. "Two of my clients who work for I.B.M. have been talking about putting extensions on their homes for five years," she said. "Now that I.B.M.'s stock is recovering, they're moving forward."
Trouble is, relative to the national economy, the impact from these kinds of case-by-case decisions is not enough to be decisive. Compared with other forces at work in the economy, from consumer confidence to changes in personal income to swings in business inventories, the impact of fatter stock portfolios is relatively modest.
How much does all this add up to? Laurence H. Meyer, president of a forecasting firm in St. Louis that bears his name, recently sent a note to clients predicting that the higher market -- provided it does not give back too much of the recent gains -- should inject roughly $22 billion in extra spending power into the economy this year. But while expressing confidence that the economy will avoid a recession, he nonetheless scaled back his estimates of future consumer outlays because of the weak job market.
"The economy would be weaker if not for the stock market," Mr. Meyer said. "But the bigger effect comes from lower interest rates," which are just beginning to work their way through the pipeline.
Economists at the Federal Reserve have developed a similar guideline, estimating that about 4 cents of every dollar in sustainable extra wealth eventually shows up in spending by consumers and business.
Many economists, starting in the 1950's with Milton Friedman, the winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, once thought the wealth effect carried a bigger wallop. But the stock market crash of 1987 changed all that. After a trillion dollars of wealth evaporated overnight, a lot of economists -- particularly those close to the epicenter on Wall Street -- predicted a sharp slowdown in consumer spending, if not an outright recession.
Instead, in part because the Federal Reserve moved quickly to counter the effects of the stock market crash by lowering interest rates, spending kept right on growing, and 1988 turned out to be a banner year in the long 1980's economic expansion.
In response to that event, many forecasters threw their wealth equations out the window or significantly scaled back their estimates of the impact on consumer spending from changes in the stock market.
"Traditionally, we had wealth variables in our models," said David Kelly, an economist at Lehman Brothers in Boston. "But the wealth effect was put to a very significant test in 1987 and failed miserably."
Why doesn't all that new-found wealth prompt more spending? Economists now point to three big reasons.
First, while a majority of Americans may hold stock through their pensions and other indirect means, four out of five households do not own any stock directly. For all the bullishness among investors, consumer confidence readings have been falling this year because most Americans are more affected by their own expectations about jobs and incomes than by reports of riches being reaped on Wall Street.
Second, many households that do own stock do not change their behavior much in response to changes in the value of their portfolios, particularly because they are aware that what goes up can also go down. Most stock is owned by the relatively affluent -- two-thirds of stock and mutual fund shares are owned by the top one-fifth of households -- who already tend to be high savers and do not alter their spending patterns simply because their accountants tell them they are worth more.
Finally, more and more stock is now held in various restricted ways, through individual retirement accounts, 401(k) plans and the like. The added wealth in those accounts cannot usually be tapped until retirement, unless the owner is prepared to pay a stiff penalty for the privilege.
In contrast to the relatively modest effect from stock market changes, rises and falls in real estate values appear to have a stronger impact. In the 1980's, real estate values and stock prices rose in tandem; that is much less true today.
"The effect of changes in equity prices is less than half the effect of a change in house prices," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at Data Resources/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. "If your house appreciates, you know it and you can borrow against it. If your debt goes up, you know it and you tighten your belt."
For all the current anxiety about the economy, however, there are other reasons than the buoyant stock market to look to for reassurance. After all, unemployment is still relatively low, income growth remains decent if unexciting, and long-term interest rates have fallen back to levels not seen in more than a year.
"Other things may save us," said Mr. Kelly of Lehman Brothers, "but I'm not sure it will be the wealth effect. Other forces are more important in reviving consumer spending than the gains you see in the stock market."

HEADLINE: Private Company Narrows Its Focus to 5 Hartford Schools

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 8

 BODY:
A private education company that gained national attention after signing a contract last year to manage this city's entire troubled public school system has narrowed its plans and now expects to concentrate on just 5 of the system's 32 schools this fall.
Faced with fierce opposition from teachers and parents, Education Alternatives Inc., has agreed with the Board of Education to take a go-slow approach. City officials said a company spending plan issued last month that called for hundreds of staff reductions and the possibility of larger class sizes sparked a revolt by parents and teachers that could not be contained. 
 "The budget was not acceptable and not do-able," said G. Stewart Murchee, a spokesman for Hartford's Mayor, Michael P. Peters, who supports the city's experiment.
Since Education Alternatives announced that it would take control of this large urban district, Hartford has been at the center of a national debate about whether private profit-making businesses can succeed where traditional public methods have failed. The new scaled down plan, education experts said today, coming on the heels of similar retrenchment earlier this year by another major education company, the Edison Project, underlines just how problematic these private ventures are, and how daunting the educational and political challenges are in big cities.
"They're finding out now what life is like in Hartford," said Henry M. Levin, a professor of education and economics at Stanford University.
Education Alternatives has faced other recent blows, including criticism this spring from the Mayor of Baltimore, Kurt L. Schmoke, who complained that school test scores were not improving rapidly enough in the company's schools there. The company's stock, traded publicly on the Nasdaq market, has also languished.
Education industry analysts who follow Education Alternatives said, however, that as with any emerging industry, a bumpy ride is inevitable.
"The biggest mistake this company makes is trying to do too much," said Michael T. Moe, an analyst at Lehman Brothers. "But whether it's a more limited role in Hartford or not, if they can prove what they do, that is the important point."
Company officials said the modification, which still requires school board approval, was not a defeat, but simply a strategic move, and that the city's schools would still all be fully brought under Education Alternatives operation within the five-year contract. Five volunteer schools selected by the board the first year, for example, might be followed by a similar number or more in the 1996-1997 school year.
The company's chairman and chief executive officer, John T. Golle, said that opposition from the teachers' union and the "natural human reluctance to change" were the driving forces behind the move.
"People do not like to change regardless of what it is you're asking to do," Mr. Golle said in a telephone interview from one of the company's nine schools in Baltimore. "The majority of the reasons for an alternative implementation plan has to deal around the simple theory that seeing is believing."
Opponents of the company and its contract here said they believed that the company's whole operating premise, as well as its plans, could now be in question. Education Alternative's contract, for example, which was approved on a 6-to-3 vote by the Board of Education last year, will almost certainly need to be amended to permit a modified plan.
And if the negotiations drag on, the composition and attitude of the board could change. Of the six-member majority who favored the contract, four -- including the chairwoman, Thelma Dickerson -- are up for re-election this fall, according to Mr. Murchee, the mayoral aide.
The Hartford school system, which is expected to have about 24,000 students this fall, has also been shrinking, losing almost 2,000 students over the last two years. Education Alternatives has based some of its proposed budget numbers about staff reductions on those declining enrollments, but also on the expected savings from more efficient technology, like automated floor cleaning machines that can replace janitors using old-fashioned floor buffers.
The change also sets up the possibility of a two-tiered system of education in Hartford and a new arena in the battle that has raged here since talks with the company began last year. The five schools would get the full Education Alternatives package, called the "Tesseract" system, and would be operated as models intended to win over skeptics. But the 27 other schools would still be under the overall financial management of the company under the contract, Mr. Golle said. Education Alternatives would also still have an obligation to make all the schools clean and safe.
That could mean, Mr. Golle said, two different sets of standards for thousands of day-to-day decisions about management, staffing and maintenance. "Our standards as opposed to theirs," he said.
Private education companies around the country have stumbled in recent months. Mayor Schmoke of Baltimore said in calling for a renegotiation of his city's contract that a clause should be inserted requiring that if Education Alternatives was not able to meet certain test score standards, remedial help for students would have to come from the company's own profits.
"He was not satisfied by EAI's own numbers, that they were accomplishing what they in fact led him to believe that they could accomplish in terms of student performance," said the Mayor's press secretary, Clinton R. Coleman, in an interview today.
The Edison Project, founded by the media entrepreneur Christopher Whittle, has also substantially rescaled at least its pace. The company had originally planned to operate private schools around the country and promised that the first 100 would open by the fall of 1996. The emphasis subsequently shifted to managing public schools under contract, and officials said this spring that the company is planning to begin managing only perhaps three or four schools fall.
Believers in the new industry, including Mr. Moe at Lehman Brothers, said that 200 years of momentum and tradition are hard to overcome, but that bringing greater efficiency to local schools is an inevitability that will ultimately benefit students.
Professor Levin at Stanford said he believed it was simply too early to tell because none of the companies has any track record.
"They're learning reality, basically," he said. "But they're learning it at taxpayer expense."
Mr. Golle, Education Alternative's chairman, said the learning would result in a better product.
"Are we going to get to the same place at the same point in time? The answer is yes," he said. "Are we going to get there a different way? Yes, and quite frankly I think a better way."

HEADLINE: Budget Conferees Gather, But Not Really to Confer

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The Senate-House conference committee on the Federal budget met for the first time today, and this much was settled:
*Democrats will have no role whatsoever in working out the differences between the House and Senate budget resolutions passed last month. 
 *Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, does not know how to pronounce the name of his counterpart in the House, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio.
*The senators on the conference committee do not know who many of the House members are.
None of that is surprising. Today's session was not meant for anything but speechmaking. The real work of the conference will take place in private beginning next week.
So what was not settled was any of the difference between the two budget measures, each of which establishes a framework for Government spending and taxes that is supposed to lead to a balanced budget by 2002.
Senator Domenici, who is the chairman of the conference committee because it is the Senate's turn to sit in the chair, said that the committee staffs would work over the weekend to try to pare differences and that the conferees would reconvene when it was convenient for both sides next week.
The overriding issue before the conference is taxes.
The House approved a tax cut of $350 billion over the next seven years, including a $500-a-child tax credit, which would go into effect next year, for all but the very richest and very poorest families.
The Senate's tax cut, estimated at $170 billion, would be contingent on annual findings by the Congressional Budget Office that the promise of a balanced budget had led to lower interest rates and improvements in the nation's economy. Only $3 billion could be cut next year, and most of the tax reduction in the Senate measure would not come until after the turn of the century.
On most other issues, the Senate and House negotiators can probably simply split the difference between the spending figures the two houses approved.
As for the role of the Democrats, the Republican leaders made no secret that the minority would be frozen out of the negotiations, just as Republicans were excluded when Democrats controlled Congress.
"We're not likely to know what's going on until we see a final document," said Representative Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, the top Democrat on the House Budget Committee.
Their irrelevance to the process did not stop the Democrats from making long-winded speeches today. "Both Republican budgets would tilt government radically in favor of the rich and powerful," asserted Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, setting forth the dominant Democratic view.
Senator Domenici's repeated mispronunciation of Representative Kasich's name -- he called him KAY-sitch instead of KAY-sick -- might be seen as a sign of disrespect coming from someone else. But Mr. Domenici, a wizard with numbers, is well known for having a problem with names. For example, he often refers to Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire as Senator Judd.
Mr. Domenici is somewhat better with symbols. Referring to Thomas Jefferson's famous description of the difference in roles between the Senate and the House, he held up a cup of coffee and said that the fidgety and frenetic Mr. Kasich was like the piping hot coffee and that he himself was the cool saucer.
But he said to Mr. Kasich, "I am as passionate about this as you are."
While Mr. Domenici was speaking, other senators were paging through Congressional picture books trying to place the representatives who were sitting on the other side of the table.
In the past, only senior lawmakers generally served on conference committees. But these are new times. The Republicans in the House named several freshmen as negotiators, which explains why the senators did not recognize them.
The budget resolutions under consideration by the conference are only a starting point. Once a compromise on the resolutions is approved, the real heavy duty will begin as Congress begins making the actual policy decisions to meet the spending targets set by the resolution.
As a first step in that process, Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, told each of his 13 subcommittees today how much money they could allocate next year for the programs under their jurisdiction.
At this stage, President Clinton has no role. But he will ultimately have a strong voice in the outcome. Mr. Domenici expressed recognition of that at the end of today's session.
"Mr. President," the Senator declared, "you will be a player, sooner or later, and if you choose later, you can destroy everything we've done with a veto. I don't presume we have votes to override it.
"But we're going to get there," Mr. Domenici continued. "We're going to do something very, very significant."

HEADLINE: Holdup Man Who Killed Is Executed

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., June 8

 BODY:
An unemployed high school dropout was executed by injection at the state prison here early today for killing a young woman during a holdup at a fast-food restaurant 10 years ago.
The 34-year-old prisoner, Ronald Allridge, had no final statement. But just before they entered the death chamber to be at his side, three of his brothers handed a reporter a note, written by one of them on the back of a lottery ticket, that said, "I hope y'all are happy!" 
 The brothers then stood holding hands a few feet away as the lethal drugs began flowing into the prisoner. After nine minutes, he was pronounced dead.
Mr. Allridge was executed for killing Carla McMillen, 19, who was eating a meal with two friends at a Whataburger restaurant in Fort Worth one night in 1985 when Mr. Allridge and two other men burst in and announced a holdup. Although Ms. McMillen threw up her hands, Mr. Allridge fired his gun at close range.
"His whole appeal was, 'Gosh, it was an accident,' " said Sharen Wilson, the prosecutor who handled the Allridge case. "But it was no accident that he had it pointed directly at the center of her chest. We're not talking about some guy who maybe didn't do it."
Mr. Allridge's final appeal was rejected by the United States Supreme Court three weeks ago, and a request from his lawyer for a 30-day reprieve or a commuted sentence of 1,000 years in prison was denied on Wednesday by Gov. George W. Bush.
Prosecutors said Mr. Allridge, who had previously served less than six years of a 10-year sentence for killing a Fort Worth high school student, had confessed to at least 20 holdups.

HEADLINE: Waging Trade War With Fax and Figures

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
Somewhere in this city there is a lobbyist whose firm has not been hired by one side or the other in America's trade confrontation with Japan. "There is one, I think, but no one knows his name," Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said not long ago.
And somewhere there is a facsimile machine in Washington not spitting out dire warnings of a "trade war" and totaling up the "casualties," as if the Bosnians were shooting car parts at one another. Just today Toyota issued its latest count of the "innocent victims" of the threatened virtual embargo on Japanese luxury cars, chiefly the dealerships and employees who handle that company's Lexus line. 
 "The punitive tariff will be fatal," declared Yale Geiszl, the executive vice president of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A., opening up all eight cylinders in what has turned into a contest of ever-escalating hyperbole.
This has been going on for weeks, of course, ever since the Clinton Administration set June 28 as the deadline for Japan to relent on opening its market or watch the sales of its most profitable export models come to a screeching halt in the American market. But today the decibel level reached new heights as Mr. Kantor's office held a hearing -- owners of luxury car dealerships called it a "kangaroo court" -- about the economic benefits and the harm of the proposed 100 percent tariff.
By late this afternoon, opponents of the tariffs were swarming on a sidewalk in downtown Washington, angry that after a day of hearings not one of them had yet testified. The trade representative's panel had broken for dinner after hearing nothing but praise all day for Mr. Kantor's strategy, from the Big Three auto makers, from sympathetic members of Congress, even from a retired auto worker.
"They broke to keep us off the 7 o'clock news," fumed Richard N. Kull, who represents the council of Acura dealers, who handle the Honda Motor Company's high-end line. "This is completely rigged."
Mr. Kull is one of the many dealers who argue that the sanctions will hurt Americans far more than they will hurt the Japanese, costing his employees their jobs. Everyone pointed to Sean G. Traynor, the president of Garden State Tanning, a leather-goods maker that produces the seats that Lexus owners sink into when they get into their cars. He has already laid off 650 workers at his factory in Williamsport, Md., but he said today that he might be able to hire back "a few hundred" because Toyota has restored some orders -- perhaps out of faith that the trade dispute will be short-lived.
Missing from the hearing, not surprisingly, were the Japanese. Save for some reporters from the big Japanese newspapers, there was hardly a Japanese face in the jammed hearing room, part of the opponents' strategy of demonstrating that the sanctions are putting people out of work in Chicago, not Osaka.
But the dealers dismissed any suggestion that the Japanese Government should bail them out of their economic troubles. "The Government of Japan, quite frankly, doesn't care about Lexus dealers," one said. "Why should they? It's not their workers."
Mr. Kantor and his colleagues in the Administration anticipated objections to the sanctions, of course, and followed a strategy intended to limit assertions that they were undercutting American jobs. The target cars are all made in Japan and have few American parts. That leaves the dealers as the primary American casualties, and the Administration is betting that they will not attract much public sympathy: car dealers, new or used, rarely do.
No one expects the hearing here, which continued into the night, to have the slightest effect on the decision the Administration must make on June 28. But in the multibillion-dollar game of chicken now under way, it is a means for both sides to increase the pressure on the other.
The Japanese car makers and their business affiliates here have to make the case that Mr. Kantor's effort to minimize the economic impact of the sanctions on Americans has failed. The Administration is out to prove that the economic benefits of opening the Japanese market to American cars and parts vastly outweighs whatever temporary effect the collapse of sales of Japanese luxury cars might have in the United States.
Without question, though, the lobbyists and the lawyers are the great winners so far, at least here in Washington. For them, the ultimate nightmare would be a cessation of trade hostilities between Tokyo and Washington. Fortunately for them, economists agree that the $66 billion trade gap will be little affected no matter how the current dispute comes out.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With few signs of progress in a dispute that may lead to punitive tariffs on Japanese luxury cars, in retaliation for Japan's reluctance to open its vehicle and auto-parts markets, tensions have risen. American employees of Japanese car makers gathered in Los Angeles yesterday to protest the tariffs. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Fall Hard Again As Rate-Cut Hopes Recede

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Fading expectations of a cut in interest rates anytime soon caused prices of Treasury securities to pull back sharply for a second consecutive day yesterday.
Lawrence B. Lindsay, a governor of the Federal Reserve, said yesterday that the economy was not likely to slip into a recession though it faced 18 months of slow growth. On Wednesday, the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said he expected an economic recovery in the second half of the year, and the vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, said he expected a quick adjustment by businesses to the slower economy. The comments have been interpreted by the market to mean that the Fed would not move soon to cut short-term interest rates. 
 The 30-year bond fell 23/32 , to a price of 1136/32 for a yield of 6.61 percent, up from 6.55 percent on Wednesday.
Treasuries sold off a bit after the release of the weekly jobless claims data, and on talk that foreign central banks were selling five- and ten-year notes in the market.
Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that while the market appeared to be waiting for today's producer price results, "I suspect that even if we get terribly constructive inflation numbers the market will likely not discount them into prices" because of the expectation of an eventual easing by the Fed.
Ms. Schaja said she believed that if people thought the economy was truly weak, then the inflation numbers would be less critical. "Next week's consumer numbers at this moment are more important in the eyes of the financial market than today's producer price data," she said.
The Producer Price Index, she said, looks as if it will be up four-tenths of a percent, with the core rate up two-tenths of a percent. In April, the index was up five-tenths of a percent and the core up three-tenths of a percent.
She said she expected that even if the producer number came in as expected there might still be some nervousness in the market. "There's a general sense that some investors are at a crossroads and so any weak inflation numbers in their eyes would move up the timetable for the next easing," she said.
The jobless claims data yesterday for the week ended June 3 showed 372,000 claims, down by 7,000 from the previous week's figure, which was revised to 379,000 from 382,000. But the four-week moving average rose by 1,000 claims, to 374,500.
Looking ahead, Ms. Schaja said she expected the economic data for May and June to fit the weak economic picture given the recent May employment report and purchasing management reports. "The question is whether it will signal whether the Fed was right about slow growth caused by inventory, or that the data signaled that it is more of a slowdown in final sales," she said.
In the municipal market, the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority was able to sell one-year general obligation notes at lower-than-expected yields because of a shrinking supply of new short-term securities and even while municipal bonds fell on concern that the rally in the market was beginning to slow.
The $240 million Massachusetts Bay debt offering through competitive bidding that was won by BT Securities, with the notes due June 12, 1996, was priced to yield 3.45 percent, or about 25 basis points better than the Los Angeles County's one-year notes sold the day before.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Growing Inventories of Wood Send Lumber Prices Tumbling

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Lumber futures prices tumbled yesterday by as much as allowed in a single day, falling to two-and-a-half-year lows on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Wood inventories are growing in a sagging housing market.
Prices tumbled after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, implied on Wednesday that he did not expect to cut interest rates despite the slowing economy, analysts said. 
 About 70 percent of American lumber is used in building. Mortgage rates have fallen in recent months, but many consumers are not buying homes because of pessimism brought on by seven interest rate increases since February 1994.
"The market's still trying to digest the unfolding reality of a weaker-than-expected housing market," said Michael Young, a partner in the Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. "The bottom line is that there's too much wood around and there's no way to hold the price in the face of weaker demand."
On other commodity markets, near-term cotton futures advanced for a second day and gasoline futures plunged. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 0.08 point, to 233.71.
Lumber for July delivery settled $10 lower at $224.60 for 1,000 board feet, erasing gains made on Tuesday and Wednesday as traders bet that interest rates would decline, which would encourage housing construction.
Futures prices fell to new contract lows in step with commercial prices, which tumbled as low as $185 for 1,000 board feet from highs of about $400 during the construction boom a year ago.
July cotton futures rose 1.55 cents a pound, to $1.13, and the new-crop October contract advanced 1.16 cents, to 90.18 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Prices were affected by an infestation of beet army worms in Texas, and experts fear that the United States may run out of cotton by October because of high demand and extremely tight supplies. But many European and American mills have curtailed production because commercial prices are sharply higher. An analyst, Judith Ganes of Merrill Lynch, said record amounts of the crop should be available by December because more farmers planted cotton this year because of high demand.
July gasoline futures plummeted 0.93 cent a gallon, to 60.84 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid waning fears of tight supplies this summer.
Prices climbed to three-year highs on speculation that more Americans will stay in the country this year because of the weak dollar, which means a likely increase in demand for vacation driving. But the higher prices led to increased gas production, a report from the American Petroleum Institute found.
American production climbed 8.2 percent, the institute said, although inventories of reformulated gas fell. Prices also fell on reports of 10 cargoes of imported gasoline arriving for East Coast use in late June.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germans Deflate Rate Rumor, And Dollar Ebbs Late in Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose early in the day, then fell against other leading currencies yesterday, in thin, volatile trading after conflicting signals from European central banks.
It strengthened early in the day after the Dutch and Belgian central banks reduced interest rates, leading some traders to expect that the German central bank, the most influential in Europe, would follow with a rate reduction. 
 Indeed, the Bundesbank's president, Hans Tietmeyer, had hinted at a cut on Wednesday at an international monetary conference in Seattle. Such an action might steer investors away from assets denominated in marks and other European currencies, making the dollar more valuable.
But the vice president of the German bank, Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, said yesterday that there would be no immediate cut in rates. That sent the dollar falling again.
"I think it was clutching at straws," Chris Iggo, an international economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said of the market's behavior. The volatile market, he said, had seen "no real trend," and adding, "We've been moving sideways all this week."
The dollar's movement against the Japanese yen yesterday largely followed the trading in the mark.
Late in the day in New York, the dollar stood at 1.4072 marks, down from 1.4147 marks on Wednesday. It slipped to 84.68 yen from 84.88.
The foreign-currency markets have been groping for direction in the absence of any significant economic data this week. They have also been influenced by the notion that the leading industrial nations of the Group of Seven, which will meet in Halifax, Nova Scotia, next week, will reaffirm support for a stable dollar.
David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics in New York, said this lack of direction had led some traders to reassess the policies of the Federal Reserve.
On Wednesday the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said that while there was a chance of a brief recession, the likelihood of a long one had "decreased very significantly." Currency traders took his comments to mean that the Fed would stand pat on interest rates. The dollar has slumped on concerns that the slowing United States economy would force the Fed to cut rates. Lower rates tend to weaken the dollar by making deposits denominated in it less attractive.
Mr. Greenspan's comments helped drive the dollar higher in Asian trading early yesterday.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Fall for a Third Week

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 8

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits fell by 7,000 last week. It was the second drop in three weeks.
The Labor Department said today that first-time applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 372,000 in the week ended last Saturday, down from a substantially revised 379,000 a week earlier. 
 Claims in the week ending May 27, originally estimated to be 389,000, were first thought to have risen by 9,000. The revision showed they actually dropped 1,000. The department said initial data reported during weeks that contain a Monday holiday -- such as those reported on Tuesday after the Memorial Day holiday -- tend to be subject to large revisions.

HEADLINE: Give Them an Alternative to the Drug Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Die-hard Congressional opponents of overseas development assistance, and their "doubting Thomas" colleagues, would do well to consider your June 2 front-page report on Mexico's long-ignored Tarahumara Indians.
Once again, the drug trade is filling a convenient economic vacuum created by "poverty and marginalization." 
 It's a familiar story. Yet there are successful alternatives to this sad scenario -- preventive remedies to drug trafficking that deserve the renewed support of Congress.
After all, when it comes to the American people and foreign aid, we advocate "helping people to help themselves," which is exactly what Agency for International Development programs do.
A good example: low-cost initiatives promoting micro- and small enterprises, such as those designed to combat coca-growing in the Andes.
Thanks to a modest investment made just a few years ago in credit, training, technology and marketing assistance, thousands of formerly marginalized alpaca herders are now linked to the very lucrative and legal global market for high-quality fiber -- and are generating close to 10 percent of Bolivia's fiber exports.
As an international traveler and former Republican member of the House of Representatives, I believe in getting the biggest bang for my buck; I also know a good investment when I see one.
For the world to be a safer place for all of us, it needs more development initiatives targeting the world's poor and rural majority, not less.
 
CLAUDINE SCHNEIDER
Washington, June 6, 1995
 
The writer represented Rhode Island's 2d District, 1980-90.

HEADLINE: City Shortfall Even Worse Than Forecast

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Just hours after lawmakers in Albany finally adopted a state budget, a grim reality settled over City Hall: New York City will receive $670 million less in state assistance than requested -- far less than expected even a week ago.
The shortfall left Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and leaders of the City Council staring down at an enormous and potentially contentious task: Finding other ways to plug this gaping hole in the budget with only three weeks to go before the city's new fiscal year begins on July 1. 
 The Mayor has already proposed $400 million in cuts to highly visible municipal services -- from libraries to day-care centers -- contingent on Albany's failure to give him the money he needs. The Council has vowed to fight most of those. But the new reality is that even if all of the contingency cuts were accepted, the Mayor would still be $271 million short.
"It's a crisis, and it's time to start dealing with it," said Michael S. Clendenin, spokesman for the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a Democrat. "No one should pretend otherwise."
At a City Hall news conference Mr. Giuliani declined to acknowledge the scope of the shortfall. And neither he nor Council leaders would detail what additional actions the city would now take to cover it.
"There are a lot of options," the Mayor said, "and when we're ready to announce them we will. Otherwise I pre-empt our negotiations on the matter."
Instead, he tried to put the best interpretation on the news.
He praised Gov. George E. Pataki and the Republicans of the State Senate for delivering "a substantial amount of what we were asking for." He then sharply attacked the Democrats in the Assembly for having failed to come to the city's aid.
The Democrats in Albany, echoing their colleagues on the City Council, in turn chastised the Mayor, saying his lobbying strategy had failed. They said he had alienated the Assembly, which has historically protected the city's interests, by embracing Governor Pataki's budget.
The state budget numbers dealt a serious blow to Mr. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor who first endorsed Mario M. Cuomo for re-election last fall and then embraced Mr. Pataki's budget cutting.
Earlier this year, the Mayor had hoped to save $1.2 billion from the new Governor's reductions in Medicaid and welfare spending, but the expectation has dwindled ever since. Three months ago, Mr. Giuliani insisted that he would still get $1 billion in savings; by late April, it was $950 million, and as late as Wednesday, he said the city stood to receive as much as $600 million, or "not way beyond the range that we anticipated."
Instead, the city received about $400 million in savings, according to the Council's estimate. The state cuts in Medicaid allowed the city to save only $373 million of the $500 million that Mr. Giuliani had proposed. (Each dollar cut by the state allows the city to cut a roughly equal share.)
Nor did the city receive any of $250 million in direct aid the Mayor had sought. And the state cuts in welfare -- most of them from strengthening eligibility screening and rooting out fraud -- saved the city nothing, the Council said, since the Mayor had already assumed savings from those measures.
The rest of the shortfall came from the city's failure to win approval for legislative changes that would limit its liability in lawsuits, among other things.
The size of the shortfall almost certainly means that the Mayor and the Council will have to consider deeper cuts in spending for municipal services. Any new cuts would fall on top of $800 million in reductions to the city's agencies and $600 million in savings from the municipal unions that are already in the Mayor's budget, even though the Mayor's office has yet to negotiate.
The city could turn to one-shot actions used in the past, like tapping surpluses, refinancing debt or selling assets. But a major bond rater, Standard & Poors, has already warned that it will lower the city's credit rating if such measures are resorted to again. And the present rating, A-, is already among the lowest for any major city.
"The one thing everyone agrees on is that the Mayor and the city lost big-time," said City Councilman Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat from Brooklyn. Of the budget talks ahead, he added, "Now it's back to the same routine we've had for years -- except there are fewer options."
One possible way to soften the blow of the state shortfall would be to revise the city's forecast tax revenues. The Council has urged the Mayor's office to increase projected revenues by $112 million, based on its own economic forecasts, a senior Council official said. And Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Democrat and chairman of the Council's finance committee, said the onus was now on the Mayor to propose alternatives to balance the budget. "They've spoken through their budget," Mr. Berman said of the Mayor and his aides. "Now they'll have to deal with that."
With a state budget now in place, the talks between the Mayor and the Council will intensify in the next few days. Around City Hall, as Council members huddled in internal briefings, the mood seemed relentlessly bleak.
Even the Council's seven Republicans, who are often at odds with the Democratic majority, agreed that the size of the state shortfall meant pain for the city, although they laid the blame entirely on the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver.
The Mayor, despite this large new hole in his budget proposal, said the dire warnings of service cuts were exaggerated. "Although it's going to be tough," he said, "we're not in a position where anything extraordinary will happen."

HEADLINE: Japanese Are in Rush to Sell Their Real Estate in the U.S.

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 8

 BODY:
Japanese companies, which unleashed one of the biggest international flows of investment ever when they flooded the United States with capital during the 1980's, are selling off many of their American assets with growing haste in a critical area, real estate, a new survey shows.
The trickle of sales of troubled real estate projects turned into a wave of auctions and negotiations last year, according to an annual survey by the E&Y Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group here. Japanese investors, according to estimates in the report, sold or were on the verge of selling $6.4 billion worth of American property last year, and could sell as much as $10 billion more this year. 
 By comparison, Japanese companies were net sellers of less than $3 billion of American property in 1993.
Perhaps the most striking aspect of the selloff is the fact that Japanese companies are suffering huge losses in the process. The report estimates that the properties being sold, mostly hotels, resorts and office buildings, are fetching only about 60 percent of what the Japanese companies had paid for them.
For instance, Japan's Sazale Group was recently reported to have sold the Hotel Bel Air, a romantic retreat filled with lush ginger plants and bougainvillea, to a member of the royal family of Brunei for about $60 million; Sazale had acquired the hotel in 1989 for $110 million.
That is why some experts say even more Japanese companies would like to unload their properties, but do not because they cannot afford to realize the losses. "Much of what can happen depends on the capability of the company to absorb a loss," said Kenji Ogawa, head of the real estate finance group here for the Bank of Tokyo. "Not all companies are in a position to do that."
The selloff is part of a large-scale retrenchment by Japanese companies. In the span of a decade, many Japanese companies went from ebullient international investors -- paying unheard of prices for everything from universities in Australia to Rockefeller Center -- to financial cripples because of Japan's recession and their reckless practices.
The Mitsubishi Estate Company has thrown Rockefeller Center into bankruptcy court. The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company has sold 80 percent of its interest in MCA, the owner of Universal Studios, at a big loss. And the Sony Corporation, which purchasedColumbia Pictures in 1989, has suffered huge losses on the studio and has spoken with other companies about selling a stake.
"This has not left any particularly lasting impact," said Paul Alston, a lawyer in Honolulu who has worked with Japanese companies on several real estate transactions there, particularly hotels. "They came in, paid huge prices and were unrealistic about what they could get in room rates. The market has now taken care of that." Sixty percent of the American real estate sold by Japanese interests last year was in California or Hawaii.
To put the sales in perspective, during the peak years for purchases, 1987 through 1990, Japanese companies acquired $57 billion worth of American property, according to the Kenneth Leventhal estimates.
The Japanese property selloff comes at a time when investment from other foreign countries is rising sharply. The Commerce Department said this week that foreign investors, mostly Europeans, spent $47.2 billion last year buying American businesses and properties, up 80 percent from 1993.
First and foremost, the Kenneth Leventhal report said, the property sales are generally motivated not just by the financial problems at the companies that own them, but by their bankers. And that means the Japanese Government, with great influence over the financial sector, is a major player in the strategy.
For the most part, the properties have been losing money from the time they were purchased, but the bankers were willing to continue to provide financing in the hopes that eventually the property markets here would recover. The Finance Ministry strongly encouraged this strategy because it fiercely resists permitting banks to post losses. Such losses would reduce their tax bills.
But Japan's banking crisis has deepened in the last several years. The Finance Ministry, after long denying the problem was that bad, has now conceded that Japanese banks are carrying more than $400 billion in bad loans. Most of the bad loans involve Japanese real estate.
The Japanese Government has recognized that holding on to the bad loans is paralyzing the banks and squelching their overall lending by keeping their capital tied up in assets that produce no interest income.
Recently, the Finance Ministry has begun to permit banks to bite the bullet, sell off some properties and take their losses to begin the recovery process. That is regarded as a key factor behind the real estate sales in the United States.

HEADLINE: Riots by Vietnamese Erode Plan to Send Them Home

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, June 8

 BODY:
An international plan to end the 20-year sojourn of the Vietnamese boat people and force the last of them back to their homeland is in danger of unraveling after riots by the Vietnamese in detention camps across Southeast Asia.
Refugee workers say the riots show that it will be impossible to deport many of the 40,000 Vietnamese in the camps without violence. The once-steady flow of boat people volunteering to return to Vietnam has evaporated, at least in part because of moves by Republicans in the United States Congress to offer thousands of them asylum. 
As a result, refugee workers say the detention camps may have to remain for years as Asian governments, fearing more bloodshed and an outcry from human rights organizations, give up on their plans to force the Vietnamese home.
Just today, the riot police in Hong Kong fired tear gas at a group of nearly 50 Vietnamese boat people protesting their imminent deportation to Vietnam. There were no reports of injuries, although the kitchen and an adjacent office at the High Island Detention Center were set on fire by the Vietnamese before the protest could be ended.
On Monday, the riot police in Malaysia fired water cannon and tear gas to force back more than 1,000 boat people who broke out of a camp on the outskirts of Kuala Lumpur, the capital, to protest the Government's plans for their imminent repatriation.
Many of the Vietnamese protesters were armed with knives, and the Malaysian police say that after the riot, they seized daggers, swords, spears, bows and other weapons from the camp, where more than 4,000 Vietnamese are detained.
Twenty Vietnamese were detained by the police on charges of rioting. And while police spokesmen said no one was wounded in the clash, reporters outside the camp saw at least two men with bleeding injuries, possibly self-inflicted. Many of the Vietnamese here have repeatedly threatened to commit suicide rather than go home.
"Until now the situation has been peaceful," said Erika Feller, regional representative in Kuala Lumpur for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. "But I think violence, at least low-level violence, is becoming a threat."
The United States has endorsed an international agreement intended to close most of the detention camps by the end of the year by encouraging the last Vietnamese still left in the camps to go back home voluntarily -- and, if that fails, by deporting them forcibly.
Virtually all of the Vietnamese left in the detention camps in Asia -- there are large camps in Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand, Hong Kong and Malaysia -- have been declared economic migrants, not political refugees, and therefore have no right to asylum under international law.
But the difficulty of carrying out the so-called Comprehensive Plan of Action has been compounded by legislation now under debate in the United States Congress that could result in offers of asylum to as many as 20,000 Vietnamese.
Republican sponsors of the legislation, which has been approved in the House of Representatives but is facing a veto by President Clinton, say many of the Vietnamese in the camps have reason to fear persecution, even imprisonment, if they are forced to return to their homeland.
Some human rights campaigners agree. A study by the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, based in New York, found that "hundreds, perhaps thousands, of Vietnamese refugees have been wrongly rejected" for asylum.
The United Nations, which employs investigators in Vietnam to monitor conditions of the 70,000 Vietnamese who have already gone home voluntarily, insists that it has been unable to document a single case of Government harassment of the returning Vietnamese.
News of the recent Congressional moves has begun to circulate in the detention camps throughout Asia, and refugee workers say it has given many of the boat people reason to believe that their protests -- even violent protests -- could help them achieve their dream of citizenship in the United States.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which runs the detention camps throughout Southeast Asia, has blamed the Congressional debate for a huge riot last month in one Hong Kong camp.
Nearly 200 people, most of them police officers, were wounded in the protest against deportation. It was the most violent clash between the Hong Kong police and the Vietnamese since Hong Kong's colonial government opened camps for the boat people in the 1970's, when the Vietnamese began taking to rickety boats and pushing off into the South China Sea in hopes of escaping their Communist homeland.
The United Nations has also blamed the legislation for having ended the flow of Vietnamese willing to volunteer to return home under a program in which they are each given a payment of several hundred dollars.
The United Nations scheduled a charter flight last week for 270 Vietnamese in Hong Kong who had volunteered to go home. But the flight had to be canceled when all but four of the Vietnamese announced that they had changed their minds.
"They clearly told us that they wanted to await the outcome of the Congressional debate in Washington," said Jahanshah Assadi, the chief of mission in Hong Kong for the High Commissioner for Refugees. "I hope the damage to the repatriation program is not irreparable, but we have very tangible evidence of people being affected by what's going on in Washington."
Ms. Feller, the United Nations official in Kuala Lumpur, said she was certain that the American legislation was "an important factor" in the clash here on Monday. "The Vietnamese," she said, "have asked us point blank: Does this legislation mean that we're going to be able to go to the United States?"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Announces Package To Deal With Banks' Crisis

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 8

 BODY:
Describing Japan's banking crisis as the worst since the Great Depression, Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura today announced a rescue package aimed at restoring confidence in the financial system, but the plan contained few concrete steps.
Although Mr. Takemura called the package "bold and aggressive," analysts said they were skeptical that the plan would help stimulate lending and investment and thereby re-ignite the sagging economy. 
 "Meaningless, in a word," said David M. Atkinson, banking analyst at Goldman, Sachs (Japan) Ltd. And David Threadgold, a bank analyst at BZW Securities (Japan) Ltd., compared the package to "rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic."
By the Government's estimate, Japan's ailing banking system is awash in bad debt amounting to at least 40 trillion yen, or $470 billion, which would make the banking sector's problems more serious than the savings and loan crisis in the United States. Other estimates put the figure as high as $1 trillion or more.
The rescue package was also billed as part of an overall strategy to stabilize the yen, which has risen 15 percent against the dollar since the beginning of the year.
Analysts said the package, which is to cover a five-year period, was useful in that it demonstrated the Government's commitment to the financial system, a commitment that had been questioned recently. Still, the general verdict was that the measures announced today were grossly inadequate to restructure the banking system.
The Finance Ministry did not offer any of its own funds as part of the rescue package. Instead, it said that the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, would be authorized over the next five years to make "special" loans to bankrupt lenders, with conditions attached, such as the resignation of top management.
The use of taxpayer money to finance the banking system has been a sensitive issue because many Japanese blame the banks partly for the current recession and would not like to see public funds channeled to the institutions.
The nation's banks often lent recklessly during the 1980's and helped push speculative property and stock prices to phenomenal heights. But the so-called bubble economy collapsed five years ago, puncturing those inflated prices, and many real estate loans went sour.
The Government's estimate of $470 billion in bad loans represents 5.7 percent of total outstanding loans. The figure is equivalent to 8.5 percent of Japan's economic output in 1994.
While Mr. Takemura, the Finance Minister, did not directly allocate any public funds, he did call for a national debate on the possible use of taxpayer money to bail out banks. But one Japanese analyst said it would be difficult for the ministry to commit to using any public money before the elections in July.
In any case, the special loans would act as a temporary mechanism while the Government expanded the Deposit Insurance Corporation, an agency that guarantees depositors' funds, up to a ceiling, in the event of a bank failure.
The problem with the agency is that it has little money and has never been used. It is expected to take five years to prop up the agency so that it could be used if a bank collapsed.
Financial disclosure by banking institutions in Japan is unusually weak for such a large banking system, so depositors have little means by which to evaluate bank creditworthiness. The ministry said it intended to increase disclosure.
Some analysts interpreted such steps as a sign that the Government was trying to create a system for allowing banks to fail. "It's good they are laying the groundwork," said David Snoddy, a bank analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd.
But it is unclear whether the ministry would actually let a bank collapse. Instead, analysts said, the ministry would be much more likely to fall back on the usual methods of forcing healthy banks to acquire ailing ones. In fact, the ministry said it would encourage that option as part of the rescue package.
Japan's financial authorities are acutely sensitive to doubts about their ability to fully support the banking system. That is why Moody's Investors Service last month is said to have angered the Finance Ministry when it put three Japanese banks under review for a possible downgrade. Moody's cited, among other reasons, uncertainty about Japan's ability to safeguard stability in the banking system.
Some banks have taken their own action by writing off portions of their bad debt, and even posting losses for the fiscal year that ended March 31. But many banks have not yet disposed of much of their bad debt.
The ministry indicated today that one-quarter of the nonperforming loans at the nation's 21 money-center banks would probably have to be written off. Nonperforming loans, on which interest has not been paid for six months, total 12.5 trillion yen at those banks, the ministry said.
Analysts said that because today's measures were not likely to solve the banking crisis, they were unlikely to help stabilize the yen. Some analysts argued that because the banks were plagued by a morass of bad debt, they were not very willing to promote lending, especially amid the uncertain economic environment. Lending has declined over the last year.
Without easy credit, the economy cannot fully recover, imports will not grow enough to significantly cut the trade surplus, and the yen will not weaken against the dollar.
Other analysts said that the real culprit in prolonging the recession was the real estate market. Only by reorganizing the real estate market, which accounts for a large portion of the economy, could the authorities then address the banking system, the analysts said. Problems in the real estate market, including prices that are about one-third below their peak and still slipping, are hampering the climate for investment and lending.

HEADLINE: Japan Deserves A Tariff

BYLINE: By Lawrence Chimerine and James Fallows; Lawrence Chimerine is chief economist of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research organization. James Fallows, Washington editor of The Atlantic Monthly, is author of "Looking at the Sun," about East Asian capitalism.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Although European and Asian governments have complained about the Clinton Administration's regrettable but justified proposal to place tariffs of 100 percent on 13 Japanese-made cars, most agree that Japanese trade barriers threaten the world trading system.
Debate in America on the issue has been more primitive. Many free-market economists, some pundits and lobbyists for Japanese and for some European interests question whether there is even a problem to be solved. 
 Mercifully, most have spared us the old argument that simply driving down the value of the dollar will eliminate trade imbalances. The dollar has lost two-thirds of its value against the yen in the last decade, yet trade between Japan and the United States has been remarkably unchanged, even though American products are much cheaper.
But we are hearing equally tired assertions, which rest on a misleading appearance of economic sophistication. The principal claim is that Americans import too much and save too little and that the Japanese do the reverse. But this supposed insight into the trade imbalance does not tell us which is the cause and which is the effect.
Most economists take it for granted that our low savings rate causes chronic, large trade deficits, because when we spend too heavily, we inevitably buy huge quantities of foreign goods. Yet it is just as proper to argue the reverse -- that the large trade deficits caused by artificial barriers to American exports help create the low savings rate. This happens because reduced exports to, say, Japan mean smaller payrolls and profits at home. With less money earned, less is saved. And less is paid in taxes, driving up the Federal deficit and further depressing savings (because the Government borrows to finance the deficit).
The existence of formidable Japanese trade barriers is indisputable. Studies by the Economic Strategy Institute and other research groups estimate that if Japan's markets behaved like those of other industrialized countries, Japan would import up to $200 billion more in goods each year than it now does; of this, almost $50 billion would come from the United States.

The United States should raise its savings rate to limit reliance on foreign capital and to encourage productive investment -- the key to vigorous long-term growth. But even if we do, we are likely to have a trade problem with Japan unless Japan changes. South Korea and Singapore, whose savings rates are even higher than Japan's, also have large trade deficits with Japan.
Another faulty assertion in the debate over imposing a punitive tariff on Japan is that we're only hurting ourselves. Some claim we should keep our markets open regardless of what anyone else does because any other course would hurt American consumers.
They ask, Why should we punish ourselves by paying more for a Lexus or an Infiniti? And they say, If the Japanese or other Asians want to penalize their own people by running a closed economy, that's their problem. We'll enjoy the benefit of bargain-priced goods.
But Americans need jobs and income to buy even bargain-priced goods. Countries that combine closed markets with aggressive exporting to the United States effectively cut the number of good American jobs and thus consumer income. Closed foreign markets also inhibit our producers from investing, supporting research and development and creating new jobs.
A third argument against the tariffon Japanese luxury cars is that American car companies brought their problems on themselves by being lazy and greedy and not making cars suitable for Japan's left-side driving. This is the oldest red herring of all. Our auto producers make millions of right-hand-drive models for other left-side markets like Britain's.
The real issue is the cartel-like structure that ties Japanese parts makers, auto companies and dealers together in networks that are hard for outsiders to penetrate, no matter how attractive their products are.
In the auto parts business, there is no question of "wrong side" spark plugs, microcontrollers or piston rings. At current exchange rates, many American-made auto parts sell for one-third the price of Japanese-made items. American-made parts are of such high quality that the nation has an auto-parts trade surplus with Europe, where they are heavily used by BMW, Mercedes and other demanding manufacturers.
Nonetheless, American parts have captured only 2 percent of the Japanese market. And Japanese-owned auto assembly plants in the United States use at most only 50 to 60 percent American-made parts.
Finally, the silliest assertion is that the Administration's tariff might lead countries to embrace managed trade -- government manipulation of international commerce for national advantage. In raising this warning, the Europeans and Japanese are being hypocritical -- and they know it.
The Europeans know it because their trade with Japan has long been managed in a Draconian way. Ever wonder why there are virtually no Japanese cars in France or Italy? It isn't because the Japanese are not trying hard enough or have the wrong steering wheels. It is because Europeans sharply limit the number of Japanese cars they will let in each year.
The Japanese know it because their own diplomats and foreign aid specialists advise the Thais, Russians, Indonesians and anyone else who will listen that careful controls on trade and capital are the best way to preserve an industrial base.

 America's economy has its own mass of trade regulations and subsidies. But its markets are the most open of all the big industrialized countries. Japan's are the least open.
Ever freer trade over the last four decades has helped much of the world prosper. If there is a threat to the continued progress of this movement, it comes from those who pretend that problems with free trade -- especially those created by the chronic American-Japanese trade imbalance -- do not exist.
The Administration is at least trying to deal with this problem, which, if unaddressed, will destroy American support for free trade in general. If those who are most concerned about saving the world trade system don't like the Clinton solution, let them come up with a better and more realistic approach.

HEADLINE: A Prince Charming?;
Disney and the City Find Each Other

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
It is not, at first glance, a marriage made in heaven: the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment giant with the family-values image, and New York City, the hard-edged metropolis.
 But a match it appears to be. For the last two years, Disney and New York have been courting, and all signs suggest that flirtation is turning into commitment. 
 Suddenly, Disney seems to be everywhere, with a superstore at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street to open by year's end, a festive premiere of "Pocahontas" tonight in Central Park and plans to help operate a huge hotel-entertainment-retail complex at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue. Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" has been running on Broadway for 14 months, and the company has plans to bring in a major new show every year.
 And next month, in a move that would cement the long-term relationship, the company is to decide whether to proceed with a $29 million plan to take over and renovate the largest abandoned theater on 42d Street, the New Amsterdam.
 A decision to move ahead, which senior Disney executives say is likely but not guaranteed, would be an extraordinary milestone in a two-decade effort by the city and state to reclaim the tawdry, rundown stretch of New York's most famous street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
 Disney's value to New York officials is clear. Although some have criticized the New Amsterdam deal as too sweet when the city is making broad cuts in education and social services, officials counter that Disney would create new jobs and tax revenues as well as provide the catalyst to revive 42d Street. The mere possibility that Disney might weave its wholesome magic on New York's most seamy strip has already caused other entertainment companies to rethink the block's potential.

 
 
A Departure, And a Gamble
 The lure of New York for Disney is more subtle.
 For Disney, New York represents a symbolic new direction, not to mention a calculated gamble with its image. While the company has opened more than 350 retail stores in recent years, including ones in London and Paris, it has not established a strong presence in an old urban center, as it is in New York. Rehabilitating the New Amsterdam Theater, a 92-year-old landmark, and creating a permanent base in the hurly-burly of Broadway would be a significant departure for a company that has preferred to create from scratch its own carefully controlled environments, far from the bustle and chaos of city centers.
 While Michael D. Eisner, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, says there is no formal strategy for New York, Disney's new passion for New York fits into larger plans to expand and diversify an already wide network. That Mr. Eisner grew up in the city -- at Park Avenue and 89th Street in Manhattan -- also figures in the mix.
 The company's most significant ambition in New York undoubtedly focuses on Broadway, where it wants to establish a permanent foothold as part of a broad venture into live entertainment. Disney intends to produce a new show annually, beginning in spring 1997, Mr. Eisner said, and to send touring companies of its latest Broadway hit around the country and beyond. Rather than renting theaters, he said, owning one would be more profitable.
 "We decided that the legitimate theater was a very desirable business for us," he said. "And to be a really legitimate theater producer, you have to be in New York."
 Many people who have tried for years to link Disney and the 42d Street renewal effort say that three people have been central to the effort to bring the company to New York: Mr. Eisner himself; the architect Robert A. M. Stern, who created design guidelines for much of the Times Square redevelopment, and Marian S. Heiskell, chairwoman of New 42d Street Inc., a nonprofit group overseeing the renovation of six old theaters on 42d Street.
 Mrs. Heiskell, an old friend of Mr. Eisner's, had tried intermittently, since he took over Disney in 1984, to interest him in creating a company presence in New York.
 Mr. Stern, also an old friend, first took Mr. Eisner to see the New Amsterdam Theater in 1993. The men had been meeting on a Friday in Mr. Stern's office, going over his architectural designs for a new town Disney is developing in Florida. They began talking about Disney's plans to mount a musical version of "Beauty and the Beast" on Broadway. Mr. Eisner mentioned that, if Disney were to make a long-term commitment to Broadway, it might as well buy a theater.
 "He knew I had been trying to get him interested in 42d Street," Mr. Stern said. The next morning, before the two men flew to Florida, Mr. Stern took Mr. Eisner to see the New Amsterdam. Combing through its crumbling interior, Mr. Eisner said, he sensed its former grandeur and began to get excited about restoring the theater and, with it, the neighborhood.
 Ten months later, Mr. Eisner was back in New York, this time in City Hall, to announce with delighted city and state officials the tentative agreement for Disney to renovate the theater.

 
 
Unfamiliar Waters For a Company
 If the company does sign a final agreement next month, Disney would be entering unfamiliar waters. Nurtured in Walt Disney's animation studios in the San Fernando Valley of California, the company came of age in the orange groves of Anaheim, where it built Disneyland, and in swampland in central Florida, where it created Walt Disney World.
 "They went to Orange County long before it was populated," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "They went to Florida and took a swamp and made it a center. The whole theory of Disney was, 'We will build our own community, with our own people.' Coming to New York is a major change for them."
 Disney has tried before, with mixed success, to assume a different role, as a consultant to cities, said Stacy Warren, a professor of geography and anthropology at East Washington University, who has studied the company. In Seattle, where Disney planners were hired to propose renovation designs for an aging civic center, the company was criticized for excessive control over the project and for failing to involve the public, Dr. Warren said.
 In New York, a handful of officials have raised related concerns.
 This week, the city was criticized for allowing the use of Central Park for the "Pocahontas" premiere, to which 60,000 tickets were given away in a lottery but which is otherwise not open to the public. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch called the screening a misuse of public space. He said the only condition that might have changed his mind would have been a threat by Disney to pull out of the 42d Street development, a theory denied by Fran Reiter, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Relations, who is overseeing the event for the city. Disney is donating $1 million for the park's use.
 If it runs smoothly, the premiere would be a publicity coup for a company that, while enormously successful -- revenues this year will probably be $12 billion, industry analysts said -- has had its share of highly public difficulties in recent years, including EuroDisney and an ill-fated proposal to build a park with a historical theme in northern Virginia.

 
 
Putting Up Image, But Little Money
 While Disney executives are taking a gamble with the company image in New York, they are not contemplating a huge initial investment.
 The preliminary plan for renovating the badly damaged New Amsterdam calls for the company to spend $29 million. Of that, Disney would spend $8 million of its own and would receive low-interest loans from the city and state, at the rate of 3 percent, to cover the rest. While the city routinely offers tax breaks, low-interest loans and other subsidies to lure businesses, in an unusual part of the arrangement, Disney would give the city and state part of its gross sales at the theater: 2 percent a year for the first $20 million in sales and 3 percent on sales over $20 million.
 City Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge and State Senator Franz S. Leichter, both Manhattan Democrats, have criticized government officials and Disney executives for not making public complete details of the agreement. They also question whether officials have offered Disney too sweet a deal for the New Amsterdam.
 City and state officials, pointing out that the agreement is still tentative, defend the arrangement as potentially profitable, saying it will produce jobs and revenue, and improve the neighborhood.
 Disney can choose to pull out of the arrangement by July 15 if two conditions are not met: final bids for renovating the theater cannot exceed projected costs -- the $29 million already estimated, plus an additional $5 million in potential overruns -- and the city and state must obtain commitments from other companies to come to 42d Street.
 City and state officials said that talks with many companies were under way. When word leaked out in 1993 that Disney had begun talking about taking over the New Amsterdam, once home to the Ziegfeld Follies, other companies began negotiating for some of the eight other theaters on the street.
 "It's totally changed the way people see the street," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, a state agency coordinating the redevelopment of Times Square.
 Mr. Eisner said negotiations were continuing, and he noted that Disney has a reputation for scrutinizing its expenditures carefully. But he also left little doubt about what he hoped the outcome would be.
 "I know we are committed and will be committed to the New Amsterdam," he said.
 John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said, "I think they realize the cachet of Broadway, and the ability to market it elsewhere is a very important thing,"
 Disney's participation in the proposed hotel complex on 42d Street would involve a smaller investment. The company is a junior partner with the Tishman Urban Development Corporation, which would raise the money, build the 680-room hotel and operate it. Disney would be responsible only for developing the retail and entertainment portion of the development.
 There is also an option for Disney to develop a 100-room time-share hotel as part of the complex. But Mr. Eisner played down that possibility. "The chances of us going forward on that are only, I would say, fair," he said.
 But Mr. Eisner said he relished the challenges of reviving 42d Street.
 "I know what 42d Street can be," he said, "and it is going to completely rejuvenate New York. I want to be part of that, and I want to be part of that as an executive of the Disney Company and I want to be part of that as a former New Yorker."
