HEADLINE: For Mercy College Teachers: Recruit a Student, Get a Raise

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
Like many other businesses facing a fiscal crunch, Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., decided this spring that it had to boost sales -- namely the number of students it enrolled.
 And so the college came up with an audacious incentive system unheard of in academia: it ties the salaries of its professors to their ability to boost enrollment. Like Wall Street investment bankers pushing for annual bonuses, Mercy's professors would receive 7 percent raises if they helped recruit and retain enough students to raise enrollment by about 400. On the other hand, if enrollment remained flat, salaries would fall 7 percent. 
 Since the professors' decision in April to embark on the new incentive program, more faculty members than ever visited high school fairs to trumpet Mercy's virtues and made late-night calls to raise the spirits of students pondering dropping out, the college's president, Jay Sexter, said.
 Apparently, it has paid off. Based on the numbers of inquiries from high school students, college officials predicted yesterday that enrollment at the school will climb by 675 this fall, nearly 10 percent.
 Still, the professors' decision to link their salaries to enrollment, prompted by a looming $2.2 million cut in state tuition assistance, has raised questions among national college officials. They worry that such a strategy might spread and eventually make professors think twice about failing students. After all, each time a student drops out, the prospects dim for a faculty raise.
 "At least since the Middle Ages, institutions have tried to divorce the business side from the academic side," said David R. Merkowitz, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, the umbrella group for the nation's colleges. "The obvious danger is it provides an incentive for a professor not to give a failing grade."
 Mr. Merkowitz said he had never heard of a plan similar to Mercy's. Nevertheless, he said, all but the most selective and well-endowed private colleges have become aggressively competitive as they try to cope with a dip in the number of high school graduates and decreases in state and federal tuition aid. The University of Rochester, he pointed out, is offering $5,000 scholarships to all New York State residents in an effort to attract more students.
 Mercy, founded in 1964 by the Roman Catholic Sisters of Mercy but now nonsectarian, is a nonprofit four-year college with strong programs in nursing, occupational therapy, veterinary technology, hotel management and personnel. It was a pioneer in building annexes close to students' homes and has classrooms in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens, Yonkers, Mount Vernon, Yorktown and Port Chester.
 Fifty percent of its 7,135 students come from Westchester County. Thirty-five percent are Hispanic, 30 percent are white, 20 percent are black and 15 percent Asian. Tuition for next year will be $6,600 a year. Salaries range from $26,000 to $81,000.
 Mercy's decision was prompted by the gloomy prospects in Gov. George E. Pataki's budget plans. The college had to present its own balanced budget on July 1, although the precise amount of Mercy's shortfall would not be known until September registration. Raising tuition was viewed as counterproductive. So the college was forced either to issue pink slips to a dozen of its 155 faculty members or come up with a contingency plan.
 During negotiations for an emergency one-year faculty contract, Benjamin B. Weisman, the chairman of business and economics, said it would be wasteful to dismiss people and then find out in September that the layoffs were unnecessary. He suggested that the college model its compensation formula on the business world.
 "There are bonuses if people do well," said Mr. Weisman, who does consulting for Wall Street. "If things go bad, then the business has to survive by cutting expenses."
 The faculty approved the plan by a 4-to-1 ratio. In an interview, another faculty negotiator, Andrew R. Joppa, an assistant professor of business, compared the virtues of the plan to the economics of a restaurant.
 "If you're running a restaurant with great ambience," he said, "you need people to sit there and eat what you're offering. So I believe it's one of our obligations to make sure people are there to receive our services."
 Some college teachers played down the value of the plan -- they denied they were hawking the school on the streets -- and credited any enrollment boost to the marketing ideas, like bus stop advertisements, of the new dean of admissions, Joy Colelli. Yet, others said they were working harder than ever at recruitment and retention.
 Donna Killian Sorkin, an associate professor of statistics, said she had given struggling students her home phone number so she could help them resolve problems. Ms. Colelli brought a dozen science professors to high schools to talk about Mercy's science programs. Other instructors made a point of calling students who signaled their problems about continuing college by not applying for financial aid.
 "We have to recognize that the health of the college as a whole depends on the individual activities of every one of us," Ms. Sorkin said.
 Professors reject criticism that they might inflate grades to keep students from dropping out. "If you're teaching 140 students and two are not doing well, you're not going to consider that by keeping two students you'll protect your job," Mr. Weisman said.
 Still, the plan is a touchy one. Marvin Karp, the president of the college's branch of the American Association of University Professors, maintained that enrollment-linked salaries were an emergency measure that would end next year. But the college's president, Mr. Sexter, saw the proposal's future differently.
 "Let's see what happens and we'll decide if it's one year or a way of life," he said.

HEADLINE: Investors See Trouble; Fed Doesn't

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
With the economy slowing sharply, investors see more trouble ahead. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, doesn't.
 That stark disagreement -- over whether the economy may be sinking into recession or will right itself -- was underscored by today's turmoil in the bond market and a 34-point tumble in the Dow Jones industrial average. In fact, stock and bond prices have fallen for three straight days since Wednesday, when Mr. Greenspan disappointed investors who were counting on the Fed to give the economy a quick shot in the arm through a rate cut. He said he was not particularly worried about the long-term health of the economy, although he acknowledged the possibility of a brief recession. 
 "The markets are disappointed that Chairman Greenspan at this time did not agree with them," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers, a New York-based brokerage firm. "The message of the markets is they think the Fed should ease."
 Today, prices of Treasury securities plunged again, fueled as well by speculation that the Japanese might curtail future purchases of Government bonds -- speculation that was subsequently denied by the Japanese Government. [Page 36.]
 Still, the fundamental reason for the turmoil is clear. If Mr. Greenspan is wrong, the economy may have stumbled into a vicious circle of factory layoffs, further drops in consumer spending and yet more layoffs -- all leading to a recession.
 But if Mr. Greenspan is right, then the economy will resume growing later this year, after companies have sold off part of the stockpiles of goods that have built up recently. At that point, they should begin ordering more from factories. In that case, all a cut in short-term interest rates now would do is to add a sharp stimulus to a natural rebound, possibly feeding inflation.
 The markets may batter finance ministers into accepting big changes in currency values, but chairmen of the Federal Reserve are more insulated, thanks to the power they have over the money supply. The danger of the disagreement between Mr. Greenspan and the markets is that a flight from stocks and bonds could erode confidence, stifle consumer spending and turn economic stagnation into a recession. Indeed, Fed optimism is partly based on the expectations that this year's rising stock market and lower interest rates would help overcome the effects of the Fed's yearlong escalation of short-term interest rates, which finally stopped on Feb. 1.
 Unsold goods are at the nub of the debate. Federal Reserve officials and Wall Street economists agree that the key to the economy's health for the rest of this year is what happens as companies try to slow the growth of those stockpiles in response to a slackening of consumer spending.
 The economic theory on the phenomenon, called inventory-led recession, has been a staple of business-cycle analysis for decades.
 "Let's say you're cruising along" with steady economic growth, explained Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve Board governor and former economics professor at Harvard University. "Suddenly sales drop. At first, while you're absorbing that information and finding out it's the case, your inventories are going to build pretty dramatically."
 "At some point you decide to shed inventories because they have become too costly to hold," Mr. Lindsey continued. "So you cut production. When you cut production, you lay off workers."
 But when workers lose their jobs, they don't just lick their wounds. They also cut back on personal spending. So do people watching these layoffs, who then start to fear for their own jobs. As all of these consumers demand fewer goods, more companies tend to lay off workers.
 "What you have to do is you have to hope your inventories are drawn down faster than demand declines," Mr. Lindsey said. Once companies have eliminated their excess inventories, they tend to resume ordering new goods, and growth returns.
 Four of the nine recessions since World War II have started with inventory problems. Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues attribute the economy's current weakness to inventory adjustments, but play down their severity.
 "It strikes me that what we are looking at right now is a reduction in inventory investment, which is still modest but is going to proceed, as best I can judge, for a while," Mr. Greenspan said. "Fortunately, the levels of inventories are still rather modest, and as a consequence there isn't in that sense the inventory tinder to create the type of sharp inventory recessions which we've experienced in the United States in the past."
 In interviews over the last week, other Fed governors offered several reasons why they were optimistic that inventories could be reduced without severely damaging consumer spending. Janet Yellen, a Clinton appointee and the board's newest member, pointed out that consumer confidence remained fairly strong, while rallies this spring in the stock and bond markets had made some families wealthier.
 Alan S. Blinder, the board's vice chairman, said that he expected the United States to sell more goods to foreign markets, which would also help reduce inventories here. And Fed officials have noted in recent months that a sizable chunk of the recent inventory accumulation consists of imported goods. If American companies cut back on their import orders while they sell the goods they have, that will have little effect on American factory production and employment.
 Census Bureau statistics show that inventories are fairly high now but not unusually so. The ratio of goods held to sales has not yet reached the levels of 1986, when inventory problems clearly braked the economy. The economy shrank by eight-tenths of a percentage point in the second quarter that year, and grew by only 1 percent in the third quarter and 1.4 percent in the fourth quarter.
 But the Fed responded in 1986 by cutting overnight interest rates four times, by a total of two percentage points. Many in the market argue that similar Fed action may be needed now. "I think it's going to need some help from the Fed," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company, a Chicago bank.
 Mr. Kasriel and other financial economists point to many signs that the economy's problems may be more serious than Fed officials care to admit, starting with the American economy's unexpected loss of 101,000 jobs in May.
 Without a Fed rate cut, stock prices have deteriorated along with prospects for the economy and corporate profits. Short-term bond prices have also fallen steeply as the Fed seems likely to hold overnight interest rates steady.
 All of which adds to a gloom on Wall Street at odds with the high-flying level of the market. The slowdown in growth, said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, "will not be reversed until there is a boost from policy measures, specifically monetary policy."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Show No Inflation, Reflecting Slowdown

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Reflecting a slowing economy, inflation at the producer level disappeared again in May, as price declines for food and some energy products offset increases for other types of finished goods, Government figures showed today.
 Price pressures also eased at earlier stages of the production process, with the Producer Price Index for such intermediate components as bolts of cloth posting its smallest rise in a year. 
 "It looks like all we're getting is a modest acceleration of inflation in '95," said Nicholas S. Perna, chief economist at the Shawmut National Corporation in Boston.
 Separately, Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a monthly compilation of the forecasts of about 50 analysts, showed sharply reduced expectations for national output in the quarter that ends June 30. The consensus now predicts gross domestic product will rise at an annual rate of just 1.5 percent, down from forecasts of 2.2 percent a month ago.
 About one-third of these predictions, in fact, were made just before the Labor Department's announcement a week ago that employers cut payrolls by 101,000 last month, a development that prompted widespread reassessment and led some analysts to contend that second-quarter growth would be negligible, perhaps nonexistent.
 G.D.P. rose at a rate of 2.7 percent in the first three months of the year, down from 5.1 percent in the final quarter of 1994.
 The inflation figures reported this morning, which on the whole were a bit better than expected, seemed to have little immediate effect on the bond and stock markets but may have contributed to sharp drops later in the day, specialists said.
 Prices received by producers of finished goods were unchanged in May after a jump of five-tenths of 1 percent in April. That gain was accompanied by hefty increases for intermediate and crude goods as well, according to the Labor Department's report.
 "We may have seen the peak pressures in input prices," said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. He noted that the price of intermediate goods other than food and energy had now risen less over the last three months than over the last 12 months.
 In one of the few negative elements in today's report, the core rate for finished goods, which excludes the wide-swinging food and energy components, posted its second straight rise of three-tenths of 1 percent for last month.
 But analysts said this inflation worry would not dissuade the Federal Reserve from cutting short-term interest rates should the economy soften enough in the Fed's view to warrant such an action.
 "As the economy weakens, the price indexes are going to reflect that," said David A. Levy, research director at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute in Chappaqua, N.Y. Citing what he saw as a larger buildup of inventories than is generally recognized, Mr. Levy put the odds at 50-50 that the economy had already slipped into recession after peaking in April.
 The finished goods index was marked by the largest of three straight monthly declines for food, which fell six-tenths of 1 percent, and by a two-tenths of 1 percent decline for energy.
 Fresh and dry vegetables skidded 14.1 percent, reversing an April surge; beef and veal fell less than in April, and fresh fruits and melons soared nearly 30 percent. In energy, declines for residential natural gas and electricity more than offset a 9.3 percent jump for home heating oil and a 2 percent rise in gasoline, the report also showed.
 Elsewhere, tobacco products climbed 2.2 percent to account for one-third of the rise in the core Producer Price Index while heavy trucks were a major factor in a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent for capital equipment.
 Among intermediate goods, which rose over all by two-tenths of 1 percent, the gain for nondurable factory materials like paperboard slowed to six-tenths of 1 percent from 2.5 percent in April.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bonds Take Plunge On a Rumor

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities, already beaten back by the fading prospects that the Fed would ease credit, were battered again yesterday, as traders speculated that the Japanese might curtail future purchases of United States Government securities.
 However, the Japanese rumor may have served as an excuse for investors to sell in a market that has run too far, too fast on anticipation that the economy will continue to slow, analysts said. No one saw it as indicative of a major new direction in the market. 
 Eugene J. Sherman, director of research for M. A. Schapiro & Company, a Wall Street investment bank, said he was not buying the rumor, even though the Japanese hold a big part of a now record amount of Treasury securities being held by foreign central banks and official institutions. "If they were to sell their holdings, there is no other market or combination of markets that can absorb that magnitude of money," he said. The bond market was ready to sell and found this a convenient reason to do so, he continued.
 Rusty Vanneman, a senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, agreed, noting that prices have risen 20 percent since the beginning of the year and have been in an upward trend since November. "Essentially it is overbought and just looking for an excuse to sell," he said. "Fundamentally nothing has really changed to alter the picture. Inflation is still in check, and -- simply put -- the market is overbought and overextended and is in need of taking a breather."
 The 30-year bond fell 119/32 of a percentage point yesterday, to a price of 11119/32 , sending its yield surging to 6.72 percent, from 6.61 percent on Thursday. It opened the week at 6.53 percent.
 Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said it was the biggest increase in the long bond's yield since Sept. 16, 1994, when it rose 14 basis points, to 7.77 percent.
 "I think we need to keep today in context with the powerful rally we've had in the market," Mr. Alexy said. The rumor that Japanese investors were being asked to sell Treasury securities had a big impact on the market, he noted, "but here again we have a situation were people have made significant profits and now are quick to defend them."
 Mr. Vanneman, who sees less volatility in the market in coming weeks, said, "We may see the market now move back into a stable environment, with 30-year Treasury yields between 6.5 percent and 7 percent."
 Prices of Treasury securities reacted little to the May Producer Price Index yesterday. Normally bond traders hate inflation and might have been expected to react favorably to yesterday's report, which showed inflation braked at the producer level. The index was unchanged from April, compared with estimates that it would rise by as much as three-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
3-Year Low For Stocks In Tokyo

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 9

 BODY:
Discouraged by the outlook for Japan's economy and the Government's rescue plan for the banking industry, investors today pushed down prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange to the lowest level in nearly three years.
 The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 398.12 points, or 2.6 percent, to 15,044.18. That was its lowest closing level since Aug. 19, 1992, when the index finished at 14,650.74. On Thursday, the index lost 237.32 points, or 1.5 percent. 
 "It is no exaggeration to say that we must keep in mind the worst may come in a further fall in stock prices," said Hideo Omura, a senior trader with Dai-Ichi Securities.
 The latest development to pull down stocks was today's release of the central bank's quarterly survey of Japanese business sentiment. The survey found that businesses had become more optimistic, despite the strong yen.
 But instead of encouraging investors, the survey made them more pessimistic. Apparently they viewed the survey as showing an economy that was strong enough to deter the central bank from cutting interest rates but not strong enough to stage a genuine recovery.
 The release of the survey followed by one day the Government's announcement of a package of measures meant to help the nation's debt-ridden banks. By some estimates, Japan's banks have bad debts totaling as much as $1 trillion or even more. But analysts said the Finance Ministry's rescue package would do little to relieve the bank situation. That, in turn, would mean that lending and investment would remain stagnant.
 In addition, investors are worried about the nation's auto trade with the United States, which plans to impose 100 percent tariffs on Japanese luxury cars if an agreement is not reached by June 28 on a further opening of Japan's market to foreign autos and auto parts.
 Analysts said the market decline also reflected the sale of a large number of futures and options contracts that became due today.
 Pointing to yet another factor weighing down share prices, Bloomberg Business News reported that Japan's big life insurance companies, once considered staunch supporters of stocks, have become some of the market's biggest sellers.
 Insurers sold 340 billion yen, or $4 billion, of stock in May, twice as much as in any month before, Bloomberg said. Most of that stock, analysts said, was sold by Japan's eight largest life insurers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers From Sharp Fall Over Rumors of Japanese Move

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar recovered from a sharp loss yesterday after currency dealers concluded that a rumor that large Japanese investors were selling United States securities was groundless.
 By the end of the trading day, the dollar was only slightly lower against the Japanese yen and German mark, and mixed against other leading currencies. Traders called it one of the more chaotic days in the foreign exchange market in some time. 
 "It's been a bit of a frustrating run," said John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager with ING Capital Markets Inc. in New York.
 The dollar selling began on a rumor that Japan's Finance Ministry was privately telling investors and banks in Japan to avoid American securities. The Japanese are major buyers of American stocks and Treasury securities, and a selloff would diminish demand for the dollars needed to buy them.
 The rumor also helped send bond prices down sharply and contributed to a stiff drop in the stock market. But Japan's Finance Ministry later denied the rumor. At the same time, traders themselves were reassessing the wisdom of selling dollars over hearsay that seemed so unlikely.
 "Once we realized what the consequences would be, we saw how ridiculous that would be," said Kevin Harris, an international economist at MCM Currencywatch Inc., a foreign-exchange analysis firm.
 Many traders started buying dollars they had sold earlier, creating a supply squeeze that bolstered the currency further in what is known as a short-covering rally.
 In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.4053 German marks from 1.4072 marks. The dollar slipped to 84.29 yen from 84.68 yen.
 There was no significant economic news to influence dollar trading, analysts said. The Labor Department's report showing that wholesale prices steadied in May helped substantiate other evidence that the United States economy is slowing, but that already had been built into market expectations.
 "In fact, we are having a hard time finding any new direction," Mr. Harris said.
 The dollar has been supported in recent days by the expectation that finance ministers of the industrialized nations meeting next week in Halifax, Nova Scotia, will reaffirm their commitment to a stable dollar.

HEADLINE: Mobutu, Zaire's 'Guide,' Leads Nation Into Chaos

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
For the three decades that the West backed Zaire's dictator, President Mobutu Sese Seko, one rationale was consistently invoked: Whatever his evils Mr. Mobutu, a wily billionaire, was the only figure who could bind this vast, chaotic country together.
But with the cold war over, the West is no longer interested in supporting a once strategic ally. And the outside world is awakening to the fact that far from being held together, Zaire, which is as large as the United States east of the Mississippi, is drifting dangerously close to disintegration. 
 Since the outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus in May, Western diplomats, officials from neighboring countries, international public health experts and economists have begun to say aloud what many of the 41 million Zairians concluded long ago: "Zaire doesn't really exist anymore as a state entity," is how one European diplomat here put it.
He cited the separate arrangements that each of the eight provinces has made to assure its survival: "Kivu lives from informal trade with East Africa, East Kasai refuses to accept the national currency, Shaba has become a virtual extension of South Africa and to visit Equateur, even though it is the President's home, is to see things just as they were in the time of Stanley."
The diplomat, who recently toured each province, said he was shaken by what he had found.
"Such roads as exist won't allow you to travel more than 15 miles an hour, and everywhere you go, people tell you stories of the things that used to exist but are no more," he said. "People can't afford beer anymore, so they drink palm wine. There's no soap, so people wash their clothes with papaya leaves."
The few reliable statistics paint a frightening picture. According to the World Bank, Zaire's economy has shrunk 40 percent since 1988. Per capita income has fallen 65 percent since 1958, two years before the country gained independence from Belgium.
The Government is a concoction born of political improvisation and Western-coerced compromise. Mr. Mobutu was pressed by the West to accept Kengo wa Dondo, an advocate of austerity and privatization, after he dismissed another Prime Minister, Etienne Tshisekedi, under questionable legal circumstances.
These days Mr. Mobutu has little to do with actual governance. Isolated for months at a time in his native village, Gbadolite, inaccessible except to those he summons, he controls only his vast security apparatus and foreign policy. Diplomats say the President also retains enough clout to protect lucrative business ties, particularly in diamond mining.
Mr. Kengo, who runs the Government, has had to fight Mr. Mobutu each time his economic changes have threatened the President's interests.
The President recently resisted Mr. Kengo's attempts to replace the president of the Central Bank; before the Prime Minister got his way, diplomats say, business executives thought to be in league with Mr. Mobutu imported at least three planeloads of counterfeit currency.
Even though two planes were seized at Kinshasa airport, the state prosecutor, a Mobutu appointee, declined to press charges, saying there was not enough evidence.
For state employees, who go months without pay and often steal Government property or resort to bribery, the counterfeit scheme provoked little surprise.
"We have grown accustomed to the blurred line between real and fake in Zaire," said a Government ministry worker in Kinshasa, "so used to it that we can't tell the difference."
For many, that the Ebola outbreak should have occurred in Kikwit is among the clearest signs of Zaire's steep decline.
Kikwit, less than 300 miles east of Kinshasa, sits astride what was once a major transcontinental highway. Unlike other cities that live from little more than river traffic and small-scale agriculture, just two decades ago Kikwit was home to the world's largest palm-oil plantation.
But the highway to Kinshasa, which cuts across one grassy plateau after another before plunging through steep river-cut valleys, has deteriorated so badly that only a handful of intrepid truckers ever take it anymore.
Foreign doctors with long experience in Zaire say that in a sense, it was fortunate the epidemic occurred in Kikwit, and not in any far more remote and even poorer area, where other epidemics are common.
"Ebola brought a response, but the people of Zaire face a very fundamental health crisis," said Dr. Dan Fountain, an American missionary physician who practices in the Kikwit region. "All over the place you find a population that suffers from malnutrition and has severely deficient immune systems. Measles outbreaks kill 300 people all the time, and AIDS, hepatitis, tuberculosis and malaria are ever present."
Like nearly every region of Zaire, which was once the largest copper producer and a major exporter of coffee, Kikwit, a city of 500,000, now lives without industry.
Fuel for the few cars in circulation is sold by the whisky bottle at the roadside, since there are no gas stations. Young people set out barefoot to reach the nearest diamond area, 200 miles to the south, where crude mining provides the only hope of earning a livelihood.
"There is just no work here," said Jean Mpongo, 24, who recently returned home from a season of mining. "If you stay here, you live by the land or you live from charity. One thing is sure, though: you live without money."
With the cold war over, there is little real disagreement between Western diplomats and Mr. Mobutu's opponents in describing the President's recipe for holding on since he took power in November 1965.
Mr. Mobutu's first trump card was his reliability as an ally of the West. For years he allowed Zaire to be used as a base for Jonas Savimbi, Washington's ally in the civil war in leftist-ruled Angola. For France, Zaire, which shares borders with nine other countries, was long an invaluable staging ground for military operations to prop up former French colonies.
Several Western military operations have rescued Mr. Mobutu from being toppled. For example, Western military assistance helped put down rebellions in Shaba that began in 1977. As recently as 1991, France and Belgium intervened there, ostensibly to rescue their citizens during rioting by soldiers who had not been paid.
Mr. Mobutu is a master of co-opting would-be opponents. Diplomats say he has systematically let his enemies feed at the state trough, rotating them in and out of office and encouraging many to become wealthy in order to neutralize them.
Like many African dictators, Mr. Mobutu has also constantly played ethnic politics. While filling the army with members of small tribes from his native Equateur Province, he has fanned hatred between several large ethnic groups, preventing them from challenging him. Several regions are embroiled in tribal wars.
Mr. Mobutu's last rampart has been a myriad of security organizations that run from the army and the gendarmerie to several layers of secret police and an autonomous presidential guard. In every major city there are soldiers and police officers on nearly every street.
The security forces have become a law unto themselves. In what has become a common occurrence as unpaid agents have turned to preying on residents, four secret policemen recently abducted two American journalists visiting a tuberculosis sanatorium in Kinshasa. After an hour's drive, during which the journalists were taken to the gate of a prison and threatened with jail, the agents made off with $350 and several rolls of film.
After a diplomatic protest was lodged, something truly odd happened: A Zairian Army general from Equateur turned up at the journalists' hotel with the lost money and film, and with this apology: "That is what happens when people insist that we have democracy here. There is no more order in the country anymore."
Despite Mr. Mobutu's unpopularity, he has recently been pressing to hold elections, to end his diplomatic isolation and, many suspect, to get rid of Prime Minister Kengo, who has been slowly cleaning house by removing Mobutu cronies.
Diplomats say there is another reason Mr. Mobutu is eager for elections. With the opposition badly divided and with Mr. Kengo, who is of Zairian-Rwandan heritage, unable to run for president because candidates must be of pure Zairian heritage, some diplomats say Mr. Mobutu could very well win.
Still, in places like Kinshasa, a city of five million where huge garbage heaps line major roads that dissolve into muddy lakes at the first rain, it is hard to find anyone who would support Mr. Mobutu.
"They talk about holding elections, but that is not the people's problem anymore," said Ernest Lutumba, a worshiper at an evangelical church in Kinshasa. "The people know that elections are for Mobutu. Our problems lie elsewhere."

HEADLINE: Colombian Drug Lord Captured In Police Raid in His Hometown

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
A principal leader of the Cali cocaine and heroin ring in Colombia, regarded as the world's largest drug-trafficking gang, was captured yesterday in a raid on a luxurious house in the southern city of Cali, Colombian Government officials said.
The officials said the raiding party had been on the verge of leaving the white stucco house without finding the man, Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela, when some officers discovered him hiding in a secret compartment. 
 Bogota television stations quoted the police officers who arrested him as saying that as they confronted him, Mr. Rodriguez Orejuela shouted: "You won. I surrender. Calm, boys. Don't kill me. I'm a man of peace." Two leaders of the rival Medellin cocaine ring, Jose Gonzalo Gacha and Pablo Escobar Gaviria, were killed several years ago as Colombian police officers and soldiers closed in on them.
Mr. Rodriguez-Orejuela and four bodyguards were handcuffed, taken to the airport in Cali and flown directly to Bogota, the capital. They were transferred by helicopter to national police headquarters.
President Ernesto Samper announced the arrest on Colombian national radio and television and proclaimed that it marked "the beginning of the end for the Cali cartel," which is estimated by the Drug Enforcement Agency to provide 80 percent of the world's cocaine and increasing amounts of heroin.
Officials in Washington, who have been pressing Mr. Samper to aggressively pursue Mr. Rodriguez Orejuela and the other Cali drug leaders as they have flaunted their power and wealth for years with little official interference, praised the capture.
"My hat is off to the Colombian Government and the Colombian people," said Lee P. Brown, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy and President Clinton's top aide on drug policy.
In the last year or so relations between the United States and Colombia had sunk as Washington had criticized Colombia for failing to take action against the Cali ring.
United States officials had been shaken by tape recordings in which people identified as leaders of the Cali cartel were heard discussing contributions of millions of dollars to Mr. Samper's presidential campaign.
Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Comittee, had sought to cut off United States economic aid to Colombia unless more was done to crack down on the drug trafficking.
In the last two months, however, Colombian authorities seemed to have begun seriously trying to catch the Cali leaders.
In April the Colombian police announced rewards of $1.25 million for help in capturing Mr. Rodriguez Orejuela and his brother Miguel, another of the Cali drug ring's leaders.
Last month President Samper added 1,600 people to a joint army-police unit fighting drug trafficking. It was that unit that arrested Mr. Rodriguez-Orejuela yesterday.
Shortly after arriving at police headquarters in Bogota, handcuffed and wearing slacks and a striped sport shirt, Mr. Rodriguez Orejuela, who is 56 years old, requested a doctor check his blood pressure, the Colombian police said.
Mr. Rodriguez-Orejuela is a banker who became known in drug circles as "the Chess Player" because of his shrewdness. He and his brother and a circle of close friends quietly built the Cali operation into the world's largest drug-trafficking gang as their rivals in the Colombian city of Medellin became increasingly violent and devoted its energies to fighting the authorities.
While the Medellin Cartel was trying to undermine public confidence in the Colombian Government with bombs in shopping centers and attacks on police officers, the Cali traffickers were shipping more and more cocaine and beginning to cultivate opium to give them entry to the world's heroin business.
Though the Cali gang members were regarded as quiet businessmen who belonged to civic clubs and tried to gain influence through bribery, they nonetheless often relied on murder to displine the ranks of their own organization.
Gunmen paid by the leaders of the Cali ring sometimes flew into New York or Miami to carry out a killing, law enforcement officials said. It was the Cali cartel that three years ago ordered the death of a New York journalist, Manuel DeDios, who had written about the drug traffickers in Spanish-language publications and books. The investigation and publicity surrounding his slaying tarnished the popular image of the Cali gang.
